HEADLINE: BLACK AIDE QUITS IN SOUTH AFRICA

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DAVEYTON, South Africa

 BODY:
For more than a decade, Daveyton's Mayor, Tom Boya, was Pretoria's evidence of the legitimacy of the municipal councils running its segregated black townships.
As president of the United Municipalities of South Africa, an organization of black municipal officials, Mr. Boya put aside his mayoral duties and traveled as far afield as the United States and Brazil to discourse on the concerns of local government. 
 But he recently stunned a crowd of 80,000 residents of Daveyton by announcing that he was quitting his posts. He said the system with which he had become identified had no future. Whether motivated by conscience or survival, his unexpected resignation elicited wild cheers and seemed to signal the beginning of the end for black township governments.
"I just feel a big stone has been removed from my shoulders," Mr. Boya said in his modern brick house in this quiet township of 200,000 black residents east of Johannesburg.
 
Electricity Is Shut Off
 Mr. Boya, who is 39 years old, said the handwriting appeared on the wall after the African National Congress was made legal and Nelson Mandela released in February. "I realized there was no room any more for a person to serve in a structure created by the Government," he said.
His decision to quit, he said, was prompted by his inability to stop the state-owned power company from switching off Daveyton's electricity for four days recently because of unpaid bills. He said it illustrated the frustrations he had faced in Daveyton since joining its town council in 1978.
"The weakness of the black local authorities was simply lack of funds, lack of local sources of revenue," Mr. Boya said. But, he quickly added, "the structures were illegitimate" because the white minority Government had imposed them on blacks.
Behind Daveyton's financial woes lies the Group Areas Act, the law that divides communities on racial lines. White towns are wealthier because their residents have better jobs and more money.
 
Accused of Being Puppets
 Their resources are not shared with the satellite black townships, which began as stark dormitories for blacks working at menial jobs in white areas and which suffer chronic poverty and unemployment.
Anti-apartheid civic associations have organized boycotts of rent and utility payments to protest inferior living conditions, which deprive municipal governments of the modest revenue upon which they depend. The associations have accused municipal officials like Mr. Boya of being puppets of apartheid.
As Mr. Boya told it, the utility company, Eskom, threatened to cut off Daveyton's electricity in September unless overdue bills, which constitute part of the township's $475,000 deficit, were paid. Mr. Boya said he was assured of a $80,000 bridging loan from the Transvaal Provincial Administration, which supervises municipal governments and provides public services in the Transvaal. In return, he said, Daveyton agreed that every household would pay the equivalent of $28 a month to work off the arrears.
 
'I Felt So Lonely'
 Satisfied that the crisis had been resolved, Mr. Boya flew to Rio de Janeiro for a conference. In his absence, the deal collapsed when the Transvaal Provincial Administration insisted that most of the money paid go to pay municipal wages and only a little to the utility company. He returned home to find the electricity turned off and his constituents irate.
"I felt so lonely," Mr. Boya said. "I felt rejected. I felt betrayed."
The electricity was turned back on after residents took the utility company to court.
Mr. Boya's foreboding about the future of black local government was heightened when he went to a United Municipalities conference recently and found only 8 of its 60 municipal councils represented.
He called a public meeting in Daveyton's soccer stadium to explain why the electricity failed. When he arrived, Mr. Boya said, nobody was there. Everyone had gone to a protest rally called by the Daveyton Interim Committee, the local civic association, in another stadium.
 
'The System Is Bankrupt'
 Mr. Boya said he went to the other rally and decided to quit. "You could have heard a pin when I went over to the podium," he said. "I then offered my resignation."
James Ngubo, chairman of the Daveyton Interim Committee said that "Mr. Boya coming out really symbolizes that the system is bankrupt." He said the white minority Government had set up Mr. Boya as a "good black man" to make black local authorities palatable. His group had pressed Mr. Boya to resign, Mr. Ngubo said, and the power cuts "must have been the last straw for him."
Four other Daveyton councillors have followed Mr. Boya's example.
Mr. Boya predicted the inevitable collapse of all township government structures. "I think it will be very healthy when it happens," he said. "From those ruins, we can build."
He said municipalites must encompass white and black communities together and pool their revenue. And municipalities, he said, should be defined by region instead of race.
"The Government should abolish black local authorities and white local authorities and call for an election of local authorities under one umbrella," he said.

HEADLINE: News's Owners Speak Softly but Take a Hard Line

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 31

 BODY:
From the 65-year-old Gothic tower of the Tribune Company, a sober place that respects prudence, the message is quietly stated but clear: The owners of The Daily News plan to hold on to their tabloid, defy strikers, revamp the newspaper's production and so, in effect, transform the way the press works in New York City.
Hardened by a strike five years ago at the company's flagship newspaper, The Chicago Tribune, over the same sort of plant modernization they now seek at The Daily News, top Tribune executives exude determination to get what they see as an essential job done in New York, just as it was accomplished here at the paper they call "the voice of the heartland." 
 While union leaders and some industry experts have suggested that the company will ultimately shut down The News, Tribune executives dismiss that notion.
"We're in New York with an excellent franchise and we plan to make it grow and prosper," said John W. Madigan, the president and publisher of The Tribune and a director of the Tribune Company. "Throughout this company, we want to be as efficient as we can and as up-to-date in every respect. The Daily News is a long way away from that."
 
Drain on Profits
 In fact, The Daily News, which the Tribune Company founded in 1919, is a major drain on the $2.5 billion-a-year media corporation, which has produced otherwise impressive results with its press, television and entertainment properties since going public in 1983. Accounting for about 17 percent of Tribune Company revenue, The Daily News has piled up losses of about $115 millon since 1980 and is expected to lose at least another $60 million this year.
"It's a nightmare," James Hoge, the chief executive of The Daily News, said in a telephone interview from New York.
"We carry an inordinate and wholly unnecessary cost," said Mr. Hoge, a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy and Yale who became managing editor of the Chicago Sun-Times at the age of 31. "Management does not have the right to hire, supervise, make changes and determine the real work that needs to be done. But we're going to reform that now."
The parent company's objective, its executives say, is to emerge from the strike with enough control over the management of The Daily News to justify building a series of new production plants that would allow delivery of a full-color, late-edition paper throughout metropolitan New York.
 
A Long History
 In making this stand, the Tribune Company is gambling that it can do in New York what it did here. It is a steady, determined company with a long history. Joseph Medill, the legendary Chicago Tribune editor who established the paper's reputation shortly after its debut in 1847, urged his successors to "in all things follow the line of common sense." Seen from Chicago, what has happened at The Daily News over the last decade is just not sensible.
But New York is considered a much tougher union town than Chicago, and the Chicago strike did not include drivers. "There was never any trick to producing papers without unions -- distributing them is always the key," Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corporation won a similar union battle in London in 1986, said in a telephone interview today. "And without police protection, I'd be surprised if Tribune can manage it."
The effect of modernization is obvious in Chicago. An interview with Mr. Madigan, who is widely viewed as the Tribune Company's heir apparent, took place in offices created in what was, until 1983, the site of The Chicago Tribune's presses.
It was the elimination of those old presses and the construction of the modern production facility, called Freedom Center, that helped The Chicago Tribune sharply increase its profit margins to nearly 25 percent -- and sparked a sometimes violent strike over how the new plant should be staffed and managed.
Although litigation continues, The Chicago Tribune effectively beat that 1985 strike, enabling it take advantage of the new technology it introduced at a cost of $200 million. The company was able to raise productivity at its highly automated plant between 50 and 100 percent, slashing costs and eliminating about 400 jobs, more than 25 percent of the production work force.
Asked how this 1985 strike affects the company's strategy at The Daily News, Mr. Madigan said, "It's an experience we had and it made us more knowledgeable."
Such brief, deadpan pronouncements are typical of this corporation, which values action far above words and where executives shun grand statements in favor of observations such as, "We believe in sticking to our knitting."
 
Owners of the Cubs
 Throughout this week, as reports of violence in New York reached Chicago, there was no sign of agitation here. Indeed, during a brief conversation, Charles T. Brumback, the 62-year-old chief executive of the Tribune Company, said he was busy with an announcement concerning another Tribune property -- the Chicago Cubs.
Labor leaders here who have fought the company offer testimony to management's toughness. "The New York unions are up against probably the most ruthless group of people that have been put together," said Bob Nader, the secretary-treasurer of the Chicago Mailers Union, whose members struck in 1985 and have not got their jobs back.
For management, what is at stake at The Daily News makes it essential to be tough. Throughout the 1980's, the Tribune Company has shunned major diversification in favor of making its existing properties as efficient and profitable as possible.
"We've put a hard focus on costs and increased revenues," said Mr. Madigan, a tall, dour man of 52 who speaks in a monotone. "I can't give you anything that sounds sexy. It's just basic, bedrock management techniques applied to our business of being more efficient."
 
Installing New Presses
 Thus, over the past decade, the Tribune Company has invested more than half a billion dollars in state-of-the-art offset presses at five of its seven newspapers, which account for 65 percent of the company's revenue.
The results have been impressive. Since the company offered shares to the public in 1983, revenue has soared from $1.5 billion to $2.45 billion last year and net profits -- rising an average of 23 percent annually -- have almost tripled, to $242 million.
"They have shown a very good ability to keep costs under control and are one of the better-managed media companies around," said Eric Philo, a vice president of Goldman Sachs, the investment house.
The conspicuous exception to this performance -- "the ugly stepchild," as Jim Squires, a former editor of The Chicago Tribune, put it -- has been The Daily News, where, the company says, union control over a large number of jobs has blocked modernization plans that have been in place for several years.
And now, after a series of steady but manageable losses during the 1980's, an abrupt downturn in the New York economy has, in management's view, made a resolution of The Daily News problem essential. Largely as a result of losses there and at its Canadian newsprint operations, the Tribune Company's net profits in 1990 are expected to plunge by 30 percent or more.
Leading the company's stand is its chief executive, Mr. Brumback, a quiet, rotund man with a reputation for toughness, who was educated at Indiana's Culver Military Academy and Princeton and received a bronze star during the Korean War. He was the president of The Chicago Tribune when it won its union battle, and got the top job at the Tribune Company three months ago.
"The New York unions think they can muscle Brumback," Mr. Squires said. "But Brumback don't muscle. You don't muscle that guy."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
U.S. Preparing U.N. Draft On Claims Against Baghdad

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 31

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is preparing a new United Nations Security Council resolution requiring governments to earmark frozen Iraqi assets to meet future compensation claims by victims of its invasion of Kuwait, American officials said today.
The resolution follows a decision by the Security Council on Monday establishing Iraq's responsibility for all financial losses resulting from its invasion of Kuwait and asking governments to draw up claims against Baghdad on behalf of themselves and their citizens. It also asked them to submit any evidence they can find of human rights abuses by Iraqi forces there. 
 American officials say the resolution is one of several new moves they are planning with a view to making the economic embargo as tight as possible. Only then, they argued, will the Council be in a position to decide if these economic sanctions are likely to force Iraq out of Kuwait on their own, or whether armed force should be considered as well.
The Security Council has already ordered United Nations members to block Iraq's overseas assets, like bank accounts and commercial property, as part of the comprehensive economic sanctions it imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.
 
Special Escrow Accounts
 The emerging Council resolution would place these frozen assets in special escrow accounts intended to meet future claims against Iraq or in some other way designate them for compensation payments. But American officials say the actual payments could not be made until the gulf crisis is resolved and all claims processed.
The total value of Iraq's frozen overseas assets has been estimated unofficially at up to $4 billion.
In the Bush Administration's view, the new resolution is intended to maintain international pressure on President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, show that the Council remains united in its determination to oust him from Kuwait and keep the world's attention focused on the gulf crisis.
As President of the Security Council for the month of November, the United States representative will be well positioned to press for its new resolution. But he is likely to run into difficulties with Arab and nonaligned members who also want the Security Council to discuss the plight of Palestinians living in the occupied territories.
 
Thoughts on Palestinians
 Later this week, the Secretary General of the United Nations is to tell the Council how he thinks the organization might better protect the Palestinians living in occupied Israeli territory, after at least 17 Palestinians were shot at Al Aksa Mosque in Jerusalem after rocks were thrown at Jewish worshipers. And Arab and nonaligned countries want the Security Council to give priority to deciding on such measures.
A popular idea at present is for one of the United Nations agencies or peacekeeping forces in the area to be given the job of monitoring charges of human rights violations by Israeli forces.
But some members may also take advantage of any debate on the occupied territories to press for firmer Security Council action against Israel for its continued occupation of these Arab lands when the Council is already punishing Iraq for occupying Kuwait.
 
U.S. Maintains Right to Fight
 The Bush Administration still maintains it already has the right in international law to go to war to free Kuwait under Article 51 of the United Nations Charter. This allows members to appeal to allies for protection against an aggressor. It was the article Kuwait and Saudi Arabia invoked when they first asked the United States and other countries to send forces to the gulf.
But American officials say the Administration is examining the possibility of seeking specific Security Council authorization, as well, because of the increased legitimacy this would give any military operation in the eyes of many countries, including the Soviet Union. But they say a decision to ask the Council for such permission would depend on their assessment of whether it will agree.
As the negotiations continued, diplomats said Jordan, one of the countries most seriously affected by the economic embargo against Iraq, had asked the Security Council to send United Nations observers to confirm that no goods or oil are leaking across its frontier with Iraq.

HEADLINE: Fed Notes New Signs Of Distress

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
The economy continues to weaken, particularly in retailing, but apparently not to the point that would call for energetic relaxation of monetary policy, a Federal Reserve survey indicated today.
Though the general appraisal of the economy was a little worse than in the preceding report, published on Sept. 19, the survey had a more ominous tone and included much anecdotal evidence of growing distress. The report cited the forced renegotiation of contracts, squeezed profit margins and a virtual lack of financing for speculative real estate ventures. 
 "Economic activity appears to have grown slowly in most Federal Reserve districts since early August, but seems to have declined somewhat in others," a summary of the survey stated. It called retail sales "sluggish or down in most of the country," while manufacturing was "mixed to weaker."
In September, economic activity was said to have been "expanding more slowly or declining in most" of the 12 Federal Reserve districts.
 
'Somber Contrast'
 An economist at the Tokai Bank in New York, Robert T. McGee, called the "beige book" report on current conditions a "somber contrast" to Tuesday's Commerce Department report of a 1.8 percent rate of increase in the gross national product for the third quarter. "Instead, the discussion is replete with evidence of further deterioration," he said.
But the survey also uncovered considerable strength in exports, a relatively robust agricultural sector and some gains in retailing and manufacturing in the Middle West. It appeared, however, that much of the apparent steadiness in automobile sales represented sales to rental fleets rather than to individuals.
The survey is conducted to aid deliberations of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee, the central bank's main instrument for setting monetary policy. The committee is scheduled to meet eight times a year, with the next session on Nov. 13.
After Congress reached agreement on a deficit-reduction package, the Fed on Monday cut by a quarter point, to 7 3/4 percent, the short-term interest rate over which it had the most direct control.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has been reported as having urged consideration of a larger cut in rates should the economy weaken further. But he has suggested publicly that he is not eager to do so in the absence of what he called a cumulative unwinding of the economy.
Today's report appeared not to meet those grounds for a vigorous relaxation of monetary policy by the Fed.
 
More Widespread Weakness
 The survey, assembled by the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond from data collected by the districts before Oct. 19, suggested that the weakness described in the survey published in mid-September had spread beyond the Northeast and Middle Atlantic areas and had intensified.
All the districts except Chicago, for example, reported that sales grew more slowly or fell in the latest period, with retail workers being laid off in some places and managers in most districts "generally pessimistic" about sales prospects.
The Boston bank said "all respondents" indicated they were trimming inventories or jobs or deferring capital projects. It added, "In the absence of some new positive force, retailers and wholesalers continue to express a lack of optimism about the possibilities for an economic recovery in the region in the next year or so."
The New York district said all of its retail contacts reported a second straight month of year-over-year declines in sales, while the Philadelphia bank said the usual fall sales upturn "has not materialized."
While a pullback by consumers rarely pushes the economy into recession, retail sales are closely monitored since they represent about a third of economic activity.
The Fed survey found weakness in manufacturing across most industries, although Chicago had "relatively strong" activity and several districts had increased production of energy or military goods.
The Atlanta district reported that companies in Alabama making military apparel were running at full capacity, but that other companies had lost export orders for Iraq and Kuwait.
No district expressed serious concern among manufacturers that inventory levels were too high, though producers in Philadelphia and Kansas City, Mo., were cutting them back, the survey found.
Exports of manufactured goods from the Richmond and Cleveland districts rose, but exports fell from the Chicago and Boston districts.
 
Drop in Vacancy Rate
 In New York, three straight months of "strong leasing" caused the primary vacancy rate in midtown Manhattan to fall for the first time this year, and the slow construction pace is expected to reduce the vacancy rate further in the coming months. Downtown rates remained "roughly stable" with the aid of lower rents.
The survey noted the inflation risk posed by continued high oil prices, and said many trucking and other companies were adding transportation surcharges. But the report found relatively little current inflation pressure.

HEADLINE: Computer Study of Cuomo Donors Finds Correlation With Contracts

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
Wells, Rich, Greene, the advertising agency, has a $30 million state contract for the "I Love New York" campaign and hopes to renew the contract next March. The agency has contributed at least $42,000 to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's campaigns over the last eight years, including $20,000 this year.
Iffland, Kavanagh, Waterbury has three engineering contracts with the State Department of Transportation worth $9.7 million, according to the State Comptroller's office. The firm and its officers have given at least $20,917 to Cuomo campaigns, including $12,417 this year. 
 Vincent Tese is Governor Cuomo's Commissioner of Economic Development and chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation, two posts that give him a role in handing out many of the state's most lucrative contracts. Mr. Tese and his wife, Joyce, have given $90,800 to Mr. Cuomo, including $25,000 last December.
These contributions -- not the largest Mr. Cuomo has received -- demonstrate the close relationship between campaign donations and state government, ties that are signaled in periodic campaign financial reports but are revealed more fully in a computerized study conducted by The New York Times of the approximately $20 million in contributions received by Governor Cuomo over his eight years in office.
For the survey, a computerized data base begun by the State Government Integrity Commission was updated by The Times. An analysis of the contributions finds a correlation between state contracts and large contributions to the Cuomo campaigns. The list also includes a hard core of large donors whose connections with the state, if any, are not always clear-cut.
The donations are legal, and contributors interviewed have denied any but altruistic motives like admiration for Mr. Cuomo and the hope that he will prosper politically.
Mr. Cuomo has maintained and reiterated in a recent interview that he does not see the fund-raising lists. But the commission said people raising funds for him led some to believe he was aware of individual contributions.
The Governor has said repeatedly that he favors public financing of campaigns to avoid any impressions of conflicts of interest. But he has argued that he will not voluntarily restrict contributions, so that he can keep up pressure on the Republican majority in the State Senate to enact such a law.
The largest cumulative contributor, the investment firm of Bear Stearns, has been the underwriter of many state bond issues. Labor unions, which are mong the biggest donors, have considerable interest in state legislation.
The largest individual contributor, Fedele V. Scutti, a Rochester auto dealer, however, is not listed as having business with the state. He did not return telephone calls to his office seeking comment.
An engineering firm, Parsons, Brinckerhoff, Quade & Douglas, which was criticized by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan recently for insufficient supervision of a construction project for the Long Island Rail Road at Hillside, received $32 million for that project and nearly $3 million for other state contracts. The firm has donated at least $24,000 to Governor Cuomo, $7,000 of it this year.
Berger, Lehman & Associates has four Transportation Department engineering contracts worth $9.7 million, according to contract records kept by the State Comptroller's office. The firm has given Cuomo campaigns at least $19,000, with $2,000 this year.
 
A Major Landlord
 The Picotte family of Albany through its real-estate firms is a major landlord for state agencies, according to the Comptroller's office, with just one of its companies receiving $670,000 in state rentals in a year. The family and its companies have given at least $40,000 to Cuomo campaigns, including $10,000 this year.
Another state landlord, the 10 Ellicott Square Corporation of Buffalo, has received $1.46 million in rents from the state in the last 18 months. It has contributed at least $5,456 to Mr. Cuomo.
A computer check of the campaign finances of Attorney General Robert Abrams found a politically significant donation.
Mr. Abrams has received the Liberal Party nomination for re-election, and the Liberal Party base could also be important in his rivalry with other Democrats if he seeks the United States Senate nomination in 1992. Mr. Abrams has given the Liberal Party $22,500 in the last year, its largest single contribution. Mr. Cuomo, who has had strained relations with Liberal leaders, has been renominated by the Liberal Party but has not given it donations. Carol Bellamy, the Democratic-Liberal candidate for state comptroller, donated $1,500 to the Liberals.
Mr. Abrams's chief political adviser, Ethan Geto, acknowledged that the relationship with the Liberals "has significant political value for the future."
 
Criticism From Commission
 The Government Integrity Commission had criticized the fund-raising efforts of Mr. Cuomo, Mr. Abrams and Mr. Regan in soliciting contributions from state contractors, saying this created at least the appearance of impropriety. Mr. Regan has since since put a $4,000 limit on such contributions.
The records of contributions do not always reflect the total amount an individual or company may have steered to the campaign since they often do not include donations by company officers, their relatives, friends and subcontractors, hich are more difficult to trace. In other cases a contribution from a law firm, for example, could mask state business by its clients or an appointment of one of its partners to a state commission or board.
Officers and spokesmen for various companies listed among the contributors denied that they had been pressured to contribute or that their state contracts were contingent on contributions. Typical was the response of Robert Prieto, a senior vice president of Parsons, Brinckerhoff, who said: "We've actively supported the political process within the limits of the law. We never felt any pressure."
One state official, Mr. Tese, said, "I don't think I have to buy a job," adding that he made his money in investments and cable television.
The integrity commission's report said a donation did not have to involve a quid pro quo, which would be illegal, to raise conflict-of-interest questions.
The law firm of Bower & Gardner, for example, has donated $17,000 to Mr. Cuomo in the last 18 months and was singled out by Common Cause this week as a firm representing clients involved in environmental matters with the state. Another law firm once identified with Republicans, Rogers & Wells, has given the Democratic Governor $64,200 during his two terms.
The computer check of the cumulative records showed little has changed since the integrity commission demonstrated the strong correlation between state contracts and contributions at hearings and in a report last year.
The commission reported that 64 of 68 engineering firms on a Cuomo list of prospects to be solicited ended up contributing to the campaign and that all but 11 of the 64 had contracts with the State Transportation Department and the State Thruway Authority.
The commission said donors who were questioned said that while Cuomo solicitors did not directly link the donations to state business, "virtually all of the engineers thought it unwise to take a chance and not contribute."
The commission said Friends of Mario Cuomo, the Governor's fund-raising arm, "aggressively pursues" people and businesses "identifiable by virtue of their dealings with the state."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1392 words

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN;
Politics of Rage Dominate Contest in Massachusetts

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
In this state where voters seem implacably angry, John R. Silber is the prophet of the politics of rage.
Once again, Tuesday night, the Democratic candidate for governor had his Republican opponent, William F. Weld, on the defensive, pounding away in their last debate. And once again, Mr. Weld seemed unable to seize the openings before him, to turn some of the Democrat's sometimes intemperate comments against him. 
 With six days until the election, the race is generally perceived here as being neck and neck, with Dr. Silber perhaps having the edge. In a poll published Tuesday in The Boston Globe, Dr. Silber led Mr. Weld, a former United States Attorney, 46 percent to 37 percent. The poll, of 600 likely voters, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
It is possible, but by no means certain, that Mr. Silber's support could be greater than the polls show. In the primary election, surveys underestimated his strength, in part, some poll experts believe, because he cut such an abrasive figure that people did not want to admit to poll takers that they would vote for him.
But whatever the polls show, there is no mistaking the response to Dr. Silber, the president of Boston University. He is the No. 1 topic here, and his I'm-fed-up-with-business-as-usual theme strikes home in a state whose current Governor, Michael S. Dukakis, is widely blamed for an economic decline and state budget crisis.
"In a normal year when voters are angry they would throw out the party in power, the Democrats, and Weld would win," said George Bachrach, a former Democratic State Senator. "But John Silber's anger matches that of the voters so well that he has made a visceral connection with them that transcends normal politics."
"It doesn't seem to matter what Silber says or who he offends," Mr. Bachrach said. Indeed, Mr. Bachrach suggested, Dr. Silber's emotional appeal and his ability to avoid being hurt by seemingly impolitic utterances that might damage other candidates, are reminiscent of Ronald Reagan. But while President Reagan offered a message of optimism for the 1980's, Dr. Silber preaches a stern sermon of wrath for the economically leaner 1990's.
Tom Kiley, a Democratic political consultant, said, "Silber is unique; he has broken all the rules of politics. Candidates usually look for ways to ingratiate themselves with the electorate, but he has an ability to force to electorate to respond to him."
 
Wanting 'New Blood'
 James F. O'Brien, a 36-year-old union carpenter from Waltham, said, "I'm for him just to get some new blood in there. The politicians in there just keep getting re-elected by making promises that they don't keep. I like the way Silber just comes out and says what is on his mind."
Still, Dr. Silber has alienated a number of voters in groups that make up major parts of the Democratic Party -- liberals, environmentalists, feminists, blacks and homosexuals -- with remarks that in other years might have sunk his candidacy. His latest "Silber shocker," as his comments have come to be called, came last week when he said that "overweening materialism" on the part of two-career couples who put their offspring in child-care centers may constitute "child neglect."
Dr. Silber's thought was in keeping with his often-stated view that working women have been disruptive of the American family, though he frequently points out that his own mother, a teacher, had to work to support his family during the Great Depression.
"There is no question that we have a generation of neglected children," Dr. Silber said in a television interview. "We have a generation of abused children by women who have thought that a third-rate day care center was just as good as a first-rate home."
Lin F. Kelleher, a 33-year-old real estate broker from the Boston suburb of Arlington, reacted with outrage. She said she was a Democrat but would vote for Mr. Weld.
"There are a lot of women who do feel guilty about having children in day care," she said. "But to come out and say it, it burns me. He really hit women where it hurts."
 
Blurred Ideological Categories
 But despite Dr. Silber's remark, he led Mr. Weld by 10 points among women in the Globe poll.
Part of the explanation is that neither Dr. Silber nor Mr. Weld fits into easy ideological categories, with both men blurring the usual lines that divide liberal, moderate and conservative.
Dr. Silber is slight of stature, but speaks in a forceful, resonant voice, tinged with the accent of his native San Antonio, that seems to emanate from a larger person. Despite his comments on subjects like welfare mothers and black drug dealers that make him seem conservative, many of his positions are liberal. He opposes the death penalty, he favors strict gun control and he advocates an ambitious program of pre-school education to help working parents.
 Like Dr. Silber, Mr. Weld has never held public office, although he ran for State Attorney General in 1978. An Assistant Attorney General in the Reagan Administration, he has a genial personality and easy sense of humor, and often comes across to voters as moderate to liberal.
He is a strong supporter of abortion rights and the environment. But he has come out against control of semi-automatic rifles, and early on he tied himself to a tax-cutting ballot measure sponsored by a conservative group, the Citizens for Limited Taxation.
In the absence of clear philosophical differences between the two candidates, it has been this tax-reduction referendum that has become the main issue in the race. The initiative would roll back state taxes and fees to their 1988 level, forcing the next governor to cut roughly $1.2 billion out of the $13 billion budget in the first six months of next year and $2.4 billion more in 1992.
Initially, Mr. Weld, who was endorsed by The Globe in its Thursday issue, seemed to be on the popular side of the debate, with polls after the September primary showing both the initiative and Mr. Weld in the lead. But as the Massachusetts economy has continued to decline, with unemployment doubling in the past year to more than 6 percent, voters began to be anxious about the effects of such deep cuts on a broad range of state programs and services.
Dr. Silber has insisted that he favors the goal of the tax-cutting measure, but he argues that its formula is too rigid and would result in "fiscal meltdown." Instead, using the initials of Citizens for Limited Taxation, he has said, "I am C.L.T. with a brain," promising to carry out a more thoughtful and humane reduction of state government.
 
Questions of Personal Finance
 As he did Tuesday in the televised debate, Dr. Silber has used fear of the tax-cutting initiative as a way to keep liberal and moderate Democrats from defecting to Mr. Weld in large numbers. Democrats outnumber Republicans in Massachusetts by about 4 to 1.
When Mr. Weld tried to explain how he would put the drastic tax cuts into effect, Dr. Silber dismissed him like a school child. "Those numbers don't make any sense at all," he said sternly.
Mr. Weld's attacks on Dr. Silber, by contrast, seem unable to do any damage. He has pointed out that Dr. Silber managed to become a millionaire while president of Boston University, technically a public charity, earning more than $275,000 from the school last year and thereby being by far the highest-paid university president in the country. Dr. Silber's total income was $522,600 in 1989, according to figures released by the Silber campaign.
Dr. Silber has said that he made his money in an entirely legal manner and that his high salary reflects his accomplishments at the university.
Mr. Weld has also challenged Dr. Silber on why he did not file his 1989 Federal tax returns by Oct. 15, the deadline required by law. But even after a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service said Dr. Silber was in error, Dr. Silber has continued to insist on his correctness in delaying his returns.
Dan Payne, another Democratic consultant, says that since the dominant issue in the campaign is bringing change to state government its outcome hinges on what kind of change voters most want. "Do they want a change in party, which Weld offers, or do they want a change in personality and style, which is Silber?" Mr. Payne asked.

SECTION: Section D; Page 23; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1148 words

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN;
Fierce Fight for Illinois Seat Pits Old Against New

BYLINE: By R.W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Walter Dudycz is a classic insurgent: an angry, underfinanced candidate, the son of immigrant parents, bursting with intermingled idealism and naivete, waging a door-to-door campaign backed by a volunteer organization.
The surprise is that he is a Republican, "the kind of candidate we almost never get," says Edward J. Rollins, co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, who helped to recruit Mr. Dudycz and considers him one of the party's three best prospects for defeating a Democratic incumbent in the House of Representatives in next week's midterm elections. 
 Frank Annunzio, the 13-term incumbent in question, is 75 years old. A onetime union official, he came up through the ranks of the formidable Democratic organization built by Richard J. Daley, and he has had only one real election fight in his career, created by redistricting in 1972.
The surprise is that he has mounted a tough, energetic bid for re-election, backed by slick direct-mail pieces and hard-hitting radio commercials put together by a team of experienced media advisers young enough to be his children. Mr. Annunzio has never been led in the private polls taken by both campaigns.
The campaign first drew national attention because of the turbulence in the savings and loan business, to which Mr. Annunzio has long had close connections.
But it has developed into a no-holds-barred clash between the old and the new, a competition for the allegiance of precisely those sorts of culturally conservative, economically more liberal voters whom Ronald Reagan attracted in the 1980's and whom the Republicans have to hold in the 1990's if they are to make any progress toward ending their minority status on Capitol Hill.
The battleground is the 11th Congressional District of Illinois, perhaps the most polyglot in the nation, which includes most of the far North Side of Chicago and a few suburbs near O'Hare Airport. On a single block of Lincoln Avenue, one of the district's main arteries, there are shops owned by Italian- , German- , Greek- , Korean- , Filipino- , Guatemalan- and Polish-Americans. The tidy side streets are lined with modest brick bungalows and low-rise apartment buildings.
Usually Democratic in local politics, the district has voted five successive times for the Republican candidate in Presidential contests.
Mr. Dudycz (pronounced DO-ditch), whose family came to the United States from the Ukraine after World War II, is a former Chicago policeman who now serves in the State Senate. He has built his career on resistance to taxes, and he drew wide attention last year when he barged into a student exhibit at the Art Institute of Chicago to pick up an American flag that had been spread on the ground.
 
Failure to Sound Alarm
 He has pounded away at Mr. Annunzio for having accepted campaign contributions from Charles H. Keating Jr. and other savings-and-loan executives. He has tried to make an issue of the fact that two of Mr. Annunzio's sons-in-law, including Kevin Tynan, his campaign manager, worked for the United States League of Savings Institutions. And he has argued that Mr. Annunzio, chairman of the House Banking Subcommittee on Financial Institutions Supervision, failed to sound the alarm in time about the emerging savings-and-loan debacle.
But the Congressman has fought back, explaining his long-term support for the industry as a service to working-class people who could buy houses only through savings and loan centers. He insists he always opposed deregulation, which opened the way to financial abuses, and he has led the attack on the role of Neil Bush, the President's son, in the collapse of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Colorado.
Mr. Annunzio has criticized Mr. Dudycz as a "double dipper," collecting pay for a part-time Cook County patronage job on days when records show that he was in the State Legislature in Springfield. The Republican says the records are faulty.
But what Mr. Annunzio has really been selling, at ward picnics and labor rallies, is the politics of the New Deal and the Fair Deal and the politics of constituent service.
"I'm going to win because I've been here 25 years, answering the letters, helping with problems, looking after senior citizens and consumers and working people," he said the other night at a 41st Ward rally straight out of 1960. It was held in a Polish-American club plastered with placards bearing the ethnic names of Democratic stalwarts, with a searchlight piercing the sky outside and a banjo trio inside playing "Happy Days Are Here Again."
 
'Lies and Terror Tactics'
 Introducing the candidate, Alderman Roman Pucinski, a silver-haired survivor of the old Daley days, told the crowd, "The people of Chicago resent the kind of lies and terror tactics used against Frank Annunzio."
Sometimes, Mr. Annunzio sounded dated, citing the Wagner Act, the Tennessee Valley Authority and the Boulder Dam -- all products of the 1930's -- as the kinds of things the Democratic Party did to help ordinary citizens. But sometimes he roused people to cheers, as when he defended his political heritage as a Chicago regular.
"These Republicans say that we're a machine," he shouted. "What the hell do you think they are, a knitting society, a sewing circle?"
Mr. Dudycz is hoping that the much-discussed backlash against incumbents will help him, and there is evidence of such feeling here. Mr. Tynan said he himself had been told several times, while out canvassing for his father-in-law, Mr. Annunzio: "Forget it. The hell with all the politicians."
 
'On the Wrong Track'
 "Washington is on the wrong track," Mr. Dudycz said after a morning of hand-shaking in grocery stores and a small electrical-goods plant. "Frank Annunzio embodies everything wrong there -- an arrogant, long-serving, big-city politician put in and sustained by bosses. If I win, if we can do it in Chicago, it will encourage little guys across the country. If I lose, we send a message that money talks, no matter how tarnished the incumbent is."
The 40-year-old Republican candidate, whom Mr. Annunzio dismisses as "the D-jerk," describes himself as "Joe Six-Pack, a guy who bites his nails, who wears cheap suits, whose wife hoses down the alley -- nothing special, just average, a guy who might be digging potatoes with a shovel in the Ukraine if his father had taken a left turn instead of a right turn."
Mr. Dudycz will be outspent by about $600,000 to $300,000. He is clearly no match for Mr. Annunzio in detailed knowledge of issues. But he is convinced that the savings-and-loan scandal, plus the budget battle in Washington, which he calls "a sloppy attempt at a bipartisan rape of the American people," plus his own following in the district, will make him that rarity in American politics, a candidate who beats an incumbent Congressman.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Frank Annunzio, a 13-term incumbent, is facing one of the few tough election challenges of his career in Chicago's 11th Congressional District. (The New York Times)

 THE ECONOMY
The economy continues to weaken, particularly in retailing, but apparently not to the point that would call for energetic relaxation of monetary policy, a Fed survey indicated. [D1.]
Many taxpayers who have not had to worry about the alternative minimum tax may find themselves trapped by it in future years. [D1.]
Consumer spending jumped 1.1 percent in September, the Government said, outpacing a 0.5 percent growth in personal income and contributing to the lowest savings rate in three years. [D2.]
Higher oil prices are driving up farm operating expenses at the fastest pace in eight years, the Agriculture Dept. said. [D2.]
Orders received by U.S. factories rose a scant 0.1 percent in September, the Commerce Department said, as demand for durable goods like cars fell sharply. [D3.]
Michael Milken "committed serious crimes in addition to his admitted crimes," prosecutors argued in a memo. [D3.]
 
 MARKETS
Stocks seesawed in quiet trading amid new signs that a recession could be on the way. The Dow fell 5.69, to 2,442.33. [D10.]
Oil prices rallied late in the day to move above $35 a barrel in a third straight erratic session. Crude gained 69 cents, to $35.23. [D5.]

Soybean futures prices rebounded from three-month lows in what amounted to a market maneuver by grain dealers. [D17.]

HEADLINE: McDonald's Expected to Drop Plastic Burger Box

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
The plastic McDonald's hamburger box may be on its way out, a packaging dinosaur that could not survive in a less wasteful age.
The rugged little box, which was a design innovation that became one of the nation's best-known packages before turning into a symbol of the garbage crisis, will be phased out by the McDonald's Corporation, according to people informed of the decision. 
 Company officials at headquarters in Oak Brook, Ill., declined to comment. But Lee Masters of Golin Harris, McDonald's public relations agency, said yesterday that the company "plans a major news announcement tomorrow regarding the environment."
A decision to abandon the plastic foam container would be an abrupt about-face for the company, which for years has stoutly defended the need to use plastic in its restaurants. McDonald's, which operates 8,000 restaurants in this country, said the foam helps hold in heat, protects the food from contamination and resists grease stains better than paperboard boxes.
But environmental advocates say the production process generates pollutants and note that the box has a useful life of only a few minutes, while it lingers for decades when it is littered or dumped in a landfill. Plastics tend to take longer for the environmnent to break down than things made from paper or wood.
As towns and cities enacted bans on containers that are not biodegradable or cannot be recycled, McDonald's has come under pressure to change its packaging. In response, it has participated in limited efforts to recycle its plastic and was close to an announcement that its current recycling program would be extended nationwide.
But some members of the plastics industry have questioned the economic viability of gathering and processing the material, which, because of its structure, is high in volume but low in value. And environmentalists have questioned the value of demonstration projects, asserting that unless there is a market for the reclaimed product and the process is economically sound, the recycled material has little value. Similarly, they say printing the recycling symbol on paper packaging, as McDonald's has done, is misleading unless the material is actually being recycled.
 
 The Biggest User
 Though most fast-food chains use plastic foam in some form, McDonald's, as the nation's largest chain, is by far the biggest user of these materials.
In Miami, a spokeswoman at the Burger King Corporation, a main competitor of McDonald's, said that the restaurant chain has used mainly paper packaging since its founding in 1954. The exception, polystyrene coffee cups, is in the process of being replaced by thick-paper cups, she said.
Earlier this year, McDonald's said it would spend $100 million to help create markets for recycled materials. It said the materials would be used in building and remodeling its restaurants.
 
A Six-Month Study
 In August, it announced an unusual joint effort with the Environmental Defense Fund to conduct a six-month study into ways to reduce the solid waste generated at its 11,000 restaurants worldwide. The director of the fund, a membership group that uses aggressive legal tactics to pursue its environmental goals, said the hamburger container was one item the group planned to look at closely.
Despite these efforts, the company has remained the target of environmental advocates. On Monday, a group called the Earth Action Network broke the windows and scattered supplies at a McDondald's restaurant in San Francisco to protest the company's environmental policies.
According to Jeanne Wirka, a specialist in solid wastes with the Environmental Action Foundation in Washington, there are two major environmental disadvantages to the McDonald's hamburger box.
 
Suspected Carcinogen
 "The polystyrene production process is polluting and the styrene monomer is a suspected human carcinogen," she said. Like most plastics, polystyrene is made of long chains of a repeating molecule, known as a monomer.
"The other is that the volume of the container is excessive compared to a flexible wrapping," Ms. Wirka said. "And for people who eat in the restaurant, the useful life is only as long as it takes them to walk from the counter to sit down and eat."
A move to abandon foam packaging would come as McDonald's is experimenting with radical changes in location, decor, food and service, trying to find the right adult-oriented combinations. The company and its rivals are acting because the population is becoming older and youngsters scarcer, making adults the customers of choice in the hotly competitive fast-food industry.

HEADLINE: Farm Expenses Increase At Fastest Pace in 8 Years

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Higher oil prices resulting from the Mideast crisis are driving up farm operating expenses at the fastest pace in eight years, an Agriculture Department report said today.
New quarterly figures through October showed farm expenses jumped an average of 2.2 percent from July, when such figures were last available. The expense index was up 5.6 percent from October 1989. 
 "A sharp rise in fuel prices since July contributed most to the largest quarterly index increase since January 1982," the report said.
The monthly report by the department's Agricultural Statistics Board also said that prices farmers get for raw products declined seven-tenths of 1 percent from September to October but still averaged 1.4 percent more than a year earlier.
 
Prices Mixed
 "Decreases in the prices of broilers, milk, corn and apples were partially offset by higher prices for hogs, tomatoes, strawberries and eggs," the board said in its preliminary report.
Prices of most food and feed grains were down from September, although higher prices were reported for oats, rice and durum wheat. Soybean and sunflower prices declined, while peanut prices increased.
"The October all-hog price increased moderately over September, while the all-cattle price was up slightly," the report said.
Department economists say consumer food prices will rise an average of 5 percent to 7 percent this year, compared with a 5.8 percent gain in 1989, the most since 1981. There has been no official forecast for 1991.
 
Farm Income Expected to Rise
 The net cash income of farmers in 1990 has been forecast at a record in the range of $59 billion to $63 billion, up about 10 percent from last year. The previous high was $57.2 billion in 1988.
Net cash income is the amount nationally that farmers have left from gross cash income in a calendar year after deducting cash expenses. It includes government payments and proceeds from crops grown previously but sold during the year.
In another method of agency accounting, which includes changes in inventories, depreciation and other allowances during the year, 1990 net farm income may be in the range of $47 billion to $52 billion, compared with $47 billion last year.
 
Drop in Price Index for All Crops
 Based on preliminary figures that could be revised next month, the October price index for all crops was down 1.6 percent from September and averaged 4.7 percent less than a year earlier.
The October index for livestock and products was down 1.2 percent from September but still averaged 5.6 percent more than in October 1989.
Milk prices, reflecting stepped-up production, dropped 60 cents from September, to an October average of $13.60 a 100 pounds. The October price was down $1.20 from a year earlier.
The all-fruit price index in October was down 6.4 percent from September and 8.7 percent from the October 1989 average. Lower prices for apples, oranges and grapefruit were mostly responsible for the decline from September.

HEADLINE: G.M. PLANS TO SHUT UP TO 9 FACTORIES; LOSES $1.98 BILLION

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 31

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation, acknowledging that it would not soon recapture lost ground in a glutted market and wary of harder times in the industry, moved today to close up to nine factories that employ tens of thousands of workers. The closings, which will cost G.M. billions of dollars, resulted in its biggest quarterly loss ever.
G.M., the nation's largest company, said it would close four assembly plants permanently and established financial provisions that made the closing of five more likely over the next three years. Because of the enormous cost of shutting down the factories and laying off workers, the company reported a loss of $1.98 billion. 
 That figure almost quadruples G.M.'s previous record loss, $565 million in the third quarter of 1980. Taken with the worst quarterly performance at the Ford Motor Company since the 1982 recession and a $214 million loss at the Chrysler Corporation, it serves as a signal that the longstanding problems in the domestic automotive industry have not been cured.
 
More Weakness Ahead
 Although the American companies have improved their cars and made their factories more productive, their dealers have been forced to offer sharp discounts, in the form of cash rebates averaging more than $1,000 a car, that cut into profits. Industry experts say car and truck sales, which were strong until two years ago, will weaken over the next year because of an expected recession, but they also said G.M.'s move today would have been made even if the economy were in better shape.
Japanese auto makers, whose growth has been the biggest reason for G.M.'s decline, have also run into problems in the United States market lately and have been forced into discounting, but despite those problems, analysts said, they continued to gain market share. The Japanese companies' share of the United States market has grown to 23.5 percent from 17.8 percent a decade ago, while G.M.'s has fallen to 36.1 percent from 44.4 percent, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.
Longer term, some experts say Detroit's progress in eliminating unneeded capacity, as evidenced by G.M.'s move today, and in improving quality may be enough for a comeback. "The question is whether this is the final turn before G.M. becomes lean and mean, or is it more of the glacial retreat that characterized the company throughout the 1980's," said James Womack, research director of the automotive study project of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
The move comes a day after G.M. announced that it would idle 16 plants at various times over the next two months in hopes of making no more products than they can expect to sell. Most of the 16 are plants that G.M. intends to operate over the long term. The auto maker operates more than 100 plants in North America.
In announcing its third-quarter loss, G.M. said it would have earned $109 million on relatively strong sales abroad and gains by its nonautomotive subsidiaries, but was forced to reduce profit by $2.1 billion, after taxes, to cover the expense of shutting down the plants it no longer needs.
G.M.'s action formalized the shutdown of four assembly plants in Framingham, Mass., Lakewood, Ga., Pontiac, Mich., and Leeds, Mo., which had been indefinitely closed during the past three years. The $2.1 billion charge against earnings, which amounted to $3.3 billion before taxes, also provides for the contemplated shutdown of five assembly and components plants -- two in Pontiac, Mich., and one each in Scarborough, Ont., Lordstown, Ohio, and Flint, Mich. -- over the next three years. But the auto maker declined to acknowledge officially that shutdowns at those factories were likely. The five plants employ about 9,000 workers, and G.M. has notified them that it has no plan to replace the vehicle models they build with new models.
G.M.'s revenue in the latest period was $30.8 billion, up 6.9 percent from $28.8 billion a year earlier. Last year G.M. earned $517 million, or 72 cents a share, in the third quarter.
A G.M. spokesman said the company had not decided whether to shut down any of the five plants and would publicly announce any shutdowns only after workers had been notified. A United Auto Workers official said, "There aren't any surprises here." The union's latest three-year contract, ratified by G.M. workers last month, contains more than $4 billion in income security benefits that assure workers a paycheck even if their plants are closed.
 
 Promise to the Union
 Under G.M.'s 1987 labor contract, the company promised the union that it would not close any more plants. That is why, analysts believe, the four idled plants were not written off on G.M.'s books until now.
G.M. officials said privately that the company's top executives were reluctant to spell out their plans for the five additional plants, fearing a repeat of what they perceived as a huge public relations black eye in November 1986, when the auto maker announced the shutdown of 11 North American plants. That move temporarily focused the public debate over the declining competitiveness of the nation's manufacturing companies on G.M.
From the perspective of G.M.'s executives, the shutdowns of older plants show that the company is serious about increasing productivity. As it has closed plants, G.M. has invested billions in new plants, including the Saturn manufacturing complex in Spring Hill, Tenn., which has just begun producing cars.
 
 Too Much Capacity
 Nevertheless, for the last decade G.M. has operated with too many people and too much plant capacity for the number of cars and trucks it was selling in the United States. Although this reflected G.M.'s optimism that it could it regain its former market position, the strategy was expensive, and it also meant that the auto maker was often producing too many vehicles.
Robert C. Stempel, who took office as G.M. chairman in August, has said since 1988 that his goal was to match plant capacity to sales and run all its plants at capacity by the end of 1992.
The redeeming features of G.M.'s latest financial results were strong results, announced yesterday, by its General Motors Acceptance Corporation finance subsidiary, GM Hughes Electronics subsidiary and Electronic Data Systems Corporation unit.
Underscoring the difficulties that lie ahead for domestic auto makers, Standard & Poor's warned its clients today that the credit ratings for the Big Three could be reduced in coming months because of eroding market conditions. The credit-rating company downgraded the senior debt of Ford and Chrysler by one notch in June.
G.M., Ford and Chrysler and their subsidiaries had outstanding debt totaling $200 billion as of Sept. 30.

HEADLINE: Lin Takeover Cited in McCaw Loss

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: KIRKLAND, Wash., Oct. 31

 BODY:
McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., the nation's largest cellular telephone company, today reported a loss for the third quarter, citing interest costs and other expenses related to its purchase of a controlling stake in the Lin Broadcasting Corporation.
In March, McCaw paid $3.4 billion for 52 percent of Lin, which also reported a loss in the third quarter. Both companies said income excluding interest payments, depreciation and other items related to acquisitions grew strongly in the period.
 
Revenues Double
 McCaw, based in Kirkland, Wash., said it lost $80 million in the quarter, compared with a loss of $44.9 million in the 1989 period. Helped in part by the acquisition of the Lin stake, revenues more than doubled to $280.5 million, from $129.7 million in the comparable period last year. 
 McCaw owns or has stakes in cellular systems in more than 100 United States markets.
Lin, based in New York, reported a third-quarter loss of $5.8 million, in contrast to a profit of $24.6 million, or 46 cents a share, in the 1989 period. Sales grew nearly 54 percent, to $94.9 million, from $61.7 million.
Lin owns interests in cellular phone properties in New York, Los Angeles, Philadelphia, Dallas and Houston and operates seven television stations.
The shares of cellular phone companies have dropped sharply in recent months as the weakening economy has cooled demand.
Today, Lin shares fell $1, to $43.25, in over-the-counter trading, and McCaw fell 37.5 cents, to $11.50.
McCaw took on a large amount of debt to finance the Lin deal. Excluding debt-related interest and depreciation and amortization costs, McCaw said income from operations soared more than five times the 1989 quarter's level to $89.3 million, from $17.1 million.
Its interest expense nearly tripled to $143.3 million, from $56.8 million a year ago.
Lin said cash flow on its cellular operations jumped 80.9 percent to $46.3 million, from $25.6 million.
It had overall interest expense of $36.8 million in the period, compared with none a year ago. The charges stemmed from the McCaw deal and transactions with Metromedia Inc. that were completed in the quarter, a Lin spokesman, Donald Guthrie, said.
Several special items affected results at each company.
Lin recorded a pretax gain of $15.4 million on the sale of a 1 percent interest in a Philadelphia cellular system to Metromedia. Results also reflected its purchase of a 48 percent interest in a New York City cellular system from Metromedia for cash and preferred stock.
McCaw benefited from a $41.4 million tax gain in the quarter and had a pretax gain on asset sales of $9.8 million, compared with a $17.4 million gain in the 1989 quarter.

HEADLINE: Revisions Adopted in College Entrance Tests

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Substantial revisions of the college admissions tests taken each year by more than one million pencil-chewing students were approved today. The changes will put more emphasis on reading skills, move the exams away from multiple-choice answers and, for the first time, permit calculators to be used.
But the College Board, a nonprofit organization that sponsors the tests, stopped short of more sweeping changes, like mandatory essay questions, that had been under consideration in the exams. The tests, the Scholastic Aptitude Test and the Achievement Tests, have been known to generations of students as "the S.A.T.'s." 
 Today's eighth graders will be the first class to take the new tests when they become high school juniors in the spring of 1994.
 
Changing the Emphasis?
 Educators who have worked for more than three years on the revisions say they will reduce the effectiveness of outside coaching companies and will emphasize to high school educators around the country that test-taking is not as important as reading and writing.
For months, word has been leaking out of a fundamental restructuring that would bring the S.A.T.'s out from under accusations that they are inaccurate and obsolescent. Donald M. Stewart, president of the College Board, and Gregory Anrig, president of the Educational Testing Service, which designs and administers the tests, have talked freely for years about how important it was to substantially revise them.
In the past three years, sample tests, including the written essay and math computations, were adminstered to 100,000 students, and the proposed changes were reviewed by more than 6,000 experts. The studies cost millions, and many observers believed the board was fully committed to the proposals, including mandatory essays.
 
Criticism From Minorities
 But in the end severe criticism, especially from minority groups who believed a mandatory essay would put them at a disadvantage, helped to kill the proposal, as did the cost of administering and scoring the essays.
Some of those gathered at the meeting today were surprised at the comparatively modest scope of change, which they said must have been a disappointment to Mr. Stewart and the board.
"If he's not embarrassed, he should be," said Robert Schaeffer, an educational consultant who opposes standardized tests.
But Mr. Stewart showed no sign of being let down by today's vote. He and other officials said the changes will improve the test and help raise standards in high schools across the country.
"Taken as a whole, these changes are designed to send positive signals to our schools, to reinforce sound curriculum in the high schools," said Derek Bok, the president of Harvard and co-chairman of a panel that reviewed the proposed changes. Mr. Bok said the revisions would make them "a more versatile set of tests serving a more diverse group of people."
 
Some See Cosmetic Changes
 But those who have long asserted that the tests inaccurately assessed student ability and were heavily biased against women and minority groups immediately attacked the changes as being little more than cosmetic.
"The test is not going to be improved in terms of predictability for college performance because it has basically not changed," said Cinthia Schuman, executive director of the National Center for Fair & Open Testing, a nonprofit group in Cambridge, Mass., that has often led the opposition to the tests. Nor, she said, will the changes correct the bias against women and minorities.
The tests are used, along with other factors, to evaluate applications to college and to grant scholarships. But they have become far more than just an educational touchstone. Although they were not designed to be used in such ways, scores often become reflections of a school's quality or a selling point, rattled off by real estate brokers, emphasizing the merits of a particular school district.
 
Other Tests Affected
 The changes will also affect two other tests administered by the College Board. They are the Preliminary Scholastic Aptitude Test, given to high school students as a sort of prelude to the Scholastic Aptitude Test, and the National Merit Scholarship Qualifying Test. Both are similar to the Scholastic Aptitude Test.
College Board officials described the changes approved today as substantial, but they insisted they were not made in response to criticism. Rather, they said, the changes are intended to improve the tests' reliability and to more accurately reflect the increasing diversity of students and what is being taught today.
The decision today also adds Japanese and Chinese to the list of languages in which optional parts of the tests may be taken and changes the names from the Scholastic Aptitude Test and Achievement Tests to Scholastic Assessment Test I and Scholastic Assessment Test II, respectively. The aptitude test is meant to gauge verbal and mathematical ability. The achievement exams, which not all colleges require, deal with specific subjects.
The most significant change is in the aptitude test's mathematics section, where problems have been added in which students, using calculators if they wish, figure out the answer instead of having a a list of options from which to chose.
The number of these problems will remain small -- no more than 15 out of about 60 items -- but it underscores a greater emphasis toward problem solving and individual thinking.
 
More Time to Think
 The verbal part of the new S.A.T. will also be altered substantially. The section asking for opposites of various words will be dropped and replaced by an expanded part on critical reading, in which students must read a passage of literature and answer multiple-choice questions about it.
Over all, nervous test-takers might feel a little less pressure because there will be slightly fewer questions to be answered in slightly more time. Twenty minutes will be added to the aptitude test, which now lasts 2 hours 30 minutes.
However most answers will still have to be picked from a list and filled in with a No. 2 lead pencil, and the aptitude test scores will be based on the same 200-to-800 scale as the current test.
While Mr. Bok and Mr. Stewart stressed the added focus on reading and writing skills, they also said a portion of the current test devoted to written English would be dropped in 1994.
But by then there will be a written essay segment in the optional achievement tests because they measure what a student has learned in different subject areas, as opposed to predicting his ability to do college work, as in the standard verbal and mathematics part.
 
Communications Skills
 The 20-minute written essay, in addition to the multiple-choice auestions, will not require specialized knowledge, officials said, but is intended to test a student's ability to communicate effectively. Factors such as grammar and clarity of expression, as well as soundness of logic, will affect scores.
Until today, there had been wide speculation that the revisions would include a mandatory English essay in the standard S.A.T. Confidential memos between members of the revisions panel indicated that the essay was being seriously considered at least through last July.
Several educators, especially in California, had opposed the essay on the grounds that it would have put foreign-born students at a disadvantage. The speaker of the California Assembly, Willie L. Brown, Jr., had warned the College Board that the state would consider dropping the S.A.T. from use at the University of California.
In recent years, California has had an influx of immigrants, particulary from Asia.
 
Decision Is Explained
 Robert McCabe, president of Miami-Dade Community College in Florida and chairman of the board of trustees of the College Board, said that because of the possible implications, and for financial reasons, the essay was dropped from consideration.
Had the essay been included, it would have meant that between 1.3 million and 2 million essays would have had to be scored, not by machines but by high school and college teachers. Instead, it is estimated that about 100,000 students will take the optional writing essay.
Even as an option to help admissions officers, the essay could still put foreign-born students at a disadvantage, officials said. But the achievement tests already contain portions in more than a dozen foreign languages, and the board today approved adding Chinese and Japanese to the list.
A number of minority interest groups joined the National Center for Fair & Open Testing in a letter calling on the College Board not to implement the revisions. The groups, which signed the letter before today's vote by the board, include the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund, the Asian Legal Defense and Education Fund and the Center for Women Policy Studies. Critics said the changes did not address the fundamental bias inherent in the test and predicted that girls would continue to score on average about 60 points below boys on the aptitude portion, even though their high school and college grades are better.
 
Economic Bias Is Charged
 They also said that the changes will exacerbate an economic bias because students who cannot afford to buy calculators will not do as well as students who use them. Students who can afford to pay for special coaching also will still have an advantage, the critics say.
Although Mr. Bok said the new test, with its essays and math problems would be harder to coach, professionals disagreed.
"I can teach this tomorrow," said John S. Katzman, president of The Princeton Review, a company that coaches 35,000 students a year. "It's the same test."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk
