HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
BUSH INTENSIFIES A WAR OF WORDS AGAINST THE IRAQIS

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Early this morning, President Bush paused on his way to a political fund-raising breakfast in Virginia to declare that he had "had it" with Iraq's treatment of American hostages and diplomats.
"The Kuwaiti Embassy is being starved," Mr. Bush said of the United States Embassy in Kuwait, where a few diplomats have stayed during the Iraqi occupation as a symbol of American resolve. "The people out there are not being resupplied. The American flag is flying over the Kuwait embassy, and our people inside are being starved by a brutal dictator. 
 "Do you think I'm concerned about it?" the President went on. "You're darn right I am. And what I'm going to do about it? Let's just wait and see. Because I have had it with that kind of treatment of Americans, and I know others feel that way."
 
Sununu's Emphasis Different
 At the same time that the President was drawing this hard line against Saddam Hussein, his chief of staff, John H. Sununu, was on a morning news show declaring that Mr. Bush was "still committed to making sure he does everything on the diplomatic front to avoid hostilities."
In an eerie replay of the budget ordeal, the President and his advisers are talking in different voices, sending different messages and moving back and forth between opposing positions -- sometimes at the same moment.
Some Administration policy makers today privately conceded that they were as confused as the Congressional leaders who met with President Bush on Tuesday about the signals the White House is trying to send and the direction in which Mr. Bush is trying to move.
"It's the budget mess all over again -- flip-flops, a message out of control and nobody in charge," a top official said.
 
Bush's and Baker's Strategy
 In recent days, Mr. Bush and his Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, have gradually escalated the verbal barrage against Mr.Hussein as a way of underlining the threat of force.
Such a plan served three functions: It was a way of trying to force the Iraqi President to believe that his choices are to stay in Kuwait and die or to leave and have his Government survive. It was a way of preparing the American public for a confrontation, if there is to be one. And it also served a political purpose by trying to redirect the public's attention in the week before elections away from the budget battle, showcasing the slumping President in an area of strength and offering Republican candidates a better issue than taxes and the economy.
But while the tougher talk was supposed to scare Mr. Hussein, it was not supposed to cause Congress, the American public and the press to assume that the Administration was leaning further toward an offensive military action.
It was a delicate line, and some Administration officials now express fear that Mr. Bush may have gone too far on the bellicose side today, a day after Congressional leaders warned him to move cautiously and to avoid provocations against Mr. Hussein as a pretext for taking military action.
Administration officials said that the President's remarks were not coordinated or planned in advance between the State Department and the White House, or even within the White House. They confessed that they really had no idea why Mr. Bush had said what he did, except that in his eagerness to shift the subject of the public debate from the budget imbroglio to foreign policy, he went a bit far.
"We seem to be zigzagging because sometimes it's less a matter of a game plan and more a matter of the President's moods," a White House official said.
 
Little Enthusiasm From Congress
 The President's approach is a high-risk strategy, according to Middle East experts and officials involved in Persian Gulf policy making. The lukewarm reception that Mr. Bush received on Tuesday after briefing Congressional leaders showed that there is still no consensus for going to war against Iraq. The more the President raises the specter of war and does not do anything about it, the more time for the public and Congress to debate the question and argue against it.
Tonight, Mr. Bush's aides tried to tamp down speculation that the military option loomed larger. "Unfortunately, there's an air of imminent activity here that is not justified," the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said.
If the President did not want to imply that he was losing patience with the economic sanctions and thinking more about a military strike, Mr. Fitzwater was asked, why did he use a phrase like "I've had it?"
"It may not be bad if those words get people's attention," the press secretary replied. "This is a very serious problem that could have very significant ramifications at any point. There are a lot of flashpoints ahead, a lot of possible provocations related to the hostages and the embassy. The President wants to refocus national attention on this issue and get people ready for any eventuality."
 
Iraqi Envoy Is Conciliatory
 At a news conference in Washington today, the Iraqi Ambassador, Mohammed al-Mashat said: "We seek to avoid bloodshed. We'd like to establish good relations with the United States." Without being specific, he said that Iraq was ready to negotiate all issues that are destabilizing the Middle East.
Mr. Mashat also released a purported Kuwaiti intelligence document that said that the Central Intelligence Agency and Kuwait had agreed late last year "to take advantage of the deteriorating economic situation in Iraq in order to put pressure on that country's Government to delineate our common border."
A spokesman for the C.I.A. called the document "a total fabrication" by Iraq.
On Tuesday, the lawmakers told Mr. Bush in strong terms that he should give economic sanctions a chance to work. Representative Dante B. Fascell, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said that he and other legislators had said: "If there is a provocation, it's got to be a real one. If there's an additional provocation, it can't be two whales passing in the night. It has to be something that can stand the scrutiny of the media, and of the public, and of history. He understands."
 
Bush Complains of Cynicism
 Today, after he attended the fund-raising breakfast for Representative Stan Parris in Alexandria, Va., the President stopped to talk to reporters and tried to debunk the idea that politics was the motivating factor in turning up the heat against Iraq.
"I don't think even the most cynical would ever suggest that a President would play politics with the lives of American kids halfway around the world," he said. "So I'm sad if you've seen reports like that. I haven't. And I think it is, you know, the ultimate of cynicism and indecency."
As the President and Secretary of State raised the volume, with a discussion of more troops being dispatched to Saudi Arabia and with Mr. Baker planning a trip to the Persian Gulf this weekend, the point was to threaten without setting a timetable or a deadline that would box in the Administration, raise the hackles of Congress or put the United States in the position of making threats before it was willing or able to carry them out.
But by allowing Mr. Sununu to make the opposite point at the same time, the White House seemed to lack a coherent communications strategy to push an agenda -- even if it has a definite plan in the Persian Gulf.
If the Administration had hoped to send President Hussein a strong signal that the United States is getting impatient, that signal was diluted both by Mr. Sununu's words and by the division in intention expressed by Congressional leaders.
Republican strategists continued to express their disdain for the performance of the White House in this critical week before the election. "They don't have their act together," one counselor to the White House said. "They're living in a fog. They're confusing the American public."
Although Mr. Bush railed today against Mr. Hussein for starving the American Embassy workers in Kuwait, the Iraqi leader has said that all diplomats are free to return to their home countries.
Asked why the United States did not simply pull the diplomats out of the embassy, as other countries did, an Administration official replied: "Because we don't want to acquiesce to the annexation of Kuwait."
Mr. Bush said that he did not know how long the diplomats could hold out before they might be forced to withdraw. He said that if Iraq blocked a resupply effort, "it would be directly contravening a mandate from the United Nations and we would view that very seriously."
From the beginning of the Persian Gulf crisis, Mr. Bush insisted that the fate of the hostages would not affect United States policy, and officials insisted that the President would never make the mistake of personalizing the hostages and their families the way that President Reagan did in the period leading up to the Iran-contra scandal.
But today, Mr. Bush offered emotional comments about the fate of the hostages. He cited reports from other foreign captives who had been held with Americans in Kuwait, citing grim conditions. "That worries me," the President said.
"Asked if the hostages have become more important in his strategy for how to deal with the Persian Gulf crisis, Mr. Bush replied, "I wouldn't say more, but I am very concerned about it."

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 1, 1990

SECTION: Section D; Page 22; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1978 words

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN;
Birth and Life of a Political Ad: A Negative Message With Common Themes

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARWICK, R.I.

 BODY:
Bathed in the ochre hues of the City Council's chambers in this fading industrial city, a voter ambled to the microphone and attacked the Republican running for Congress as being "Ed DiPrete's handpicked candidate."
In Washington, 399 miles south, Peter H. Fenn exulted. His 30-second television commercial for John F. Reed, the Democratic candidate in the race to represent Rhode Island's Second Congressional District, had apparently worked. 
 "Certain phrases we put in a spot will resonate, like in a jingle," said Mr. Fenn, who came up with the idea of linking the Republican candidate, Trudy Coxe, with the Republican Governor, Mr. DiPrete.
This is the chronicle of the birth and life of that advertisement. Although it is specific to Rhode Island -- linking a Congressional candidate to a Governor whose popularity, like his state's economy, has been declining -- in many ways it is emblematic of political advertising in the 1990 campaign: It is negative, it responds to an attack and its themes are taxes and class warfare -- elements that define much of the political commercials on television this year.
 
'This Is Rock and Roll'
 Observing its genesis shows that swaying voters is less an orchestrated symphony of manipulation than a last-minute improvisation of sounds and symbols. Or, as Mr. Fenn said in the middle of the frantic hour and a half it took him to produce the advertisement, "This is rock and roll."
The process began a week earlier in the campaign for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Claudine Schneider, a five-term Republican who is challenging Rhode Island's senior politician, Claiborne Pell, a 71-year-old Democrat who was first elected to the Senate 30 years ago.
In the second week of October the Reed campaign confronted a new television commercial for Ms. Coxe. In a scant 87 words, it accused the Democrat of missing 363 votes in his six years in the State Senate, but of voting to raise taxes and legislators' pensions. It ended with an ominous gong and the admonition, "Hit the road, Jack."
To the Reed campaign's protest that the candidate had, in fact, voted for $460 million in tax cuts during his term, Ms. Coxe responded: "That was in the mid-80's. He voted to increase the budget five out of the last six years, which led to two tax increases."
 
The Philosophy: Attack and Control
 Like most political consultants this year, the principals of Fenn & King, the Democratic firm representing Mr. Reed, took it as an article of faith that they would have to hit back. Their reasoning was not scientific; rather, it was based on experience.
In a videotape the firm sends to prospective clients, It says: "The lessons we've learned are, first, go on the offensive and dictate the campaign's agenda. Second, always answer an opponent's charge if it's determined to be effective. And third, counterattack and make certain you control the dialogue."
At 8:45 A.M. on Thursday, Oct. 18, Thomas J. King, a burly, 39-year-old former political director of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, burst into the firm's unmarked Georgetown town house and began spewing lines he had thought of while driving to work.
"Sometimes politicians get confused," Mr. King said as David M. Woloch, a 1989 Cornell graduate who is the firm's production coordinator, took notes. "Take Trudy Coxe. Trudy Coxe is on television attacking Jack Reed for missing votes. The truth: Jack Reed has a 99 percent attendance record. Why the attack? Because Trudy Coxe supports another tax cut for the rich and powerful. Trudy, even in politics you should tell the truth."
Mr. King told Mr. Woloch to type the text. "Hey, David," he shouted after him. "Add Republican Trudy Coxe."
At 9:15 A.M., Mr. Fenn arrived and was told about the need for a new Reed commercial. His immediate reaction: "Stick 'em with DiPrete."
 
 The Emphasis: Class Warfare
 Mr. Fenn's suggestion had two sources. One was a series of thick looseleaf binders filled with research on Ms. Coxe's personal life and professional history. "The punch-counterpunch stuff is so immediate now that you have to have everything really ready," Mr. Fenn said. From the binders the consultant knew that Ms. Coxe's husband had been Governor DiPrete's 1988 campaign manager, a connection close enough to exploit.
A second source was polling. Few Congressional campaigns can afford the luxury of daily surveys. But a mid-October survey by WJAR-TV in Providence showed the Reed-Coxe race to be virtually a dead heat in a district that ranges from the seashore vacation homes of Narragansett to the hardscrabble wards of Cranston and Warwick. And a survey by Brown University in mid-September showed the Governor with an approval rating hovering around 20 percent.
Mr. Fenn took the script of the commercial and added in pen: "She supports Governor DiPrete's tax cuts for the rich and powerful."
This year Fenn & King has offered up class warfare in three-fourths of its 22 campaigns, most of which are for the House of Representatives. It is a far cry from 1983, when Mr. Fenn, who had been administrative aide to former Senator Frank Church of Idaho, established the consulting firm. In that year he created commercials for only two House races. Today 11 people crowd the firm's cramped headquarters, dodging piles of videotapes and taking a never-ending series of telephone calls from frantic candidates from Washington state to South CArolina.
The 42-year old Mr. Fenn and his colleagues debated the Reed commercial. Steve Murphy, who earned his political spurs as Iowa campaign manager in Representative Richard A. Gephardt's abortive run for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1988, wanted to add how large Ms. Coxe's tax break for herself would be if the cut in the capital gains tax that she favored were passed. Mr. Fenn demurred. "You know how hard it is to attack a woman on personal stuff," he said.
But the most serious disagreement was from the Reed campaign. In an 11:30 A.M. conference call, the candidate expressed his desire to go after Ms. Coxe's record as an environmentalist. The consultants disagreed, arguing that the Republican's long-time stewardship of Save the Bay, a Rhode Island enviromental group, had made her virtually unassailable on the issue.
 
 The Message: She's 'Confused'
 At 12:30, Fenn & King sent to the campaign its third revision of the script, which had been entitled, "Confused." In it, Mr. King had written that Ms. Coxe was "Ed DiPrete's hand-picked candidate."
One hour later, Mr. Fenn joined Mr. King in the sanctum sanctorum of Democratic Congressional campaigning, the Harriman Communications Center in the basement of the Democratic Party's headquarters, just down the hill from the Capitol. Here, Congressional candidates whose races are deemed important by the national party can use a suite of editing rooms, sound studios and satellite transmission equipment without charge.
A campaign might save $1,500 on the production of a single commercial, and perhaps $15,000 to $20,000 over the life of a campaign, Mr. Fenn said. On average, his firm's Congressional races spend about $500,000 for broadcast advertising, paying Fenn & King a 15 percent commission on that spending plus a $25,000 fee.
The rituals and language in the dark, sequestered editing room were arcane. When the consultants wanted text to appear on screen, they talked not of writing but of doing a "Chyron" -- the name of the machine that draws the video letters. They discussed the dictum that it is best to go negative on Thursday night, or, failing that, Friday. Because the advertising departments of most television stations are closed on weekends, it is impossible for the opposition to respond with its own ad before Monday, allowing the attacking candidate his longest sustained assault.
At 6:10 P.M., having finished an advertisement for a Congressional candidate from Idaho, Mr. Fenn began work on the Reed commercial. His deadline: 8 P.M., when another consultant was scheduled to use the room.
Mr. Fenn reviewed the videotape of Ms. Coxe's attack, which he had finally received, by plane and courier, from Rhode Island. He decided to lift from it one shot that accused Mr. Reed of missing votes.
In a matter of minutes, Mr. Fenn laid out the plan of attack. Start with a "Chyron" reading, "Sometimes politicians get a little confused." Cut to a photograph of Ms. Coxe, then to a shot from her attack on Mr. Reed, to remind voters that although she portrayed herself as an outsider, she used negative television commercials just like Washington insiders do. Then, in writing, state "the truth" about Mr. Reed's record. And then use her photo, a shot of Governor DiPrete and photographs of legislation to link her to Republicans and taxes.
 
 The Production: Some Improvisation
 There was no time to plan "hidden persuaders" capable of tripping the viewers' subconscious anxieties. The Reed spot's persuaders were more obvious, chosen simply because they were on hand. Mr. Fenn was going to use a photograph in which Ms. Coxe looked young and callow. But Carol Rachou, a Harriman Center technician who was operating the Chyron machine, saw another photograph of the candidate, in which she looked drawn and angry, and said: "Let's use this one. She looks 20 years older."
Much of the language, too, was last minute. When Mr. Rachou wrote on the screen that Mr. Reed had "voted against tax hikes," Mr. Fenn realized that he should add the Governor's name "since DiPrete is the Devil up there."
With Mr. Fenn conducting, Mr. Rachou and Rolyn Franzen, the video editor, sat at two electronic consoles, frantically tapping buttons and tossing words and images on the screen, enlarging some, shrinking others, looking to all the world like two jamming jazz pianists.
At 8:18 P.M. they finished. The next day, Friday, a Fenn & King employee drove several copies of the videotape to Washington's National Airport and loaded it on a 10:45 A.M. plane to Providence, where it was picked up by the Reed campaign.
Three weeks earlier, Fenn & King's broadcast television buyer, Lisa Goodman, had reserved time on Rhode Island's three network affiliates. Learning about the new Reed commercial, she immediately faxed orders to the stations to replace the candidate's previous commercial. At least through Tuesday, the response to Trudy Coxe would be the only Reed advertisement that Rhode Islanders would see.
The campaign would spend from $30,000 to $42,000 to insure that most of them would see it eight times, on shows like "The CBS Morning News" and "Wheel of Fortune." Ms. Goodman said. She also took care to place the ad on programs popular with people 45 and older, who are the most likely to vote. " 'MacGyver' and '60 Minutes' are incredibly good," she said.
Late that Friday afternoon, voters in the Second District heard the Reed campaign accuse Ms. Coxe for the first time of being "a little confused."
 
 The Impact: Few Are Moved
 But in the end the advertisement drew only shrugs from the public, with many voters saying it made little difference.
"That goes with politics," said Mary Harvey, a 67-year-old part-time nurse. "I don't like name-calling, but it happens."
Over at the candidates' forum in the Warwick City Hall, Ted Jarrett, a retired Chamber of Commerce executive, also said the ad was immaterial. "There was an inference that she was handpicked, but that's not critical," he said.
But Charles Allen, the voter who ambled to the microphone to attack Ms. Coxe, was moved. "I thought Jack's ads were fine, excellent," said Mr. Allen, a retired salesman. "But Trudy Coxe -- she's really going negative against Jack and she can't substantiate what she's saying."
Then he added, "She's DiPrete's handpicked candidate, and DiPrete is way behind."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A 30-second television commercial for John F. Reed, a Democratic candidate for Congress from Rhode Island, showed Trudy Coxe, his Republicanopponent, and Gov. Edward DiPrete, whose popularity has been declining. The commercial called Ms. Coxe "Ed DiPrete's handpicked candidate." (The New York Times)

PUB-DATE: November 1, 1990

SECTION: Section D; Page 23; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 937 words

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN;
Silber Grabs Attention But Not All the Backing

BYLINE: By BOSTON, Oct. 31, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
At a backstreet diner here in downtown Boston, where
hundreds of city workers, lawyers and bankers rub elbows daily, conversations usually revolve around the Celtics or the daily specials scribbled above the cash register.
But here at the Hungry Traveler in Court Square, the talk these days is of politics, and in particular of the Democratic candidate for governor, John R. Silber. 
 "Everybody is talking about the election," said Amy Hale, a 27-year-old waitress who sat at a back table during her lunch break. "And I think most people support Silber. Why? He's his own kind of guy. He says what he thinks. He's just a breath of fresh air and the state really needs that."
Voters seem to see Dr. Silber, who is on leave as the president of Boston University, as the Democrat who is not a Democrat, the politician who is not a politician. Dr. Silber has portrayed himself as an angry crusader for leaner, meaner government.
 
'He's Got the Guts'
 And in a state that is sliding into recession, even many of those who shudder at his dictatorial style say they will vote for Dr. Silber if he can whip Massachusetts into better fiscal shape.
"I don't agree with him issue for issue, but he's got the guts to do some of the things we need to do to turn Massachusetts around, like attract business," said John T. Maley, a 28-year-old accountant who sat alone at a red-topped table reading The Boston Globe sports section. "I deal with a lot of small companies and a lot of them decided to leave because of the old Taxachusetts thing under Dukakis. They went to New Hampshire."
Unlike his Republican opponent, William F. Weld, Dr. Silber opposes a proposed tax rollback that would cut more than $1 billion out of the budget during the remaining six months of the fiscal year. His 20 years of experience leading Boston University gives him credibility as a manager, Mr. Maley said.
 
Friends on Different Sides
 At a nearby table, Roy E. Prout and his luncheon partner of 20 years, Eugene D. Smith, sat under a multi-colored wall menu advertising specials "Hot and Fried on the Grill," quietly discussing next week's election.
Mr. Prout, a 60-year-old Boston police detective, said he supports Dr. Silber. Mr. Smith, a 51-year-old banker in gray pin-stripes, is for Mr. Weld. But when asked which candidate had grabbed the voters' attention, both men named Dr. Silber.
"I'm going to vote for Weld, but I think Silber is going to win," Mr. Smith said. "Weld doesn't have any baggage, so to speak, and that's what the people should be looking for. But I like Silber, too. I like the fact that he's outspoken and he says what he thinks. He's a business man, not a politician, and that's what we need. Someone who can make tough decisions."
But it is precisely Dr. Silber's outspokenness that has troubled many voters throughout the campaign.
"Although I am voting for Silber, I kind of feel bad when he calls the guy a son of a bitch in public," Mr. Prout said. "We could at least expect gentlemen wouldn't talk that way in public."
 
A 'Silber Shocker'
 Last week, Dr. Silber referred to Mr. Weld as a "back-stabbing son of a bitch" for resigning as United States Attorney to protest the leadership of Edwin Meese 3d. That "Silber shocker," as the news media has dubbed many of his provocative statements, was followed by another statement last week on a local television program in which he said that the proliferation of working mothers had led to an increase in child neglect.
"It's a dilemma," said Judith A. Gaddie, a 34-year-old city administrator. speaking of the choice between the two. "I definitely did not vote for Silber in the primary and it totally blew my mind when he won. I thought it was a bad dream."
But like many voters in this largely Democratic state, Ms. Gaddie criticized Mr. Weld as too conservative on social service spending. She also called Mr. Weld's budget-cutting plan as too vague and said he "talked like a politician."
"Silber may be too rigid, but Weld just reminded me too much of Bush and Reagan," she said. "He's kind of slippery and too slick,"
 
Reluctant Silber Backer
 But Ms. Gaddie said she would vote, although reluctantly, for Dr. Silber. "I'm really afraid to vote for Silber because I'm afraid he'll take away my rights," she said, noting Dr. Silber's conservative views on women's issues. "That's scary. But I think it is very important to vote.
"After watching him on television, what I finally figured out was that Silber is a straight talker. He may be wrong, but he says what's on his mind. Everybody's torn about who to vote for."
Many women around the state have expressed similar concerns about Dr. Silber's views on women's issues. Earlier last week, in a telephone interview from her real estate office in Arlington, Lin F. Kelleher said Mr. Silber's comments about working women had made her decide to vote for Mr. Weld.
"I'm a Democrat but I'm voting for Weld," said Mrs. Kelleher, who is married and has two children. "I think it is mainly just that Silber comes across looking like a maniac. He basically feels the woman's place is in the home. I don't think he is for working women. I don't think he is for women at all."
Mr. Prout said that given the voters' dissatifaction with the Democratic Party, Mr. Weld should be able to win the election. "I've said to Gene here on many occasions, if the Republicans can't win this time, they should just pull out of the state and never run again," he said. "And in a way, I do question Silber's arrogance -- sometimes -- his coldness. But I think that's what we need."

HEADLINE: Unified Albany Supports Spending Cuts to Close Budget Gap

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 31

 BODY:
In an uncharacteristic display of unity, legislative leaders said today that they concurred with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's dim assessment of the state's finances and approved of plans to close the budget gap through spending cuts alone.
But because the fiscal year, which started in April, has only five months left, financial analysts said it would be extremely difficult for the Governor and the Legislature to live up to their pledge to close the gap through spending cuts. Much of New York State's $50 billion budget, they noted, has already been spent or committed. 
 "It's going to be very tough," said Hy Grossman, a managing director at Standard & Poor's, which recently lowered the state's credit rating. "You're into the last third of the fiscal year. And the problems we're seeing now are the accumulation of three years of poor fiscal management."
With just six days to go before Election Day, legislators today were loathe to discuss specific spending cuts they would make to fill a gap that the Cuomo administration estimated would be $824 million for the current fiscal year. They noted that Mr. Cuomo, who is running for a third term, has put off presenting his plan to close the gap until after Nov. 6.
 
The Sooner, the Better
 "I am encouraged to hear that the Governor will not resort to borrowing or new taxes to close the budget gap," said the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, an Oyster Bay Republican. "As far as his plans for further spending reductions, the sooner the Governor submits them, the better."
Responding to assertions that Mr. Cuomo had purposely delayed presenting spending cuts until after the election, aides to the Governor said the administration had only just learned the magnitude of the problem. "There obviously will be a plan," said Gary G. Fryer, a Cuomo spokesman.
On Tuesday, Mr. Cuomo imposed an immediate hiring freeze on all state agencies and suspended the letting of new state contracts. He also called on all state agencies to submit by Friday plans for cuts totalling 3, 5 and 7 percent of their budgets. From those proposals, Mr. Cuomo said he would draft a plan to fill the budget gap.
"I don't think we can wait because the longer you wait the harder the cuts get," Mr. Cuomo said at a campaign stop in New City today.
The spending cuts, which would require legislative approval, would affect not only state agencies but local governments, who are the major recipients of state dollars.
 
Wrenching Budget Battles
 Today in New York City, Mayor David N. Dinkins, who is struggling with substantial budget problems of his own, said he could not respond to the latest bad news from Albany because he did not yet know what spending cuts would be recommended.
In Albany, lawmakers seemed genuinely dismayed by the latest budget forecast, and they predicted that the next several months would be spent in wrenching budget battles.
For once, however, Democratic and Republican lawmakers appeared to agree with the Democratic Governor and with each other about the magnitude of the state's problems.
Releasing his new estimates of the budget gap on Tuesday, Mr. Cuomo's budget director, Dall W. Forsythe, said the state was feeling the effects of a national recession, which he said "has already started." The Cuomo administration's assessment contradicted a more upbeat analysis offered on Tuesday by President Bush, who said the latest gross national product figures showed that the economy "has not been in a recession as some have claimed."
 
Some 'Real Belt-Tightening'
 In a rare show of support for Mr. Cuomo, Republicans in Albany today sided with the Governor, saying that his economic forecast seemed credible. In the past, Senate Republicans have often scoffed at the Governor's cheerless projections.
"We are not quarreling with the size of the problem," said Abraham M. Lackman, director of the Office of Fiscal Study in the Republican-led Senate.
In the Democratic-led Assembly, the word on the state's financial outlook was equally grim. "The Governor's numbers are consistent with what we've been seeing all along," said Carl Carlucci, secretary to the Ways and Means Committee. "It's going to take a lot of real belt-tightening."
Intensifying the gloom was the growing consensus that, after two years of fiscal troubles, the state had run out of reserves to cushion against painful spending decisions.

HEADLINE: 472 of the Rich Avoided Taxes

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Some wealthy Americans are still able to scrape together enough deductions to avoid paying any Federal income tax, the Internal Revenue Service said today.
Of 557,848 couples and individuals who reported income of $200,000 or more on returns filed in 1988, 472 with total income of $211 million paid no income tax. Two of them, both unidentified, even reported receiving unemployment compensation.
Of the high-income people who paid taxes, about 9,300 paid less than 5 percent. Another 17,082 reduced their liability to less than 10 percent, which is about the same as that paid by the average $35,000- a-year family.
In its annual report on the tax liabilities of high-income people, the I.R.S. said two- thirds of those with income of $200,000 and up reported capital gains -- profits from the sale of investments -- that averaged $284,814. By comparison, salaries averaged $264,331.
The study, prepared by the Treasury Department's Office of Tax Analysis, is based on raw tax returns. Some of the nontaxpayers could be moved onto the tax rolls following I.R.S. audits.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Yen Hurt by Political Fears; Dollar Up in Thin Trading

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Fears of political upheaval in Tokyo pushed the yen down yesterday, while the dollar gained in thin end-of-month trading that was dominated by technical factors.
"It was one of the quietest days in a long time. A little range is starting to develop," said Leslie Puth, vice president of Banque Indosuez in New York. Even most of the yen's movement occurred in overseas trading, dealers said. 
 Against the Japanese currency, the dollar closed at 130.15 yen, up from Tuesday's 128.65 yen. The dollar closed at 1.518 German marks, up from Tuesday's finish of 1.515 marks.
The dollar had risen to 129.55 yen by the opening of United States trading, helped by a report in The New York Times that a top Treasury official said the Bush Administration was concerned about the dollar's recent fall.
This led traders to speculate the Federal Reserve might intervene to support the dollar, which has tumbled recently, and it prompted some dollar-buying.
Also fueling the dollar's rise was speculation that Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party will lose a by-election Sunday, which hampered the yen, traders said.
The dollar was little moved by September economic data released yesterday, traders said. The data showed factory orders rose a scant one-tenth of 1 percent in the month, after a 1.7 percent gain in August, that personal income rose five-tenths of 1 percent, and that personal consumption rose 1.1 percent. Also, the Federal Reserve reported that growth appeared to have slowed nationwide.
The reports seemed to offer no new insight into the state of the economy, and dealers instead turned to technical factors to determine their trades.
Since hitting a record low of 1.491 marks and a 22-month low against the yen in mid-October, the dollar has traded in narrow bands.
Frank Pusateri, a vice president at the Bank of Boston, said the dollar's rise yesterday did not indicate any real strength in the currency or confidence in the economy, and he predicted the dollar would not jump off its recent lows anytime soon.
"Just because the dollar is not going down does not mean it is going up," Mr. Pusateri said.
Despite the gloomy outlook, the dollar posted gains against most major currencies. It ended at 1.2855 Swiss francs, up from 1.2825 francs Tuesday, and at 5.084 French francs, up from 5.0655. The dollar bought $1.1665 Canadian dollars, down from $1.1685 Tuesday, and stood at $1.9435 to the British pound, down from $1.9565.
Gold dipped, with December delivery losing 30 cents, to close at $379.40 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Mayoral Summit: Hoping to Shape Urban Agenda

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins is hoping to accomplish what none of his predecessors have been able to do for at least two decades: rally fellow mayors of major cities to help shape a realistic national urban agenda.
Of 65 mayors approached, 38 have already accepted Mr. Dinkins's invitation to a summit in New York later this month to draft an urban compact that, the Mayor hopes, will mark "the re-emergence of urban America as a full partner in the national political debate." 
 Among those scheduled to attend the Nov. 11-13 summit are the mayors of Boston, Chicago, Denver, Houston, Los Angeles, Miami, Newark and Philadelphia.
Not since John V. Lindsay was the mayor of New York and Richard M. Nixon was the President have cities been taken very seriously in Washington. That was when promising solutions abounded, as did Federal money on which most of those solutions depended. That was also before drugs, AIDS and homelessness had become epidemic. The severity of those problems further taxed municipal resources. Their ubiquity may now unite many of the nation's mayors.
Mr. Dinkins, like his predecessors, has not been shy about pointing fingers at the Federal Government. When he unveiled his sweeping public-safety proposals in a televised news conference last month, he urged New Yorkers -- four times -- to telephone the Speaker of the House of Representatives to lobby for national legislation that would impose a waiting period for gun pur chases.
 To shift blame to another level of gov ernment is perhaps the local equivalent of a diversionary for eign venture by a President whose do mestic program is under siege. By convening a summit, an official can also enhance his stature at home.
The attention that a mayor of New York City commands makes him uniquely situated to lobby for urban America. Many attempted to. Mr. Lindsay transformed his coalition of mayors from New York State's six largest cities into a national crusade. His successors were at first consumed with their parochial fight for Federal loan guarantees to keep their city solvent, then confronted a national administration whose urban agenda was largely grounded in self-help. During the 1988 Presidential campaign, reasoned debate about urban policy was mostly replaced by symbolism -- Boston Harbor and Willie Horton.
Mr. Dinkins may fare better than his predecessors because the problems he inherited are no longer viewed as unique to New York. A planning group of 10 mayors has defined the urban summit's goals: to explore the role of American cities in the global economy; to expand regional perspectives by integrating city and suburban solutions; and to confront common fiscal challenges.
Mr. Dinkins views the three-day summit, organized by Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, as the basis for a continuing collaboration. Its longer-range missions, he wrote fellow mayors, include pursuing economic development strategies in conjunction with industry and encouraging "a more balanced and diversified coverage of cities in the local and national media," a subject about which Mr. Dinkins is particularly sensitive as it relates to his city.
The Mayor maintains that the four in five Americans who do not live in major cities are sympathetic to urban problems. He cites a public-opinion poll that suggests support among commuters for his proposed payroll tax to pay for more police officers and a national survey, overseen by the City University of New York's Office of Urban Affairs, in which people who do not live in cities said they would be willing to pay higher taxes to help house the urban poor, among other things.
The mayors' challenge is to transform compassion and self-interest into practical solutions. Also, to convert skeptics into partners.
"The U.S. does not have a 'national urban crisis,"' cautions Richard P. Nathan, director of the Nelson A. Rockefeller Institute of Government at the State University of New York in Albany. "Rather, some cities -- typically older cities, declining in population, and with a high proportion of minority residents -- have urban crisis conditions."
That those conditions prevail in large and small cities alike may provide the basis for a broader political coalition. But Dr. Nathan suggests that "there is a great deal to be gained by shifting our attention from making policies to carrying them out, from bold new visions to steady and continued policy innovation, from big headlines in Washington to strong leadership at the state and city levels, from ranting about more money to winning raves about how we use money once it is allocated."
Some mayors might find that confining. Others may seize the opportunity.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
New United Air Executive Plans to Build Brand Loyalty

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
UNITED AIR LINES, America's largest carrier, has big ambitions. So does Adam M. Aron, its new senior vice president for marketing, who starts work on Monday when he leaves his current earthbound employer, Hyatt Hotels.
Mr. Aron says he wants to spend more advertising dollars to build brand loyalty to United, which he says will be especially important as a recession looms and the price of jet fuel soars. And he hopes, competitors willing, to escape the industry's destructive round of fare discounting. "For every person who wants a cheaper airplane ride," he said in an interview, "there is another person who wants a better airplane ride." 
 He would also like to see less emphasis on destination in United's marketing. "My message would no longer be, 'We fly the Pacific,' but, 'Here's how we fly the Pacific.' "
Mr. Aron has his job cut out for him. With United's recent deal to buy Pan Am's routes to London, which is subject to British regulatory approval, United must cast itself as more of an international airline and must learn to sell itself to Europeans.
For clues to Mr. Aron's brand-building approach, one needs look only at his successful "The Hyatt Touch" marketing campaign, which emphasized Hyatt's facilities, room service and frequent-guest program, modeled after the airlines' frequent-flier programs.
But the Hyatt television commercials are also frankly sensual. As the Platters sing a version of their hit "The Magic Touch," the camera pans past fluttering curtains, bedsheets in artful disarray and enough lithe limbs to outrage retired hotel detectives everywhere. Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, in Boston, handles the Hyatt account.
The UAL Corporation, United's parent company, is not feeling quite that frisky, but it is getting there. UAL spent an estimated $127 million last year on print and broadcast advertising. But its marketing has been pretty much in a holding pattern because of the three-year battle over who will own the carrier. The airlines' unions had sought to it, as did other parties. The unions' latest bid collapsed last month.
Mr. Aron said he admired United's current campaign, devised by Leo Burnett USA of Chicago, and planned no changes in the agency or its longtime slogan, "Fly the Friendly Skies of United." Burnett's commercials are lushly colored, briskly edited montages of airplanes and foreign ports of call, with the booming strains in the background of George Gershwin's "Rhapsody in Blue."
With the ownership question apparently resolved, UAL's chairman, Stephen M. Wolf, has taken firm control of United. He is buying a record number of new planes and also wants a new marketing approach. That effort will be led by Mr. Aron, a Wolf protege from 1982 when Mr. Wolf was senior vice president for marketing at Pan American World Airways and Mr. Aron was liaison to Pan Am's travel agencies.
At 36 years old, Mr. Aron has a Harvard M.B.A. and is a marketing veteran from Western Air Lines as well as Pan Am. When Mr. Aron was with Western in 1985, the California carrier emphasized such amenities as steak, shrimp and champagne on its $59 flight from Los Angeles to Seattle.
Mr. Aron also revived Western's venerable slogan, "Western Air Lines -- the Only Way to Fly." He said the slogan helped a great deal in a brutal competitive battle in California, which nonetheless resulted in Western being acquired by Delta Air Lines.
"There was a lot of equity in that Western slogan and there is a very big lesson for United Airlines in that," Mr. Aron said. "Way too many marketers underestimate the brand loyalty of airline customers."
Mr. Aron sees many similarities between airlines and his most recent employer, the hotel business. Both are similarly seasonal, have similar business and leisure customers, and, most of all, have similar kinds of "perishable inventory."
"An unsold hotel room is like an empty airline seat," he said. "Once the sun sets or the airplane door closes, you're not going to make any money from it."

HEADLINE: U.S. Health Care Costs Soar, But Not as Much in New York

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
New York State has health care costs among the highest in the country, but the rate at which those costs are increasing is the slowest of all 50 states, according to new estimates of health care costs issued today.
The report is the first state-by-state breakdown of health care costs since the Federal Government stopped issuing such figures in 1982. In addition to citing current and past costs, it reports the number of uninsured in each state and estimates how much health care will cost at the end of the decade. 
 "We are paying more and getting less," said Ron Pollack, executive director of Families U.S.A. Foundation, a nonprofit health care policy group in Washington, which put out the report. "Americans have a life span two years shorter than our neighbors in Canada. We have higher death rates from heart disease. Our infant mortality is higher than that of Singapore. At least one out of every four Americans will go without health insurance for a month or more over the next three years."
 
Costs Nearing a Trillion
 The cost of health care in the United States shot up to $606 billion from $230 billion in the last decade, and if trends remain the same, will reach almost $1.5 trillion by the end of the decade, the report said.
 New York spent an estimated $50 billion on health care in the fiscal year 1990, up from about $22 billion in 1980, a rise of 128 percent. While that increase is very high compared with inflation, it is the lowest of the 50 states. It comes to $2,818 a person in the state in 1990.
The number of people in New York without any kind of health insurance rose to 2 million in 1988, or 11.5 percent of the population, from 1.6 million in 1980.
Connecticut had the lowest percentage of uninsured people of any state in 1988 -- 186,000, or 5.8 percent, of the population. The number dropped by four percent from 1980 to 1988. The state's 147 percent increase in spending on health care -- from $3.5 billion in 1980 to $8.8 billion in 1990, was 32d highest in the nation. Spending in the fiscal year 1990 was estimated at $2,699 a person.
New Jersey's spending rose to $17.4 billion from $6.8 billion in the past decade, for a 154 percent increase, the 27th highest in the nation. The number of uninsured also declined 7 percent in New Jersey in the last decade, to an estimated 638,000 for 1990, or 8.3 percent of the population. Spending was estimated at $2,224 a person for 1990.
Costs varied widely around the country. Massachusetts had the highest, at $3,031 per capita, and South Carolina the lowest, at $1,689 a person. The lowest costs are generally in the South.
The highest rates of increase came in Arizona, Alaska, Florida, New Mexico and Maine. Mr. Pollack noted that three of these are Sunbelt states with a higher-than-average number of elderly.
The states with the greatest number of uninsured are, in order, New Mexico, Arkansas, Texas, Florida, Oklahoma, Mississippi, Arizona, Nevada, Louisiana and California. The first nine of these are Sunbelt states in which a high proportion of jobs are in service industries, which have a high percentage of nonunion workers with low pay and low benefits, Mr. Pollack said.
Citizen Action, an advocacy group with 2.5 million members in the United States, assisted in compiling the report. It can be obtained by writing to Families U.S.A. Foundation, 1334 G Street N.W., Washington, D.C., 20005.

HEADLINE: Kodak Loss Is Less Than Projections

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday reported a loss of $206 million for the third quarter after taking a charge to pay $909.5 million in a patent infringement award to the Polaroid Corporation.
But Kodak's stock rose sharply because the loss was smaller than many industry analysts had expected. 
 The net loss compared with a profit of $300 million, or 93 cents a share, in last year's third quarter. Revenues totaled $4.77 billion, up about 5 percent from $4.54 billion in the 1989 quarter.
 
'Some Comfort'
 On an operating basis, Kodak said its earnings were up about 22 percent, to $835 million, from $682 million in last year's quarter.
"I think it was a solid operating quarter and that it may give some comfort as one looks ahead on estimates for the next year," said James Meyer, an analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott.
Kodak's stock was up $1.375, to $39.875, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
On Oct. 12, a Federal judge ordered Kodak to pay Polaroid $454.2 million in lost profit and royalties and $455.3 million in interest for bringing out instant cameras in 1976 that infringed on Polaroid's patents.
The award was well below the $12 billion Polaroid had sought and the $1.5 billion to $2 billion industry analysts had expected.
Brenda Lee Landry, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, said Kodak's stock had been "morbidly depressed" even after the patent settlement and that the earnings report could be the beginning of a recovery.
Kodak, based in Rochester, said its worldwide sales continued to rise in the quarter, though gains in international markets were partly offset by lagging United States shipments because of a sluggish economy.
"Although we are concerned about general softness in the U.S. economy, we have characterized 1990 as a year of higher sales and sharply higher operating earnings," Kodak said in a statement. "We see no reason to change that characterization."

HEADLINE: Orders at U.S. Factories Rose 0.1% in September

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Orders received by United States factories rose a scant one-tenth of 1 percent in September, the Commerce Department said today, as demand for durable goods like cars fell sharply.
The gain in September orders, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $244.5 billion, followed a revised 1.7 percent rise in orders during August, when higher petroleum and chemical prices pushed the total value of orders higher. 
 Department officials said September's rise was the weakest performance since June, when orders dropped 1.9 percent, although it was above economists' expectations of a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent.
The department said September factory orders were inflated by higher petroleum prices since the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq on Aug. 2. Excluding petroleum, orders in September fell 1.1 percent.
 
Durable Goods Drop 1.4%
 A principal component of factory orders, durable goods, fell 1.4 percent in September after declining nine-tenths of 1 percent in August. Durables are items like refrigerators and automobiles intended to last at least three years.
Excluding transportation, total factory orders rose 1.2 percent in September after gaining 1.8 percent in August. Auto sales have weakened in the fourth quarter as consumers grow more cautious about buying amid growing signs of a recession and climbing gasoline prices.
A week ago, in a separate report just on durable goods, the department said orders had fallen 1.7 percent in September.
Durable goods account for about half of the factory orders index.
Transportation equipment orders fell 6.8 percent in September after rising 1 percent in August. Within that category, orders for aircraft and missiles were up 20.4 percent in September after falling 21.3 percent in August.
 
Little Change Since March
 Factory orders have been essentially unchanged since March in a pattern of moderate monthly rises and falls, and there is little to suggest that will change.
The nation's gross national product rose at a fairly strong 1.8 percent annual rate between July and September, the Commerce Department said Tuesday. But that was mostly because of a burst of consumer spending on cars and other goods that has since waned. Most private economists say the economy is headed into recession.
Shipments of motor vehicles and parts plunged 14.3 percent in September after an 8.5 percent increase in August.
Orders for primary metals were down 1.1 percent in September after a 2.5 percent drop in August.
 
Electrical Machinery Orders Fall
 Orders for electrical machinery decreased 6.3 percent in September after a 2 percent rise in August, while non-electrical machinery orders rose 6.2 percent after falling 5.2 percent in August.
Orders for nonmilitary capital goods, a measure of expansion plans by business, gained 7 percent in September after declining 10 percent in August.
Military orders for capital goods, another volatile category, fell 6.7 percent in September after gaining 12 percent in August.
Excluding the military, total orders rose three-tenths of 1 percent in September after increasing by 1.4 percent in August.
Shipments of manufactured goods declined seven-tenths of 1 percent in September after increasing 3.3 percent in August.

HEADLINE: Bethlehem Steel Profit Plunges 78%

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, stung by sharply lower steel prices and higher operating costs, said yesterday that its third-quarter net income dropped 78 percent. Bethlehem, the nation's second-largest steel company, also said the level of shipments dropped 6 percent for the quarter.
Bethlehem, like other leading steel makers, was hurt by the widespread price discounting in the industry in the quarter, as previously announced price increases failed to stick. 
 The company reported net income of $10.1 million, or 5 cents a share, compared with $46.9 million, or 53 cents a share, in the 1989 period. Sales for the quarter declined 4.7 percent, to $1.21 billion, from $1.27 billion. The third quarter of 1989 included $105 million in charges for restructuring and reducing the size of two of its operations.
While price discounting has affected the earnings of several other steel companies, Bethlehem has been particularly vulnerable because it has few operations outside of steel. Also, Bethlehem is the only big producer that has no joint ventures with foreign steel companies.
 
Underlying Problems
 "Bethlehem may have a couple of little problems beneath the surface that will affect them more negatively than some of their competitors," said John Jacobson, an analyst with AUS Consultants in Philadelphia. "They have higher costs for retiree benefits, a large number of retirees and high health-care benefits -- and the potential for restructuring and charges associated with those."
In an interview, Walter F. Williams, Bethlehem's chairman, complained that rival producers had allowed pricing to collapse in an effort to gain market share. "Some of the people in the industry felt there was a need to cut prices to hold on to volume," Mr. Williams said. "And that has impacted the pricing structure severely."
At the same time, Mr. Williams said, costs have continued to climb. "We have seen some increases that resulted from the labor contract signed last year," he said. "Also, there have been increases in purchased materials, oil costs and energy. Our price increases have been across the board." The price declines have been surprising, he added, because industry shipments have remained at about last year's level.
 
Cost of a Shutdown
 The company said its results were further affected by a planned 25-day shutdown of its mill in Sparrows Point, Md., as part of Bethlehem's modernization efforts and repairs of coke ovens. The company added that those costs were expected to continue into the fourth quarter and next year.
Bethlehem reported operating income from its basic steel operations of $27 million, compared with $59 million in the period last year. From steel-related operations, the company reported operating income of $12 million, in contrast to a loss of $8 million in the period last year.
Mr. Williams said Bethlehem would raise prices at the beginning of the year. "We're hopeful that, if we don't have a more significant recession than people are predicting, those 1991 price increases will hold."
On the New York Stock Exchange, Bethlehem's stock was up 25 cents, closing at $11.375.

HEADLINE: Price of Oil, Still Erratic, Exceeds $35

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil prices rallied late yesterday to move above $35 a barrel in a third straight erratic trading session that largely ignored news on the Persian Gulf standoff.
Crude oil had been down about $1 a barrel in early trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, but a surge in the afternoon pushed it up by about $2 from the morning lows. Crude settled at $35.23 a barrel, up 69 cents for the day, on contracts for delivery in December. 
 All later contract months closed higher in a market that stayed about as sluggish as in the two previous sessions.
"Compared to normal changes, it's a wimp today," said Philip L. Dodge, an oil analyst with Nomura Securities International Inc. "There hasn't been anything to signal that we're closer to war or peace. It just gets caught in the middle."
There was no dominant news moving the market, although some of the move down was attributed to conciliatory remarks from Iraq and some of the move up was attributed to war talk from the United States and Britain.
Thomas Blakeslee, an energy analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J., said the late rally came as floor traders who had agreed to sell oil early in the day found they had bet the wrong way as oil refused to drop. They then bought crude-oil contracts to avoid losing more money and the price went up.
"On the close, the market took off," Mr. Blakeslee said. "You found locals caught on the wrong side. As it turned positive, locals realized this market had no oomph to the down side." Locals are traders who perform functions similar to the specialists in the stock market.
Future contracts for refined petroleum products also seemed to fluctuate with little sense of direction.
Home heating oil closed 1.63 cents lower, at 89.54 cents a gallon on November contracts. December and January contracts fell, but more-distant months moved higher for the day.
Unleaded gasoline contracts were all higher at the close, with November delivery up 2.71 cents, to 96.44 cents a gallon.
Natural gas prices were also mixed. December delivery contracts fell 4.8 cents to $2.36 a 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: Filming in New York May Be Disrupted By a Labor Dispute

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
With the expiration last night of a contract between the major Hollywood film and television producers and a production crafts union, New York City is facing a slowdown in an industry that is a source not only of prestige but of badly needed jobs and revenue as well.
At stake is the continued employment of nearly 3,500 workers who toil on more than 100 New York film productions yearly, as well as the future of the city's third largest industry, behind tourism and fashion. Film and television production pumps more than $2.7 billion into the city's economy each year, according to the Mayor's Office for Film, Theater and Broadcasting. 
 "This is far from a typical labor situation where a factory shuts down, or the presses stop rolling," said Amy Sultan, the assistant director for film of the Mayor's Office.
The impact of the labor dispute is unclear thus far. "We're going into our slowest season here, from now to March, and we might not see the effects immediately," said Ms. Sultan. "But we'd begin to know for sure when films scripted for New York wound up shooting in Toronto."
 
The Union and Its People
 The producers have promised to steer films away from New York City until an agreement is reached with the union, Local 52 of the International Alliance of Theater Stage Employees and Moving Picture Machine Operators. It provides the sound people, electricians, shop craftsmen, prop people, camera grips, gaffers and set dressers for the city's film and television productions.
 Yesterday a new proposal for an agreement was presented to the producers by Local 52. There was no immediate response from the producers, and at the moment there are no plans for further negotiation or for a contract extension. "We are still at a bargaining impasse with 52," said Joel Grossman, the vice president of labor relations at Columbia Pictures and the producers' chief negotiator with the union.
 Another Manhattan-based local, representing 1,500 cinematographers, is also negotiating with the major producers. The producers' contract with the union, Local 644 of the International Photographers of the Motion Picture and Television Industries, expired on Sept. 30. The local's next session with the producers is scheduled for December.
"My people will continue to work while we're in negotiations, and we fully expect to be bargaining in good faith in December," said Lou D'Agostino, the business representative of Local 644, which has jurisdiction over the entire East Coast.
 
Embargo? Well, Not Exactly
 Until the dispute is resolved, the Hollywood producers have said, they will institute what amounts to an embargo on film production in New York, though they are not calling it that. "It's not an embargo, it's just a good business decision not to come to New York," said Nick Counter, the president of the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers in Los Angeles, which bargains for the major studios and television producers in Los Angeles.
In the current negotiation those parties include Columbia Pictures , the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation, Paramount Pictures , Warner Brothers , MGM/United Artists and Orion Pictures , which participates as a distributor.
The producers would avoid New York, Mr. Counter said, "because nobody will risk millions of dollars on a production without a contract, because the union has a legal right to strike at any time." He added, "I know of at least 10 pictures that have been rescheduled so they will not be in New York for the next three months."
He declined to give specifics about these productions. Jaynne Keyes, the director of the Mayor's Film Office, said that she had not been notified that any productions were pulling out of the city, and that six film productions were scouting locations for future movies in New York.
 
Willing to Keep Working
 Local 52 has promised producers its employees will work in good faith until a new contract can be agreed upon, said John Patrick Oates, the president and business manager of the 1,950-member Local 52. "We're not looking to put our people out of work," he said.
Mr. Oates said that currently eight productions were shooting in his union's jurisdiction, which includes New York City and Long Island.
Members of Local 52 and Local 644 staff most of the film and television productions shot in New York City. The International Alliance merged with the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians on Oct. 1, and any agreement would affect both unions.
Both unions are grappling with complex issues of parity between the New York film locals and the West Coast locals, which have different work rules involving overtime and weekend differential rates, as well as different financing for their health and pension benefits.
 
East vs. West
 The producers want to be able to employ the East Coast union members for a workweek consisting of five days of the producers' choosing, paying straight time for each eight hours worked in a day, and time-and-a-half for any overtime up to 14 hours. The West Coast locals agreed to these conditions last year, in return for some $40 million in payments into health and pension funds from the residual earnings of films from videocassette, cable television and network television sales.
The East Coast locals want to preserve their current work rules, which call for a five-day Monday-through-Friday workweek, with double time on Saturdays and Sundays, double time from 8 to 14 hours, and triple time for some night and weekend shooting. Mr. D'Agostino, the business representative for Local 644, said that the extra money earned in overtime was needed to equal the residual payments received by the West Coast local members.
 
New York's Crowded Weekdays <>
Mr. Counter, of the Producers' Alliance, said that its payments for pension and health funds were higher for East Coast union members than for those on the West Coast, and that the money from residuals was not a factor in the negotiations.
The crucial issue, Mr. Counter said, was that film makers often needed to shoot on weekends because of the congestion of weekday New York, and that the high cost of overtime reduced the number of film productions in the city.
If the producers cancel future productions in New York, the economic loss to the city "could be substantial depending on how long the disagreement goes on," said Ms. Sultan. Last year, there were 110 movies shot partly or totally in New York City.
 So far this year, all or part of 127 films have been shot in New York, "and economically we're running ahead of last year," Ms. Sultan said. "We had a lot of very big budget movies here this year, including 'Bonfire of the Vanities,' 'Hudson Hawk,' and 'Billy Bathgate.' "
 
A Written Promise
 The latter, a Touchstone Pictures film version of the E. L. Doctorow novel, is currently shooting in Manhattan. The film is being directed by Robert Benton and stars Dustin Hoffman, Bruce Willis, Nicole Kidman and Loren Dean.
Mr. Oates, of Local 52, said the film makers had been sent letters promising that the union would work despite the expiration of the contract.
"We've heard the majors are trying to relocate outside of New York City," said Mr. D'Agostino of Local 644. "But that's just the normal saber rattling in collective bargaining."
In the film industry, "it has not been unusual for contracts to expire and for people to work as long as two years while negotiations went on," said Ms. Sultan. "But perhaps the majors are not choosing to do that any longer."

HEADLINE: WASHINGTON TALK;
Moving to Slow the Revolving Door

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
From the "Great Barbecue" scandals of the Ad ministration of Ulysses S. Grant to Teapot Dome to vicuna coats, the United States has swung from long spasms of concern about corruption to equally long periods of complacency.
In an era of $1,500 toilet seats, a multibillion-dollar savings and loan bailout and anxiety about international competitiveness, the cycle has turned to reform, focused this time on the so-called revolving door. 
 The idea that political appointees to Government posts bring a leavening influence to the bureaucracy and a sense of political direction is seemingly unexceptional. The reformists argue that many appointees view Government as no more than a way station to the next job -- or, as Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., president of the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington policy-research group, put it, "are simply burnishing their credentials to make money."
There was concern, and even complaint, though not a reform rush, when domestic interests like Motorola hired senior officials from the White House, the Office of the United States Trade Representative and the International Trade Commission. But now, Japanese businesses have been hiring scores of American officials to promote commercial interests in Washington, and the reformers are in full cry.
"From my own experience," said Richard T. Imus, a former American economics minister in Bonn recently hired by Daimler Benz, "having someone who understands the U.S. and advises a company on things that let business get done without stresses and strains is advantageous for everyone, including the U.S."
 Still, reformers may be succeeding in slowing the door's revolutions.
One tool is the postemployment section of the Ethics Reform Act of 1989, chiefly sponsored by two House Democrats, Marcy Kaptur of Ohio and Howard Wolpe of Michigan. Aimed principally at trade negotiators, it goes into effect Jan 1. It will slow the revolutions of the revolving door by barring those people from lobbying for a year in areas of their government expertise. Sponsors are pressing new legislation to stretch the ban to four years.
"The mood here?" said one official at the Office of the United States Trade Representative. "I'd say it's more annoyance than anything else. This is the sort of legislation that punishes those who are serving now for the perceived sins of the past."
Yet for some like Don Ahrens, vice president of the AP Parts Company, making mufflers, pipes and shock absorbers in Toledo, Ohio, the sins of the past are egregious.
In preparing for a Commerce Department export trade mission in Japan, Mr. Ahrens shared proprietary information about his business with officials in charge of the mission.
"When I met with him later, he explained to me in dismay that after he returned to Washington to follow up on matters related to that mission, he discovered that the same people he had previously dealt with were now working on behalf of the very foreign interests that compete with his company," Ms. Kaptur recalled.
 Passing laws to cure a problem is typically American. Yet while reformers in this case talk about "changing the way business is done in Washington," many analysts believe a French expression may better sum up the likely results: "The more things change, the more they stay the same." (In France, by the way, former civil servants are barred for five years from contracts with companies they worked with as government employees. In Britain, Germany and Japan most civil servants serve until retirement.)
Allan J. Lichtman, a professor at American University, has studied past scandals as well as attempts at reform. Not surprisingly, he has found that, for the most part, "cures" did not work.
Laws of the 1970's were supposed to correct campaign financing abuses, but now the same abuses come through political action committees.
Sometimes reforms have adverse consequences, like personal voter registration and at-large elections of the Progressive era that are now deemed to keep minorities out of office.
Of the latest reforms, Mr. Lichtman predicted: "I don't think they'll work. They're like a Band-Aid."
