HEADLINE: Old Disease Emerges as a Factor in AIDS Spread

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
The man was a prototypical patron of Nairobi's crowded city clinic for sexually transmitted diseases. An unmarried worker 31 years old, he had had sexual relations with about 20 women in the last year, he said. No, he never used condoms. He said he believed a recent "pickup" gave him the painful genital infection that brought him in, an oozing sore the size of a dime.
As the doctor prescribed an antibiotic he also talked the man into giving blood for an AIDS test. For the man was prototypical in another sense, too: as a candidate for AIDS. Not only was he sexually active in a city where many prostitutes and bar girls carry the AIDS virus, he was also suffering from chancroid, a little-known disease that causes genital ulcers and is one of the most potent known promoters of the sexual spread of AIDS. 
 A scourge of troops in World War I, almost forgotten in Western countries as it fell to negligible levels there, chancroid has emerged as one of the chief villains of the global epidemic of acquired immune deficiency syndrome.
 
Major Factor in Afrian AIDS
 Chancroid (pronounced SHANG-kroid) spreads through sexual intercourse and is caused by the bacterium Hemophilus ducreyi. It is especially common in many African countries, where it has been a major factor in the lightning proliferation of AIDS. The World Health Organization estimates that at least five million Africans have been infected with the AIDS virus, in most cases through heterosexual intercourse.
In the United States, too, chancroid appears to be giving an extra nudge to the small but growing heterosexual spread of AIDS in inner cities. A new study of men visiting a sexually transmitted disease clinic in New York City found that those with chancroid were much more likely than those with other venereal diseases to become infected with the AIDS virus.
But chancroid is not common enough in the United States to be an accomplice in more than a small fraction of the country's AIDS infections, researchers say.
"Until recently nobody cared about chancroid," said Dr. Allan R. Ronald, who is chief of internal medicine at the University of Manitoba in Alberta, Canada, and helped run landmark studies of venereal diseases and AIDS in Nairobi. "It's not a chronic disease and it doesn't hurt babies.
"Some doctors even considered it a good thing," he said. "It brought in patients who could then be treated and counseled about other more dangerous sexually transmitted diseases."
 
'Vital to Attack Chancroid'
 But now, in view of the strong link to AIDS, "all would agree that it's vital to attack chancroid," Dr. Ronald said.
Beyond Africa, the disease is common in parts of Asia, including Thailand, where chancroid and rising AIDS cases among prostitutes suggest the ominous possibility of an African-style epidemic of AIDS. The incidence is relatively low in Latin America and in the industrialized world, said Dr. George P. Schmid, a chancroid expert at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta.
In the United States, chancroid peaked in the 1940's, was seldom seen in the 1970's, but then jumped back in the 1980's, with outbreaks in several cities causing a total of several thousand reported cases each year. Almost all the patients were black or Hispanic men who frequented female prostitutes; gay men have seldom been afflicted.
New York City has accounted for most of the American cases, with a recent high of 3,200 reported in 1988. In a development that has left officials totally mystified, the cases of chancroid in the city are now falling as abruptly as they rose, with around 1,600 cases projected for 1990, said Dr. John Miles of the New York City Health Department. The decline is all the more mysterious because it is occuring even as rising syphilis rates betray a failure of disease control programs.
 
Outbreaks in Other Cities
 Among other cities currently experiencing outbreaks of chancroid are Memphis, New Orleans, Dallas, Houston, Los Angeles, San Francisco, and several cities and towns in Florida, Dr. Schmid said.
Ordinarily the heterosexual spread of AIDS is difficult, especially from female to male. But genital ulcers, researchers believe, provide ready pathways in and out of the body for the AIDS virus, and they are teeming with the type of immune cells the virus invades.
Syphilis and herpes also cause genital ulcers and evidence indicates that these too can facilitate transmission of AIDS. Some studies have not found as powerful an effect as with chancroid, perhaps because the sores are not likely to fester as much. Other experts say there is no biological reason to think ulcers caused by chancroid are more dangerous than others.
 
Other Diseases Raise Risks
 Recent studies have found that nonulcerative sexual transmitted diseases like gonorrhea and chlamydia also increase the chances of AIDS transmission during sex, perhaps because of the inflammation they cause. While the effect may be weaker than with ulcers, from a public health viewpoint the news is alarming because these are by far the most common sexually transmitted diseases.
For an individual, though, chancroid is a far more powerful multiplier of the AIDS risk.
When a woman has a chancroid ulcer, her risk of receiving the AIDS virus from an infected man is increased threefold, Dr. Ronald estimated, based on data from several African countries. When a woman already has the AIDS virus and she also has chancroid, the AIDS risk to a male partner is increased at least fivefold from its normally slight level, he said.
Studies in Nairobi indicate that a man has more than 1 chance in 20 of contracting the AIDS virus in a single sexual encounter with a woman who is both infected with AIDS and has chancroid sores. This risk may be doubled again if the man is uncircumcized, since the area under the foreskin is especially prone to infections and microscopic lesions.
Chancroid, first described as a distinct disease in the mid-19th century, has traditionally thrived amid poverty and war. It is largely spread by prostitutes: in 19th century Europe, outbreaks were said to follow the path of traveling circuses and carnivals.
Chancroid afflicts far more men than women. This apparently results from the different ways its symptoms emerge.
Although women develop several small genital ulcers, and some suffer discomfort, many women do not realize they have chancroid. Antibiotics can cure the disease; left untreated, it lasts for at least several weeks and is presumably infectious all the while.
In a common pattern, researchers say, a prostitute, who is either unaware of her ulcers or who from economic necessity or drug addiction overlooks the pain, spreads chancroid to large numbers of men.
Men with the disease develop one or more festering sores on the penis, usually within a week. They do not fail to notice it.
"I don't think there is such a thing as a male silent carrier," said Dr. Schmid. "Men by and large cease sexual activity and get treated."
 
Sores Prove Virus Entry
 A woman with chancroid ulcers is more vulnerable to AIDS because the sores provide a ready entry for the virus. But evidence suggests that the disease increases female-to-male transmission of the AIDS virus, HIV, through a different pattern.
"We think men are getting HIV and chancroid at the same time," said Dr. Francis A. Plummer, a colleague of Dr. Ronald's who has conducted venereal disease studies at the University of Nairobi for many years.
According to the theory, a woman who has both genital sores and HIV has vastly higher quantities of the virus in her genital tract than normal. This multiplies the danger for a man who has even a microscopic break in the skin of the penis.
The risk is apparently substantial. In a research project at the Nairobi city clinic, Dr. Mark Tyndall, another Canadian researcher at the University of Nairobi, followed men who came in with genital ulcers, largely chancroid, but did not have antibodies to the AIDS virus in their blood. During followup periods ranging from only 4 to 12 weeks, 6 percent of the patients developed AIDS antibodies.
Because it takes weeks or months for antibodies to develop after infection with the AIDS virus, the findings strongly suggest that many men are picking up chancroid and AIDS simultaneously, Dr. Tyndall said.
 
Some Confirming Evidence
 New research in New York City led by Dr. Edward E. Telzak of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center has pointed toward the same conclusions. Men who sought treatment at a South Bronx venereal disease clinic, did not have AIDS antibodies and were not intravenous drug users, were followed for at least three months.
Two percent of the men overall developed AIDS antibodies during the study period but 5 percent of those who had come in with chancroid did. Again, evidence suggested that men often became infected with chancroid and AIDS in the same sexual encounter.
Because chancroid is such a visible disease, among men, at least, with most patients actively seeking treatment, it should be susceptible to eradication. But for women, one of the greatest needs is to teach them to be aware of chancroid symptoms and seek immediate care, doctors say. In poor countries, an impediment is the high cost of effective drugs; the bacterium has become resistant to many inexpensive antibiotics.
"Chancroid could be eradicated and its role in the AIDS epidemic be removed," Dr. Ronald said. But it is not clear just how much difference renewed control programs would make in the United States.
"Certainly a lot of AIDS transmission occurs in the absence of any sexually transmitted disease," said Dr. Mary Ann Chiasson of the New York City Health Department, a co-author of the Bronx study. "The most important thing still has to be changing behavior."

HEADLINE: A West Coast Composer Looks to the Far East

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

 BODY:
The California composer Lou Harrison, whose "Last Symphony" will receive its first performance tomorrow night as part of a three-concert Brooklyn Philharmonic/Next Wave event at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, had his links at one time to New York. He lived here in the 1940's, composing and organizing concerts and even writing music criticism for The New York Herald-Tribune when Virgil Thomson was that paper's chief critic.
 But by now, the Oregon-born Mr. Harrison is about as far removed from the stereotype of the tough-guy New York composer, with maximally dissonant music and bristling polemics obbligato, as one could possibly imagine. He looks for inspiration not to Europe (which he puckishly calls "northwest Asia") but to the Orient. He wears informal Western dress, is a determined internationalist (fluent in Esperanto) and pacifist, and composes in an eclectic, tuneful style far removed from the knotty complexity that has defined New York avant-garde music in recent decades.
 
 The diversity of Mr. Harrison's musical and biographical experiences is something far removed from a more conventional, career-track kind of composer. Having studied in California with Henry Cowell and Arnold Schoenberg, he organized concerts with John Cage and worked as a florist, record clerk, poet, dancer, dance critic, music copyist and playwright.
 In New York, aside from his composing and music criticism, he edited scores and prepared many editions of the music of Charles Ives, whose manuscripts were in a notoriously chaotic state. Settling in Aptos, Calif., near Santa Cruz, where he still lives, he composed, worked in an animal hospital, taught and lectured. He also made trips to every corner of the Orient.
 
A Gamelan Proponent
 His two main concerns, which are interrelated, have been Javanese gamelan music and pitch relations, meaning the study of arrangements of the scale purer than the compromises built into the Western equal-tempered system. He and the man he calls his life companion, William Colvig, have constructed several Indonesian gong orchestras, and the "Last Symphony" uses three such instruments, one of them built by Mr. Colvig. By now, Mr. Harrison counts as the father of the American gamelan movement, which comprises some 200 ensembles, half in California alone, playing both Indonesian and contemporary repertory.
 At 73 years of age, and with a recent history of diabetes and heart trouble, Mr. Harrison might seem to have entitled this "Last Symphony," his fourth, with gloomy premonitions. In fact, he sounds positively cheerful, remarking in his program notes that "should I ever write another, I can call it 'Very Last Symphony.' "
 Aside from his generally bucolic nature, Mr. Harrison has reason to be cheerful. His doctors now wonder whether his diabetes diagnosis was really something milder, and he has had successful triple bypass surgery to relieve his heart problems.
 "I can run around like a kid again," he said the other day. "This is my third life, sort of. I had what they call a nervous breakdown in New York, and it took 10 years to recover from that.
 "Now, when I finish my last couple of commissions, I want to retire a little bit. For one thing, I'm going to get a power parachute, which is like an ultra-light aircraft. You don't need a license, and you can fly as high as 7,500 feet. And I have just bought a motor home, or what the State of California charmingly calls a house-car. Among other places, I want to go back to the Four Corners area."
 Not that Mr. Harrison plans to abandon composition. Having retired from teaching three years ago -- at San Jose State University and at Mills College in Oakland -- he accepted a number of commissions to fill the income gap. Now that his health has improved and his finances are more secure, he wants to return to what he's done all his life -- to explore music in all its ramifications, without pressure from economic imperatives.
 His fascination with all manner of Oriental musics, and his eagerness to explore in his compositions what he has learned from Oriental cultures, has led to the charge of pastiche, but he rejects it.
 "When I get interested in another kind of music," he said, "I actually study that music and learn to play it and comprehend it as closely as possible, as the people of that culture do from the beginning. I am now a practiced gamelan player, and know a lot of the repertoire. The opening movement of the 'Last Symphony' is almost entirely done in Javanese procedures. It's the procedures that interest me. I don't try to imitate."
 The score, dedicated "with love and astonishment" to the conductor Dennis Russell Davies, with the final Stampede movement "offered" to Mr. Colvig, is in the conventional four movements, although Mr. Harrison makes no pretense at following sonata-allegro form.
 
'Something Old and Something New'
 "For me a symphony is a large, serious work," he said. "One of the movements is a suite. My rationalization there is that the minuet-trio movement of the traditional symphony is a small suite already. In this instance I found I wanted to set some Coyote songs" (American Indian legends). "They were originally intended for gamelan," he said. "All of my big pieces have something old and something new. They're like marriages."
 Although parts of this score are written in what Mr. Harrison calls "my chromatic and dissonant style," which Mr. Davies particularly admires, it seems unlikely to win over East Coast hardliners who dismiss his music as too simple to be taken seriously. Which bothers Mr. Harrison not a bit.
 "I laid out my toys on a large acreage when I was young, and I've played with them all ever since," he said of his varied stylistic procedures. "The most important statement about that came from Ives. He set up a system of balances between styles, so I do that, too. Material gets transformed by what's on either side of it. I wonder if it's really eclecticism at all; it's more a narrative experience.
 "The notion that you have to get more and more dissonant is ridiculous," Mr. Harrison added. "I don't think increasing complexity is the answer to anything. In California and in the West generally, we're not afraid if a thing sounds pretty, and we're not out to terrorize everybody. I don't think significance is opposed to beauty."

HEADLINE: Consumer Spending Jumps 1.1%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Consumer spending jumped 1.1 percent in September, the Government said today, outpacing a five-tenths of 1 percent growth in personal income and contributing to the lowest savings rate in three years.
The Commerce Department report "shows consumer purchasing power obviously is under intense pressure in the aftermath of the oil shock" from the Persian Gulf situation, said Stephen S. Roach, senior economist with Morgan Staney & Company. 
 Nevertheless, Mr. Roach added, "consumers are really sort of clinging tenaciously to their life styles."
"Their spending is holding up just fine," he said.
 
Waning Confidence
 The Federal Reserve reported separately today, however, that the confidence of consumers and businesses was waning in many regions of the country because of "greater uncertainty and higher fuel prices." Every one of the central bank's 12 districts was reporting either slower growth or an actual decline in economic activity.
The Commerce Department said that the incomes of Americans reached a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.7 trillion in September, a $23.8 billion increase over August.
At the same time, it said spending reached a rate of $3.73 trillion, up $39.9 billion from a month earlier. It was the biggest increase since a 1.2 percent gain last June.
In its report on the third-quarter gross national product on Tuesday, the department had said consumer spending from July through September rose 3.6 percent, well above the two-tenths of 1 percent advance from April through June.
But Mr. Roach of Morgan Stanley said he expected spending would drop to "the 1 percent vicinity" during the current quarter.
"There's no way we'll be able to hold up" the 3.6 percent pace, he said, "in the weak income and low savings environment."
 
Decline in Growth
 Consumer spending represents about two-thirds of United States economic activity, and Mr. Roach said a lower level of consumption this quarter would mean a temporary decline in overall economic growth.
But he said his company was not projecting a recession, which is defined as two consecutive quarters of declining gross national product, the total output of the nation's goods and services.
The Commerce Department report said the rate of Americans' savings as a percent of disposable income fell to 3.5 percent, down from 4.1 percent in August and the lowest since a 3.3 percent rate in October 1987.
The report said Americans' income after taxes increased by four-tenths of 1 percent, up from a two-tenths of 1 percent gain in August.
 
Adjusting for Inflation
 The spending and income figures were not adjusted for inflation. When adjusted, spending rose three-tenths of 1 percent, after declining one-tenth of 1 percent in August. Disposable, or after-tax, income fell three-tenths of 1 percent, compared with a five-tenths of 1 percent drop the previous month.
A key component of the income category -- wages and salaries -- rose $17.4 billion, up from $600 million the previous month.
The $39.9 billion increase in personal consumption, which includes all types of consumer spending except interest payments on debt, was up from a $20.1 billion gain in August.
Spending on durable goods -- relavitely expensive items expected to last more than three years -- totaled $487 billion, up from $477 billion from August.
Spending on nondurable goods rose $11 billion, to $1.2 trillion, following a $10.6 billion gain in August. Spending on services was up $18.2 billion, to $2 trillion, after a gain of $18.2 billion the previous month.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Big Figure For Phils' .268 Hitter

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
If anyone thought this year's free-agent market would be less lucrative than last year's economic explosion, the contract that Darren Daulton and the Philadelphia Phillies agreed to yesterday should signal otherwise.
On a day when two longtime stars, George Bell and Fernando Valenzuela, became free agents, Daulton, a free agent with one decent season in the major leagues, gained a three-year contract worth $6.75 million. 
 It matched the most lucrative contract, based on annual average, ever given a catcher. Lance Parrish signed the exact same contract with California last December: a $500,000 signing bonus and salaries of $1.75 million the first year and $2.25 million each of the last two years. When Tony Pena signed with the Boston Red Sox as a free agent a year ago, he got $6.4 million for three years.
This year, Daulton earned $470,000, $425,000 in salary and $45,000 in bonuses based on plate appearances. Twenty-four catchers earned more money.
Players and agents entered this off-season period of free agency with some anxiety. After last year's cascade of $3 million salaries, they didn't know what to expect this year. They had heard owners and general managers say that money would not be as bountiful because of the pending penalty for three years of collusion against free agents. That penalty could reach, or even exceed, $10 million per club.
Those waiting for an answer to the anxiety didn't have to wait long. With four days still remaining in the free-agent filing period, the Phillies opted to re-sign Daulton, and for big money.
"My feeling was that was the marketplace," Bill Giles, the Phillies' managing partner, said. "My people feel he is probably the best catcher in the National League now, except maybe for Santiago, after what he did this year. Parrish got the same and Pena got almost the same. We didn't want to take a chance on anybody offering more and then us having to pay more."
Daulton, who is two months short of his 29th birthday, entered this past season with a .206 batting average for five years in the major leagues. Injuries, especially a torn knee ligament in 1986, hampered him during those years.
This year the left-handed-hitting catcher established career highs with a .268 average, 12 home runs, 57 runs batted in, 143 games played and 540 plate appearances.
"Everything came together at the right time obviously," Arn Tellem, Daulton's agent, said.
Giles said that negotiations with Tellem began about a week before the end of the season and continued through the filing period. From the time a player files for free agency until next Monday, only the team with which he finished the season can negotiate with and sign him. Beginning Monday, all clubs may sign any free agent.
 
Valenzuela Looking
 Valenzuela, a starting pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers for 10 years, made himself available to everybody. There appeared to be a strong chance that he would not return to Los Angeles, where he had become a celebrated hero with the Mexican-American community.
If Valenzuela, who had a 13-13 record this year, does move on, he may not have to stray far, either in geography or competition. He could move slightly south to San Diego, where the Padres need a starting pitcher and where he could also have a large following among Mexican-Americans.
Bell has been a major part of Toronto's perenially contending teams for seven seasons. He faltered this year, though, plunging to career lows with a .265 average and 86 runs batted in.
Also filing for free agency yesterday were Ron Oester of Cincinnati and Sid Bream and Ted Power of Pittsburgh.
Greg Harris, who could have become a free agent, agreed with the Red Sox on a two-year, $2.8 million contract.
 
Joint Meetings Called Off
 Because negotiators for the major leagues and the minor leagues could not reach agreement by yesterday on a new player development contract, the two organizations will not hold their annual joint meetings in Los Angeles in the first week of December.
The National Association, the umbrella organization for the minors, plans to meet in Los Angeles as scheduled, but the major leagues will go elsewhere, perhaps Chicago or Dallas.
If no agreement is reached by Nov. 15, the majors will proceed with alternative plans for their minor league teams for 1991.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Darren Daulton of the Phillies, who yesterday signed a three-year contract worth $6.75 million. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: PRO HOCKEY: NOTEBOOK;
Blues' Star Is Looking Like a Million

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 31

 BODY:
With his game-winning goal Tuesday night in Detroit, Brett Hull of St. Louis has scored 15 times in the first 12 games of the season. That pace over the 80-game schedule would give him 100; the record is 92, set by Wayne Gretzky in 1981-82.
"I'm not going to talk about that," Hull said of his record pace. "It's 12 games into the season." 
 After leading the league with 72 goals last season and signing a new contract for more than $1 million a season, was Hull worried about a slow start?
"I was scared to death," Hull said, adding that he was deadly serious about his fears. Perhaps people would have said he is overpaid and complacent.
Hull said he is annoyed by negative publicity about how his salary is causing inflation for the rest of the league.
"I've never seen a business that doesn't win without spending money," he said. "There are so many great players who haven't been getting the money they deserve for so long it is scary."
When someone joked that, in view of his torrid start, he might be underpaid, Hull replied with a smile, "I'm not going to renegotiate."
 
Inquiry Into Bruin Victory
 Brian O'Neill, executive vice president of the N.H.L., viewed videotape in Boston yesterday with off-ice officials who work Bruins' home games in Boston Garden.
O'Neill is investigating events at the end of Saturday night's 5-4 victory by the Bruins. During the last minute of play, it appeared to many at the game that Chicago had tied the score.
But the goal light didn't go on and, some insist, the last seconds were allowed to tick off the clock after play stopped.
"The integrity of the game was jeopardized," said Mike Keenan, coach and general manager of the Blackhawks, who was restrained after the game when he tried to confront the off-ice officials.
"Why did the goal judge not put the light on? Why did the timekeeper continue to let the clock run out when the referee signaled a goal with three seconds left on the clock? Why did the referee not confer with the goal judge? Why did the referee not confer with the timekeeper until he had already made his decision? How can five people in this particular case make a mistake? This is not a witch hunt. It has to do with the integrity of the game."
Keenan said he has videotape that shows the puck in the net with time left on the clock. He said referees should use such videotape to settle such disputes.
After the game, Keenan charged that off-ice officials are hired by Harry Sinden, general manager of the Bruins, and should be dismissed. Sinden said today that the league hires them after the home team recommends them. Sinden also conceded, "Obviously, somebody erred."
 
Tour of Expansion Sites
 An N.H.L. subcommittee on expansion is scheduled to tour three cities in Florida on Thursday. Mike Ilitch, owner of the Detroit Red Wings, Marcel Aubut, owner of the Quebec Nordiques, and Gilbert Stein, the league's general counsel, will visit Tampa, St. Petersburg and Miami.
The N.H.L. has said it hopes to name at least two more expansion cities when its governors meet during the first week in December. Godfrey Wood, a Harvard goalie in the early 1960's, said he was optimistic that his Miami group would be chosen.
"Very much so," he said. "We've got a great market, a strong ownership group, a good facility. In terms of what the league needs -- major markets to expand into where they can build on their TV contract -- Miami and South Florida is the sixth-largest market in the country."
On the negative side, Wood said he could not yet reveal the names of investors who would put up the $50 million entry fee. Although ice conditions were terrible for an exhibition game there in September, Wood said those problems can be corrected easily. Although the potential team has a new building in which to play, it would have to share it with the Miami Heat of the National Basketball Association.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK CITY MARATHON;
Runners Have No Fear Before Hitting the Streets

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
More than 25,000 runners, a record, are expected to start the 21st New York City Marathon on Sunday. Nearly 24,000 others wanted to but were rejected for logistical reasons. That's a record, too. If New York's crime, urban squalor, high prices and economic decay have made headlines around the world, marathon runners from beyond the metropolitan area do not seem overly concerned. Maybe they have been too busy training.
"It doesn't matter," Robert Reekie, a 52-year-old civil servant from Fife, Scotland, said yesterday, as his wife, Linda, and daughter, Lynn, waited in line to register for the race. "We have always wanted to visit America; we have never been here before. Oh, we were warned about what to do in the subways and to watch our money. We also heard about all the rude people, rude policemen and rude taxi drivers. But so far, we haven't found any of them." 
 Hundreds of runners lined West 52d Street at the Sheraton Centre hotel, clutching the precious cards that identified them as entrants, all looking so eager for the race. If anything assuaged their fears about New York, it was the chance to join the spectacle of the world's most populous marathon, which this year has attracted more than 9,300 runners from 80 foreign countries and about 6,600 Americans from outside New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
 
It's Her Dream
 "It has been a dream of mine to run New York," said Dawn Balletto, a 24-year-old real estate saleswoman from Greentown, Pa., who has never run a marathon. "Everybody told me I was crazy to come to New York. One friend wished me luck and asked me if I had any Mace. I just laughed. My dream outweighs everything."
Most runners interviewed acknowledged an awareness of the problems of New York, including some of the more celebrated recent tragedies like the brutal attack on a female jogger in Central Park in April 1989 and the stabbing death of a tennis fan from Utah who was here with his family attending the United States Open in September.
But only a few of the out-of-towners expressed anything close to concern.
 
'It's Different'
David Collins, a 31-year-old first-time marathoner, grew up in New Jersey and moved to California 17 years ago. He lives in Novato, a town in the wine country north of San Francisco and only began to realize how different New York had become riding into Manhattan earlier this week.
"It's different," he said. "A guy came up to the window of the limo, asking the driver for money. Another guy wanted to wash the windows and tried to smash the windshield when the driver said no. The event itself, though, should be real safe. Racing has always been a safe atmosphere."
"I'm sure it's much the same here as in London," said Mike Swallow, a 48-year-old gymnastics coach from England on his first trip to the United States, which he built around his participation in the marathon. "Some people are frightened to go to Northern Ireland because of bombs and the I.R.A., and all that. For me, fear wasn't a factor at all. I've never been outside of England except for sport. I've been all over Eastern Europe, Africa, and I never thought twice about any of that."
Besides, all locales have their problems, even such a majestic spot as Banff, a resort town of 8,000 permanent residents in the Canadian province of Alberta. Jim Bennett is the town manager, a 49-year-old first-time marathoner, who by virtue of his job is well aware of the effects of negative publicity.
"Crime is receiving a higher profile right now," he said of New York. "But all cities have a certain crime rate. Ours is higher than the crime rate of most other towns our size. But New York's wasn't sufficient enough to dissuade me from running. My wife, I'm sure she would probably give you a different opinion. I would have to say that she was a little concerned. But I feel the positive things here still outweigh the problems."
Fred Lebow, the president of the New York Road Runners Club, which organizes the marathon, said he could recall no incident that marred any of the 20 previous marathons, although there had been occasional moments of alarm.
"I remember before the first marathon, in 1970, Gary Muhrcke told me, 'Fred, I'm a fireman, and you're flirting with disaster,' " Lebow said. "I remember being a little scared, too, but I was not going to let him get that feeling." The cause for concern had been threats by members of several gangs, suggesting that the marathon was trespassing on their "turf," as Lebow recalled.
"They had come to me, and they looked kind of threatening," Lebow said, amazed at their audacity. The marathon was little more than a cult event back then, with 127 starters and Muhrcke leading 55 finishers. "So I got an idea. I said, 'You know, I need some marshals in that area, and I'll give you T-shirts if you marshal the area.' They thought it was a good idea, so they got out there that day. The only trouble was, the area they guarded had no spectators."

HEADLINE: So Long, Faux: New Materials Woo Designers

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

 BODY:
WE are (thank you, Madonna) living in a material world -- materials like dichroic glass and hand-woven bauxite.
Contemporary designers are engaged in an exploration of ever-more technologically advanced stuff: from chameleonic glass that changes color to paints that shimmer differently from every vantage point. 
 This material world, and how architects and designers are responding to it, is the subject of "Mondo Materialis," an exhibition on view through February at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street in Manhattan. Organized by the Steelcase Design Partnership , an office furniture company, the show offers more than 100 collages executed in varying degrees of artiness by leading architects and designers. The curators of the show were Jeffrey J. Osborne, a design consultant, and George M. Beylerian, a vice president of Steelcase.
The participants were asked to create collages using materials they believed would be "relevant and inspirational" in their work in the next five years. Neoprene sheeting, anyone?
As their written statements suggest, texture and surface may be to the 90's what color and form were to the 80's. So long, faux; recent infatuations may be giving way to a new preoccupation with unadorned natural materials and some bizarre synthetic ones.
If these designers have their way, new high-tech wonders like Varilite Vision Panels , which change from clear to frosted with the switch of an electric current, may be wedded with humble materials like plastic laminate and particleboard. Luxurious materials like onyx, marble and granite may be replaced by raw steel, plastic, concrete and ceramics.
In today's tight economy, Mr. Osborne said, "People want inexpensive materials that look rich."
"Mondo Materialis" reveals a brave new world. According to Mr. Osborne, the slightly schizophrenic collages (one of them brings together black foal skin and rubber flooring) represent the coming together of the modernist love of new forms and materials with the post-modern interest in ornament.
"We're in a period of testing alternatives," said David Revere McFadden, the decorative arts curator of the Cooper-Hewitt. "Designers are intrigued by the sensuous qualities of surfaces."
Intriguing is certainly the word to describe the plastic hedge used by Casson Mann, a London design firm, and the wriggly purple plastic fishing worms by Lisa Krohn and Martha Davis of New York. In its collage, Larson Associates of Chicago combined bird's-eye maple, woven leather, corrugated fiberglass and hand-woven bauxite.
Though some of the mixtures of material seem right (Rosenberg/ Kolb's bringing together of flagstone, birch bark, crackle glass and iridescent glass), a few play rather heavily on liberal guilt (Nob & Non's panel depicting Earth as the "universal material").
There is a growing awareness that some materials are ecologically off-limits. Exotic woods are becoming the fur coats of design; synthetics seem destined for new respectability.
"The environment," said the designer Adam Tihany, in a rather dark premonition, "will force us to spend time finding ways to preserve, store and imitate the glorious materials of the past."
But theory and collages are one thing; how materials are applied in the real world is quite another. While "Mondo Materialis" only hints at future applications, the show's participants are already engaged in explorations of these materials.
Among the most promising are dichroic glass, which is coated with a special film and transmits a color while reflecting the color's complement; Electroluminescent Lamp , a plastic sheet that glows white with an electrical charge, and Syndecrete, a "high-tech material with a low-tech esthetic," according to its inventor, David Hertz, an architect. Syndecrete, made by Syndesis of Santa Monica, Calif., is half the weight of concrete but can be shaped, cut and sanded like wood.
The "new tactility," as some call it, addresses a hunger for the tangible and sensual aspects of design. Metals, are now being exploited for their craftsmanlike, rather than high-tech, qualities. To achieve new textures, Eric Chan, a product designer in Manhattan who is best known for his rubber phone designs, is experimenting with mixing plastics with sand and even hair. The furniture design firm of Godley-Schwan of Brooklyn is emphasizing raw woods and metals with no paint.
"The 80's were a little cool, with interiors that didn't seem to have much to do with the people who lived in them," said Lynn Godley, a partner in the firm. "Using materials in their natural state strengthens the connection between people and their objects."
In a showroom for Esprit, the clothing company, Michael Vanderbyl, a designer in San Francisco, covered the floor in black Astroturf. The bristly black floor was "familiar but strange at the same time," he said. Mr. Vanderbyl also likes the "rawness" of colored cinderblock and strand board, the rather ugly subflooring material that looks like big wood chips suspended in plastic.
Economic realities, he said, are furthering the drift toward unpretentious materials. "The budgets to do terrazzo and large marble entryways are drying up," he said.
Many designers are elevating common materials, an approach popularized by the Los Angeles architect Frank Gehry. Around a fireplace in a recently completed house in Marina Del Rey, Calif., Frederick Fisher, a Santa Monica architect, used concrete block and Spectraglaze, a colorful glazed concrete block made by Burns & Russell of Baltimore. He chose these materials for their "layered, fragmented" feeling, he said.
Others are looking to new technology for cues. Nicholas Goldsmith of FTL Associates, a New York architectural firm, uses the shiny stretch fabric associated with wet-look ski clothing to help illuminate walls. Bran Ferren of Associates & Ferren in Wainscott, L.I., is experimenting with electrochromic glass, an electrified glass, akin to liquid crystals, that can be "red in the morning and green in the afternoon," he said.
To Kevin Walz, a New York designer, part of the designers' responsibility in an era of limited resources is to redefine the public perception of which materials constitute quality. The adventurous Mr. Walz once used sandpaper as decorative wallpaper.
"It's time to give up the idea that the only idea of quality is what was done in English libraries a hundred years ago," he said.
This is not to say that granite and Carrara marble will become passe. But, as the New York architect Lee H. Skolnick points out, part of the designer's role is "coming to terms with what's out there."
For Mr. Skolnick, this includes corrugated fiberglass, used to make desks and platforms; steel mesh, recently chosen to cover a ceiling of a Long Island art gallery, and generous use of concrete, stucco, plastics and simple grades of wood.
In a new house for Suzanne Farver and George Berky in Aspen, Colo., the architect Harry Teague sheathed the entire structure in simple rusted corrugated steel. The house, on the site of an old ranch, is designed to recall weathered mining cabins. Time, and Aspen's semi-arid climate, will only enhance its quality, he said.
Many of the Cooper-Hewitt collages suggest that designers are preoccupied with recyclable materials. In prototype tabletop objects, Constantine Boym, a New York designer, explores the visual appeal of a new material that combines recycled plastic and sawdust.
And in what may become the most useful new material of the decade, Arthur Apissomian, a designer in Wadena, Minn., recently invented Permaprose, a plywoodlike material derived from recycled design magazines.

Rusted corrugated steel figures prominently in Harry Teague's collage, above, and a new house he designed in Aspen, Colo., at left. (pg. C12)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Kollmorgen Lowers Estimates

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: SIMSBURY, Conn., Oct. 31

 BODY:
The Kollmorgen Corporation said it had lowered its estimates of earnings for 1990 and 1991 because of the costs of closing its motor operations in Sierra Vista, Ariz.; a $2 million settlement with the Vernitron Corporation over a terminated merger deal, and the current economic slowdown. The company said it now expects 1990 after-tax earnings from continuing operations of $6.5 million to $7 million.
Earlier, the company reported nine-month earnings from continuing operations of almost $4.1 million. The company's stock price rose 75 cents today, to $6.875, on the New York Stock Exchange, where its 12.2 percent rise was the fourth best of the day.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
The Second Front

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
What European member of NATO has the largest standing army? What NATO nation borders on Iraq?
The answer to both: Turkey. That nation of 55 million people has armed forces, including gendarmerie, of 750,000; Iraq, by contrast, has a population base of 13 million, not counting its persecuted Kurds, and an army of 550,000 (three-fourths now in Kuwait) with reserves of another half-million. 
 Saddam Hussein, contemplating the next phase of his war against the world, is willing to gamble that he could endure sustained bombardment from the air; and he hopes to bog down the combined Western-Arab armies moving up from the south into Kuwait -- at least long enough to let cries of compromise rise in the West.
But what if there were a second front? That's what defeated Adolf Hitler. Turkey lies to the north, its fighting men proud of their reputation for being what Douglas MacArthur in Korea called "the bravest of the brave."
The Turks, with 15 percent of their forces now on Iraq's border, have not been friendly to Saddam Hussein. When the world looked away, Turkey took in 100,000 Kurdish refugees from Iraqi poison-gas attacks. Turkey was the first nation in the region to denounce the invasion of Kuwait, first to support U.N. sanctions and first to make the blockade count by shutting down Iraq's pipeline.
When James Baker travels to the region next week (why do we send a professional deal-cutter on a mission to avoid cutting a deal?) his most important stop will be in Ankara.
President Turgut Ozal has already welcomed U.S. F-111 bombers and F-16 fighters to his Incirlik Air Base; as the front-line state in the world squeeze on Iraq, he expects reimbursement from the Saudi-Kuwaiti war kitty of $7 billion for one year's loss of trade.
Turkey deserves that, as well as consideration of Mr. Ozal's request, made in the White House last month, for financing and sale of 120 F-16's to give some punch to Turkey's antiquated air force.
That lack of sophisticated weaponry -- many of its tanks are Korean War vintage -- has caused some U.S. strategists to downmouth Turkey's capacity to become a second front. They say President Ozal is not too popular at home, and claim that Turkish generals -- who do not control him -- are wary of displaying technological weakness in combat.
This overlooks Turkish concern with having a messianic nuclear aggressor to its south. It completely misses what the historian Thomas Kuhn called a "paradigm shift" in explaining the force of scientific change. When the model of perception shifts, amazing inventive changes take place all along the line.
Turkey's paradigm was the "bulwark blocking access to the Mediterranean by the Soviet Black Sea Fleet," and its border with the Soviet Union made it a front-line state in any attack on NATO by the Warsaw Pact. After the fall of Iran's Shah, it became our intelligence window on the East.
That concept of Turkey's role bought it a ticket to Western defenses and markets, even though Europeans treated Turks with cultural scorn.
But the old model of Turkey's place in the world is obviously crumbling. Turkish workers are being kicked out of Germany and Bulgaria; the European Community is closing its doors. What's to replace the old paradigm? With the Russians not coming, who needs the Turks?
Their future is in their other front line: not the one bordering the implosive Soviet Union and Asia Minor, but the one bordering explosive Iraq and the Middle East.
Turkey is Muslim but secular, a developing democracy with women emancipated; a free-market economy, and a friend to both Palestinians and Israelis. Despite its unproductive enmity with Greece, Turkey could be a bridge between West and Middle East. That's where the world will need the Turks.
In this new light, rethink the military possibilities. With allied aircraft using Turkey's airfields to provide tactical support, Turkish infantrymen driving on Baghdad would be more than a match for the divided Iraqi Army, its most modern elements trapped in Kuwait.
When the war begun on Aug. 2 is over, new boundaries will be drawn, as usual, to penalize the aggressor. Oil reserves should be shared among an independent Kurdistan, a helpful Turkey, a free Iraq and those nations that sacrificed most.

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 521 words

HEADLINE: How to Rattle Iraq

 BODY:
President Bush is clearly seeking ways to put new pressure on Saddam Hussein. But he's floundering. He warns Iraq that he's prepared to attack, and snarls at mistreatment of American hostages. In the next breath, he tells Congress that U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf are in no imminent danger of war. He can't have it both ways and still send a credible message.
There's a better way: Invite Congress to debate the tough question of what happens if his present strategy of economic sanctions and military buildup fails to move Iraq. Mr. Bush has been reluctant to do that. Instead he hints at going to war on his own authority. He thus misses a chance to rally Americans behind his strategy and truly show Iraq that America intends to stay the course. 
 Why debate the possibility of war at all, especially if such a debate reveals serious disagreements, and thus risk increasing Saddam Hussein's intransigence? One reason is that for the President not to take the people into his confidence now invites recrimination later if war in fact occurs and casualties mount.
And the other side of the coin is even more urgent. To move Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait without a war, Mr. Bush needs both economic sanctions and a credible threat of war. To make it credible, he has to convince Iraq that the American people back him all the way.
Some people suggest that one way to begin the discussion would be for either Mr. Bush or Congress to invoke the War Powers Act. The act allows the President to dispatch troops abroad but requires that they be withdrawn within 60 days unless Congress votes for them to remain. Mr. Bush has shied away from invoking the act, contending that U.S. troops are in no imminent danger of hostilities. Closing its eyes, Congress accepted his claim, and then authorized him to call up reserves for 360 days without declaring a state of emergency.
Mr. Bush seems intent on going it alone. "History is replete with examples where the President has to take action," he said Monday.
He'd do well to reflect further on precisely those examples. Harry Truman, fearing a partisan debate over Korea, avoided Congress and went to the U.N. instead. That cost him popular support. Lyndon Johnson, instead of debating his Vietnam strategy openly, escalated by stealth. That undid his Presidency. And Richard Nixon made war on Cambodia without telling Congress. That alienated even some of his own partisans.
Presidents pay when they don't come clean with Congress. And there are other ways for Mr. Bush to do so short of the War Powers Act or a declaration of war. Congress could reconvene after the election and hold hearings on his gulf strategy. And the President could seek a joint resolution endorsing that strategy.
Whatever the method, the President and Congress have a duty to discuss and explain the circumstances under which they might take America to war, their reasons for doing so and the ends for which the war would be waged. The better the explanation of the policy, the more the public will support it. The more the public supports it, the less likely war becomes.

HEADLINE: No Time to Give Raises to City Workers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 While I agree with "Mr. Dinkins Faces Fiscal Reality" (editorial, Oct. 18), it does not go far enough.
We are in a recession heading toward a depression, and under these circumstances there should be no increases in salaries for government employees because every increase to a substantial number of workers will result in layoffs of other employees. 
 The difficulties Federal, state and municipal governments are having in formulating budgets that retain needed services make it evident that the income shortfall cannot be ignored.
Walk around New York City and see the ever-increasing number of vacant stores and offices in desirable locations. Look at the increasing number of employees at prestigious businesses laid off daily. Take note of the billions of dollars that will never be repaid that foreign governments owe our most important commercial banks. Observe the huge individual and government debt that cannot be liquidated in the foreseeable future.
The agreement with the United Federation of Teachers should be rescinded before it is put into effect. Although the teachers' union makes a valid argument that teachers of comparable skills and experience in the suburbs earn considerably more than those in New York City, it is questionable how long this situation will last.
Increasing numbers of taxpayers in Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester counties earn their livelihood in New York City, and it is not far to see that the economic recession in New York City will catch up with many of them.
There is no justification to increase wages of municipal employees, while firing their fellow employees to meet those costs.
 
HARRIS L. PRESENT
New York, Oct. 18, 1990

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Harvard Economist To Join World Bank

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

 BODY:
Lawrence H. Summers, a Harvard professor and Keynesian economist who specializes in tax, labor and financial issues and who served as Michael S. Dukakis's chief economic adviser during his 1988 Presidential bid, is joining the World Bank as vice president and chief economist.
The appointment has caused some sniping from Washington conservatives but was endorsed by the Bush Administration.
Besides working with Mr. Dukakis, Mr. Summers, who is 35 years old, served as a domestic policy economist in the Council of Economic Advisers in the Reagan Administration and has been a consultant to the Labor and Treasury Departments.
He will replace Stanley Fisher, an international economist who just returned to his tenured professorship at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Mr. Summers, whose annual salary will be around $120,000 after taxes, was picked after a list of possibilities had been narrowed from 60 to 4 -- three Americans and a Briton, said a World Bank official yesterday who requested anonymity.
Professor Summers holds the Nathaniel Ropes chair of political economy at Harvard. He has a Ph.D. from Harvard and joined the faculty in 1983, after a year as an associate professor of economics at M.I.T., where he had been an undergraduate. He will leave Harvard for two and a half years to serve the World Bank.
Although he has worked with the Governments of Jamaica, Indonesia and Mexico on debt and other financial problems, he is known more as a domestic than international economist, fitting into a mainstream consensus that has believed that the United States needs a tax increase to reduce its budget deficit.
In an interview yesterday, Professor Summers emphasized his position in mainsteam economics and elaborated on some of his views on taxation. He said he "recognizes that taxes have important adverse incentive effects, particularly on capital formation," but added that "taxes are the price of government services, and running budget deficits doesn't avoid pain, it only postpones it."
Some conservative critics, led by Senator Bob Kasten Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, have questioned the appointment because of Mr. Summers's support for higher taxes and his alliance with Mr. Dukakis. An aide said yesterday that Mr. Kasten was "disappointed because Mr. Summers does not share the President's economic views and does not have a grounding in development economics."
Although the World Bank is owned by 155 member governments, the United States, with about 20 percent of the agency's stock, has a big influence on its internal matters. An American has led the organization since its founding in 1945.
He will join the World Bank on Jan. 14, after the current Harvard term. He and his wife, Victoria, a lawyer, have twin daughters.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Looking Ahead at Fay's After a Top Resignation

BYLINE: BY DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Fay's Inc., a drug-store chain in New York and Pennsylvania, has said that its president and chief operating officer, Lawrence J. Rose, has resigned to pursue other interests.
Henry A. Panasci Jr., chairman and chief executive, said yesterday that he would assume Mr. Rose's duties until a successor was named. 
 Mr. Panasci, who is 62, declined to elaborate on Mr. Rose's decision other than to say that "succession is not a part of this at all."
Mr. Rose, 49, has been with Fay's three years. He replaced Daniel A. Herrmann, who also resigned as president for personal reasons.
In a statement, Mr. Panasci said he accepted Mr. Rose's resignation with regret. "His contribution to Fay's during his tenure was significant," he said. Mr. Rose also resigned as a director.
Mr. Panasci co-founded the chain with his father in 1958. The company is based in Liverpool, N.Y., near Syracuse, the area in which the chain started.
Mr. Panasci's father is retired. The chief executive's son, David H. Panasci, 32, is president of the company's Paper Cutter division, which operates 25 stores in New York, Pennsylvania and New Jersey.
The Paper Cutter stores sell discount office supplies, books, greeting cards and party supplies. Other businesses include 190 Fay's drug stores and 26 Wheels discount auto supply stores.
The company has said that the auto supply and office supply chains, now relatively small, will take on increasing importance. Companywide sales last year reached $527 million.
Mr. Panasci, who owns about 24 percent of Fay's stock, said that despite recessionary concerns, business was "very strong," and that the Paper Cutter stores were "doing well."
Thomas R. Kully, an analyst at William Blair & Company in Chicago, agreed that Fay's had been doing well. "It had some earnings problems in last year's fourth quarter but it bounced back beautifully," he said.
As for recessionary times, Mr. Kully added: "I'd be a fool to tell you that any business is recession-proof. But I think the drug store is as close to recession-resistant as you can find."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Case Offered By the Optimists

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE Government's report that the American economy expanded at an annual rate of 1.8 percent in the third quarter startled economists who have been saying a recession has already started or soon will.
Many doubting economists said the official numbers must be wrong, because the Commerce Department had underestimated the rate of inflation and therefore overestimated the rate of real economic growth. They rejected the data, saying, "Wait for the next revision!" 
 But is it possible that the third-quarter G.N.P. data are telling a correct story and that the economy is stronger than most economists, business people and consumers believe?
Not all economists found the new numbers incredible. One who was not at all surprised was Gail Fosler, chief economist of the Conference Board, who predicted a month ago that third-quarter G.N.P. would rise at a rate of 1.8 percent, precisely as the Commerce Department says it did. She also forecast that real G.N.P. would slow to a 1.1 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter but would increase by 1.6 percent in 1991 and 2.5 percent in 1992. These days when a wave of pessimism is sweeping the country, Ms. Fosler is being called the most optimistic of forecasters.
Nevertheless, she regards what she calls the "recession discounting" by business as a source of economic stability. Many businesses, she said, "are already operating as though they were in a recession, holding down operating rates and employment levels, slowing investment plans, cutting costs to raise margins and profitability." As a result, order backlogs are stable and delivery times are lengthening.
She sees little danger of a huge lurch toward inventory-cutting, which is the usual trigger of a recession. For, despite the gloomy mood of consumers, as measured by surveys, consumer spendinghas been holding up. The Commerce report showed consumer spending, corrected for inflation, rising at an annual rate of 3.6 percent in the third quarter, as consumers cut their savings rate.
Ms. Fosler is by no means the last of the optimists. Some economists who focus on financial assets, especially the spread between interest rates on short-term and long-term assets -- the yield curve -- see no recession ahead.
Campbell R. Harvey of the Fuqua School of Business at Duke University is holding to his forecast that the economy will grow 2.2 percent between the third quarter of 1990 and the third quarter of 1991. Well aware of all the bearish talk in business circles, he says, "talk is one thing and action is another."
And he maintains that financial indicators reflect business actions affecting turning points in the business cycle far more accurately than surveys of expectations. Over the last 25 years, a flattening or inversion of the yield curve has correctly called all the major turning points in the United States business cycle but that is not what is happening now.
Using data similar to Professor Harvey's, the Experimental Index of Leading Indicators, developed by James Stock and Mark Watson for the National Bureau of Economic Research, is forecasting strong economic growth of nearly 4 percent in the next several months, with only a minuscule probability of 3 percent that the economy will be in recession by next February.
The Stock-Watson index derives its prediction of such strong growth mainly from the spread between interest rates on 10-year and one-year Treasury securities and between six-month commercial paper and six-month Treasury bills.
 Despite the historic correlation between these financial indicators and business-cycle turning points, could they be misleading now? George R. Perry of the Brookings Institution says they could. He suggests that the long-short spread might be giving off a false signal now because the Federal Reserve, to avoid the risk of causing a recession, is not raising short-term interest rates to check inflation. And he contends that long-term interest rates may be kept relatively high by such special factors as heavy long-term borrowing for the savings and loan bailout and the retreat of some Japanese investors from the American bond market.
He finds the lack of a recession signal coming from the private-Treasury spread baffling, and suggests that the data used in the Stock-Watson index do not reflect the downgraded credit ratings of well-known companies or the yield spread between "junk bonds" and Treasuries, which he says is soaring.
But Professor Harvey denies that such data are now signaling a recession. Using the spread of interest rates between Baa and AAA bonds, as rated by Moody's, he notes that the spread between low-quality and high-quality bonds rose to 262 basis points in 1982 before the recession, and above 300 basis points before earlier recessions, but has been rather stable since, oscillating gently between 121 in October 1983 and 126 in October 1990, with only a small uptrend in recent months.
Recession could still happen if the current extremely pessimistic psychology should translate into a self-fulfilling prophecy by causing consumer spending and business investment to plummet, or if war in the Persian Gulf should send oil prices soaring. But the Fosler, Harvey and Stock-Watson analyses offer hope that recession can still be avoided.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
$2.4 Billion in Bonds Retired in RJR Swap

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Moving to cut the huge debt from the biggest leveraged buyout in history, the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation said yesterday that it had retired $2.4 billion in high-interest bonds by swapping them for cash and stock.
RJR said the swap, which is part of a $6.9 billion recapitalization program begun in July, will give bondholders cash and stock in the company in exchange for the bonds.
The debt was incurred in the company's $25 billion leveraged buyout, completed early last year. 
 By retiring the bonds now, the privately held company avoids a steep increase in interest rates that would have taken effect in April. Instead, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the major owner of RJR Nabisco, obtained fresh bank loans in July to lower its debt and increase equity.
RJR Nabisco Holdings is the parent company of RJR Nabisco Inc., the tobacco and food conglomerate.
Since RJR Nabisco was taken private after the takeover battle that began in late 1988, the "junk bond" market that made the deal possible has plunged. But, unlike some other companies with heavy debt loads, RJR has managed to reduce its interest costs.
In its most recent quarter, RJR paid total interest expenses of $845 million, compared with $983 million in 1989's third quarter. It had a loss of $83 million in the quarter, compared with a loss of $447 million in the year-earlier quarter. With more than $15 billion in sales last year, the company ranks among the 25 largest manufacturers in the United States.
The current exchange involves two issues: a senior convertible debenture due in 2009 and a subordinated debenture due in 2007. For every $1,000 in debt tendered, RJR will pay $333 cash and will grant stock valued at $667.
RJR said that based on a preliminary count of tenders, 91 percent of the senior bonds would be replaced with RJR's cash and stock package, while 34 percent of the subordinated bonds tendered would be exchanged.

HEADLINE: MEXICAN ADAMANT ON CONTROL OF OIL

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 1

 BODY:
President Carlos Salinas de Gortari today strongly defended his ground-breaking efforts to open the Mexican economy to the outside world.
But he emphatically rejected any weakening of Government control over the country's lucrative oil industry, and pointedly asserted that any liberalization of Mexico's tightly controlled political system would remain an exclusively Mexican affair. 
 Speaking before more than 2,000 Government officials, legislators and dignitaries in his second annual State of the Nation address, Mr. Salinas said an open economy was vital to protect Mexican competitiveness in the face of a rapidly changing world.
But he asserted that the Mexican political system, which has long been dominated by his Institutional Revolutionary Party, was "not subject to external evaluation."
 
Remarks on Oil Applauded
 "Our democracy is sovereign," Mr. Salinas declared. "There are no limits placed on discussions of our democracy, but there is only one definitive judge, and that is the Mexican people."
As in the past, Mr. Salinas's comments on politics were greeted by howls and hoots from opposition politicians, who have accused the ruling party of widespread fraud and asserted that the President rose to office in a fixed vote in 1988.
At several points during the speech, opposition congressional delegations in the audience began heckling Mr. Salinas with chants of "fraud" and other political epithets, at times forcing him to stop speaking.
But Mr. Salinas drew general applause for his adamant position on Mexico's state-run oil industry, which many Mexican politicians and commentators believe should be excluded from talks toward a new free trade agreement with the United States. And the language of his address, which is closely watched for clues to future Government policy, seemed to leave little room for compromise on the oil issue.
"I want to confirm the fact," Mr. Salinas said, speaking about the trade talks with the United States, "that Mexico will maintain its ownership and complete dominion over hydrocarbons."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Silver Prices Rise Sharply Amid Hope of Fed Rate Cut

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Silver futures prices rose sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York, extending a recovery from 15-year lows, in a rally fueled by technical factors and speculation that interest rates might fall soon.
Gold futures also rose, while those for platinum fell.
Silver futures settled 7.6 cents to 7.9 cents higher, with the contract for delivery in December at $4.256 an ounce. 
 Gold ended $1.60 to $2.10 higher on the Comex, with the active December contract at $383.10 an ounce; the current November contract rose $2.10, to close at $381.50 an ounce.
Platinum futures were $2.70 to $2.90 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with January at $435.70 an ounce.
Silver prices have risen 5 percent since Monday, when the December contract touched a 15-year low of $4.05 an ounce amid perceptions of slackening demand and rising supplies of the metal.
Analysts said much of silver's recovery yesterday reflected technical buying signals derived from chart analysis.
The rally yesterday was also prompted by expectations that an anticipated decline in payroll employment and a rise in the national unemployment rate would prompt the Federal Reserve Board to move to lower lending rates, said Stephen W. Platt, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago.
The Labor Department is scheduled to release the monthly employment data tomorrow.
Higher stock prices also supported silver yesterday. The metal's price tends to respond to economic indicators because silver has many industrial applications.
Tim Evans, a trader with Deak International Inc., said the silver market appeared to have established a trading range of $4.25 to $4.35 an ounce.
"I would guess that in the short term, barring any major events, we're going to have a dull, trading-range kind of market," he said.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, grain and soybean futures ended mostly higher, helped by speculation that the United States will grant export credits to the Soviet Union before Election Day on Tuesday.
The buying was at least partly stimulated by speculation that the Bush Administration would take the long-expected step of declaring the Soviet Union a most-favored trading partner in an attempt to help Republican candidates from farm states, said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc., a Chicago brokers' advisory service.
The most-favored designation would make the Soviet Union eligible for credit on purchases of agricultural commodities. The Soviets are believed to be seeking export credits to buy American corn and soybean meal.
Wheat futures settled 1/4 cent to 3/4 cent higher, with December at $2.62 1/4 a bushel; corn was 1/4 cent to 3/4 cent higher, with December at $2.29 3/4 a bushel; oats were 1/4 cent to 1/2 cent lower, with December at $1.21 a bushel, and soybeans were 1/4 cent to 4 cents higher, with November at $5.96 a bushel.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Broadly Weaker As Rates Rise Overseas

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against all major currencies but the Japanese yen yesterday amid further signs of a weakening United States economy and rising interest rates overseas.
The dollar was pushed lower in European trading after an announcement by Germany's central bank that it was raising the Lombard rate, a crucial interest rate, by half a percentage point, to 8.5 percent. Traders sold the United States currency to buy marks. 
 Although dealers knew a German rate increase was inevitable to finance the cost of reunification of East and West Germany, the timing of the move caught the markets by surprise, said Bob Morrissey, senior trader at the Bank of Boston's office in New York.
 
 Signs of Weakening
 When trading shifted to the United States, the already weakened dollar was hit again by a Government report showing a sharp rise in initial jobless claims for the week ended Oct. 20 and a separate report from the nation's purchasing managers indicating the manufacturing sector weakened again last month.
Further, the Commerce Department said construction spending sank 2.8 percent in September, its sharpest plunge in eight years.
Because of the bearish indicators, traders expect the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates. Such a move would erode the value of dollar-denominated securities, and with interest rates rising overseas, incentives for foreign investors to put money in the United States is declining.
"The German move illustrates the direction of international interest rates and highlights the lack of interest-rate support for the dollar," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with IDEA in New York.
Against the German currency, the dollar fell to 1.5035 marks, from 1.5185 on Wednesday. The dollar also weakened against the British pound, which rose in London to $1.9525, from $1.944 late Wednesday. In New York, it cost $1.945 to buy one pound, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.943.
But the dollar rose against the Japanese currency, settling in New York at 130.56 yen, up from 130.15 yen on Wednesday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 130.7 Japanese yen, from 129.35 yen on Wednesday. And in London, it traded at 130.4 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.2753 Swiss francs, down from 1.2865; 5.0410 French francs, down from 5.0855; 1,127.25 Italian lire, down from 1,138, and 1.1643 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1668.

HEADLINE: A Warning to Taxpayers: Deductions Under Attack

SERIES: The New Tax Law - Last of five articles: A Challenge To Precious Deductions

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:
Long accustomed to a tax code that helps them achieve their most cherished financial goals -- home ownership and a decent retirement, for example -- Americans are being treated rather rudely. And that raises questions of how to plan for the future.
The Tax Reform Act of 1986, which snatched deductions for Individual Retirement Accounts away from the more affluent taxpayers and phased out everyone's deductions for consumer interest, began to chip away at the tax benefits people had come to expect. 
 The deficit-reduction measure approved by Congress on Saturday invaded more sacrosanct territory: deductions for interest on home mortgages, charitable contributions and state and local taxes. The invasion was by the back door, not addressing any of these deductions directly, but putting a floor on the total of itemized deductions equal to 3 percent of adjusted gross income above $100,000. Congress left people asking, 'Is this the thin edge of a wedge?'
 
 A 'Hidden' Increase
 The floor on itemized deductions is "a hidden rate increase," said William J. Goldberg, national director of personal financial services for KPMG Peat Marwick in Houston, who added that it raises concerns for the future. His advice to anyone shopping for a home today is: "Be conservative. Be sure you can pay the mortgage interest and real estate taxes without tax deductions."
What about people who already have big mortgages, which they took in the belief their after-tax cash flow would be sufficient to cover the payments? "They're stuck," Mr. Goldberg replied, noting that "there has been an absence of grandfathering" since the 1986 act.
"They're not going after the perceived middle class," he added, but the upper and upper-middle classes could face more ugly surprises and will need to reorder their finances to cover mortgages, for example.
The bill held other pain for individuals, phasing out personal exemptions for the more affluent and extending the 1.45 percent Medicare portion of the Social Security tax to earnings of $125,000, well past the $54,600 where old-age and disability insurance collections will stop next year.
"It's more a collection of tax nibbles that one big tax bite, but it adds up," Mr. Goldberg said. "There is no one big thing to plan around."
John G. Wilkins, a partner in Coopers & Lybrand's Washington office and the firm's director of tax policy for economic analysis, predicted the tax package "will probably last for a year -- then we'll be back in a pickle again." The next time Congress tries to raise money, corporate taxes are likely to be affected, he said, "but ultimately, individuals pay corporate taxes."
"The thing that bothers me is the creeping up in rates," Mr. Wilkins said, because high rates spawn unproductive tax shelters. One possibility, he said, is that capital gains would stay at 28 percent after 1991 but rates on ordinary income could go higher than 31 percent.
 
 Tax-Deferred Savings
 George E. L. Barbee, who is in charge of personal financial planning for Price Waterhouse in Boston, advised people to contribute as much as they legally could to tax-deferred retirement savings plans like Keogh and 401(k) plans, especially if the employer matches contributions.
"Don't lose the opportunity," he said. "At least we know where it is this year -- $7,979" for 401(k) contributions. "With legislation driven by deficit reduction, there are no sacred cows," he continued.
Joel S. Isaacson, partner for personal financial planning at Weber Lipshie & Company in New York, advised taking advantage of other employee benefits now available. Putting pretax compensation into flexible spending accounts for medical and child-care expenses will lower the adjusted gross income as well as avoid taxes on money in the plan, he noted.
Mr. Barbee said: "I think one has to be terribly conservative. The recession is here. Economists in Washington may war over words, but it is here." Repay debt, he said, first nondeductible consumer debt, then home equity debt, and do not count on the deduction to be there forever.
 
 'Cash Is King'
 David A. Berenson, national director of tax policy for Ernst & Young in Washington, agreed that "cash is king now." The time to raise taxes was five years ago, not now, as the economy slides, he said. As for the 1986 tax act, which treated capital gains as ordinary income and imposed a maximum bracket of 28 percent, "that deal is blown out of the water," he said.
"The one thing that is certain is constant change, permanent uncertainty," he said, forecasting more changes in the tax law in coming years for two reasons: the need for further deficit reduction and to address the confusion that is bound to arise as a result of the complexities in this package, which he called "shameful, unconscionable."
The situation "does not bode well for employee benefits, the biggest thing not on tax returns," Mr. Berenson said, adding that "bad ideas, once they raise revenue, tend to grow."
 
 Others in Jeopardy
 Sidney Kess, a New York tax lawyer and certified public accountant, cited other tax benefits that could be curbed by future legislation. One is tax-free exchanges, which are often used in real estate. Gift and estate-taxes could be raised in several ways, and the right to give gifts up to $10,000 annually tax free could end, he said. Upper-income taxpayers frequently make such gifts to family members over a period of years because estate taxes go as high as 55 percent.
With the economy heading toward a slump and many companies cutting costs, many professionals agreed that people should give more importance to these factors in personal financial planning than to taxes. For example, given the change in rates next year, with a top rate of 31 percent compared with the 28 percent for some taxpayers this year and 33 percent for others, when should a year-end bonus be taken?
"Take it when you can get it, if you're a big hitter," said Byrle M. Abbin, managing director of Arthur Andersen & Company's Office of Federal Tax Services in Washington.
 
 Giving to Charities
 Economic concerns are also overriding when it comes to deductions for contributions to charities. Neal P. Myerberg, chief executive of the UJA-Federation's Department of Planned Giving and Endowments, said that when people see real need, they come through.
Top tax brackets were cut in stages from 91 percent to 50 percent and now 28 percent, reducing the value of deductions accordingly. Yet every year, contributions have risen, Mr. Myerberg said, because people have seen the need for his group's programs like relocating Russian Jewish refugees.
"It's more and more of a human plan," he said, "and less a tax plan."
