HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Global-Lender Aid Is Seen For Debtors Hurt by Crisis

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund is expected to move Friday toward getting more and faster financial aid to countries feeling the economic shock from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, American and other officials said today.
"The whole idea is to make the fund more flexible in dealing with members' requests for cash," said an international official who insisted on not being identified. 
 While technical in nature, the steps could help about 40 countries that have been affected by the adverse consequences of higher oil prices, lost exports, reduced pipeline and canal revenues, decreased worker remittances, the return of thousands of displaced workers and other problems resulting from the invasion.
Countries closest to the area of tensions -- Jordan, Egypt and Turkey -- are hardest hit. Also severely affected are countries that are heavily dependent on imported oil and worker remittances, like Morocco, Pakistan, the Sudan, Bangladesh, India, the Philippines and Sri Lanka.
 
Vulnerable Eastern Europe
 Eastern Europe is particularly vulnerable as well, I.M.F. officials said. Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia are suddenly paying more for oil while undertaking revolutionary economic readjustment.
Referring to all affected countries, the fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus, said in a speech in New York last week, "An effort of solidarity in their favor is required."
The moves, which are in line with proposals made in September by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, would be taken at a meeting of the executive board, comprising senior officials representing the 155 member governments of the Washington-based lending organization.
It was unclear whether final decisions would be made on Friday or whether more sessions would be required to tie up loose ends. An American official said she did not expect final action at the meeting.
 
World Bank's Role
 The World Bank, sister agency of the I.M.F. and fellow lender to many third-world countries, has a task force assessing the steps it would take and is expected to hold a board meeting in 10 days to consider its response to the crisis.
The aid issues were initially reviewed in September in Washington when the two lenders, which together commit about $30 billion annually to third-world countries, held their 45th joint annual meeting.
An overall assessment of the situation is expected Monday, when a special steering group organized by President Bush to coordinate economic assistance meets in Rome.
It would be the third session of the so-called Gulf Crisis Financial Coordination Group, which includes the I.M.F., the World Bank and about 20 governments. Two earlier meetings were held in Washington. One reason for the selection of Rome was that Italy is currently heading the European Community's Council of Ministers.
 
Economic Emergency Cushion
 On a worldwide trip in September, Mr. Brady won commitments of $20 billion in economic and military assistance in support of the gulf operation. The aid was pledged from countries like Japan, West Germany, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates and is separate from money to be disbursed by the fund and the World Bank.
The steering group is to manage the $13 billion to $15 billion of that sum that has been earmarked for economic assistance, American officials said.
The objective of the Rome meeting, a Bush Administration official said, "is to get a handle on the exact amounts of money involved and turn commitments of donors into actual disbursements." The American delegation is being led by Under Secretary of the Treasury David C. Mulford, who will serve as chairman.
The I.M.F. has what it calls a Compensatory and Contingency Financing Facilty, which has been used in the past to cushion economic emergencies like destruction of a sugar crop by a hurricane or a sudden rise in global interest rates.
One of the proposals expected to be taken up on Friday is to broaden the criteria for use of that special pool of money to include reductions in oil-pipeline and canal-transit fees.

HEADLINE: A Crucial Lending Rate Is Raised by Germany

BYLINE: By FERDINAND PROTZMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Germany lifted one of its two primary lending rates today, bucking the international trend toward lower interest rates. Economists said the move could rekindle a dormant dispute between Germany and its trading partners over its restrictive approach to monetary policy.
The rate increase reflected the deepening concern at the Bundesbank, Germany's staunchly independent central bank, with the Government's plans to finance German unity almost exclusively through the capital markets. That stance has pushed up the cost of borrowing and brought an element of uncertainty to the nation's financial markets.
 
 Takes Effect Friday
 The Bundesbank's policy-setting central bank council raised the nation's Lombard rate to 8.5 percent, from 8 percent, effective Friday. The increase was decided upon at the council's regular biweekly meeting today. 
 The Netherlands also raised its maininterest rates by a quarter of a percentage point. Other European countries that often mirror the Bundesbank's policy moves did not immediately react. Some European financial centers were closed for the All Saints' Day holiday.
Germany last altered interest rates on Oct. 5, 1989, when it lifted the Lombard rate and the longer-term discount rate by a percentage point each, to 8 percent and 6 percent, respectively. Commercial banks peg their lending rates to the discount rate, which was left unchanged at 6 percent.
The Lombard rate is the interest the Bundesbank charges on short-term borrowings by commercial banks using securities as collateral. It is intended as a last-resort borrowing mechanism that effectively acts as a ceiling for interest rates.
 
 Some Warning Signs
 Economists and financial market participants were not surprised by the move.
"There were some signs of a Lombard increase on the horizon for the past week," said Ulrich Ramm, the chief economist of Commerzbank A.G. in Frankufurt. "But I didn't think the Bundesbank would choose to do it now, so soon after the French and the Americans cut their interest rates.
"I believe it is a show of strength by the Bundesbank, sending the message that they are sticking to their course," Mr. Ramm said. "But this risks increasing tensions over monetary policy within Europe and with the Americans."
 
 Technical Adjustment
 The Bundesbank presented today's increase as a technical adjustment meant to strengthen its ability to steer Germany's money market, saying that the historical gap between the Lombard rate and market rates had recently been lost and that this would restore it.
Surging demand for credit since the two Germanys merged their economic and monetary policies on July 1 has pushed money market interest rates higher, and in recent months they have hovered between 8 percent and 9 percent. Banks have made extensive use of the Lombard program because it was cheaper than the call money rate, the interest paid on funds borrowed overnight from the central bank, which has been at or above 8 percent for weeks.
The combination of heavy Lombard borrowing and high market rates had severely undermined the Lombard rate's function as a ceiling, economists said.
 
 Cuts by U.S. and France
 On Wednesday, France cut its leading interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point, after the United States Federal Reserve Board had moved the Fed funds rate down by the same margin earlier in the week. Both nations were acting to bolster sagging economic growth.
Germany, by contrast, is increasingly concerned that its economy is overheating, in part because of an avalanche of pent-up consumer demand from the eastern section of the country.

HEADLINE: Gloomy Outlook for Global Talks on Farm Trade

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 1

 BODY:
The European Community's continued failure to agree on a common negotiating position on agriculture has deepened pessimism over whether four years of talks aimed at liberalizing world trade can conclude successfully early next month.
Government officials from the United States, Japan and developing countries, as well as the European Community, have warned that the collapse of the negotiations could set off a disastrous wave of protectionism that could seriously cripple world trade. 
 Agriculture is considered the make-or-break issue. A huge gap exists between the United States, which has pushed hard to end agricultural subsidies, or at least to reduce them, and the European Community, which has opposed such changes. And Europe has not even been able to adopt a unified position from which to negotiate.
 
 German and French Opposition
 A summit meeting of community leaders in Rome last weekend ended with Germany and France refusing to endorse a proposed 30 percent reduction of farm export subsidies over the next 10 years. Even if the Community agreed on that it would be far short of a proposal made by the United States and broadly backed by the leading food-exporting countries that export subsidies be cut by 90 percent over 10 years and overall farm supports by 75 percent.
A new effort to break the deadlock will come in informal negotiations starting Friday at the headquarters in Geneva of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 105-nation world body that oversees trade. And agriculture and trade ministers of the 12 European Community nations will meet in Brussels on Monday.
 A group of 13 food-exporting nations known as the Cairns Group and Canada, Brazil, Argentina and Australia, will also meet in Geneva on Sunday and Monday. Some members say they may walk out of the broad trade talks. "We want to produce a crisis in these talks," Argentina's Agriculture Secretary, Felipe Sola, said today.
 
 Other Areas Discussed
 Although agriculture is only one of 15 areas in which the reduction of trade restraints is being negotiated, the lack of progress there is holding up negotiations in other areas, including services, textiles and telecommunications.
Many trade officials say that only a conference of top-level ministers of the GATT nations has a hope of breaking the deadlock. Those ministers will meet in Brussels in early December.
Some governments have suggested postponing the Brussels meeting to provide more time for negotiations. But the United States objects because Congress has given the Administration authority to negotiate only until March 1. Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, has said the first two months of 1991 will be needed to prepare legislation for Congress.
"The situation now is a lot worse than anyone ever contemplated it could be," Canada's Trade Minister, John Crosbie, said after last weekend's community summit. He added that France and Germany "are apparently prepared to see the whole Uruguay Round fail." The four-year round of trade talks is known as the Uruguay Round because the talks began in that nation.
 
 Power of Farmers
 Farmers throughout Europe benefit from a range of generous subsidies, but France and Germany are blocking a sharp reduction of agricultural protectionism because of the political weight of farming lobbies in both countries.
With Germany to hold general elections on Dec. 2, Chancellor Helmut Kohl is believed to fear a defection of rural votes from his Christian Democratic Party if he accepts the negotiating position proposed by the community's executive commission.
In contrast, Britain and the Netherlands, where small farms are less numerous, have long criticized the community's agricultural policy on the grounds that consumers and taxpayers are handing over $100 billion a year to shield 11 million farmers from market forces.
The United States itself is channeling some $8.5 billion in subsidies to 2.2 million of its farmers this year and providing other indirect assistance to stimulate production. But it claims that it lost $11 billion in farm exports last year alone because of European protectionism.
 
 Other Damaged Nations
 No less important is the trade lost by other food exporters, particularly in the third world. Argentina, for example, claims it lost 25 percent of its farm export income last year because of protectionism in Europe and the United States.
Further, several Eastern European countries and the Soviet Union are counting on farm product exports to help them consolidate their moves toward market economies, but their natural market in Western Europe is currently largely closed to them.
"The greatest single gesture to perestroika that Western Europe can make is to provide open, rich markets that will give this European breadbasket a chance to recover from Communism," The Economist of London said last week. "Mr. Kohl talks of handing aid to his Eastern neighbors, even as he denies them their real need -- trade."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Report By U.N. On Arabs

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the report submitted to the United Nations Security Council by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar on the Palestianians in the Israeli-occupied territories:
 Palestinians have expressed a profound feeling of vulnerability at all times, whether in the workplace, at school, in places of worship or simply walking down the street. This fear was compounded by their view that there was no recourse to any authority, other than the security forces who were so often responsible for the measures inflicted upon them.
They have stated that they feel unsafe even inside their homes, which were frequently subjected to midnight searches, and during which entire households, including children, were beaten. It was said that arrests during such operations were common. A wide range of collective punishments had, they said, become routine during the past three years, such as curfews, the demolition of homes, administrative detention and the uprooting of trees.
A system of arbitrary and heavy taxation had been imposed, which if not complied with, might lead to the confiscation of personal property and even arrest. Furthermore, the Palestinians have complained bitterly about a number of longstanding Israeli practices: the taking of land, especially for Israeili settlements and the privileged access that these settlements were given to water supplies; the closure for prolonged periods of the universities, and the periodic closure of elementary and high schools, which, in the Palestinian view amounted to a denial of their right to education, and the overall economic exploitation of the territories.
Palestinians emphasized that their distrust of the Israeli occupation authorities -- be they the security forces charged with maintaining law and order or officials of the Civil Administration whose role affected most aspects of their daily lives -- had grown so deep that they felt that only an impartial presence, properly mandated by the United Nations, would be able to provide them with a credible sense of protection.
In this connection, many of them drew attention to the military observers stationed in Jerusalem at the headquarters of the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization , and inquired why they could not be assigned to monitor the situation in the occupied territories.
While they expressed appreciation for the humanitarian efforts carried out by representatives of international agencies and voluntary agencies, they were nevertheless deeply frustrated that those organizations were prevented from intervening or unable to intervene more effectively on their behalf.
 
Israeli View of Strife
 During the past three years I have had occasion to meet with a number of senior Israeli officials in New York, and have frequently voiced to them my concern about the situation in the occupied territores. In discussions with me, and with members of my staff in the area, the Israeli authorities have maintained that measures such as administrative detentions, curfews and the closure of schools and universities have been carried out in order to restore calm in the territories.
Israel's position has been, and continues to be, that it retains exclusive control over the territories it administers. Furthermore, the Israeli authorities point out that even under the Fourth Geneva Convention it would be for them to maintain law and order in the territories.
According to them, their policy during the past three years has been to put an end to the unrest in the territories which, in their view, is fomented by elements from the outside.
They note that the security forces are adhering to strict regulations determined by the Minister for Defence and that violations of those regulations are punishable. In response to expressions of concern regarding the need for the safety and protection of the Palestinians, the Israeli authorities point out that the many Palestinians who have been killed by other Palestinians should be a matter of equal concern to the international community.
Had it been possible for me to end a mission to the area at the present time, it would have followed up on the discussions begun last summer with the Israeli authorities and the Palestinian leadership. The Israeli authorities indicated at that time that they would be implementing new measures in the territories.
It should be noted that, in the subsequent months, there was a decreased military presence in the occupied territories and a decline in casualties resulting from actions involving the Israeli security forces there.
 
Practical U.N. Steps
 Further, there has also been a reopening of certain academic institutions. Nevertheless, the essential facts of the occupation have not changed and the potential for friction and confrontation between Israelis and Palestinians has remained very high, as evidenced by the tragic events of Oct. 8, 1990. The spate of violent attacks that have occurred since then, with more bloodshed on both sides, has generated further mistrust and bitterness.
The issue before us today is what practical steps can, in fact, be taken by the international community to insure the safety and protection of the Palestinian civilians living under Israeli occupation. Clearly, the numerous appeals -- whether by the Security Council, by myself as Secretary General, by individual Member States or by I.C.R.C., which is the custodian of the Geneva Conventions -- to the Israeli authorities to abide by their obligations under the Fourth Geneva Convention have been ineffective.

HEADLINE: Purchasers Index Declines To Lowest Level in 8 Years

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Steeper energy costs, declining production and higher unemployment helped to push the nation's manufacturing economy in October to its lowest level in eight years, the nation's purchasing managers report.
Their monthly survey also found that new orders fell last month and prices increased sharply. Economists said the figures provided further evidence that inflation is growing and the nation's economy is entering a recession. 
 The National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of economic activity fell to 43.4 percent, registering its fourth consecutive monthly decline. It was the weakest showing since December 1982. The September index stood at 44.4 percent.
A reading below 50 percent indicates that the manufacturing economy is generally declining; a reading above that level suggests expansion. The October index of economic activity was the fourth consecutive month in which the reading fell below the 50 percent mark. The index also remained below 50 percent in the first three months of this year.
 
 Growth of About 1% in 1990
 "If the purchasing managers' index remains unchanged at the October level for the remainder of the year, then past experience indicates this would be consistent with real gross national product growth of about 1 percent for all of 1990," said Robert Bretz, chairman of the association's business survey committee and director of materials management at Pitney Bowes Inc.
The purchasing managers' report is considered an important economic indicator because managers from a wide range of industrial companies across the country are surveyed. It is also the first important indicator released each month.
The report also comes a day after the release of a Federal Reserve survey that indicated that the economy was continuing to weaken, particularly in retailing. The survey found that economic activity in September was expanding more slowly or declining in most of the Federal Reserve's 12 districts.
And two days ago the Gvernment reported that the gross national product grew at a 1.8 percent annual rate during the third quarter, higher than the rate of four-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter.
Neal M. Soss, chief economist with the First Boston Corporation, said of the purchasing report: "The numbers indicate that we are sliding, but not tumbling, into recession. I suspect things will remain the same for the rest of the year."
 
 Imports Decline
 Imports declined for the sixth consecutive month, although at a slower rate than in September.
Production registered a sharp decline in October, with the index falling to 43 percent, from 45.1 percent in September. The survey said the continued weakness in new orders suggests no near-term improvement in production.
Prices rose sharply in October for the fifth consecutive month, with the price index rising to 76.4 percent, from 73.4 percent in September. The increase in prices, the association said, was almost entirely a result of the Persian Gulf crisis and increases in the prices of crude oil, petrochemical feed stock and petroleum derivaitives.
The association listed 47 items that were up in price, up from 40 items in the September survey. Thirteen items were listed as being down in price, compared with 16 items in the September survey.
The employment index declined in October to 40.7 percent, from 41.5 percent in September. The October rate is the lowest since May of 1985, when the index stood at 40.4 percent. The figure "indicated that manufacturers continue to adjust employment levels to reflect the declining economy," the report said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Pushed Up By Job Data

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
An unexpectedly large rise in weekly unemployment claims reported yesterday helped to push up prices of Treasury securities and drive down interest rates as traders speculated that the ever-weakening economy would prompt the Federal Reserve Board to move quickly to ease credit again.
The report, released early in the session by the Labor Department, suggested to traders that today's October employment report will be even weaker than people in the market had anticipated. 
 The claims numbers showed an increase of 33,000 in the week ended Oct. 20, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 454,000. It was the second straight week that the claims increase had exceeded expectations.
 
 Effect of the Budget
 Responding to Congressional approval of a new Federal budget, the central bank signaled Monday that it had reduced the Federal funds rate, an important short-term interest rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans. That reduction, by one-quarter of a percentage point, to 7.75 percent, was not viewed as sufficiently large enough to prompt a decline in either the prime lending rate charged by commercial banks, consumer borrowing rates that are pegged to the prime or in residential mortgage rates.
"People seem to be getting on the recession story and are looking for a second ease in policy," one government bond trader said.
Based on the new jobless claims figures, economists are now anticipating that nonfarm payroll employment may have declined by as much as 100,000 jobs last month and that the unemployment rate, currently at 5.7 percent, may have risen by one-tenth or two-tenths of a percentage point.
 
 If Unemployment Rises
 "If the unemployment rate goes up, the Fed would probably have to move," the trader said.
Before the claims figures came out, most analysts were anticipating that nonfarm payroll employment rose modestly in October.
Although overshadowed by the jobless claims figures, the results of the monthly survey of purchasing managers across the country, as well as a report on construction activity during September, provided additional evidence that the economy is sliding into recession, market participants said. [Page D5.]
The reports showed that activity in manufacturing and construction had fallen to its lowest level since 1982, the last time the economy was in recession.
"Conditions are no longer soft; they are weak," said Mitchell Held, chief financial economist at Smith Barney Harris Upham & Company.
The economic reports encouraged heavy buying, traders said.
"People who have not played in a long time are back in the game," said one trader of short-term Treasury notes.
Talk of recession helped to push down both long-term and short-term interest rates in the secondary market for Treasury securities.
By late in the day, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 100 3/4, up 23/32, to yield 8.67 percent, down from 8.75 percent late Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 3/8, up 15/32, to yield 8.53 percent. And the 7 3/4 percent two-year notes rose by 5/ 32, to 100 6/32, to yield 7.64 percent.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills fell.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.04 percent, down 5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates dropped 6 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.01 percent. And one-year bill rates slid by 8 basis points, to a late rate of 6.83 percent.
 
 Move May Be Too Quick
 The quick move in short-term interest rates over the past few sessions may be overdone, some traders said.
"The market is beginning to price itself toward the next easing in Fed policy, but I don't think it is going to happen before Thanksgiving," the short-term note trader said. "Betting on the Fed has not been a smart thing to do this year."
The drop in interest rates over the past few days encouraged a number of corporations to offer new debt issues yesterday.
Among the issurs was the GTE Corporation, which became the first company in some months to price a traditional 30-year bond.
Since late summer, uncertainties about the Middle East and the outlook for interest rates, among other factors, have persuaded most companies to satisfy their financing needs by issuing short- to intermediate-term securities.
The $400 million worth of 10.25 percent GTE bonds, which mature Nov. 1, 2020, were priced at $98.984 to yield 10.36 percent, 1.65 percentage points above the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing.
Paine Webber Group acted as lead manager for the issue, which is noncallable for 10 years. The securities are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
 Tax-Exempt Issues
 In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the Metropolitan Water District of Chicago sold $100 million worth of bonds at competitive bid.
A group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets won the issue, which consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1992 to 2010.
Coupons on the bonds range from 5.80 percent in 1992 to 6.70 percent in 2000 to a maximum of 7.20 percent in 2010.
The securities are rated AA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for municipal bonds, traders said prices of most issues had risen by about 1/4 of a point.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said prices had inched about 1/8 of a point higher.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply declined in the week ended Oct. 22. The third, largest measure, M3, rose by $1.6 billion.

HEADLINE: Layoffs Set At Morgan Stanley

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
Morgan Stanley & Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 50 investment banking jobs, or 6 percent of the 800-member division. It is expected that this round of cuts will be followed by investment banking layoffs at other Wall Street firms.
Similar layoffs have taken place at Paine Webber Inc. and Shearson Lehman. But Morgan Stanley's are significant because of the firm's reputation. It is considered a corporate finance powerhouse and its investment bankers are generally viewed as the elite of Wall Street and were instrumental in arranging some of the biggest deals of the 1980's. 
 Investment banking is considered one of the most prestigious and profitable lines of business on Wall Street, and while the securities industry has been swept by layoffs in other areas, this is the first time a brokerage firm of Morgan Stanley's caliber has cut investment bankers.
 
 'No Clear Precedent'
 A spokesman for Morgan Stanley said the cuts would come from all four investment banking areas: corporate finance, mergers and acquisitions, capital markets and real estate. He said those being let go range from junior analysts to "quite senior people," although the spokesman declined to indentify the employees involved.
"These layoffs are a reflection of the firm's feelings about the business outlook in the intermediate-term future," said the spokesman, who spoke on the condition he would not be identified. He added that there was "no clear precedent" for the layoffs and that "nothing quite like this has happened before."
The layoffs come at a time when Morgan's overall earnings have been holding up. But its investment banking revenues have fallen steadily throughout the year. For instance, in the second quarter, investment banking fees dropped by 30 percent from the period a year earlier, and were down 8 percent in the third quarter from the 1989 quarter.
"The true earnings of the firm have held up relatively well this year," the spokesman said. "But you've certainly seen the statistics on merger activity so far this year, and the outlook for that is uncertain at best."'
 
 'Not Surprising'
 Michael Goldstein, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said the layoffs reflected "the basically weak business environment."
"This is not suprising," he added. "I've been expecting the entire Street's investment banking capacity to contract because investment banking revenues have been at their lowest level since 1984 and a lot of jobs were added since then."
But investment banking, which generally involves raising capital for American companies and arranging financing for mergers and buyouts, has been hard hit by the economic downturn as well as the stagnation of the "junk bond" market. American corporations are not raising money to expand and the number of mergers and buyouts has fallen sharply since their heyday in the 1980's.
The Morgan spokesman said the layoffs would have no effect on fourth-quarter earnings and that no charge would be taken. By the end of the year, he said, he expected that the investment banking department would number about 750, and he added that no further investment banking layoffs were planned.
 
 Expansion Abroad
 The firm has about 7,100 employees, up from 6,600 at the beginning of the year. But the expansion has taken place in Morgan Stanley offices overseas, primarily in London, Tokyo and Hong Kong, and not in New York.
Morgan is not planning any major structural changes as a result of the layoffs, but the spokesman said the firm would merge its capital markets, debt and equity operations.
Since the 1987 market crash, employment in the securities business has fallen by 50,000, to 210,000. But most of the cutbacks have resulted from the collapse of several firms, most notably E. F. Hutton & Company and Drexel Burnham Lambert.
At the same time, profits in the industry have been battered. The double-digit profits of the early 1980's have shrunk to an average of 4 percent since 1987, according to the Securities Industry Association. Pretax return on equity, which averaged 50 percent in the 1980's, has fallen to an average of 7 percent since the market crash, the association reports.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Faces The Painful: More Taxes

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
In a year in which New York State increased taxes by $1.3 billion, its largest rise ever, and New York City imposed $817 million in new taxes, its largest rise ever, economists and even politicians are worrying about how much more a faltering city economy can afford.
"We're removing income right and left from consumers," said Rae D. Rosen, senior economist at the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York. "We're squeezing corporate profits. It exacerbates what was a very poor situation to begin with." 
 Still, with the economy slumping, tax revenues have been disappointing, even as crime and other problems raise demands for more spending. Washington, with budget problems of its own, is unlikely to offer new aid. So it seems almost inevitable that new local taxes will be needed if the city and the state are to erase budget deficits for next year, as they must under the law.
The question is, which taxes will inflict the least harm on the city's declining economy?
 
Weighing the Property Tax
 If local taxes must be raised, some economists, including Dick Netzer, a professor at the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University, recommend the property tax, the only major tax New York City can raise without first getting permission from Albany. And they say that much of the new burden should be borne by homeowners, who have long been protected by statute and by politicians afraid that if taxes get too high, homeowners will turn their wrath on officeholders -- or simply move out of the city.
In 1977, 45 percent of the property taxes the city collected came from residential property and 55 percent from nonresidential -- largely commercial -- property. By last year, the residential share was down to 37 percent and the nonresidential share up to 63 percent. During that time the percentage of local tax revenue from the property tax dropped to 43 percent from 51 percent.
"Just simple, across-the-board raising of taxes scares me," Professor Netzer said. "It's only low for those properties that were favored: Class 1 properties and co-ops and condos. That's where I'd press."
Class 1 properties are one-, two- and three-family homes. Professor Netzer also suggested that land values in the city be re-examined and the assessment on undervalued residential and commercial parcels be pushed up.
But if it was politically hard to increase taxes on residential properties during good times, when property values were soaring, what are the chances of imposing increases at a time when values are falling?
In searching for new revenue, economists say, city officials will inevitably bump up against the weakening economy, tax rates that are already high, or both.
 
Sluggish Retail Sales
 For example, raising the sales tax in the city -- already 8.25 percent -- would be likely to depress retail sales at a time when they are already weak. Similarly adding to the relatively high tax on real-estate transactions in a slow market might be counterproductive. Raising the city's tax on cigarettes -- now 8 cents a pack -- might spur smuggling from lower-tax areas.
Even before this year's round of tax increases, the city's Tax Study Commission -- a panel established in the more prosperous days of 1986 -- recommended the elimination or reduction of the city's commercial rent tax. This tax, which is imposed on tenants in properties used for business, is in addition to the property tax paid by the owner.
The commission, in its report in December 1989, also called for reducing or ending the unincorporated business tax, which is applied to income from partnerships and proprietorships -- income that is already taxed under the city's personal-income or nonresident taxes.
The commercial rent tax and unincorporated income tax are rarely found elsewhere, and the panel said they contributed to "negative impressions of the city's business climate."
But these two taxes also raised about $1 billion a year, a sum the panel acknowledged could not completely be replaced through other taxes.
 
New Federal Aid Unlikely
 The commission concluded that "the state and the Federal Government must assume a more equitable share" of the city's costs in providing welfare and medical care for the poor. But given the fiscal problems in Albany and Washington, it seems unlikely that much new aid will be available.
As the city's economy has deteriorated -- 34,000 jobs were lost during June, July and August -- concern about the impact of new taxes seems to have intensified.
Last month, for example, when the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins proposed raising $1.8 billion in new revenues over four years to hire 6,000 additional police officers, business leaders and others who had pressed the Mayor for a response to a surge of violence seemed relieved.
But Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, says that developers' support for the plan will depend on the extent to which the rest of the Mayor's budget relies on additional taxes.
Instead of raising property taxes, the Real Estate Board has proposed expanding the city's tax incentive program -- in effect, forgiving some of the taxes on new projects that it argues will not be built otherwise.
The New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry and its sister organization, the New York City Partnership, last year gave state leaders in Albany a list of taxes that it said could be raised, an unusual move for such business groups.
"I've been haunted by that a long time," said Ronald K. Shelp, the president of the groups.
This year, Mr. Shelp said, the state and city will have to make a case that they have cut costs and increased productivity. "Then you can talk about taxes," he said. "Not before."
 
Threats to the Economy
 Higher taxes threaten the weak city economy in several ways. They siphon money that might otherwise be spent by consumers, reducing retail sales and the demand for services. Perhaps even worse, they put New York City at a further disadvantage in competing with other localities for businesses or residents, especially at a time when the city is cutting services and when taxes just across the Hudson in New Jersey are much lower, even after recent increases there.
Like spending by consumers, spending by government can stimulate economic activity. But Richard K. Vedder, an economics professor at Ohio University, said he believed the "growth-enhancing effects" of government spending were less significant than the "growth-impeding effects," largely because taxes must be collected to pay for the spending.
"My own research leads me to believe that high-tax states and high-tax cities would be engaging in an act of self-destruction, or at least hurting themselves if they continue to add taxes in the midst of a decline," he said, echoing the sentiments of business leaders and economists in the city.
Besides the immediate economic consequences, some worry that ever-higher taxes will reinforce an image of the city as anti-business, which could be especially destructive in a slump.
"Part of it is that intangible thing of climate and business outlook," said Charles Brecher, research director of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private organization that studies government finances and is sponsored by businesses.
 
Lessons of the Past
 In some ways the city can be considered a case study of the effects of higher taxes in an economic slump. In the years leading to the fiscal crisis of 1975, New York raised taxes year after year, even as its economy was collapsing and hundreds of thousands of jobs were disappearing.
The city abruptly and unexpectedly reversed its slide in 1977, and there was an attempt to stablilize tax rates and in some cases lower them, especially on the state's part. Even with stable or declining tax rates, though, revenues rose as the economy expanded and property became more valuable.
Although New York City already has 24 separate taxes, Professor Netzer suggested that it might consider adding one: a tax on vehicles driving into midtown and downtown Manhattan, an idea the city itself put forth a few years ago when the goal was to reduce air pollution, not raise money.
A congestion tax, which could be levied through special license plates or windshield stickers, might raise as much as $500 million a year, Professor Netzer said, and it would improve business conditions for some industries, like trucking.
In any case, by taxing traffic, New York City would at least be singling out a commodity in which it is still rich.

HEADLINE: With Budget Wars Ended, Frantic Campaign Begins

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 1

 BODY:
What Representative Wayne Owens calls his "nervous factor" hit new heights today when a man named Milt phoned him on K-TALK radio here to register his complaint that Congress had dithered over the budget deficit.
"I feel like Congress is fiddling while Rome is burning," said Milt, who admitted to deep uncertainty about voting next Tuesday to return Mr. Owens, a Democrat, to Washington. "We're in such a deep deficit problem, and you guys didn't cut anything." 
 To incumbent members of Congress stumping around the country this week, the refrain is all too familiar. After the longest pre-election Congressional session since World War II, lawmakers are finally back in their districts and are faced with compressing what should have been a final month of campaigning into a week. They also are confronted by voters who have almost nothing nice to say about them.
 
An Unsettling Time
 It is an unsettling time for many of the incumbents. While they are overwhelming their rivals with campaign money and other perks of incumbency that should help the great majority of them get re-elected, it seems clear that many lawmakers would rather still be wrestling with the budget than with angry voters. They are being chastised for not acting soon enough to bring down the deficit, for raising taxes and Medicare fees and, some say, for making Congress look like a laughingstock.
Then there is the uncertainty brought on by the threat of war in the Persian Gulf. On top of that, incumbents whose only presence in their districts of late has been on television are racing against the clock to show their faces.
In San Diego, Representative Jim Bates said one constituent had told him, " 'I like you and like what you're doing, but I want to vote against Congress and the only way to do that is to vote against you.' " Mr. Bates, a Democrat, said frankly, "I'm prepared to lose."
In Methuen, Mass., Connell J. Vincent did not mince words when he confronted Representative Chester G. Atkins this morning at a senior center. "You need a lot of help, Mr. Atkins," Mr. Vincent told the Democrat, "and not just mine."
Mr. Atkins replied, "You know we've been there to help you with Medicare."
"Well," shot back Mr. Vincent, a retired machinist, "how is it going to help me when it goes up $50?"
 
Frantic Campaign Efforts
 In the suburbs of Philadelphia, Representative Curt Weldon, a Republican, was frantically crisscrossing his district, trying hopelessly to make up for the 55 campaign appearances he missed or canceled because of Congress's late adjournment.
In Hawaii, Representative Patricia Saiki, a Republican in a tightly contested Senate race, said the truncated campaign season "is absolutely wild." Interviewed on a cellular phone as she raced to Honolulu Airport on Wednesday morning for a flight to Hilo on the Big Island, she added breathlessly, "I'm running on a full tank of adrenalin."
And in Salt Lake City, framed by the snowcapped Wasatch Range, Representative Owens, who as the sole Democrat in Utah's Congressional delegation faces a spirited challenge, perhaps best summed up the fears of incumbents on the radio show today: "This has been a traumatic time. People don't feel like Congress has behaved in a seemly fashion."
Clearly understating his worries, he added, "It may not be the best time for an election."
The 53-year-old Mr. Owens knew he was in for a rough week when he picked up The Salt Lake Tribune on Monday, his first morning back from Washington.
 
'Summarily Furloughed'
 In a letter to the editor, a friend of 25 years and a former campaign treasurer, Louise Hess, declared that all of Congress should be "summarily furloughed."
"Any person who spends more than 30 consecutive days in Washington, D.C.," she wrote, "becomes infected with a debilitating and even deadly virus that is so pervasive and all-encompassing that as soon as one's mouth opens, one's thinking and reasoning centers completely shut down."
Mr. Owens said he has had some sleepless nights of late, thinking about a replay of his "nightmare of 1974," when he gave up his House seat after one term to run for the Senate and lost in an upset to Senator Jake Garn.
After years as president of a Mormon mission in Montreal, practicing law in Salt Lake City and running unsuccessfully for governor in 1984, he was re-elected to the House in 1986. Though Mr. Owens holds an edge in polls, his Republican rival, former state Representative Genevieve Atwood, has gained steam in the surveys.
Sitting on a sofa in his district office Wednesday while Barbara Bush was in town stumping for Ms. Atwood, Mr. Owens fretted about "Mrs. Bush and her Mormonly demeanor and appeal -- that's what makes it nervous time."
 
Barbara Bush's Support
 At the same time, Ms. Atwood was milking the First Lady's visit for all it was worth, cutting short a debate with Mr. Owens so she could greet Mrs. Bush. "I'm a President Bush supporter right down to my underwear," Ms. Atwood, a former state geologist, proclaimed to her supporters.
Perhaps Ms. Atwood was so emphatic about declaring her loyalty to Mr. Bush because at times it had seemed as though Mr. Owens had more closely toed the Administration line.
The Congressman holds the odd distinction of being the only House Democrat who is facing a strong challenge but voted for the budget summit agreement that his fellow incumbents deserted in droves.
"My pollster, Doug Schoen, called from New York and said, 'You fool, don't even think of doing that. She'll kill you on this,' " Mr. Owens recalled. But the Congressman bucked his advisers and, as was expected, Ms. Atwood seized on his vote.
"Do you believe in higher taxes? Wayne Owens does," the announcer intones in an Atwood television commercial. "Do you believe citizens should pay twice as much for Medicare while cutting benefits? Wayne Owens does."
 
Returning Fire
 Mr. Owens, whose campaign is flush with political action committee donations, has returned fire in television advertisements that have blanketed the district, and in debates, in which he links her to conservatives who led the rebellion against the initial budget package.
"I am totally supportive of his deficit-reduction efforts," Mr. Owens said of the President. "Genevieve's decision to go with the Newt Gingrich firebombing group in the Congress of the United States isolates her from all the Republicans in this state."
Despite his tough talk, it is almost comedic the way Mr. Owens is sprinting around his district to make up for lost time.
This week, he has scheduled 13 debates, 11 fund-raising events, 60 phone calls for more money, and six mornings and evenings of waving at passing motorists. Wedged in between, he expects to sign 900 thank-you notes to contributors.
Multiply that by the 406 House members and 32 Senators seeking re-election.
 
'Very, Very Worried'
 "I was very, very worried about this campaign -- it's a tough one," said Representative George E. Brown Jr., a Democrat of Southern California, who is threatened by increasing Republican registration in his district. "Getting out here one week before the election is just not going to give me much of an opportunity to recoup."
When Mr. Brown did make it to the district for a debate during the budget impasse, he was ridiculed by his opponent for leaving behind important business on Capitol Hill. Another Californian, Senator Pete Wilson, the Democratic candidate for Governor, relied heavily on broadcasts from the Capitol by satellite to get his message to the state's voters.
As he made his way around a lunchroom for elderly people in Massachusetts today, Mr. Atkins observed, "People like to see you. They want you to ask for their vote. And they don't understand if it's election time and you're not around asking."
But for other incumbents, being stuck in Washington was something of a political godsend.
"Actually, it has worked out nicely from a strategic standpoint because we were able to put some strong surrogates in the field speaking on behalf of the Congressman," said Robert Hinkle, a spokesman for Representative Bill Sarpalius, a one-term Democrat from the Texas Panhandle who is in one of the country's most hard-fought House races.
"And the Congressman has been very stately in Washington, diligently working in this economic crisis."
Representative Ben Jones, a Democrat from suburban Atlanta, did not seem fazed about spending a week instead of a month in his district.
"I suppose that missing fund-raisers and forums hurts, but how can you tell?" he asked. "You can't measure an event that didn't happen."

HEADLINE: Construction Outlays Fall 2.8 Percent

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Construction spending fell 2.8 percent in September, its steepest drop since the last recession, the Government said today. Analysts said any recovery is at least months away.
"Given what we see now, we have several more months to go before we can say we've hit the bottom," said Daryl Delano, an economist with Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass.
The Commerce Department said total construction spending, which was flat in August and July, was at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $428.7 billion in September -- the lowest dollar level since $423.1 billion was spent in November 1988.
 
 Drop in Confidence
 Declines in all categories led to the sharpest tumble since a 3 percent drop in January 1982 during the 1981-82 recession. September spending was 1.1 percent below the $433.4 billion spent in September 1989.
"The weakness across the board probably reflects the overall decline in business confidence to go along with the well-documented decline in consumer confidence," Mr. Delano said.
The Conference Board, a New York business research group, reported last week that consumer confidence in the economy plunged 24 points in October to its lowest level since the last recession.
The construction industry also has been hurt by high interest rates, tight lending requirements and, in some areas, high vacancy rates. It has not posted an increase since it rose four-tenths of a percent last March.
The Labor Department has reported the loss of more than 100,000 construction jobs in the last four months alone. This included 20,000 jobs in September, after seasonal adjustment.
Residential construction spending fell 2.3 percent, to an annual rate of $182.2 billion, after a 1.1 percent decline in August.
Spending on construction of single-family houses was down 2.7 percent, to $105.6 billion, after a 1.9 percent loss the previous month. Apartment construction declined 3.7 percent, to $18 billion, after being unchanged a month earlier.
Nonresidential spending fell 2.3 percent, to $101.8 billion, after a 4.8 percent plunge in August.
"The weakness is more pervasive now than it was even three months ago, when we still had good industrial spending, fairly good retail and other commercial spending as well as spending for education and hospitals," Mr. Delano said. "Those that had been good are at best holding their own now and the others are continuing to deteriorate."
Government construction spending, which rose 6.5 percent in August, fell 5 percent in September, to $109.3 billion. Spending on streets and highways, which paced the August advance, was off 3.5 percent in September.

GRAPHIC: Chart: Total construction spending in billions of dollars at seasonally adjusted annual rate. (source: Commerce Dept.)

HEADLINE: Packaging and Public Image: McDonald's Fills a Big Order

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
As recently as a week ago, the McDonald's Corporation was preparing to respond to public pressure for a cleaner environment by announcing that it would extend its limited plastics-recycling program to all of its 8,500 restaurants nationwide.
But then the fast-food chain changed course, announcing yesterday that it would do away with its plastic foam "clamshell" hamburger box and switch to paper packaging. That abrupt decision came largely as a result of an unusual alliance forged in August with the Environmental Defense Fund, people involved in the discussions said. 
 The change to paper, which will start in about a month, is an indication of the way public pressure can affect the decision-making process of a company, particularly one as concerned about its image as McDonald's.
 
How Customers Feel
 The company had insisted to the end that its foam packaging was environmentally sound. But "our customers just don't feel good about it," said Edward H. Rensi, the president of McDonald's U.S.A. "So we're changing."
McDonald's has gone far beyond being a mere seller of hamburgers -- it is a national institution. So the last thing it needs is to have schoolchildren be told it is a force of evil, damaging to society. If it appeared to be putting profit over the environment by stubbornly staying with a material widely regarded as detrimental to the environment, the company risked alienating many of the same younger customers who avoided buying tuna caught by methods that kill dolphins.
"Customer demands are changing," said Jonathan Asher, a vice president of Gerstman & Meyers, a design firm. "In the past, convenience was the most important attribute of a package. Now there is a new need: to be sensitive to the environment."
The process by which McDonald's decided to switch to paper illustrates how a giant company can work with special interest groups. Well before the move, McDonald's had established a joint task force with the Environmental Defense Fund to study how to deal with the company's solid-waste problem. When it decided last week that it would stick with recycling, Frederic D. Krupp, the executive director of the fund, was able to call directly to Mr. Rensi to object.
"When we learned they were planning to go to comprehensive recycling, we reacted strongly," said Mr. Krupp during a joint interview yesterday with Mr. Rensi at company headquarters in Oak Brook, Ill. "We had the access due to te program."
Mr. Rensi said Mr. Krupp's protest prompted a top-level management review of the company's approach to packaging. "Fred called on Thursday while I was in New York," he said. "When I got back in the office on Friday, I called Shelby Yastrow, who heads our environmental work, and told him to get some people together and study whether we should get rid of foam and switch to paper."
Data Were on Hand
Mr. Rensi indicated that the company had already been studying the feasibility and economics of the switch, so most of the data needed to make a decision were on hand. "We already knew we could switch to paper and save money," he said.
Mr. Rensi said the company was also aware that public concerns about the environment and solid waste have been growing. "All you have to do is look at the evening news to know that," he said.
Mr. Krupp said the environmental group is not against recycling, but felt that it was not economical to recycle polystyrene and that the benefits of a switch in materials was greater. "The hierarchy is: reduce, reuse and recycle," he said. "The new packaging has 90 percent less bulk than the foam."
Weighing all the factors, the company decided early this week to make the change. "It was not a complicated management process," Mr. Rensi said. In a statement, the company said: "Although some scientific studies indicate that foam packaging is environmentally sound, our customers just don't feel good about it."
 
One of Many Voices
 Mr. Krupp said the environment fund was "one of many voices" influencing McDonald's on the paper-versus-foam issue. But he said the fund was prepared to oppose the recycling program publicly if the company had gone ahead with its original plan. The group has been criticized within the environmental movement for its ties to a company many see as the symbol of a wasteful society.
The decision by McDonald's, Mr. Krupp said, will be a signal to industry in general to move toward more environmentally sensitive packaging. "The end of the polystyrene clamshell represents the turning of the tide on the throwaway society."
But the swiftness of the company's reversal after years of vigorously defending the use of foam came as a surprise to some of those involved in solid-waste disputes. "This is a case study for the business schools," said Allen Hershkowitz, a senior scientist with the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group. "The decision was made in the last 72 hours. You get the impression they do something and then try to figure out what it means."
 
Other Issues
 Some disagreed with the wisdom of McDonald's decision or its potential impact. "This is an environmental attack on the throwaway, fast-food life style and the company with the highest profile," said John Giroux, president of the Amoco Foam Products Company, a subsidiary of the oil company and a supplier of foam packaging to McDonald's. "This is not about polystyrene."
He said the material is used widely in the food and packaging industries, including the making of egg cartons, and that these sectors have not come under significant attack. He said about 10 percent of Amoco Foam's sales were to McDonald's.
Other companies producing the material include the Mobil Corporation, Jen-Pak and Huntsman Chemical, none of which will be hurt greatly by McDonald's decision.
 
1 Billion Pounds a Year
 R. Jerry Johnson, executive director of the Polystyrene Packaging Council, a trade association, said the total market for foam packaging like the McDonald's box is about one billion pounds a year in the United States. "Our sense is that McDonald's is about 7 or 8 percent of that," he said.
McDonald's officials said the new packaging, which will include a cellophane-like outer wrapper, will start appearing in its restaurants in about four weeks. The company said it uses a large number of suppliers for its paper products and would not identify any specific paper companies that would benefit from the changeover.
The new paper-based material McDonald's will use will not be recyclable because of its multilayer construction. But Mr. Hershkowitz, of the Natural Resources Defense Council, said the company indicated that its goal was to find a material that could be disposed of by composting.
The first package to be phased out will be the foam hamburger box, which Mr. Rensi said accounts for 75 percent of the total foam used.
Mr. Rensi conceded that the new containers would not be as good as foam in retaining heat. But he said improvements in cooking methods since the company last used paper-based packaging in the early 1970's would compensate. "The technology of the cooking process has caught up to the defects of paper," he said.
 
Some Difficult Problems
 He said complex sandwiches, like the Big Mac, would be made inside a paper collar to retain heat, and then wrapped with an outer sheet. The McDLT sandwich, where foam was used to keep the hot hamburger separated from the cooler lettuce and tomato slices, "is a very difficult problem" without the use of foam, he added.
The environmental community is not uniformly behind the switch from plastic to paper, illustrating the complexity of the problem. "Using a lot more paper means a lot more pollution," said Jan Beyea, a scientist at the National Audubon Society. "It is a mistake to make plastic the great satan and paper the great saint. Both processes generate pollution."
He said the shift by McDonald's, which had switched to foam from paper packaging in 1975, "shows that consumer pressure works."
McDonald's officials said all the details of the shift to paper-based packaging had not been worked out, but that over time the company expected paper to be less expensive than foam. But the officials said the impact would be small. "It will not affect our prices or our profits," Mr. Rensi said.
 
Example of Cooperation
 Both Mr. Rensi and Mr. Krupp said the plastic-to-paper decision was an indication of how often-warring corporations and environmentalists can cooperate. "This is an indication of how business, consumers and environmentalists can meet, discuss issues and create a partnership without a fight. We recognize that not all our decisions are right."
Mr. Krupp said: "McDonald's recognizes that the future is green. If they do, others will as well. McDonald's is to be applauded for changing course."
But groups representing polystyrene packaging companies reacted with dismauy. "This came as a shock to us," said Mr. Johnson of the polystyrene council. "We have been working for 10 years with these guys on recycling."
"This is a big deal to us because of the fact that McDonald's bowed to public pressure," said Joseph W. Bow, president of the Foodservice and Packaging Institute. "We want to see a free economy where materials are used based on their advantages, not on the wishes of powerful groups."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edward H. Rensi, right, of McDonald's U.S.A., and Frederic D. Krupp, of the Environmental Defense Fund, with samples of McDonald's foam hamburger boxes and the new packaging that will replace them. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times) (Pg. D5)

SECTION: Section B; Page 6; Column 1; National Desk; LAW: AT THE BAR

LENGTH: 809 words

HEADLINE: Among Lawyers, Do Litigators Have Some Kind Of Hormonal Edge? Science May Deliver The Answer.

BYLINE: By David Margolick

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
In the past few weeks, 50 lawyers here have taken sticks of Extra sugarless gum, placed them in their mouths, worked up some saliva, and expectorated into a small plastic vial.
For maximum freshness, each bottle has been whisked into the freezer across the hall from the office of Dr. James M. Dabbs Jr., a psychologist at Georgia State University, where it awaits analysis. 
 "These are the lawyers," Dr. Dabbs's research assistant, Elizabeth Carriere, recently told a visitor as she opened the freezer. "They've already been centrifuged."
Trial lawyers often say they have more gumption, more guts, or more other parts of their anatomy than their paper-pushing partners. What Dr. Dabbs and Ms. Carriere are out to learn is whether these boasts are physiological facts or just self-aggrandizing figures of speech.
In the mini-spittoons of Dr. Dabbs's freezer is the saliva of trial lawyers, of government lawyers, of corporate lawyers, of real estate lawyers, of criminal lawyers, of judges, and as of a few days ago, one lawyer-turned newspaper-reporter. In the next week or so, all of them -- samples from women as well as men -- will be tested for their level of testosterone, the principal male sex hormone.
High levels of testosterone has been linked with overly aggressive or anti-social behavior. Juvenile delinquents, substance abusers, rapists, bullies and dropouts tend to have too much of the stuff. It is Dr. Dabbs's hypothesis that trial lawyers, too, are overly endowed in this department, but have learned to harness this primordial force for fun and profit.
"Trial lawyers may have stumbled into this wonderful ecological niche in which they can go out and be aggressive and confrontational and still get a lot of rewards for it," he said. "It may be one of the more primitive ways of making a prestigious living."
Dr. Dabbs tried to include lawyers in a similar study three years ago, which examined doctors, football players, sales people, actors, ministers, professors, firefighters and the unemployed. But no lawyers would cooperate -- perhaps, his original research assistant, Denise de La Rue, hypothesized, "out of some underlying fear of failure."
Enter Ms. Carriere, an undergraduate at Georgia State and the daughter and granddaughter of lawyers. She persuaded some of her father's friends to take part in the study, and from there, secured toe-holds in some of the city's major law firms. She also solicited volunteers at the DeKalb County Courthouse.
Sure enough, courtroom and boardroom lawyers reacted quite differently when a 22-year-old woman asked to test their testosterone. Ms. Carriere said some of the trial lawyers seemed to think they had been selected because of their self-evident machismo. One promptly volunteered to recruit some of his fellow "hormonal lawyers," as he put it. When it came time to produce specimens, they spit with gusto.
For these would-be he-men, a low testosterone count could prove far more crushing than any 500 on their Law School Admissions Test. But one of those tested, Robert Katz of Gorby, Reeves, Moraitakis & Whiteman, suggested that for him, at least, the experiment was a no-lose proposition. What if he got a low score? "I don't think a low-level reading means that that attorney is incapable of functioning in court," he said solemnly. And a high one? "Obviously I'll put that in our firm resume," he said.
Many of the non-litigators, on the other hand, blanched when Ms. Carriere approached them. "They just about crawled under the desk," she said. One real estate lawyer refused, acting, she said, "like I was asking him to donate money," she said. Others insisted on spitting in private.
Dr. Dabbs's research has its skeptics, like former Attorney General Griffin Bell of King & Spalding in Atlanta, two of whose lawyers participated in the study. "It's useless information as I see it," he said.
That may be a bit harsh. The scores could aid career counselors, who might steer poor performers away from courtroom work. It could finally determine whether Wall Street "litigators," who rarely get into courtrooms, are really trial lawyers. It could help elite groups like the American College of Trial Lawyers pick members more scientifically.
Dr. Dabbs has other experiments in mind. To gauge the relative roles of nature and nurture in the making of a trial lawyer, he is considering testing law students. A leading Atlanta criminal-defense lawyer, Bruce Harvey, has agreed to spit periodically while on trial. Dr. Dabbs also dreams of testing the superstar saliva of a Joe Jamail, a Richard (Racehorse) Haynes and or an Alan Dershowitz.
He could also team up with Dr. Donald Clifford of the Medical College of Ohio in Toledo, who is currently working on another, closely related population. He is testing the testosterone level of pit bulls.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN;
The Ones to Watch: Snapshots of Some of the Hottest Contests for the House

 BODY:

California
 
 17TH DISTRICT. Calvin Dooley, the Democratic candidate, appears to be benefiting greatly from the headlines in the Fresno area about the six-term incumbent, Charles (Chip) Pashayan Jr., a Republican, and his ties to the savings and loan industry and Charles H. Keating Jr. Mr. Pashayan is not the target of any inquiries, but he received $26,000 in contributions from Mr. Keating in 1986 and shortly after wrote letters and introduced legislation to help the S.& L. industry.
36TH DISTRICT. For two decades, George E. Brown Jr., a Democrat, has represented the San Bernardino area. But now he faces a strong challenge from Bob Hammock, a Republican, who while on the City Council and County Board, built strong ties to Hispanic voters, who make up a quarter of the district.
37TH DISTRICT. In the Palm Springs area, the incumbent, Alfred A. McCandless, a Republican, represents a district that has seen such a population boom that lots of new voters do not know him, leaving him vulnerable to challenge from the actor Ralph Waite, a Democrat best known as the father on the Waltons television show.
 
 Connecticut
 
 FIFTH DISTRICT. Toby Moffett, a Democrat, faces Gary A. Franks, a Republican, for a seat John Rowland vacated to run for governor. Mr. Franks, a three-term Waterbury alderman, is a conservative black Republican, and Mr. Moffett is a former Congressman who lost races for the Senate and governor in the 1980's. Mr. Moffett is trying to avoid the carpetbagger label, based on his recent move into the district. Mr. Franks, a real estate owner, has been criticized for failing to release income tax data.
 
 Florida
 
 FOURTH DISTRICT. Craig T. James, a freshman Representative and a Republican, faces a strong challenge in northeastern Florida from Reid Hughes, a wealthy former oil distributor who is trying to tap anti-incumbent sentiment by portraying Mr. James as a tool of special interests.
11TH DISTRICT. Bill Nelson, a Democrat, vacated the seat representing east-central Florida to run for the nomination for governor, which he lost. Republicans hold the registration advanatage, but Jim Bacchus, a Democratic Orlando lawyer, has run a strong race. The Republican candiate is Bill Tolley, who ran against Mr. Nelson in 1988.
 
 Georgia
 
 FOURTH DISTRICT. Ben Jones, a Democrat, won this district in 1988 from Pat Swindall, who was under indictment on ethics charges. The Republican, John Linder, is trying to win it back by painting Mr. Jones as too liberal, although he seems to have trouble getting his race to take hold in the district, just outside Atlanta.
 
 Idaho
 
 FIRST DISTRICT. Democrats hope Larry LaRocco, a Boise stockbroker, can win this seat back for them against C. A. (Skip) Smyser, a Republican lawyer and longtime state senator. The incumbent Republican, Larry Craig, is running for governor. Both candidates are using anti-incumbent tactics, but both are restrained: Mr. Smyser because of his political career, Mr. LaRocco because the neighboring district in Eastern Washington is represented by Thomas S. Foley, a fellow Democrat and the Speaker of the House.
 
 Illinois
 
 11TH DISTRICT. Frank Annunzio, the 75-year-old Democrat who has held this seat in northwest Chicago for 13 terms, faces a strong challenge from Walter Dudycz, a Republican who is making much of Mr. Annunzio's contributions from Charles J. Keating Jr.
16TH DISTRICT. John Cox, a Democrat and former prosecutor for Joe Daviess County in the state's northwest corner, is battling to overcome implications by his Republican opponent, John Hallock, a state representative, that Mr. Cox wants to meddle with the Social Security trust fund. The charge is based on a proposal Mr. Cox made that has been oversimplified. Lynn Martin vacated this seat to run for the Senate.
 
 Indiana
 
THIRD DISTRICT. John Hiler has been in a competitive election every two years since he won this seat, representing north-central Indiana, including South Bend, from John Brademas in 1980. His Democratic opponent is Tim Roemer, a legislative staff worker in Washington.
FOURTH DISTRICT. Jill Long, a freshman Democrat in Vice President Dan Quayle's old seat from northeast Indiana, is running against spending and taxes. That is how she won a special election in 1989, and it is how she hopes to keep her seat against Rick Hawks, a Republican former television minister. It's a real baby boomer race: She is 38; he is 37.
 
 Iowa
 
 SECOND DISTRICT. Thanks to a sound farm economy, this district that includes Dubuque and Cedar Rapids, is enjoying relatively stable economic times, so the contest between Eric Tabor, the Democratic farmer, and Jim Nussle, a Republican prosecutor, has consisted largely of personal attacks, based on charges like misrepresentations of their work histories. Tom Tauke gave up the seat to run for the Senate.
 
 Maine
 
 FIRST DISTRICT. David F. Emery, a Republican who held this seat in south Maine from 1975 to 1983, is trying to get it back, with Joe Brennan's leaving to run for Governor. Mr. Emery, with solid conservative credentials, is trying to paint his more populist Democratic opponent, State Senator Thomas H. Andrews, as a liberal, but not with limited success. Mr. Andrews has succeeded in portraying himself as an economic development advocate.
 
 Maryland
 
 FIRST DISTRICT. Roy Dyson, despite being under attack for close ties to military contractors, was renominated in the state's southern district. But new disclosures of ties to contractors have hurt the incumbent Democrat since. Wayne Gilchrest, a Republican high school teacher who nearly beat Mr. Dyson in 1988, is playing up his service in Vietnam. Mr. Dyson was a conscientious objector.
 
 Massachusetts
 
 FIFTH DISTRICT. Chester Atkins is state Democratic chairman, and that is not a good thing to be this year in Massachusetts, where voters are consumed by anti-government fury. State Representative John MacGovern, a Republican, is trying to paint Mr. Atkins as a clone of the unpopular Gov. Michael S. Dukakis. The district is northwest of Boston.
 
 Minnesota
 
 SEVENTH DISTRICT. Arlan Strangeland, the Republican who has represented the district that includes St. Cloud since 1977, may be in peril. The cause is a character issue revolving around his use of Congressional telephones for personal calls. Collin Peterson, a Democrat making his fifth try at unseating Mr. Strangeland, has unified party backing this time.
 
 New Jersey
 
 FIRST DISTRICT. The anti-tax furor in New Jersey has given Republicans hope in a district where they normally would not have much. This is Gov. Jim Florio's old seat, in southwestern New Jersey, and it is Mr. Florio's tax increases that have provoked voter outrage. Still, the Republican, Dan Mangini, with a relatively modest campaign, is in an uphill fight against Rob Andrews, the Democrat who has a huge, well-financed organization.
 
 North Carolina
 
 11TH DISTRICT. This district has changed hands more than any other in the 1980's. Jamie Clark is now in his second term, the longest anyone has served in more than a decade. Former State Senator Charles Taylor, a tree farmer, is the Republican. He nearly beat Mr. Clark in 1988. Mr. Clark has more money but Mr. Taylor has Jesse Helms at the top of the ticket in this rural district that includes Asheville.
 
 Oregon
 
 FIFTH DISTRICT. Denny Smith, the Republican, is among the most vulnerable incumbents in the country, largely because of his well-publicized savings and loan links, which resulted in a House ethics complaint. Mike Kopetski came within a few hundred votes of beating Mr. Smith two years ago in this district in state's northwest corner. Now he has the S.& L. issue and has avoided being painted as a sympathizer with radical environmentalists.
 
 Rhode Island
 
 SECOND DISTRICT. Claudine Schneider gave up this seat, representing western Rhode Island, to run for the Senate. State Representative Jack Reed is the Democratic candidate against Trudy Coxe. Ms. Coxe is a well-known environmentalist, and Republicans hope that will protect her against the effects of the souring economy, which seem to be working to Mr. Reed's benefit.
 
 Texas
 
 11TH DISTRICT. With the retirement of Marvin Leath, Democrats are scrambling to hang on here, near the center of the state. Chet Edwards, a Democratic state senator, and Hugh Shine, a Republican state representative, both aim to portray themselves as in tune with the true Texas of the 1990's. In a state that has been tipping gradually to Republicans, this conservative central Texas district with a long Democratic history is being seen as indicative of 90's trends.
13TH DISTRICT. Bill Sarpalius, a Democrat, is in danger of losing the seat he has held for one term. This Panhandle district, with an economy based on agricultural and minerals, is the most Republican part of the state, and Mr. Sarpalius's Republican challenger, State Representative Dick Waterfield, is running a better-financed campaign.
 
 Vermont
 
 FIRST DISTRICT. Peter Smith, the Republican Representative completing his first term from this one-district state, is facing a challenge from an independent socialist, Bernie Sanders, a former Mayor of Burlington. The Democratic candidate in this race is barely a factor.
 
 Washington
 
 THIRD DISTRICT. Jolene Unsoeld, a Democrat, was elected from this southwest Washington district, in the closest election in country in 1988. Bob Williams, the Republican challenger, a strong supporter of the gun-owner rights, is attacking her for reversals on gun control, yet the National Rifle Assiciation has endorsed Ms. Unsoeld because she voted for the gun group's position on domestic production of semiautmoatic weapons.
