HEADLINE: The Curtain Goes Up Again at Sardi's

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

 BODY:
Among the glitzy marquees and crumbling sidewalks of the theater district recently, a hand-lettered sign was propped in the window of a darkened restaurant for more than a month. "Very soon I will reopen Sardi's The Longest Running Show on Broadway," it read, and it was signed "Vincent Sardi."
Similar posters have become indigenous to New York City's landscape. More often than not, the reopening notices are replaced by others that say "Closed" or "Foreclosure"; New Yorkers have learned to avert their eyes. 
 But pedestrians on West 44th Street yesterday noticed that the sign was gone, the windows were shining and the 79-year-old restaurant's facade had a new coat of Chianti-red paint. Tonight Sardi's is opening its doors to the public again.
The restaurant has been closed since July, but it hasn't been itself for many years. In its heyday, Sardi's was Glamour. It was John Barrymore, Helen Hayes, Lilian Gish, Rex Harrison, Marilyn Monroe. It was a world of red-leather banquettes, silk stockings, cigarettes glimmering in onyx holders and sauces warming in copper pans at tableside. It was the brightest light of the Great White Way.
And Mr. Sardi, who ran the restaurant that his father began as a speakeasy in 1921, was the unofficial mayor of 44th Street. In addition to pouring cocktails mean enough to please Damon Runyon, and serving top-shelf roast beef, filet mignon and canneloni, he knew and charmed le tout New York. But after three decades, Mr. Sardi stopped spending 14 hours a day in his restaurant. The glamour quotient dipped, the carpets got thinner, the patina on the banquettes turned to dinge, and food from industrial cans became the kitchen's mainstay. By 1987, The Zagat New York City Restaurant Survey called the place a "culinary laughing stock." One customer who was surveyed called Sardi's "The longest-running gag on Broadway."
 
A Namesake as Receiver
 This didn't stop the tour buses. Nevertheless, four years ago Mr. Sardi sold the restaurant to a group of investors and retired to Vermont. Soon after the sale, the group failed to make its monthly payments. In July, the group closed the restaurant. Pending sale of the site, the courts appointed Mr. Sardi as "temporary receiver." "His hope is that he will get legal possession," said David Garelick, the attorney who represents Mr. Sardi.
In the past five months, the restaurant rumor mills have churned with Sardi-reincarnation plans. At least half-a-dozen well-known operators, including Brian McNally, the impresario of 150 Wooster, considered purchasing the remaining nine-year lease on the property, but the necessary multi-million-dollar overhaul of the vintage dining rooms and kitchen was daunting to most propective buyers. A second investment group convened with visions of restoring the Sardi glory and placing a renowned Italian chef in the kitchen.
It wasn't only the lingering Sardi mystique, its icon status, the ghosts of Broadway-past that set potential buyers and investors spinning with grandiose plans. The restaurant, once among only a handful of large Broadway eating spots, is in the heart of what has become the hottest and most competitive dining area in town. Five new hotels and thousands of square feet of new office and residential space have been opened in the last year. Defying the dining-out economy in other parts of town, restaurateurs have flocked to the Times Square area with modern and shrewdly competitive business plans, multi-million-dollar investors and late-model names of their own.
Last summer, David Liederman, who owns Chez Louis, opened the Broadway Grill, a $2.2 million dining room on 48th Street. The restaurant designer Adam Tihany opened Remi, a high-styled trattoria on West 53d Street that cost about $3 million. Peter Aschkenasy, who owns Gage & Tollner in Brooklyn, is spending more than $2 million to build Chesapeake House, which is to open in late winter at 47th Street and Broadway, only three blocks from Sardi's. Dean & De Luca and Brian McNally are negotiating for food-service space in the Paramount project at 235 West 46th Street.
"Everybody wants to be here," said Mr. Aschkenasy. It's no wonder that investors huffed around Sardi's like so many bellows over a waning flame.
 
Aware but Unworried
 But in the end, Sardi reincarnated is simply Sardi redux. Mr. Sardi, who is now 75 years old, spent $500,000 to make minimal repairs to his restaurant and to lay new carpeting and reupholster the banquettes. "My pension plan is my partner," he said yesterday, strolling through the three floors of dining rooms that he has spent most of his life tending. He is not unaware of the brave new restaurant world that is sprouting around him. He is not unconcerned that 48 hours before the opening, his liquor license was still pending and the paint was still wet. He is a believer.
"We got through Prohibition and the Great Depression," he said. His gaze skipped past the hastily reupholstered banquettes, stray wires and unfinished electrical outlets and rested on the gallery of caricatures on the walls. The faces that used to giggle, confide and gossip at his tables, the scores of actors, writers and politicians whom, for half a century, he protected from autograph hounds, now line his walls in frames. "You can't just let a tradition like this go down the drain," he said.
"We already have 52 reservations for Friday night," said the guardian of the 700-seat establishment on Wednesday. "So many lovely people call me on the telephone to wish me well, and I promise them all a free glass of wine."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sardi's will reopen tonight. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
On a Musical Journey of Discovery

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
The camera pans slowly across the flat, frozen desolation of the Finnish north to discover a small unheated barn where the world's worst polka band is playing an audition best described as relentless. They are 10, if you include the manager, Vladimir, and one musician who is laid out in a home-made coffin, frozen stiff and, it is assumed, dead.
It is further assumed that they are brothers since each looks to have been hatched at the same time from the same egg. Alive or dead, each is equally expressionless and, perhaps, equally committed to music. 
 Their most stunning physical characteristic is their hair, which is jet black and grows horizontally forward from the brow into a sort of tilde shape. They could have come from the drawing board of Dick Tracy's Chester Gould.
They are, instead, the seriously detached, deadpan comic heroes of "Leningrad Cowboys Go America," written and directed last year by the gifted Aki Kaurismaki.
 In case you came in late, Mr. Kaurismaki is the not-quite-minimalist Finnish film maker whose two later comedies, "The Match Factory Girl" and "I Hired a Contract Killer," were the highlights at this year's New York Film Festival.
When the audition on the tundra ends, after an especially brisk solo riff on an electric guitar, a Helsinki impresario tells Vladimir that the band's best chances are in New York. "They'll buy anything there," he says, giving Vladimir the name and address of a cousin who will take charge of the band's fortunes in the States.
Thus begins "Leningrad Cowboys Go America," a road comedy so laid back and so cool that to laugh out loud at it would seem to be hopelessly square. It opens today at the Angelika Film Center.
 After taking off from the world's sleepiest international airport, the members of the band, including the stiff one, arrive on the Lower East Side. The New York promoter suggests that they make their American debut in a concert either at Madison Square Garden or Yankee Stadium.
Then he listens to them. Without missing a beat, he sends them off to play a wedding in Mexico.
There is no room for surprise in the Kaurismaki universe.
Vladimir and his group walk to the nearest used-car lot where the friendly, fast-talking salesman (played by Jim Jarmusch, the American director) tries to sell them a Checker cab that appears to have been dropped from a great height onto its radiator. They appreciate everything the salesman says but choose, instead, the roominess and luxury of a $700 Cadillac.
"Leningrad Cowboys" follows the band as it makes its unhurried way from New York to Memphis; New Orleans; Natchez, Miss.; Langtry, Tex.; Galveston, and, finally, Mexico.
The film observes the world through eyes that have never left home so that, though it was photographed on recognizable New World locations, every place looks like Finland. The occasional petrochemical plant, the ubiquitous suburbs and even the Louisiana bayous cannot disguise the truth. This is the world they left.
The only difference is the temperature: this particular Finland is warmer.
In isolated gigs along the way (all disastrous), the musicians learn for the first time about rock-and-roll and how to lip-sync the recordings of, among others, Herb Alpert and the Tijuana Brass. At some point, they even pick up a title song, about a Leningrad cowboy raising cattle on the steppes ("Won't you pour him another vodka/To help him to forget?").
 "Leningrad Cowboys" is a road movie, but not like any other. It rigorously avoids sociology, easy laughs or even irony.
Though Mr. Kaurismaki's films have been seen at the New York Film Festival, and have been the subject of a retrospective at Anthology Film Archives in Manhattan, this is his first film to receive a regular commercial theater run here. "Leningrad Cowboys" is not the ideal introduction to the Kaurismaki work, but it is a start.
Mr. Kaurismaki could well turn out to be the seminal European film maker of the 1990's. His films see all but appear to divulge nothing. They refuse to be surprised or to take sides.
They also seem to express the only sane response to the sudden collapse of the cold war and Eastern Europe's new enthusiasm for a kind of free economy that, elsewhere, is beginning to get the shakes. Mr. Kaurismaki's characters live in a world of dreadful timing, magnificently manifest in the music of the wild and crazy band in "Leningrad Cowboys."
 It's still too early to tell whether Mr. Kaurismaki will be as prolific as Rainer Werner Fassbinder, but eight features in seven years seems promising.
"Leningrad Cowboys" isn't much more than a shaggy-dog story, though a packed one. It's an extended cross-country sketch compared to his other films, which, though far more somber, are also funnier. "Leningrad Cowboys" is frequently less like the director's earlier work than like an homage to the films of Mr. Jarmusch.
The two men share a similar sensibility, but they approach their work from different directions. Mr. Jarmusch is, in his way, a kind of social historian. Whether he means to be or not, Mr. Kaurismaki is far more political.
It is this sense of purpose that, though never more than obliquely expressed in his other films, is missing from "Leningrad Cowboys." Yet the singular voice of the man who made it remains strong and clear.
"Leningrad Cowboys Go America," which has been rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned), has some vulgar language.
 
Leningrad Cowboys Go America
 
Directed by Aki Kaurismaki; screenplay (in English and Finnish with English subtitles) by Mr. Kaurismaki; story by Sakke Jarvenpaa, Mr. Kaurismaki, Mato Valtonen; edited by Raija Talvio; cinematography, Timo Dalminen; music by Mauri Sumen; produced by Mr. Kaurismaki, Klas Olofsson and Katinka Farago; released by Orion Classics. Running time: 80 minutes. At the Angelika Film Center, corner of Houston and Mercer Streets. This film is rated PG-13.
 
Vladimir . . . Matti Pellonpaa
Igor . . . Kari Vaananen
Car Dealer . . . Jim Jarmusch
Rock Promoter . . . Richard Boes
The Leningrad Cowboys . . . Sakke Jarvenpaa, Heikki Keskinen, Sakari Kuosmanen, Puka Oinonen, Silu Sepala, Mauri Sumen, Mato Valtonen, Pekka Virtanen

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Patience Is Strength

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The escalation of President Bush's rhetoric about Iraq and American hostages has led some to believe that he will soon order military action.
On the best information available, any such early turn to force is not likely. Apart from all the considerations of policy and law, military experts indicate that it will be another month at least before the United States has the necessary forces in the Persian Gulf. 
 Nor is it convincing to suggest, as some do, that Mr. Bush has talked tough just before Election Day for domestic political reasons -- to get voter attention away from his performance on the budget. That would be dangerous, and quite inconsistent with the way he has handled this crisis from the beginning.
Why, then, has the President begun to speak in emotional terms about hostages and U.S. diplomats caught in Kuwait? "The American flag is flying over the Kuwaiti embassy and our people inside are being starved by a brutal dictator," he said on Wednesday. "I have had it with that kind of treatment of Americans."
Such statements by Mr. Bush and Secretary of State Baker evidently had two purposes. One was to signal Saddam Hussein that the President was losing patience and might well turn to war. The other was to refocus the attention of the American public on the gulf and stiffen its resolve.
But if so, the statements seem miscalculated. On reflection, they show why the President should have stuck with the course he was on -- and should return to it.
From the start Mr. Bush had played down the hostage question. By doing so he made sure that it was not a serious limitation on his freedom of action. He had plainly learned from the terrible experience of President Carter, who found the issue of the hostages in Iran driving his policy.
Saddam Hussein wants his hostages to be the issue up front in people's minds. That is why he comes up with a new gimmick every day or two, releasing some hostages because of their nationality or state of health, now making the disgusting offer to let families visit those he is holding. He wants attention to be only on the hostages. Mr. Bush should not.
The heated statements are miscalculated in a deeper sense, too. They point Americans toward a belief that we must succeed in getting Iraq out of Kuwait at once, or our effort and the world's will have failed.
Again, that is a view that Saddam Hussein would almost certainly like to see take hold in the United States. He would like Americans to show impatience, a short attention span. It would suit him well if our public concluded that his aggression must be undone within a short time or he will have won -- and we then might as well give up.
What Saddam Hussein has to fear most is patient determination. United Nations sanctions are already beginning to hurt Iraq, running down its industry and its development projects. It has been able to sell almost no oil. The longer the coalition against him holds together, the worse it will get for him.
Patience is also an essential virtue for President Bush in terms of the last resort, making war. For he must know, and Saddam Hussein knows, that for serious, sustained military action an American President must have the support of his people and their representatives in Congress.
Members of Congress made the point bluntly when they met Mr. Bush this week. Senator Patrick Leahy of Vermont said: "Nobody asked the President to rule out a military option, but many of us told him to make sure that we don't use the military option out of impatience." Representative Dante Fascell of Florida said any claimed further provocation by Iraq had "better be real."
Just before Congress adjourned, 82 Democrats in the House signed a statement prepared by Representative Ronald Dellums of California. It said that the consequences of a war in the gulf would be "catastrophic," that sanctions must be given every chance to work, and that if Mr. Bush thinks force is necessary he must ask Congress for a declaration of war.
That statement, signed by nearly a third of House Democrats, shows that Congressional support for war cannot be taken for granted. It will require a convincing demonstration by the President that he and the United Nations have gone as far as they can on the course that he originally set: the course of collective economic and diplomatic pressure, with force as a last resort.
Mr. Bush needs to do some more educating on the stakes in the Persian Gulf. He needs to talk about strength and patience in resisting aggression -- and why they go together.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Bush Missed Golden Opportunity on Iraq

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Who Will Pay for the Gulf Crisis?" (editorial, Oct. 8) justly complains that the United States is taking on too great a burden in assuming most of the expense of containing Iraq. But calling for greater participation by our allies will not assure the Middle East nations that we realize the basic problem posed by Saddam Hussein's aggression is one they must solve for themselves, albeit with help from their friends. 
 President Bush had a golden opportunity to accomplish this after he had done such an outstanding job in convincing not only the Soviets but also 12 of the 21 members of the Arab League that it was in their interest to take a stand against Iraq. Successfully encouraging Egypt, Syria and Morocco to send combat troops to defend Saudi Arabia was even more extraordinary. Gaining United Nations approval of economic sanctions against Iraq climaxed his achievements in this international emergency.
Having accomplished what even the experts did not believe possible, he could have won even greater prestige throughout the Arab world -- at relatively little expense -- by acknowledging that the ground defense of Saudi Arabia should be left to troops from Arab nations and whatever third world countries might wish to join them. He could have guaranteed military hardware and supplies in whatever quantities those troops required, with United States forces limited to those on duty in the Persian Gulf and in our bases in Turkey.
This would not have interfered with our leading the effort to support the United Nations economic sanctions by a naval blockade of ships from many nations. Moreover, our Persian Gulf fleet would have assured a nearby reserve force that would be immediately available in the unlikely event that Saddam Hussein would be foolish enough to attack Saudi Arabia and run the threefold risk of earning the enmity of most of the Arab world, insuring an all-out attack by American planes and ships, and opening Iraq to a renewed assault by a still-vengeful Iran. Despite his bold talk, President Hussein has shown that he is not one to take such a risk.
Unfortunately, though President Bush has taken up the big stick that Vice President Theodore Roosevelt recommended in 1901, he has ignored Roosevelt's admonition to speak softly. Rather, he has so loudly and persistently announced his intention to wield that stick vigorously that he cannot turn back without tarnishing his image as a strong and forceful leader.
In that role, he has committed this country to an enormous military outlay that for an indefinite period will destroy all prospects for a balanced budget and reduction of the ever-growing national debt.
For this, his country will suffer in more ways than one. Some third world governments have expressed their dismay at what they see as Mr. Bush's pugnacious presumption of leadership in a dispute between Arab countries. The American people will be equally dismayed when they learn the price they must pay for his open-ended commitment of our military resources.
 
WILBUR EDEL
Mifflinburg, Pa., Oct. 8, 1990
 
The writer is professor emeritus of political science, Herbert H. Lehman College, CUNY.

HEADLINE: Religion Notes

BYLINE: Ari L. Goldman

 BODY:

Methodists Ponder Move
Little noticed in the flight of jobs, businesses and just plain people from New York City in recent years has been a host of church agencies moving their headquarters out of the city. The Lutherans have left for Chicago, the Presbyterians for Louisville and the United Church of Christ for Cleveland.
Now a major agency of the United Methodist Church is considering a move. The top staff official of the agency has argued, however, that it would be unbecoming of his agency to "turn our backs and walk away."
"When others say the Big Apple is rotten to the core, the people called United Methodists will say, 'No, it is merely ripe for mission,' " the Rev. Randolph Nugent, the general secretary of the Methodist's General Board of Global Ministries, told a board meeting last month in New York. The agency, which runs religious and social programs around the world, is the largest unit of the 8.9-million-member denomination. It has a $100 million budget and 500 employees, 140 of them in New York.
"The very location of our mission headquarters ought to be a symbol of attracting the attention of our constituency, standing firmly and faithfully in the midst of the world's woes," Dr. Nugent added.
But the head of the church group that is exploring the feasibility of moving the agency's headquarters said the decision would not be made on the basis of symbolism but on an economic analysis of where the board can most efficiently operate. The group's chairman, Randy Smith, a Houston lawyer, said, "I don't look at New York City as a mission any more than any other large city."
 
 Column May Return
 For the last few weeks, the nationally syndicated column of the Rev. Richard P. McBrien has been absent from The Brooklyn Tablet, the weekly newspaper of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn.
The head of the diocese, Bishop Thomas V. Daily, has in the past expressed his displeasure with Father McBrien, a liberal theologian at Notre Dame whose column appears in religious publications around the country. When Bishop Daily was head of the diocese at Palm Beach, Fla., the conservative prelate ordered the McBrien column dropped from the local Catholic paper.
But Ed Wilkinson, editor of The Brooklyn Tablet, said the column has not met the same fate in Brooklyn, at least not yet. "It's really a matter of space consideration," Mr. Wilkinson said. The paper has been carrying fewer pages than normal in recent weeks, he said, "and we feel more of a commitment to print our local columnists than our syndicated columnists."
Asked about Bishop Daily's reaction to Father McBrien, the editor said: "He told me he doesn't like him because he shows too much disrespect for the Holy Father. But he did not give me a directive to get him out of the paper."
If he got such a directive, Mr. Wilkinson said, he would drop the column. In addition to being the Bishop of Brooklyn, Bishop Daily is the publisher of The Tablet.
Mr. Wilkinson added, however, that he likes the column. "The reason I like McBrien so much is because he gets a lot of reaction. McBrien is a lightning rod. There are times when letters about him, pro and con, can fill the entire Readers' Forum page. When you're putting out a newspaper you like to get reaction."
 
 Baptist Church Move
 Theologians, individuals and even a few universities have severed their affiliation with the Southern Baptist Convention in recent years as a result of the struggle between fundamentalists and moderates in the 15-million-member denomination.
Now comes word that a church has followed suit. The 570-member Grace Baptist Church in the Richmond neighborhood of Windsor Farms announced last week that it is indefinitely suspending its participation in the denomination by ending all contributions to its national ministries.
Church officials said the congregation had been disturbed by the dominance of fundamentalists who wanted to impose their interpretations of the Bible on the policies, agencies and institutions of the denomination. The pastor of Grace Baptist, the Rev. James B. Johnson 2d, said that delegates to the annual Southern Baptist Convention reported back this year, "We were not welcome there."
At the most recent convention, held last June in New Orleans, an effort by moderates, including people like the delegates from Grace Baptist, failed to unseat the fundamentalist leadership for the 12th year in a row.
A resolution adopted by the Grace Baptist's Church Council said that congregation "recognizes and honors its proud heritage" as a Southern Baptist church but added that it will not reaffiliate until the denomination's leadership has "returned to those tenets and philosophies that are compatible with this congregation."
Stan Hastey, executive director of the Southern Baptist Alliance, which is composed of moderates, said he has heard of several congregations withholding funds from the denomination because of displeasure with the fundamentalists at the helm. But he said that Grace Baptist was the first "that has declared itself per se inactive with respect to the Southern Baptist Convention."
 
 Realignment at the Top
 Some major appointments in the religion world are expected to be made in the next few days. The National Council of Churches, which represents more than 30 Protestant, Anglican and Eastern Orthodox denominations, is expected to name a new general secretary when it meets on Nov. 14-16 in Portland, Ore. The new executive will succeed James A. Hamilton, who chose not to seek re-election. In addition, the National Conference of Christians and Jews, which has 70 regional offices around the country, is expected to name a president to succeed Jacqueline G. Wexler, who is retiring after eight years in the job.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metals Off Sharply In Heavy Japanese Selling

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Precious metal futures prices fell sharply yesterday, led by a drop of more than $15 an ounce in the price of platinum amid heavy Japanese selling.
Platinum futures settled $15.10 to $15.90 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange with the spot price at $416.60 and the actively traded contract for January delivery at $420.60 an ounce. 
 Gold finished $5.10 to $5.50 lower on the Commodity Exchange in New York, with the December contract at $377.80 an ounce. The November contract closed at $376.40, off $5.10. Silver was 7.1 cents to 7.8 cents lower, with December at $4.185 an ounce.
The selloff wiped out most of the price gains registered in precious metals earlier in the week.
Analysts said lower Japanese stock prices and weak United States economic data prompted heavy selling of platinum on perceptions that industrial demand for the metal will decline as economic conditions worsen.
"A good part of the selling was coming from the Japanese," said Don Tierney, metals analyst with Fortune Commodities Inc. "Whenever their stock market falls off, they've got to sell some of their platinum to lighten up on their holdings."
Yesterday's sharp drop in oil prices was also cited as a sign of easing inflationary pressures. And several analysts said gold futures weakened because of Middle Eastern sales of gold bullion and perceptions that more Middle Eastern selling could occur over the weekend.
"This seems to be a pattern we've developed on Fridays: traders get quite nervous and sell out because of fears of weekend sales from the Middle East," said Peter Cardillo, of the futures brokerage Jesup, Josephthal & Company.
Mr. Tierney said buying by Swiss and United States investors lifted gold off its lows. The November gold contract traded as low as $376.10 an ounce during the session.
Pork belly futures soared their permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, aided by higher prices for fresh bellies. Analysts said belly demand by bacon makers remained strong.
Cattle futures ended mixed in dull trading.
Grain and soybean futures ended mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybeans sold off late in the session amid disappointment that President Bush did not announce export credits to the Soviet Union yesterday as some analysts had expected.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops After Reports Show Economic Weakness

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday after two Government reports provided further evidence that the economy is weakening and promoted speculation, analysts said, that the Federal Reserve would push interest rates lower.
The Labor Department said the unemployment rate was unchanged last month from the 5.7 percent of September, but nonfarm payrolls fell by 68,000, indicating that companies have less need for workers. The Government also reported that its chief economic forecasting gauge, the Index of Leading Economic Indicators, dropped eight-tenths of a percent in September, the second straight monthly drop. 
 Foreign exchange markets sold the dollar after the reports were released, believing the data would put more pressure on the Fed to nudge interest rates lower as a means of stimulating the economy. Lower interest rates are bad news for the dollar because they reduce the yield on investments denominated in dollars.
Jack Barbanel, a market analyst with First Global Asset Management Inc., said the dollar was further hurt by Germany's decision on Thursday to raise a key interest rate, the Lombard rate. The increase provided more support for the German mark.
The dollar fell to 1.4945 marks in New York yesterday, from 1.5035 late Thursday. In earlier European trading, the dollar fell to 1.5020 German marks, from 1.5070.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a close of 129.10 Japanese yen, from 130.70 yen on Thursday. Later, in London, it fell to 128.50 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 127.78 yen, down from 130.56.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.9515, from $1.9525 late Thursday. But in New York, the pound rose to $1.9590, from $1.9450.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Thursday, included: 1.2605 Swiss francs, down from 1.2735; 5.0180 French francs, down from 5.0410; 1,123.75 Italian lire, down from 1,127.25, and 1.16475 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16425.

HEADLINE: Price of Oil Drops $1.17 In Calm Day

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
As the Persian Gulf crisis turned three months old yesterday, oil prices fell $1.17 a barrel in a weary futures market that traders said has lost its enthusiasm for going wild on news and rumors.
"They're not looking at every headline now and saying: Buy, because Saddam said this," said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. "They're waiting for something real." 
 Crude oil for December delivery closed at $34 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Contracts for delivery in later months also settled lower.
For the week, crude for near-term delivery rose 99 cents. Oil traders said it was by far the slowest week since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.
"You're in a very narrow range on very light volume," said Ed Kevelson, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
Analysts attributed yesterday's drop to perceptions that President Bush's latest comments about President Saddam Hussein of Iraq were softer than a day earlier.
Mr. Bush has been attacking the Iraqi leader sharply most of the week, but traders have paid little attention because the comments have come on the campaign trail, where the President is stumping for Republicans running in the elections on Tuesday.
"If he's out there campaigning and he's down in Florida, can he really start a war from there?" Mr. Blakeslee said.
Petroleum products also fell yesterday.
Unleaded gasoline dropped 3.09 cents, to 89.21 cents a gallon for December delivery, with later months also down. The near-term contract finished the week down 2.26 cents.
Home heating oil fell 2.95 cents, to 87.42 cents a gallon for December delivery. Later contract months were all lower. For the week, heating oil dropped 0.83 cent.
Natural gas for December delivery settled at $2.358 a 1,000 cubic feet, up 0.8 cent from Thursday.

HEADLINE: Nebraska Governor in Fight To Save Her Political Career

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OMAHA, Nov. 1

 BODY:
With Nebraska's unemployment rate at 2.1 percent, the nation's lowest, and the state's farm economy as healthy as it has been in a decade, political logic would suggest that Gov. Kay A. Orr should have little trouble winning re-election next week.
But Mrs. Orr, the nation's first and only Republican female governor, is fighting for her political life in a tight and sometimes meanly fought campaign with Ben Nelson, the Democratic challenger and a political newcomer who has never held elective office. 
 Governor Orr, who is 51 years old, has been dogged during most of her first term by the same problem that has afflicted other Republicans, from President Bush on down: a perception among voters that the Governor went back on a campaign pledge she made four years ago not to raise taxes.
The higher taxes came after Nebraska adjusted its state tax codes in 1987. Although Governor Orr at first denied that there had been any tax increase, growing ire among voters led her earlier this year to acknowledge that she had driven up some people's taxes -- inadvertently, she said -- and then to issue a public apology in an attempt to limit political damage.
 
Polls Have Changed
 Public opinion polls last summer seemed to give her little chance of re-election. But in the most recent poll, released over the weekend, the two are running even.
James E. Johnson, a professor of political science at the University of Nebraska at Omaha, said he thought Mrs. Orr had regained some ground by admitting her mistake and then throwing her support behind a plan to roll back taxes.
"But there is a residue," Mr. Johnson said. "Voters believed she not only increased taxes, but then lied about the fact she didn't."
The Nebraska contest has special significance for Republicans nationally, not only because the Governor is a woman but because of her profile within the national party.
With the backing of Bush supporters, Governor Orr was named chairwoman of the platform committee at the 1988 Republican National Convention.
 
More Republicans in State
 In winning her first term in 1986, Mrs. Orr defeated Helen Boosalis, the Democratic mayor of Lincoln, in the nation's first contest for governor in which two women representing the two major parties competed.
Although registered Republicans outnumber Democrats in Nebraska, and the state historically goes strongly Republican in Presidential elections, no Republican governor has been re-elected to a second term here since 1957.
In recent years, the state has also sent two Democrats to the United States Senate. The senior senator, former Gov. Jim Exon, seems assured of winning re-election to a third term next week. He has a substantial lead in the polls over Hal Daub, a former Republican Congressman from Omaha.
Mr. Nelson, who is 49 years old, won the Democratic primary last spring only after a recount upheld his slim margin of 41 votes. Even so, party regulars have united behind his campaign, and his background as a insurance executive seems to appeal to many Republican voters.
 
Tax Issue Is Raised
 The Democratic strategy so far has been to keep strong pressure on Mrs. Orr on the tax question, and try to depict her as a big spender who cannot be trusted.
In response, Republicans have unleashed a barrage of accusations against Mr. Nelson, raising questions about his financial and business dealings, and criticizing him for refusing to make public his income tax returns, as the Governor has.
As is the case in other states, there is a widely shared perception here that this season's political campaigns are more negative than usual. The Omaha World-Herald, the state's largest newspaper, wrote an editorial this week: "How revolting this year's political season has become. It's hard not to turn away in disgust."
Pepper Horvatich, who farms with her husband in Hooper, a small town about 50 miles west of here, said she was so repulsed by the ads she did not know which candidate to support. "Times like this you wish there was a third party," she said.
Professor Johnson and others expect a strong turnout on Election Day, in part because of several ballot initiatives that have drawn wide public interest, including a referendum that would put an annual cap of 2 percent on increases in state spending.
 
Anger Over Dump Site
 Governor Orr's campaign has also run into turbulence in rural northeast Nebraska, where she has backed a plan to situate a low-level nuclear waste dump that would serve Nebraska and surrounding states.
The Republican organization in Boyd County, the site of the planned dump, was so incensed by her support for the plan that it endorsed Mr. Nelson.
Mrs. Orr and other Republicans running statewide are also closely watching an unexpectedly tight Congressional race in western Nebraska, where Representative Virginia Smith, the dean of Republican women in Congress, is retiring after 16 years.
In recent years, the popular Mrs. Smith provided some long coattails for other Republicans by ritually running up winning close to 80 percent of the vote. But Democrats are making a race of it this fall, with Sandy Scofield, a state legislator, running neck and neck in the opinion polls with Bill Barrett, a Republican.
 
Help on the Trail
 With the campaign in its final days, Mr. Nelson took to the stump this week at the side of Senator Bob Kerrey, the popular former Governor.
But Mrs. Orr, who has outspent her Democratic opponent two to one, was accompanied by an even more potent figure on a six-city tour of the state Wednesday. At her side was Bob Devaney, the athletic director at the University of Nebraska, and a man venerated for making the Nebraska football team a national powerhouse.
At a stop in Omaha, Mr. Devaney received as big a hand as the Governor when he assured the crowd that the Cornhuskers, who are currently unbeaten and ranked third in the nation, would not have been as successful without the support of Governor Orr.

HEADLINE: Democratic Candidates Shying From Florio

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Democratic candidates in New Jersey this fall have generally avoided appearing on the stump with Jim Florio, the Governor who a year ago was elected with 62 percent of the vote. The reason is his $2.8 billion in tax increases, a program that has helped drive his approval ratings in polls below 20 percent.
But despite finding himself treated as if he were a man with the flu, the Governor continues to defend his program, just as he continues to voice faith in the future of class politics for Democrats.
Ignoring criticism and the polls with a persistence that makes some fellow Democrats nervous, he insists that promoting what he regards as sound policy will eventually be rewarded politically. 
 "The polls and politics of the moment come and go," said Mr. Florio, who will not face re-election until 1993. "We're in this for the long haul."
The loneliness of Mr. Florio's approach seemed highlighted on Thursday night, when he appeared on a dais at an EssexCounty Democratic dinner with New Jersey's two Senators.
Mr. Bradley, the state's senior Senator who appears highly popular as he seeks a third term, talked about the possibilities for America created by the end of the cold war, and he urged support for local candidates. Not once did he mention Mr. Florio, who sat only yards away.
Mr. Florio, by contrast, praised Mr. Bradley and repeated his theme that Republicans will now be seen as the protectors of the rich who have lacked the courage for tough decisions.
"The Democratic tide is rising," Mr. Florio said. "Their decade, for the speculators, is over."
Then the state's junior Senator, Frank R.Lautenberg, sang the praises of Mr. Bradley. And he said of Mr. Florio: "Now, Jim Florio may not be somebody with whom you always agree, but Jim Florio stands up for what he believes in."
Mr. Florio's tax program, enacted in June by the Legislature, raised the sales tax one percentage point to close a budget gap. It also raised income taxes for the top 17 percent of wage earners. The administration said it did this to increase aid to less affluent school districts and to middle-class homeowners. Mr. Florio says middle-income New Jerseyans will support the program when they receive larger property tax rebates next year.
Since Labor Day, Mr. Florio has appeared at several Democratic fund-raising dinners, where he has generally been received warmly. He has also made a number of joint appearances with one of three Democrats in special legislative elections, Edward H. Salmon, who is running for the State Senate in Ocean County.
He has plunged into crowds on behalf of Democrats around his old district near Phil adelphia and at a campaign appearance Thursday in Hudson County, two heavily Democratic areas.
But in the 13 congressional races, most Democrats have preferred to keep Mr. Florio at a distance. Even a onetime Florio follower, Robert Andrews, running for the Governor's old seat in the First Congressional District, has criticized parts of the Governor's tax plan.
In the 12th District, Marguerite Chandler went from standing by Mr. Florio's side during the tax battle last June to taking out radio ads attacking the plan after his popularity plummeted this fall.
Mr. Bradley has refused to comment on the Florio tax package, saying it is a state matter, not a Federal one. Mr. Florio has not appeared with him at campaign stops.
Meanwhile, Mr. Florio has given a series of speeches on the state's problems in education and in dealing with AIDS and on his plans for new construction projects to stimulate the economy.
 
Few Signs of Forgiveness
 But a number of Republicans and Democrats in the state believe he may be making a severe political miscalculation. Though recent polls indicate that support for Republicans has eroded in New Jersey and around the nation since President Bush's deadlock with Congress over the Federal budget, there is no evidence from polls or local campaigns that many people are forgiving Governor Florio.
Steven A. Salmore, a Republican consultant, said that while voters may eventually forget a tax increase, they will probably remember Mr. Florio as a man who raised taxes with enthusiasm just months after promising in his election campaign that he "saw no need" for new taxes.
"The reaction is twofold," Mr. Salmore said. "One is to the taxes. The other is to the person. It is not just that he went back on his promise not to raise taxes. It is that he went back gleefully."
In July, the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University released a poll showing that the percentage of New Jerseyans who viewed Mr. Florio favorably had dropped to less than 25 percent right after the taxes were passed. But perhaps most devastating to the Governor was a poll released Oct. 14. It showed that after months of speaking out in the state on behalf of his tax program, he was seen even more unfavorably.
"He could talk about something else, anything else," one Democratic official said of Mr. Florio's talk of taxes. "Here's a horse that keeps on coming in dead last every time, and they keep saying, 'Let's get on that horse and ride it again.' "

HEADLINE: Wilding Youth And Homeless: A Blood Feud

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
The footbridge between Wards Island and Manhattan arches between two groups of people who dislike each other despite their shared struggle against poverty and drugs.
On one side, hundreds of homeless men struggling to find work and housing live in a shelter that is rife with drug abuse and its running mates, prostitution and robbery. On the other side of the bridge live the striving poor of the East River Houses and other tenements. 
 In the wake of the Halloween attacks on the homeless that killed one man, the police are focusing their investigation on the projects and adjoining neighborhoods, where young men on the street say there was no love lost between them and the homeless, whom they described as crack addicts and worse.
Investigators believe the attackers, who wore Halloween masks and wielded knives and bats, were from the neighborhood because they apparently knew that the homeless men in the shelter habitually cross the drawbridge shortly before 10 P.M., when it is raised for the night, Capt. Daniel McKenna of the Manhattan Detectives said.
"We're pretty comfortable they came out of that area," said Captain McKenna. "They knew the bridge."
That theory is bolstered by a history of similar assaults by local youths against the homeless during the last two years, Captain McKenna said. Detectives yesterday were interviewing people arrested in a series of attacks on the bridge in early 1989. "We've got a couple of people we have spoken to in the area," the captain said. But, he said, no one had been arrested by last night.
In interviews, shelter residents said the youths from the projects attack them several times a week for sport, sometimes robbing them of the few dollars they have from welfare payments or jobs. Many said they do not report the attacks.
On the other side of the water, local youths accused the shelter residents of being crack addicts who bring prostitution and crime to their asphalt courtyards and playgrounds.
"They be coming into our park and smoking crack," said Vincent Perez, 16, a student at Julia Richman High School. "They expose themselves to little children. Especially at night. We can't even play in the park anymore. They snatch old ladies purses."
 
'All These Things Boil Up'
 Another youth, Raymond Page, 20, said: "All these things boil up together and people take the holiday of Halloween to pay back the homeless. They figure nobody will say anything about it because most of the people are crackheads."
The homeless say such sentiments are evidence of a growing bigotry. They say the youths, who have little opportunity themselves, want to set themselves above others.
"They treat us like we're dogs, or dirt," said one homeless man, Pete Williams, 27. "They walk over us."
But other homeless residents acknowleged that the dark, weed-choked woods at the foot of the bridge on the island are flooded with people smoking crack at night and that some residents of the shelter mug people coming off the bridge. The criminals among the homeless have given the youths an excuse for violence, they said.
 
'Let's Go Beat Them Up'
 "You've got a large number of people doped out over here, hanging out in the open," said a 40-year-old homeless man who asked to be identified as Ronald. "It gives them a reason to look down on us. They say, 'Hey, there's a bunch of crackheads. Let's go beat them up.' "
In interviews, several youths in the East River Houses confirmed that they had seen other youths assault homeless people on the bridge for fun. All said they had not participated in the Halloween attack, although some acknowleged attacking shelter residents in the past.
"Some people want to just beat them up for nothing," said Robert Raveneu, 15. "Every day you see it."
The youths said the gang attacks on homeless people were part of the hip-hop generation's form of recreational crime sometimes called "wilding." In its mildest form, they said, roving teen-agers, who may only know each other loosely, collect on the street and raid department stores en masse, knocking down the clerks and absconding with goods.
 
Peer Pressure and Hate
 "They go block to block, and they get bigger and bigger," said Jarrell Vulture, 18. "Then they go do their thing."
Sometimes "their thing" includes robbing people purely for excitement, Mr. Vulture said. Worse, as in the Central Park jogger case and Wednesday's attacks, the violence sometimes escalates to rape and murder. Several youths said beating or knifing someone raised them in the eyes of their peers.
But Mr. Page said the attacks on the homeless were "a mix between peer pressure and hate."
"You look around and see a neighborhood going to pot" because of the homeless, he said.
"If you slice somebody up around here and people find out, that makes you look big," said Mr. Perez. "Everybody says it makes you feel big."
 
Fair Fights Are Old-Fashioned
 The notion of a fair fight in these encounters is outdated, the youths said, and pulling a knife or ganging up on a victim is praiseworthy because the attackers outwitted their prey. The worst possible fate is to be a "sucker" or be "caught playing out of position" -- be caught unawares.
On Wards Island, the attacks have left homeless men terrified, complaining that the police do not patrol the island and the city has failed to put lights along the dark path between the bridge and the Charles H. Gay mens's shelter where most of the muggings take place.
Keith Summa, an advocate with the Coalition for the Homless, said attacks against homeless people have been rising steadily for the last two years.
In a shanty town on Wards Island yesterday, Michael Gonsalves, a 31-year-old unemployed laborer, gingerly touched his cheek, which was ripped open from his left ear to his upper lip by a meat cleaver on Wednesday night, and said he fully expected more attacks at Thanksgiving and Christmas.
"Every holiday they do it," Mr. Gonsalves said. "On holidays it's fair game. They just go for it."

HEADLINE: Leading Indicators Drop Again

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
The Government index designed to forecast turning points in the economy skidded eight-tenths of 1 percent in September, its second straight monthly drop, the Commerce Department reported today.
Nine of the 11 components of the index of leading indicators declined, paced by tumbling stock market prices. 
 The report, combined with separate figures the Government reported today on labor market conditions during October, thickened the gloom over economic prospects and left only a few diehards contending that a recession may still be avoided.
 
 'Prospect Is Inevitable'

 "The United States economy is headed for a recession, if it's not already begun," said Robert L. Marks of Siff, Oakley & Marks, a New York consulting firm. "That prospect is inevitable."
As a rule of thumb, a string of three straight declines in the leading index is regarded as pointing to an economic downturn. The decline for September followed a 1.2 percent fall in August and a reading of unchanged for July after a gain of one-tenth of 1 percent in June.
The index sometimes predicts recessions that do not occur, however, as when it recorded four straight declines starting with October 1987, at the time of the stock market collapse, and the three months following.
 
Drop in Coincident Indicators
 Meanwhile, a companion index that gauges current economic conditions, the index of coincident indicators, fell for the third straight month in September, the first time this has happened since 1982, the year in which the latest recession ended and which marked the beginning of a record-length peacetime expansion.
The decline of eight-tenths of 1 percent in the leading index was largely as expected, since most of its components have been published previously. But the report nonetheless contributed to the conviction among most economists that a recession was no longer avoidable.
The only element in the index to rise was a fairly large rebound, to July levels, in contracts and orders placed by companies for new plant and equipment. Many companies have continued to invest in such modernization this year to remain efficient and competitive but analysts said today that this may be fading, too.
The components that contributed to the index decline, besides lower stock prices, were, in order, a decline in manufacturers' new orders for consumer goods and materials, an increase in weekly initial claims for state unemployment insurance, declines in building permits, consumer expectations, manufacturers' unfilled orders, the money supply, a speedup in deliveries by vendors and a drop in the price of materials that are particularly sensitive to the business cycle.
The Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, is believed to regard vendor performance -- represented as the percentage of companies reporting slower deliveries from suppliers -- as highly revealing because of what it says about possible bottlenecks in the production chain. For September, the index edged down to 49.9 percent, from 51.1 percent, suggesting slightly speedier deliveries as the economy slackens.
 
 No Change in Work Week

The 11th component, the length of the average work week, was unchanged for September. Today's Labor Department report on the job market in October, however, showed a big decline in working hours throughout the private sector.
The jobless report also showed that, although the October unemployment rate remained unchanged at 5.7 percent, employment fell by 187,000 as measured by the household survey and 68,000 as measured by business payrolls.
The Commerce Department's index of lagging indicators, those that tend to move only after the economy turns, eased two-tenths of 1 percent in September. This meant that the ratio of coincident and lagging indicators, which economists consider an alternate predictor of turns in the economy, moved down to 1.1299 from 1.1322.
A private forecasting index compiled by Safian Investment Research in New York fell 1.4 percent in September, its lowest point since January 1987. Of its 23 components, 15 declined, 7 rose and 1 was unchanged.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN;
In Switch of Campaign Tactics, the Kinder, Gentler Bush Emerges

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, Minn., Nov. 2

 BODY:
With some advisers urging him to be Harry Truman and some pressing him to be Dwight Eisenhower, President Bush has finally come down on the side of Mr. Eisenhower.
Mr. Bush has abruptly dropped the slash-and-burn approach he had planned to use through Election Day, modeled on the way Harry Truman campaigned in 1948 as a fiery Washington "outsider," criticizing the Government he was running and the opposition party. 
 Instead, Mr. Bush is trying to take a moderate, bipartisan approach, one that seems more Presidential and that some of his advisers refer to, in shorthand, as "Eisenhower."
With an implicit acknowledgement that it does not play well to denounce Democrats as big taxers so soon after cooperating with them to raise taxes as part of a budget compromise, and that it is difficult to run as an outsider when he has developed an image as an insider, Mr. Bush has put aside the scorching speech he unveiled on Monday at the Cowboy Hall of Fame in Oklahoma City.
 
Old Aide's New Influence
 The speech was a blistering catalogue of the Democrats sins, accusing them of slowing the economy and stalling the budget deal for partisan gain, mortgaging the future of children and turning their backs on the American dream, stuffing the budget with pork barrel items and behaving with arrogance, ineptitude and selfishness.
His chief of staff, John H. Sununu, and Mr. Sununu's aide Ed Rogers, who is the de facto head of the White House political office, liked the aggressive speech.
But White House officials said that Robert Teeter, a longtime Bush strategist who lives in Michigan but who has been spending more time at the White House of late to help get it out of a slump, found the speech too unstatesmanlike. Moreover, he thought the President could not get away with the attacks on the Democrats over taxes so soon after working with them on the budget deal.
Mr. Teeter is a poll taker who was a strategist for Ronald Reagan and in the Bush campaign. Early in Mr. Bush's Administration Mr. Sununu quashed an attempt to have Mr. Teeter work in the White House as a Presidential counselor, in a position equal to the chief of staff. But now the two men are working together.
"The President decided he wanted a more positive tone in the last five days," said the White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater.
The first speech got a fast response from Democratic leaders, who accused Mr. Bush of cynically ignoring the fact that he had spent much of his Presidency promoting the idea of governing with a bipartisan consensus. Mr. Bush's five months of budget negotiations were, after all, the epitome of Washington deal-making.
 
Some 'Flamboyant Rhetoric'
 Yet even with a tilt toward a new tone today, the President continued to offer a little "flamboyant rhetoric," as he calls it, against "liberal" Democrats.
"The Democrats wanted to do it all by raising taxes, including income tax rate increases for working Americans with that insidious indexing provision," he told a rally in Rochester, Minn., for Senator Rudy Boschwitz. "And thanks to Rudy and others up there, we beat it. Beat it to its knees."
The crowd at John Marshall High School was enthusiastic as the President promised that Saddam Hussein of Iraq would "pay the price" for bullying his neighbors.
But Mr. Bush's devotion to bipartisanship does prevent his rallies from having a punchy, rousing partisan pitch.
His new speech, which he is giving in campaign appearances in eight states before the next Tuesday's elections, focuses mainly on the accomplishments of his Administration and on the Persian Gulf crisis.
He says his Administration has made strides in child care and raising awareness of the war on drugs and in anti-crime legislation.
"Our agenda is not fulfilled," he said today, "but our ideas are still strong and they're still sound."
 
Hitler Reference Disappears
 Mr. Bush continued today to make a reference to Harry Truman, but merely to note that the buck does indeed stop at his desk, and that is why he had to compromise on a budget deal. Mr. Bush's Clint Eastwood sneer, and the majority of his most inflammatory lines have been put aside. Instead he talks about how supportive Democrats have been on the Persian Gulf issue.
"I will say at the very outset that regardless of the politics, the Democratic leaders in the House and the Democratic leaders in the Senate have been extraordinarily cooperative," he said.
In a bow to criticism about his comparison of Saddam Hussein to Hitler, Mr. Bush dropped that reference from today's speeches.
His focus on the Persian Gulf has provoked some charges that he is using the issue for partisan gain, trying to strengthen his own floundering fortunes and those of Republican candidates hurt by coming tax increases and the curdling economy.
Asked whether he should talk about the Middle East crisis at rallies with political flags behind him, Mr. Bush replied at his press conference on Thursday: "I go to great ends to make sure that I give proper credit to the Democrats and the Republicans in Congress; make clear that this is not a partisan effort that we're involved in here."
 
Awkward Relationship
 Mr. Bush's sometimes-awkward relationship with Republican candidates was underscored again tonight when he arrived for a rally in Sioux City, Iowa.
Representative Fred Grandy of Iowa, who once played the character Gopher on the television program "Love Boat," shared the stage with Mr. Bush. But only a week or so ago, one of Mr. Grandy's top aides was quoted by The Associated Press saying that Mr. Grandy did not want to use any advertising linked to the President because the budget ordeal had made Mr. Bush "radioactive."
Nodding to Senator Charles Grassley of Iowa, who was on stage with him, Mr. Bush said dryly: "I'm glad to be standing here with a Senator who does support me."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush with Senator Rudy Boschwitz at a rally in Rochester, Minn., where Mr. Bush campaigned yesterday for fellow Republicans. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Credit Markets Calm, Awaiting Auctions

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
After an early flurry of activity, trading in Treasury securities declined yesterday as most market participants moved to the sidelines to await the Government's record refunding auctions next week. Prices were minimally higher late in the day.
The day's most important economic indicator, the Government's report on October employment, contributed to the dismal picture of the economy but was considered positive on balance for the bond market and prompted some buying after it was released just before the opening. 
 While the unemployment rate was unchanged at 5.7 percent, the number of nonfarm jobs declined by 68,000 in October.
 
 Data Had Been Anticipated
 "Looking beyond the raw numbers, the bond market was buoyed by the big drop in hours worked and earnings last month," said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president of Dean Witter Reynolds. "As usual, any negative economic news is welcome by the fixed-income market."
In any event, Mr. Sullivan said the jobless data had been largely expected and absorbed on Thursday, when bond prices soared on speculation that the new signs of economic distress would prompt the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates further. After brief carry-over buying at the opening yesterday, Mr. Sullivan added, "the market's major preoccupation was positioning for next week's record $34.25 billion refunding auctions."
On Tuesday, the Treasury will auction $12.5 billion of three-year notes, followed by $11 billion of 10-year notes the next day and $10.75 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday. The three issues each rose a basis point, or a hundredth of a percentage point, in trading on a when-issued basis.
Thus, the anticipated yields are 7.84 percent for the three-year notes; 8.55 percent for the 10-year notes, and 8.69 percent for the 30-year bonds.
In late trading in the secondary debt market, the new 7.75 percent notes of 1992, auctioned on Wednesday at an average yield of 7.84 percent, were offered at 100 5/32, off 1/32 on the day, and now yield 7.66 percent.
 Because of a recent increase in basic interest rates in Germany and Japan, where 10-year bonds are considered bellwether issues, attention was again focused on the Treasury's 10-year notes.
Late in the day, the Treasury's long notes, the 8.75 percent issue that matures in August 2000, were offered at 101 8/32, down 3/32 on the day, to yield 8.55 percent, compared with 8.62 percent a week ago. By comparison, the 10-year Japanese bonds fell to 7.73 percent, from 7.87 percent on Friday, and the 10-year German bonds dipped a basis point, to 8.97 percent.
 
 Yield Up on Long Bonds
 The Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75's of August 2020, were offered late in the day at 100 21/32, off 2/32. The yield rose to 8.68 percent, from 8.67 the day before. But the long bond's yield was well below the 8.77 percent of a week ago.
At the short end of the market, the discount rate on 90-day bills rose 3 basis points, to 7.09 percent; six-month bills gained 2 basis points, to 7.05 percent, and one-year bills rose 3 basis points, to 6.88 percent.

HEADLINE: SHARP DROP FOUND IN NUMBER OF JOBS IN U.S. WORKPLACE

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
The number of jobs in the nation declined markedly in October, particularly in construction and manufacturing. The unemployment rate remained steady at 5.7 percent, but only because the number of Americans looking for work also shrank, the Government reported today.
The figures, the first comprehensive view of economic performance in October, were the latest in a nearly unbroken successsion of recent reports reflecting various degrees of stagnation or contraction of business activity. The data prompted more economists to join a growing chorus of experts who have declared the demise of the record peacetime expansion that began in 1982. 
 The Labor Department's survey of businesses found that the number of jobs fell 68,000 in October, following a 52,000 decline in September. The layoff of temporary census workers was no longer a significant factor in the figures as it has been for much of the year. The September figures were revised slightly for the better, offsetting a revision in the other direction for August.
 
More Bleak News
 The job report, along with another Government report on the economy, thickened the gloom over economic prospects. The Government index for forecasting turning points in the economy skidded by eight-tenths of 1 percent in September, its second straight monthly drop. Nine of the 11 components of the index of leading indicators declined. [Page 33.]
In an appearance before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, which received the jobs report this morning, Lawrence Chimerine, an economist for Data Resources Inc., gave a dismal view of the economy. "As of right now it is declining quite rapidly," he told the panel. He said he foresaw a "moderate" recession that would extend to mid-1991. But he said it was quite possible that the contraction would be deeper and longer.
 
Opposing Points of View
 His pessimistic view was seconded by Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist for Merrill Lynch, who raised the possibility that because of the fragile condition of banks and other financial institutions, "we could end up with the longest and most severe" recession since World War II.
But Lawrence A. Kudlow, a former Reagan Administration official who is now chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company, dissented. While asserting that recession risks were real and that tax increases would make them worse, Mr. Kudlow said the economy was still slowly moving ahead. Recession remains "only a forecast," he added.
Asked whether the nation was in a recession, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Janet L. Norwood, said, "I don't really know." But she repeatedly pointed to signs of a weak economy.
As a rule of thumb, the economy is considered to be in recession after two consecutive quarters of decline in the gross national product, the total output of goods and services. For the last six quarters, the nation's economy has been growing very sluggishly, but there has not been a decline in any quarter.
 
Factory and Construction Losses
 The job report included strong evidence of an accelerating slide, with 80,000 construction jobs and 61,000 factory jobs lost in October. The construction industry's unemployment rate rose to 13.2 percent from 11.8 percent. The further disappearance of factory jobs brought the total of lost jobs to 175,000 for the latest three months. All told, 580,000 factory jobs have been lost since the peak employment level of January 1989, a total decline of 3 percent. For the third straight month, more industries lost jobs than gained them and there was a widely spread drop of a full half-hour, to 34.2 hours, in the length of the average workweek in the private sector.
The combination of fewer workers and shorter hours produced what Jeffrey R. Leeds, a senior economist at Chemical Bank, called a "very sharp" 1.6 percent skid in the index of the total number of hours worked in October, which fell to 123.3. This barometer had been steady in the third quarter, standing at 125.3 in both June and September.
 
Pressure on Monetary Policy
 While neither the Labor Department's report nor the Commerce Department report on its Index of Leading Indicators was a major surprise, the bleak news appeared to increase pressure on the Federal Reserve to further relax monetary policy by putting more money into the banking system, which in turn has the effect of trimming short-term interest rates.
The stock market appeared to rally on this prospect but for various reasons, including a weak dollar and the military confrontation in the Persian Gulf, analysts were not convinced that the Fed, which made a small cut on Monday, would move quickly.
In her monthly interpretation of the job figures for Congress, Dr. Norwood noted that the trend in payroll jobs had weakened each month since June as sizable declines in goods-producing jobs had barely been offset by gains in service jobs. "Indeed, even the usually robust service sector has lost much of its vitality during the period," she added. Much of the growth in service jobs occurred in the health-care field, which does relatively little to stimulate the economy. The health industry accounts for 12 percent of private employment but has produced 39 percent of the growth in private-service jobs over the past year.
In all, the economy generated 74,000 new service jobs last month but this was more than offset by a 142,000 drop in goods-producing jobs. Retail trade lost about 50,000 jobs, including 15,000 in department stores where early holiday hiring fell short of expectations.
Just under 45 percent of industries were adding to payrolls last month, the same as in September, but for manufacturing industries these optimists represent a decided minority of 37.8 percent, down from 48.2 percent as recently as July. Wholesale trade lost 10,000 jobs as problems in manufacturing and construction continued to hurt employment in distribution, the report also showed.
The department's separate survey of households showed that the ranks of those who had lost their last jobs, as opposed to quitting them, did not rise markedly as it had in September. An increase in dismissed workers was nearly offset by a decline in layoffs.
Over all, the ranks of the jobless rose by a scant 4,000, with a 187,000 decline in jobs nearly matched by a 183,000 decline in the labor force, the number of people working or actively looking for work.
 
A Changing Population
 The recent slow growth of the labor force is occurring largely because relatively few people are coming of working age. This has kept the unemployment rate from rising much more than it has, Dr. Norwood observed. The labor force grew by only about 600,000 people over the past year, only one-third of the pace of the late 1980's.
This has meant that the proportion of the population with jobs and the proportion of the population in the labor force have both begun to decline in recent months from record levels.
Some of the largest states experienced wide swings in unemployment rates last month. Unemployment in Illinois fell 1.3 percentage points, to 5.9 percent, while unemployment in North Carolina rose by nine-tenths of a point, to 4.6 percent, and joblessness in Ohio increased by seven-tenths of a point, to 5.9 percent, in Ohio. The New York State unemployment rate edged up a statistically insignificant one-tenth of a percentage point, to 5.6 percent.
By region, the jobless rates were 5.5 percent in the Northeast and South, 5.3 percent in the West and 5.2 percent in the Midwest, according to figures not adjusted for seasonal variation.

HEADLINE: Satmars Win Approval Of Williamsburg Plan

 BODY:
A Federal judge yesterday rejected an attempt by Hispanic groups to block plans by Hasidic Jews to build a 6,000-seat synagogue, a school and faculty housing in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.
The area's largest Hasidic sect, the Satmar, plans the construction on land that it bought from New York City. But a coalition of Hispanic groups went to court to block the construction, contending that the city had sold the urban-renewal land improperly to foster "a religious enclave." 
 After conducting hearings in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, Judge Eugene H. Nickerson issued a 37-page decision recounting the long history of the project and refusing to block it.
Judge Nickerson said the opponents wanted him to "infer that the city's decision-makers were actuated, at least in part, from 1977 on by an intent to discriminate against Hispanics and in favor of the Hasidim." But he ruled that he could not draw that inference.
Hasidic community representatives have argued that they followed all legal procedures for developing the one-block parcel of land and that it would increase local stability.
The Hispanic groups' lawyers could not say yesterday whether they would appeal.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 35.89 as Gulf Tensions Ease

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices advanced briskly yesterday in heavy trading amid a reduction of tensions in the Persian Gulf, a drop in crude oil prices and increasing evidence that the economy is now so weak that the Federal Reserve may soon cut interest rates again.
On Monday, the Fed cut the Federal funds rate a quarter point, to 7 3/4 percent, and Wall Street now expects another quarter-point cut in the rate, which is the rate banks charge one another for overnight loans. 
 Some traders argued that a good time for the Fed to take action again -- if indeed it does -- might be close to its Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Tuesday, when it discusses monetary policy.
 
 Financial Stocks Improve
 Banking, insurance and other financial stocks rose in the expectation that, if rates come down, they will be among the first to benefit. Oil shares also advanced.
By the end of the day, the Dow Jones industrial average had climbed 35.89 points, to 2,490.84, bringing the rise for the week to 54.70.
Trading activity rose to 168.7 million shares, from 159.3 million on Thursday. Showing that the breadth of the gain was strong, 1,091 stocks advanced while only 466 declined.
The difference between the new lows and the new highs, however, was still wide, 95 to 11.
Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said that five waves of heavy buying lifted the Dow close to 16 points throughout the day.
 
 War Seen as Less Likely
 Oil prices slid $1.17 a barrel, to $34. Traders said that because President Bush would leave for several European capitals on Nov. 16, spend Thanksgiving in the Middle East and return to Washington on Nov. 23, the likelihood of war anytime soon seemed less likely. Some had speculated previously that there was a probability of war breaking out after Tuesday's elections.
Wall Street's best guess on when another rate cut might come is that it could happen shortly after the elections and the Treasury's record three-day auction sale ending on Thursday.
In yet another sign that the economy could do with a little lift, yesterday's employment figures showed that it was still losing momentum and, analysts argued, could be losing even more before long.
 
 Rising From the Opening Bell
 From the start of trading yesterday, the Dow began rising. Within an hour it had climbed 17 points; by 1:30 it was ahead 30. It dropped briefly after that but moved steadily ahead for the rest of the day. Oil moved mostly in the other direction. By 11 it was off 70 cents, bouncing back for a while but then heading down again, particularly in the last 15 minutes.
The New York Stock Exchange's financial average, which rose close to 1.5 percent on Thursday, rose 3.5 percent more yesterday. Two big stocks in the index, Citicorp and Fannie Mae, topped the Big Board active list, while a third, American Express, was 10th most active. Citicorp rose 3/4, to 12 5/8, on 4.1 million shares. Fannie Mae rose 7/8, to 29 1/4, on 2.7 million. American Express rose 1, to 19 3/4, on 1.7 million shares.
