HEADLINE: After Noriega, Change Comes Slowly and Panama's President Is Frustrated

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
Despite encouraging signs of national recovery, President Guillermo Endara continues to face political and economic frustrations as his Government tries to rebuild Panama after two decades of military rule.
Since the early morning of Dec. 20, when Mr. Endara was sworn in at a United States military base as American troops massed to invade the country, the new Government has succeeded in staking out the basics of its political and economic authority. 
 The American military presence in daily Panamanian life has diminished and will soon be removed altogether. The economic situation has also begun to stabilize, even in the seemingly intractable area of unemployment.
 
No 'Positive Mandate'
 But against the high, almost euphoric, public expectations that accompanied the overthrow of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, even the important achievements of the Government have appeared tardy or inadequate to many Panamanians. And as a Government of coalition and consensus, it has moved with a slowness and deliberation that has left it open to frequent charges of weakness or poor leadership.
"This Government did not rise to power on the basis of its abilities, but rather on the disabilities of someone else," said a foreign diplomat who has maintained good ties with the Panamanian Government under General Noriega and Mr. Endara alike.
"It was the beneficiary of a vote against Noriega, which gave it moral authority, and an American invasion, which put it in office," the diplomat said. "But it has never enjoyed the kind of positive mandate that would give it real power."
Diplomats and Panamanian politicians say the maneuvering and infighting that once dominated relations between Mr. Endara and his two Vice Presidents, Guillermo Ford and Ricardo Arias Calderon, have finally begun to subside, easing a major source of instability that had hindered their diverse coalition since it was first formed to oppose General Noriega at the ballot box.
 
Quarrels Are Postponed
 Although the three remain determined rivals, politicians say they appear to have been sobered by the effects of their political shoving matches, which reached a peak during the selection of leaders in the National Assembly in September.
Most overt quarrels now appear to have been postponed until the country comes closer to its next presidential vote, in 1994, when the three men are expected to abandon coalition politics in vigorous competition for an electorate that has never had a clear opportunity to express its preferences among them.
But consensus within the current troika has been bought at the expense of forceful leadership, prompting a rash of public criticism and newspaper editorials with headlines like "Use Your Authority, Mr. President" and "Indecision, the Cause of Our Ills."
The dampening of high-level discord has also appeared to highlight the broader sluggishness and inefficiency of the Government bureaucracy in areas as diverse as the economy, law enforcement and criminal justice.
"There is more than anything a feeling of frustration," said Luis Martinz, a spokesman for Mr. Endara. "People are aware that there has been progress, but it often does not directly affect them, and in any case it is only a fraction of what we lost during the crisis."
 
President Is a Target
 Even committed opponents of the Endara Government are often unable to articulate specific complaints about Government policies. In a recent protest march organized by student groups and Government unions in downtown Panama City, many demonstrators interviewed were unable to name concrete changes that they wanted Mr. Endara to make.
Perhaps for the lack of a more defined target, criticism has thus gravitated to Mr. Endara himself, and to his very public life and recent marriage.
Never shy of publicity, the heavyset, 56-year-old Panamanian leader has frequently made himself the center of political events. Before the American invasion, he went on a hunger strike in a hospital bed in a downtown store window. He then repeated that tactic during delays in the arrival of American aid to Panama last spring, putting himself on display behind red ropes in a Roman Catholic cathedral.
But nothing has drawn public attention or comment like his marriage in June to the former Ana Mae Diaz, a 23-year-old student whom he met during his pre-invasion hunger strike.
Mr. Endara's supporters have denounced criticism of his new First Lady as idle gossip or, at worst, racism on the part of a Panamanian elite that is notoriously intolerant of race and class differences. Mrs. Endara has darker skin and is from a poorer social and economic background than the President.
But the furor has also been fed by Mr. Endara, who delights in showing off his new wife, and acknowledges her from the podium at public events with special, often saccharine greetings.
"It's one of those unexpected factors in politics," said a foreign friend who attended the couple's lavish wedding, "He is in love and he wants the world to know it."
 
Economy Regains Some Ground
 Government analysts, private sector economists and diplomats agree that the Panamanian economy, which shrank by roughly 20 percent in the last two years of the Noriega Government, will have regained roughly a third of that loss, or about 7 percent of total activity, by the end of this year.
But that resurgence has resulted less from Government actions than from a rapid re-expansion of the private business sector, particularly banking. The return of up to $2 billion in foreign deposits has revived local lending, permitting a rapid recovery of larger businesses and industries that had been paralyzed by the absence of credit.
One of the most conspicuous, and politically important, beneficiaries of looser credit has been Panama's construction industry, which has suddenly sprung to life in the capital and across the country, reactivating dozens of major construction sites that had been left in weed-covered limbo by the economic crisis.
The increased construction activity, economists say, has been a major element in reducing unemployment, which soared to as much as 50 percent nationwide in the initial weeks after the crisis.
"When you revive the banks themselves, you employ a few bean counters," an American official said. "But construction gives jobs to a lot of blue-collar types who do not have many other alternatives for employment. It has affected a lot of families."
 
Worries Over Street Crime
 The relative growth of employment has helped stave off what had begun to loom as an imminent political and social crisis for the Endara Government. Government and American Embassy officials place the nationwide unemployment figure at 17 to 20 percent, with higher levels in urban areas like Panama City and Colon, on the Atlantic coast. Private-sector economists and officials of the Panama Chamber of Commerce put the rate at roughly 25 percent nationwide.
But the large number of Panamanians who are still out of work has contributed to what Panamanians and foreign officials say is a deepening concern about street crime. And it has greatly inhibited Mr. Endara's ability to restructure or modernize the country's bloated Government bureaucracy.
In addition to growing numbers of robberies and burglaries in urban areas, local authorities say, the level of drug trafficking through Panama's remote countryside and rugged coastlines has remained high or even grown since the invasion, both as a result of poor Government surveillance and high unemployment.
American efforts to gain greater access to Panama's secretive banking trade have also encountered stiff resistance from the private business sector, dividing Mr. Endara's Government against itself in a sharp debate over the tradeoffs among sovereignty, economic growth and law enforcement.
 
Government Payroll Reduced
 Since taking office, Government officials say, Mr. Endara has reduced the Government payroll by a total of 6 percent, and that figure is expected to reach 10 percent by year's end.
But strong public sector unions, which were used by General Noriega to form the generously paid backbone of his civilian support, have begun organizing to protect their salaries and perquisites. They recently helped to stage the largest street demonstration yet held against the Endara Government.
"This is the price of democracy," a Government official said. "And we're learning we have to pay it like everyone else."

HEADLINE: Review/ Theater;
Dark Visions of America In a Modern Depression

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW

 BODY:
In Richard Caliban's "Famine Plays," the center of the country cannot hold. America's heartland has become a disaster area. Facing unemployment and poverty, people move from street to highway, looking for a resting zone. Some grasp a livelihood in crime. No one has enough to eat, and there is no solace on the horizon. The once-sedentary become eternal nomads, as the Okies did in the 1930's.
As written and directed by Mr. Caliban, "Famine Plays," at the Triplex Theater, is an ambitious attempt at creating a "Grapes of Wrath" for modern, depressed times. The period is undated, but it seems more like the near future than anything futuristic. Each of the images in the collage is evocative, and at the same time each is overextended. The play runs more than two and a half hours, and half the length would have been an improvement. 
 As Mr. Caliban has shown in his previous work, he is a venturesome playwright and director, but "Famine Plays" is marred by self-indulgence. It needs editing, which was not the case last season with his "Rodents and Radios." Dealing with a related theme, the disorientation of young people living on the edge of life, that play had an exactitude that had one looking forward to each of the interlocking episodes.
The similarly structured "Famine Plays" is an earlier work, first presented several years ago at the Cucaracha Theater and brought back for a return engagement in the company's new downtown home. Having seen the later play first, as well as Mr. Caliban's staging of Mac Wellman's "Crowbar," one knows the breadth of his talent, varyingly in evidence in the current production.
On a broad, open stage, slashed by a crossroad of light, the characters tramp their way into oblivion. A young mother leaves her family to look for work, and a street urchin treats her as an adoptive parent. The son of a suicide turns mugger. A married couple pack remnants of a once-stable life; they become the equivalent of a walking tag sale.
In the background as counterpoint are pictures of artworks by everyone from Andrew Wyeth to Edvard Munch, and striding through the play is a choral figure acting as the specter of Norman Rockwell. His presence reminds us that before famine, America's image of itself was a Saturday Evening Post cover of a bountiful Thanksgiving dinner.
The narrative is most enveloping when it is least pretentious, especially during moments of eccentric humor. Two dirt-encrusted wanderers become partners in crime. One, apparently an immigrant, carries a cudgel, with which he beats his victims. He also strikes them with a verbal curse of "Walt Whitman! Walt Whitman!" -- words that somehow, irrationally, force them into submission.
Wandering through the evening is a buffoon, who comments on the action with pronouncements like "God is an omnipotent waiter." He and others are accompanied by cultural detritus from a former existence; carless travelers remember a verse of "See the U.S.A. in Your Chevrolet."
The show, labeled a "downtown opera," is at least partly a musical, with a score written and played by John Hoge. Moving from neo-liturgical to recitative, the songs help to capture the vagrancy of the open road.
The fact that a number of the actors appeared in contrasting roles in "Rodents and Radios" certifies their range. Lauren Hamilton, poignant as that scruffy urchin, previously played the opposite, a self-styled visionary. Mollie O'Mara, Vivian Lanko, Glen Santiago and Lia Chang also appear to advantage, and Steven Bland adds an affable touch of tomfoolery. The actors have the makings of an ensemble.
As the characters crisscross the stage, they become routeless. None has a sense of destination, and, in an odd, ironic note, neither does the play. It wanders prodigally on Mr. Caliban's endless road, moves past several possible exits and never quite arrives at a conclusion.
 
FAMINE PLAYS
 
Written and directed by Richard Caliban; music by John Hoge; lighting by Brian Aldous; costumes by Mary Myers; projections by Tony Jacobs; sound by John Huntington; stage manager, J. Tori Evand; assistant director, Daniel Tharau; production manager, Janet Paparazzo. Presented by Under One Roof and Cucaracha. At the Triplex Theater, 199 Chambers Street, between Greenwich and West Streets.
 
WITH: Steven Bland, Lia Chang, Mark Dillahunt, Corinne Edgerly, Lauren Hamilton, Vivian Lanko, Mollie O'Mara, Brennan Murphy, Hugh Palmer, Glen Santiago, David Simonds and George Tynan.

HEADLINE: New York Fears Exodus of Jobs On Wall Street

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Just when New York can least afford to lose them, several major financial institutions are considering leaving the city and taking thousands of jobs with them.
The biggest and most immediate concern to New York is the possible departure of the five commodities exchanges, where options and futures for items like gold, platinum, aluminum, oil, coffee, cocoa, sugar, orange juice and currencies are traded in a frenzied choreography of capitalism in the World Trade Center complex. They are the hub of an industry that annually generates $1.3 billion a year in goods, services and salaries. 
 City and state officials, in a joint proposal dated Oct. 1, initially offered the exchanges a $50 million grant to help build a new headquarters on what they called "the largest and best located parcel of vacant land in lower Manhattan," along with tax breaks, rent subsidies and low-cost energy that would save the exchanges another $50 million. The 20-year deal would bring the average occupancy costs, including rent and utilities, for the first five years to just under $30 million a year.
 
Just Across River
 But New York City's adversaries in prior corporate tugs of war, Jersey City and the State of New Jersey, are urging the exchanges to move to a site at the Harborside Financial Center, just across the Hudson River from the Trade Center and one stop from the exchanges' current location on the PATH line.
In recent days, Mayor Gerald McCann of Jersey City said, New York has more than doubled its construction grant offer. He did not disclose details of the New Jersey offer but said that he believed New York had still not been able to match the exchanges' estimated occupancy costs in Jersey City -- said to be about $20 million annually -- and that the difference would widen after the first five years as New York's tax incentives expired.
Jersey City has the advantage of starting with much lower taxes. New York officials are constrained by the fiscal problems facing the city and the state but have an advantage, too: the city's long ties with the exchanges, which were established in New York more than a century ago.
 
$300 Million in Annual Taxes
 "We're as competitive as we can be with New Jersey," said Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, New York City's Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, adding that she was "cautiously optimistic."
The prize is enormous. The five exchanges -- the Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange Inc.; the Commodity Exchange Inc.; the New York Cotton Exchange; the New York Mercantile Exchange, and the New York Futures Exchange -- share a trading floor and employ 11,700 people, a figure expected to grow to 23,500 over this decade, and generate $300 million a year in Federal, state and city taxes.
Should the exchanges move, they could take with them many other workers who are employed in commodities departments at investment companies in the Financial District.
Unrelated to the negotiations over the exchanges, three other large financial services concerns are also considering leaving New York when their leases run out in coming years.
Prudential-Bache, which rents space in two downtown buildings under leases that expire in 1994, is studying the feasiblity of moving about 2,000 employees to Jersey City, although it has not ruled out going elsewhere or remaining in New York City.
Mr. McCann said he also has "ongoing talks" with Morgan Stanley Group, which has 4,200 employees in New York City, and Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, which employs almost 3,500 people in the city, including those at its brokerage offices. Morgan Stanley is also said to have an interest in Fairfield County, Conn., relocation experts indicate.
 
Final Approval in December
 Representatives of the two companies acknowledged only that leases would expire in the mid-1990's. Taht gives them time to make up their minds.
Officials of the commodities exchanges, though, are expected to analyze what both New York and New Jersey call final offers this weekend. Exchange officials could make a preliminary decision as early as Tuesday, with final approval by the membership coming in December.
It is in a company's interest to appear to be ready to leave New York, even if it intends to stay, in hopes that a landlord will offer a cheaper lease and that the city and state will forgive tax payments and make financing or grants available.
The departure of the commodities exchanges or one or more major financial companies would be a blow to New York's struggling economy, which shed more than 30,000 jobs over the summer. It would also damage the city's standing as a center for finance and weaken its argument that the advantage of conducting business "face to face" with representatives of other financial companies in the city outweighs the higher costs of doing business in New York City.
 
'Can't Imagine It Going'
 The commodities exchanges are especially important because of the additional jobs that might follow them across the river. Under pressure to expand, and with ambitions to surpass Chicago for supremacy in trading, they had negotiated a deal with the city to build a headquarters on a site atop the Manhattan entrance to the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, but the project was shelved after the stock market's plunge.
"You're talking about an industry," said Vincent Tese, a former commodities trader who, as chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation, signed the New York offer along with Ms. Hernandez-Pinero. "We can't imagine it going."
Four exchanges now operate on a 25,000-square-foot trading area on the eighth floor of 4 World Trade Center, with the futures exchange trading in another part of the same floor.
The Jersey City site would allow the exchanges to have a trading floor as large as 100,000 square feet, said Michele de Milly, a spokeswoman for the exchanges. On the New York City parcel, which is bounded by West, Warren, Murray and Greenwich Streets, the trading floor could be only as large as 75,000 square feet.
The negotiations with the commodities exchanges and the rumblings from other financial services companies bring to mind the corporate exodus that New York City has already endured. In the last few years corporate departures slowed but did not cease, as the city lost Mobil, Exxon, J. C. Penney. By granting packages of incentives, it kept the National Broadcasting Company and Chase Manhattan Bank, among others, but lost a contingent of Merrill Lynch employees to Jersey City.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 507 words

HEADLINE: Government by Cabal -- Again

 BODY:
Whatever anyone thinks of the new deficit-reduction package, the process that produced the 1991 budget was a frightening display of government-in-secret. Members who battled and bargained into the wee hours are only now discovering the full content of what they approved. There is a better way, called telling it like it is.
The problem began with the President's January budget message. Like his predecessors, President Bush slipped easily into telling it like it isn't, submitting estimates that were simply not credible. His awesome miscalculations for fiscal 1991 pretended to shrink the deficit to $64 billion without new taxes, but now he's accepted new taxes to help cope with a deficit of $250 billion-plus. 
 Congress has been a willing accomplice in the deception. Since enacting the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law in 1985, members have resorted to trickery and subterfuge to hide their failure to meet its deficit reduction targets. But the law was doomed from the start; it set arbitrary targets further into the future than any reasonable forecast could reach. Hopelessly off target for 1991 and beyond, Congress has now substituted a procedure that sets supposedly inviolable caps on future spending.
Like the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law, the new device was hatched at the last minute without public discussion -- indeed, without even enough explanation to let members cast an informed vote. The architect was Robert Byrd, the crafty chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, who wanted, and got, more leeway for his committee to expand or compress spending bills within its jurisdiction.
But Mr. Byrd's mischief was only the final act in a serial of secret negotiations by a handful of Administration officials and Congressional leaders. After three months of getting nowhere, they closeted themselves at Andrews Air Force Base, but their "summit" deal was rejected by House members who hadn't been consulted and weren't buying.
None of this conniving would have occurred were it not for the Reagan Administration's "voodoo economics" -- George Bush's phrase -- promising a decade ago to balance the budget with tax cuts and more billions for defense. The promise was preposterous on its face, but Congress didn't blink an eye, happily voting to spend more and tax less.
Now comes the hard part -- control and cutbacks, so painful and controversial that neither the Administration nor Congress dares admit what's really going on.
The new tax increases and spending caps are shrouded in complicated formulas. The new process, based on spending limits, could be more constructive than the old one, which focused on deficits. But if recent history is any guide, Congress and the Administration will devise new tricks to beat the system. In any event, the effect won't be known for years, and meanwhile the Government is stuck with procedures imposed yet again by cabal.
A responsible Government would let the public know what it's up to. A responsible President would start with a realistic budget for 1992.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Questions Are Intensifying About Insurance Safety Net

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
The faltering economy is casting a shadow over virtually all aspects of American life, and insurance is no exception. Many insurance companies have invested heavily in real estate or junk bonds whose market value has declined sharply, making them more vulnerable to insolvency.
The safety net for insurers in trouble has long been each state's insurance guaranty fund, a mechanism through which solvent insurance companies absorb the losses of insolvent insurers through assessments.. But now questions are being raised by consumer groups and members of Congress about the vulnerability of these funds, also known as guarantee associations. 
 The reason for this heightened interest in guaranty funds is the rash of savings and loan and bank failures, despite Federal deposit insurance. Although savings and loan associations and insurance companies are two different types of businesses, there are enough parallels between them to raise doubts about the adequacy of the insurance industry's safety net. This concern is heightened by the patchwork nature of state insurance regulations.
 
'A Domino Effect'
 William Westoff, a senior vice president of IDS Financial Services, a Minneapolis financial planning company that issued a study on the insurance industry's solvency earlier this year, said: "If problems occur to a very large company, the assessment could be quite onerous. That could create a domino effect and cause another company to fail."
The House Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee said in a report this year, "The insurance industry and the nation could face a solvency crisis rivaling the present savings and loan situation." The report, which studied the failures in 1989 and 1990 of such national companies as the Mission Insurance Company, the Integrity Insurance Company and the Transit Casualty Company, cited "completely inadequate" reserves of those companies.
To prevent a disaster, proposals are being made to strengthen or change the guaranty-fund system. Among them: establishing national standards that would apply to all state funds, sharing information among states about financially troubled insurers and creating a separate Federal system to handle insurance companies' insolvencies.
"The guaranty funds were set up when there were very few insolvencies," said Caroline Smith DeWaal, the insurance specialist for Public Citizen's Congress Watch, a consumer advocacy group that published a report on insurers' financial solvency last month. "In the last eight years, the number of insolvencies has increased dramatically, and we need a Federal answer to this problem."
The existing state funds and the insurance industry generally scoff at the thought of abolishing the current fund system. "The system is not perfect, but there really hasn't been a displayed incapacity to deal with the problem," said Dale Stephenson, the president of the National Conference of Insurance Guaranty Funds, the umbrella group for the state funds that cover property and casualty companies.
The first of the guaranty funds were created in the 1940's to cover particular insurance, like workers' compensation or automobile insurance. Today, there are two broad categories of funds, usually run by a board of directors chosen or approved by the state insurance commissioner: property and casualty funds, which exist in all 50 states, and life and health funds, which exist in 47. The exceptions are Colorado, Louisiana and New Jersey, plus the District of Columbia.
Model laws on insurance guaranty funds prepared by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners have been adopted by many states. Every state law sets limits on the amounts the funds can pay to any individual, so that if a claim exceeds the limit, it is not covered. Claims are filed directly with the fund.
All of the funds, other than New York's property and casualty fund, function like this: insurers are assessed to meet necessary obligations after insolvencies occur, according to a formula based on their total premiums. However by law, the New York Property and Casualty Security Fund is required to have $150 million in reserves. If the assets of the fund go below that level, companies selling this kind of insurance are assessed.
"The object of the game is not to use the security fund," said Kevin Foley, the Deputy Superintendent of the New York State Insurance Department. "Insurance companies are conservatively invested, and their portfolios are closely monitored."
 
Monitoring Portfolios
 But other states may not be as effective in monitoring companies' portfolios, and failures of insurance companies have recently been high. Insolvencies of life and health insurers totaled 43 last year, with 15 more occuring through August 1990. Insolvencies of property and casualty insurers totaled 23 in 1989, with 11 more recorded through the end of August.
As the insurance industry sees it, there is no reason for alarm. "In the very unlikely event that a major insurer became insolvent, the shortfall would not be of such a measure to exceed the guaranty system's capacity to handle it," said Eden Sarfaty, the president of the National Association of Life and Health Guaranty Associations.
But some consumer advocates question the very nature of the guaranty funds. "The system is designed to pass off costs" to taxpayers or policyholders, said Marty Leary of the Southern Finance Project, a nonprofit research center in Durham, N.C., referring to the additional taxes or premiums that often follow guaranty-fund assessments. "Reform should take place whereby costs rest on the capital of the industry."
 
ON AVOIDING THE WORST

Unless your insurance company becomes insolvent, you will probably not have any dealings with a state insurance guaranty fund. But here are some of the precautions that you can take to reduce the possibility of ever being faced with such a situation:
*When buying an insurance policy, make sure that the company's claims-paying ability has the highest rating of A-plus from A. M. Best , the insurance-rating agency. Ask the insurance company about its rating or consult Best's Insurance Reports at your local library.
*Check with your state's insurance department for information about the financial health of an insurer. Departments usually have a division that answers consumer telephone calls or mail.
*If you purchase a policy through an independent agent, ask how an insurance company's service compares with that of other companies. Among the points to consider: the insurer's promptness and thoroughness in handling claims, its accuracy in changing a policy or adding an endorsement and its willingness to communicate with policyholders.

HEADLINE: Never Has So Few Owned So Much

BYLINE: By Robert Blake; Lord Blake, a former Provost of Queens College, Oxford, is the author of "Disraeli" and "The Decline of Power, 1915-1964."

 BODY:
THE DECLINE AND FALL OF THE BRITISH ARISTOCRACY
By David Cannadine.
Illustrated. 813 pp. New Haven:
Yale University Press. $35. 
 THIS is a long, learned and highly readable account of a change in British social history that has never been so fully charted before. David Cannadine, a British expatriate who is a professor of history at Columbia University, has spent 10 years of research in tracing the changing fortunes of the landed aristocracy of Britain during the century between 1880 and 1980. He is not the first historian to deal with the subject. The pioneer work on which he has freely drawn with full acknowledgments is F. M. L. Thompson's "English Landed Society in the Nineteenth Century" (1963). But, as Mr. Thompson said of his own book, it "is, like all history, only more so, an interim report." Mr. Cannadine may not have given us a final report -- perhaps there never can be such a thing -- but he has written a brilliant, multifaceted chronicle of economic and social change that is unlikely to be superseded for many years to come. It is a picturesque drama -- half-tragic, half-comic -- peopled by a vast variety of characters, some of them able, honorable and public-minded like the 3d Marquess of Salisbury, others incompetent, disreputable and selfish like the 16th Marquess of Winchester, who became the front for the fraudulent company promoter Clarence Hatry.
In 1880 the 29 greatest British landowners possessed enormous estates. They all had titles; 12 of them were dukes. The smallest holding in acres -- 19,749 -- was that of the Duke of Westminster, but since a sizable chunk of it was in London he had the biggest income of all -- 290,000 -- just beating the Duke of Buccleuch, who had 460,108 acres, much of them in Scotland, and the Duke of Bedford, another London landowner, who had 86,335 acres all told. Fourteen of these landowners owned more than 100,000 acres each. The Duke of Sutherland, whose holdings were largely in the Scottish Highlands, had well over a million.
By 1976, the latest date for which figures are available (and they are limited to England and Wales), the picture had drastically changed. Although there were a few maverick cases of an actual increase, more typical were the Duke of Devonshire, down from 133,000 acres to 56,000, and the Duke of Norfolk, from 40,000 to 25,000. Many falls were far greater. Of course, this did not mean that some of the surviving grandees were other than extremely rich. The postwar boom in agricultural land and the soaring price of objets d'art have recouped the fortunes of many landowners who can now get by with far fewer acres. When the 10th Duke of Devonshire died in 1952, four months before the date when his estate would have been exempt from 2.5 million in death duties, that indefatigable diarist and gossip Chips Channon wrote: "Is this the end of Chatsworth?" Those who were guests at the two days of colossal splendor to celebrate the 21st birthday of the grandson and heir in July of this year know that it was certainly not the end -- anyway not yet.
But, although the Duke of Devonshire is still one of the richest men in England and although there is still great wealth among the aristocracy, Mr. Cannadine's basic theme is correct. The landed world is not what it was. There are still supposed to be some 2,000 landed estates in Britain, but whereas they covered over half the land in 1880, they covered at most a quarter, perhaps a lot less, in 1980. And those who have gone by the board are not so much the seriously rich, though some of them have, but the country squirearchy, the men of 1,000 to 10,000 acres who propped the whole system up, constituted the governing class in the counties, went to Parliament as perennial backbenchers, lived on their estates, hunted and held High Tory views. They really have largely vanished.
The basic causes of the decline of the landed aristocracy are clear enough: the collapse of agriculture and the march of democracy. The first was the more important. It was simply the result of the end of the American Civil War, the opening up of the American West to farming on a larger and more profitable scale than anything in Europe, together with greatly improved transportation. These developments knocked the bottom out of the market. Its revival in the 1950's after 70 years of decline was too late for the squire archy and much of the aristocracy, except for the substantial element that owned mines, minerals and urban property.
This change affected the Continental aristocracy just as badly, and it is one of the many virtues of "The Decline and Fall of the British Aristocracy" that Mr. Cannadine puts the whole process in its European context. In fact the British aristocrats, being far richer than their Continental counterparts, were less badly placed to survive than the French, German and Italian nobility with their endless subdivision of estates and titles. Only the Magyar grandees in Hungary did better -- till 1945. Most successful of all were the Spanish, thanks to Franco. The unique British system of entail and primogeniture was not always popular with younger sons surveying the wealth of their eldest brothers. Hence the younger sons' grace: "For what we ought to have received, may the Lord make them truly thankful." But the system did preserve estates as long as there were estates to preserve.
The other cause of decline was the growth of democracy. This, too, was a European phenomenon. It was bound to be inimical to the concept of a ruling privileged elite. As early as the 1850's Toqueville, the shrewdest observer of the world political scene, predicted that democracy would destroy aristocracy everywhere. He did not mean individuals but the principle of rule by landed grandees. And this is what has happened. Whether one dates the change in Britain from the enlargement of the franchise in the Reform Act of 1867, F. M. L. Thompson's choice, or the further extension of it in the Reform Act of 1885, preferred by Mr. Cannadine, a great decline in aristocratic power has undoubtedly occurred.
IN 1880 the House of Lords was overwhelmingly landed and hereditary; it had virtually coequal powers with the Commons, most of the members of which were sons or collaterals of the Lords; and it dominated the political scene. A century later it had become in essence a senate of lifetime members, though the largely absentee hereditary peers were still a majority. It is a useful revising chamber but little more. In the Commons the old "landed interest" is negligible now. There has never been a complete sweep of the aristocracy as in parts of Europe but a merger with an upper middle class of professionals, financiers and businessmen -- a new Establishment.
In the face of these facts, it is hard to see why a few peers who have been given, or told about, proof copies of this book seem to be so cross. There are errors. To categorize landowners like Lords Pembroke and Northesk by their hobbies as film producer and silversmith, respectively, is absurd. It is a solecism to spell Eaton Hall, the Duke of Westminster's seat, like the college, and Lady Caroline Gilmour's ducal connection, as any reference book shows, is with Buccleuch, not Portland.
These are venial errors. They do not warrant the reported words of Lord St. John of Fawsley (Norman St. John Stevas, the former Conservative member of the House of Commons): "total rubbish." The book is not an attack on the aristocracy. The author recognizes how much of it has still survived. He merely chronicles in neutral terms a major change of power over the last century and a lesser change of wealth. The complainers ought to read the book. It will take them quite a time, but they may then have a different view of a remarkable achievement.

 
 
TARNISH ON THE ESCUTCHEON
 When seeking for a partner worthy of the delectable Zuleika Dobson, Max Beerbohm created the Duke of Dorset, an aristocratic paragon, endowed with Olympian wealth, rank, and intellect. His inherited possessions were stupendous, his riches were incalculable, his British titles were innumerable, and he was in addition a prince of the Holy Roman Empire and a duke in the peerage of France. As an Oxford undergraduate he took a First in Mods. and carried off a clutch of university prizes, he was awarded the Garter by the government in instant recognition of a dazzling speech he delivered impromptu in the House of Lords, and he excelled at any human activity to which he turned his hand or his head. Yet for all his youth, his great position, his brilliant attainments, and the splendid prospects that lay before him, the Duke of Dorset was a fallen idol, who drowned himself in a gesture at once utterly magnificent yet totally futile. And, appropriately enough, the novel that related his fictional and fanciful plunge into the River Cherwell was first published in 1911, the very year that, in reality, witnessed the most successful assault in recent history on the House of Lords -- and thus on the hereditary, titled, landowning classes of the British Isles. . . .
The Duke of Dorset may be taken as a larger-than-life exemplar of . . . the notables and nobles of the British Isles. . . . As late as the 1870s, these patricians were still the most wealthy, the most powerful, and the most glamorous people in the country, corporately -- and understandably -- conscious of themselves as God's elect. But during the hundred years that followed, their wealth withered, their power faded, their glamour tarnished, and their collective sense of identity and purpose gradually but inexorably weakened. . . . How, when, and why did this pride of lions decay into a fable of unicorns?
 
From "The Decline and Fall of the British Aristocracy."

HEADLINE: Poker and Nothingness

BYLINE: By Madison Smartt Bell; Madison Smartt Bell's novels include "The Year of Silence," "Soldier's Joy" and the forthcoming "Doctor Sleep."

 BODY:

THE MUSIC OF CHANCE
>By Paul Auster.
217 pp. New York:
Viking. $18.95. 
 THERE may be some doubt as to whether Paul Auster really means to be a novelist at all. Like Julian Barnes, though with infinitely greater success, he has used the form of the novel as a shell for intellectual speculation of one kind or another. His most brilliant effects have been achieved by his reworkings of the mystery in "The New York Trilogy," where the formalism of the genre also does much to specify the plot. Mr. Auster's latest novel, "The Music of Chance," seems however to have taken a picaresque model, whose form is less distinctly defined.
Jim Nashe, a Boston fireman, is catapulted into existential uncertainty by a couple of inadvertencies: his desertion by his wife, Therese, and the death of his estranged father, who leaves him a surprisingly sizable legacy. He sells all his possessions, parks his daughter, Juliette, with his sister's family in Minnesota, stocks his Saab with classical cassettes and takes to the road:
"Speed was of the essence, the joy of sitting in the car and hurtling himself forward through space. That became a good beyond all others, a hunger to be fed at any price. . . . As long as he was driving, he carried no burdens, was unencumbered by even the slightest particle of his former life. That is not to say that memories did not rise up in him, but they no longer seemed to bring any of the old anguish. Perhaps the music had something to do with that, the endless tapes of Bach and Mozart and Verdi that he listened to while sitting behind the wheel, as if the sounds were somehow emanating from him and drenching the landscape, turning the visible world into a reflection of his own thoughts. After three or four months, he had only to enter the car to feel that he was coming loose from his body, that once he put his foot down on the gas and started driving, the music would carry him into a realm of weightlessness."
All Nashe wants is to preserve this state of orbital nullity, which is inherently unstable and begins to decay as his money decreases. With $14,000 left in the stash in the Saab's glove compartment, he meets Jack Pozzi, a young and feckless down-on-his-luck gambler, who presents himself as "an opportunity in the shape of a human being, a card-playing specter whose one purpose in the world was to help Nashe win back his freedom." Nashe agrees to back Pozzi in a poker game against Bill Flower and Willie Stone, a couple of fabulously wealthy lottery winners, supposed to be easy marks.
This pair occasions the sort of tour de force of eccentricity and obsessionalism at which Mr. Auster most excels. During a tour of their baroque mansion in rural Pennsylvania, the fat and garrulous Flower, a former accountant, expatiates at length on the proposition that "numbers have souls" (so that what seems to be chance may not be at all), while the compact and monosyllabic Stone merely indicates the miniaturized City of the World that he is building, including replicas of his own house and minuscule figures of himself and his friend, and describes his plan to build a second model within the model, so creating an infinite recession.
There's something obscurely offensive to Nashe about "such extravagant smallness," and while the game is in progress he sneaks back and steals the miniatures of Flower and Stone. By chance or in consequence, Pozzi's luck fails; Nashe stakes the Saab on him and loses, then crashes $10,000 into debt on a single cut of the cards. Flower and Stone, whose model city includes images of both comical roguery and dire punishment, are not amiable about the situation. Nashe and Pozzi find themselves compelled to remain on the estate, hand-building a stone wall of Egyptian magnitude, working for an hourly rate until the debt is repaid.
The rest of the story revolves around Nashe's gradual recognition that by following the appealing rhythms of chance he has landed in a rigidly determined system: "Sometimes, powerless to stop himself, he even went so far as to imagine that he was already living inside the model. Flower and Stone would look down on him then, and he would suddenly be able to see himself through their eyes -- as if he were no larger than a thumb, a little gray mouse darting back and forth in his cage." Within this sinister predicament, Nashe is eventually able to regain the zero state he most desires, "for even the smallest zero was a great hole of nothingness, a circle large enough to contain the world."
Mr. Auster has succeeded admirably in dressing up this very abstract situation. But, diverging from the tactics of his earlier work, he has also tried to mix the unreality of Nashe, Flower and Stone with a more realistic portrayal of other characters, and here the results are less fortunate. Nashe's sometime girlfriend Fiona, a hooker called Tiffany and especially Pozzi are not rendered well enough to convince. Pozzi's monologues are shakily, inconsistently written and, unfortunately, too much hangs on his role as a credible and engaging picaro, for Nashe comes to see him as a sort of alter ego: "Once a man begins to recognize himself in another, he can no longer look on him as a stranger." So the failure of this characterization is a serious flaw.
The haphazard wandering of the plot, random as the path of Nashe's Saab, may be less problematic, since it can be justified by the title and subject, though the reader may miss the elegant formal recursions of "The New York Trilogy." Still, its rambling path does lead the book to a convincing statement of Mr. Auster's insistent theme that Nashe's identity, or anyone's, is not an innate quality or even a fixed one, but is instead a product of surrounding circumstance. And so if "The Music of Chance" is not Paul Auster's best novel, it is still a very good one.

 
 
HEDGING HIS BETS

At ten thirty, he switched off the television and climbed into bed with a paperback copy of Rousseau's Confessions. . . . Just before he fell asleep, he came to the passage in which the author is standing in a forest and throwing stones at trees. If I hit that tree with this stone, Rousseau says to himself, then all will go well with my life from now on. He throws the stone and misses. That one didn't count, he says, and so he picks up another stone and moves several yards closer to the tree. He misses again. . . . That was just the final warm-up toss, he says, it's the next one that really counts. But just to make sure, he walks right up to the tree this time, positioning himself directly in front of the target. He is no more than a foot away from it by now, close enough to touch it with his hand. Then he lobs the stone squarely against the trunk. Success, he says to himself, I've done it. From this moment on, life will be better for me than ever before.
Nashe found the passage amusing, but at the same time he was too embarrassed by it to want to laugh. There was something terrible about such candor, finally, and he wondered where Rousseau had found the courage to reveal such a thing about himself, to admit to such naked self-deception. Nashe turned off the lamp, closed his eyes. . . . At some point during the night, he dreamt of a forest in which the wind passed through the trees with the sound of shuffling cards.
 
From "The Music of Chance."

HEADLINE: CRIME

BYLINE: By Marilyn Stasio

 BODY:
"I know every bayou and channel from Sabine Pass over to Barataria," boasts Dave Robicheaux, the Cajun detective who works this swampy Louisiana territory in James Lee Burke's lushly descriptive crime novels. In A MORNING FOR FLAMINGOS (Little, Brown, $18.95), the tough but principled hero loses heart (as well as face) when two convicts escape his charge on their way to the penitentiary for execution, forcing him to plead with one of them for his life. Partly in penance and partly for vengeance, Dave leaves his rural home on Bayou Teche to set up a sting operation for the Feds in New Orleans.
Once undercover in the Big Easy, Dave maneuvers himself into the confidence of his sting target, a Mafia drug lord who is haunted by his war experiences in Vietnam and sees a kindred sufferer in Dave. As their odd friendship grows, so does the menace of one of the footloose convicts, a certifiable crazy who has landed a mob contract on the Mafioso's life. Dave wrestles with his conflicting loyalties to several people who figure in this complicated plot and then does the decent thing, in a throat-burning finale that scorches the moss-hung landscape from New Iberia to the Pearl River basin. 
 "This started out as a story about my own fear," muses Dave, who happily resists the impulse to indulge his psychic aches and pains to the numbing depths he did in three earlier books. "Instead," he says, "it became a story of others." And in the process, we must add, Mr. Burke also discovered -- in these rich characters, in the idiosyncratic freshness of their language and in the brazen originality of the evil they introduce to Acadia -- something worth writing about beyond his hero and the picturesque but stagnant scenery.
 If you think of the act of writing as a game of chicken between the author and his talent, then Derek Raymond is one author who achieves his ecstasy by sailing off cliffs.
Everything about I WAS DORA SUAREZ (Available Press/Ballantine, Paper, $7.95) shrieks of the joy and pain of going too far. No. 4 in the English writer's procedural series about an unnamed detective's garbage-detail job in London's Bureau of Unexplained Deaths, this hair-raising narrative opens in the midst of a double murder whose graphic horrors would be unreadable were it not for the author's unflinching insights into the killer's madness -- glimpsed through "eyes that had perished violently centuries ago" -- and for the appalling beauty of the prose. Just as there are no limits to the vileness of the crimes uncovered during the police investigation, which leads to a nightclub that traffics in loathsome debaucheries, so, too, there is no bottom to the detective's rage and anguish.
"Do you know I cry in my sleep?" demands this mournful witness to the inhumanity he sees throughout society. "My tears were not for me," he makes clear, "they were for the rightful fury of the people." Truth to tell, the life of Dora Suarez would move anyone to tears. "I was constructed to have a nature that could neither bend nor speak, nor be of a kind to ask for help," the murdered woman wrote in her journal. "I wanted to keep my sense of my own dignity, but it is the most difficult thing of all to keep when you are poor."
Touched by her story, the detective kisses the dead woman's hair and makes the only promise he can make to her and to all other violated human beings: retribution and respect. "We'll get our dignity back," he swears to the victims; "whether alive or dead, we shall all be as we used to be." No less obsessive than the maniacal killer he is stalking, the detective employs methods that are brutal and probably illegal. But there is something angelic about his fierce sense of justice.
Nature asserts a harsh presence in Archer Mayor's BORDERLINES (Putnam, $19.95), whose violent events occur during that dead-eyed non season in New England after the leaves fall and before the snow flies. "T'Aint Season," they call it in the sparsely populated and economically depressed area of Vermont known as the Northeast Kingdom. Hunting season is another name for it. Either way, it's the killing season, and Mr. Mayor's bracing police procedural captures the bone-cold chill in the air.
Joe Gunther, the veteran Brattleboro police officer first encountered in "Open Season," is on temporary assignment up north when five members of a religious cult that has taken over his hometown are killed in an arson fire. As part of the state police team investigating the homicides, Gunther slowly becomes sensitized to the changes in his old friends, observing in their hardened faces the deeper social disintegration of "this high, cold country [where] the law had less to do with rules, and more with personal honor."
Mr. Mayor writes invigorating outdoor action scenes, and his authoritative handling of forensic procedures has us marveling at his thorough knowledge of knife wounds and body burns. The formal beauty of this ugly detail is matched in tone by the crisp dialogue and tense confrontations he writes for characters who don't care to waste words or squander emotions. For a writer so new at this game, Mr. Mayor has astonishing control of his craft.
 Sharon McCone, the sensible and rational legal investigator in Marcia Muller's journeyman mysteries, bristles whenever one of her colleagues at the All Souls Legal Cooperative calls her sensible and rational. In TROPHIES AND DEAD THINGS (Mysterious Press/Warner, $16.95), the San Francisco operative prefers to describe herself as a realist, while admitting that she is "the white sheep in a family of rebels" and still envious of those who dare to challenge authority. That wistful admiration for the spirit of rebellion, along with her own sturdy reliability, makes Sharon the perfect detective for this mystery about a 1960's cell of radical Berkeley students whose past comes back to haunt -- and in some cases to kill -- certain remnants of their number.
The investigation opens when the victim of a sniper's bullet leaves a will that disinherits his children and grants large legacies to four nobodies. After some very smart legwork that takes Sharon into the past and present lives of these secretive beneficiaries, the detective finally pries out information that not only solves the case but also strips away "what little remained of the mythic charm of the 1960s."
Like her heroine, Ms. Muller works in a style more admirable for its clarity and efficiency than for boldness or brilliance. Her dense plots are models of construction, and if her characters lack spark, they are observed in a manner both sensible and rational.

SECTION: Section 4; Part A; Page 27; Column 1; Education Life Supplement

LENGTH: 1670 words

HEADLINE: Indian Rootlessness

BYLINE: By Dirk Johnson

 BODY:
IN THE MANNER of her ancestors, the girl knelt in the midst of a circle of her peers, placed a bit of ceremonial tobacco in a basket and gave thanks for the goodness of the Creator. Each Monday at the Hannahville Indian Reservation School in Michigan, the children participate in this ancient ritual, in which they are purified by the smoke from a burning stalk of braided sweetgrass.
"Megweech," says each child, echoing the Ojibwa word for thank you.
The ceremony is part of a sacred tradition for the Chippewa tribe. But it also represents the powerful and seemingly contradictory forces pulling at American Indian students and dividing tribes: on the one hand, the effort to instill an appreciation of Indian heritage so that these children's education will be more relevant; and on the other, the push to assimilate them into mainstream American culture as a guarantee of educational and thus work-force success. 
 These forces clashed most recently in New Mexico, where pueblo elders are pressuring parents to send their children to reservation schools -- while the parents, seeing local public schools as bridges to a broader American society, are deserting the reservation schools in droves.
The same divisive forces may also underlie the current dispute over the proposed reorganization of the Interior Department's Bureau of Indian Affairs. The Government wants to form three divisions, including an Indian education bureau that would receive an extra $100 million. But tribal leaders say that they would prefer being given the money outright and left free to deal with Indian education as they see fit.
For American Indians, this philosophical schism has become a physical divide; about half the Indian population lives off the reservation and half live on it. It has also created a quicksand on which Government administrators, tribal leaders, educators and parents are trying to rebuild a system of mostly inferior schools both on the reservations and in the poor urban and rural areas where Indian families often live.
 
 
Indians Called 'The Minority's Minority'
 In socioeconomic terms, Indians are perhaps the poorest minority group in the nation, "the minority's minority," as one educator, herself Indian, put it. Indeed, the Federal Education Department has appointed a 15-member "Indian Nations at Risk" task force to study the condition of education of Indians in the United States and, in a report due next year, to make practical recommendations.
"Finding solutions is going to be tough," said G. Mike Charleston, an associate professor of education at Pennsylvania State University who is on leave from the American Indian Education Policy Center to direct the task force. Professor Charleston explained, "We already know from previous research that education can be hindered by the extreme poverty and shortcomings in health, social and economic conditions faced by a major percentage of Indians."
These conditions are in turn influenced by levels of educational attainment. According to the United States Census Bureau, for example, the median income for Indian families in 1980 -- the most recent figures available -- was $13,680, compared with a national median of $19,920. On many reservations, alcoholism is rampant and the unemployed outnumber jobholders. But the Census Bureau figures also show that only 56 percent ofIndians over age 25 graduated from high school in 1980, compared with 66 percent of the total population.
There are some bright spots. On the latest Scholastic Aptitute Test for college admissions, for example, Indians registered a dramatic nine-point improvement in math skills, from 428 to 437. Verbal scores rose from 384 to 388. These compare with nationwide averages of 476 in the math portion of the exam and 424 in the verbal, each out of a possible 800.
 
 
Forced Assimilation Was Common
 This achievement is more remarkable considering the ignoble history of Indian education in the United States. Earlier this century, forced assimilation was the preferred approach, as many Indian children were taken to federally supported boarding schools where they were forbidden to speak their languages or wear traditional clothing. Henry Pratt, who ran such a school in Carlisle, Pa., was known for the motto: "Kill the Indian; save the man."
In recent years, educators have begun turning from this approach and opening reservation schools, like Hannahville, in which youngsters learn the native languages and customs. Indian figures who have played important historic roles are emphasized in lessons. Public schools, especially those with significant numbers of Indian students, are imbuing their curriculums with lessons on Native American history and contributions.
Several universities have expanded programs of cooperative education with Indian reservations. Northern Michigan University, for example, is sponsoring a program to upgrade mathematics and science studies at the Hannahville school.
"A lot of these kids have a certain amount of shame," said Steve Hirst, who is coordinating the program. "We ask them, 'Are you proud of being Indian?' And we get some negative answers." In response, the Michigan program will stress Indians' achievements in astronomy, mathematics, medicine and agriculture in an effort to boost the children's self-esteem and the relevance of the curriculum to their lives.
"Much of what we've learned about teaching theory, and are trying to apply for Native American schools, are the same methods that have proved effective for all children," said Lois Hirst, Mr. Hirst's wife and a professor of education at Northern Michigan University. "Learning in groups, for example, and applying what is learned, is effective for all children."
But some educators believe that special techniques must be fashioned in response to culturally engendered behavior that characterizes Indian children exclusively. Education experts say, for example, that when placed in non-Indian surroundings, Indian youths often exhibit a reticence or shyness that can impede effective learning.
"It's a cultural thing that involves showing respect," said Erin Kelley, a teacher at the Native American Preparatory School, which was started in 1988 by the Cushing Academy, a private prep school in Ashburnham, Mass., in hopes of providing Indian youngsters with the educational grounding needed to succeed in good secondary schools and colleges.
"When they go into a classroom," Ms. Kelley said, "they often view the teacher as an elder. And so they sit there quietly. That could inhibit learning if they don't speak up to ask questions, or participate in discussions."To help these children become more verbally assertive, teachers encourage them to speak before the class, even to shout answers. The class also sings together, as a way of promoting verbal expression. "By the end of the summer you can really see a change," Ms. Kelley said. "They'll come right up and start talking about their families, or what they've been doing."
The Cushing Academy program, which started with 50 children in 1988, served more than 300 youths last summer. A host of prestigious prep schools, including Exeter, Choate, Middlesex and others, have agreed to admit qualified students from the program, and to pay tuition and boarding costs.
Derek Begay, an Indian from Grants, N.M., is a sophomore at Cushing. Living far from home in an atmosphere that differs starkly from home, the 15-year-old has undergone an intensive learning process, on both sides of the classroom door. "A lot of these kids are so rich that their parents give out $20,000 a year for them to go to school," he said with amazement. "At home, I was used to seeing mostly Mexicans and Indians. Here I feel like one of a kind. But I feel unique, not lonely."
 
 
'My Parents Were Kind of Worried'
 Derek, who once wanted to be a lawyer but changed his mind because "there are too many of them already," recently received his midterm examination grades: A's, B's and a lone C. "My parents were kind of worried about me going away," he said. "And my mom doesn't want me to get involved with any non-Indian girls. But that's pretty hard, since there are only about four Indian girls here."
Indeed, the desire for education often exacts a price -- assimilation. For many Indians, the fear of losing the sense of identity and culture has stood in the way of leaving home for school. "It often depends on the particular tribe's sense of education," said Dana Wilson Klar, a member of the Houma Tribe and the director of American Indian Studies at Washington University in St. Louis. "The tribal elders sometimes think the people will come back 'white washed' -- no longer a real part of the group. It can be a very difficult issue to face."
Only 27.3 percent of Indian students who enter college eventually graduate, according to a recent survey of 72 colleges with significant Indian enrollment. Robert Wells, a professor of government at St. Lawrence University in Canton, N.Y., who conducted the study, contends that Indian students often encounter financial problems or homesickness because of being so far from home.
"It has been our contention," he wrote, "that a very important mission for higher education was to serve nontraditional Native American students where they work and live."
To that end, St. Lawrence worked with tribal leaders at the St. Regis Reservation in upstate New York to permit Mohawk Indians to take college courses on the reservation. And there are now 24 tribal colleges in the United States and Canada, which operate on a contract with the Bureau of Indian Affairs, although only the Navajo college in Tsaile, Ariz., and the Oglala Lakota college in Kyle, S.D., offer four-year degrees.
"One of the biggest solutions has been to take colleges directly to the reservations," said Jeffrey L. Hamley, director of the Native American Program at the Harvard Graduate School of Education. "It's really been a success story."

HEADLINE: Hispanics in Despair

BYLINE: By Roberto Suro

 BODY:
WITH just two months to go before his high school graduation, Maccario Garcia had the lead role in his drama club's production of "Macbeth" and was looking forward to attending college. It should have been a happy time, but sitting in the living room of his family's small apartment in Houston's East End one afternoon in April he toyed with the idea of dropping out of school.
 
 'Crisis in Hispanic Education'
 No single factor adequately explains the causes of this problem. Language, immigration and the effects of poverty all play a role. The impact of discrimination and cynicism about the prospects for economic advancement also have an influence. But over all, dropout rates are only one symptom of what President Bush late last year proclaimed "the crisis in Hispanic education." 
 According to the Federal Department of Education, some 29 percent of Hispanic 3- and 4-year-olds were enrolled in nursery schools in 1986, compared with 39 percent of non-Hispanic white children and 38 percent of black children. In a 1988 Federal assessment, 47 percent of 9-year-old Hispanic students showed a reading proficiency rating at or above the "basic" level, compared with 68 percent for whites. And although Hispanic college attendance rates have been skyrocketing lately, in 1988 only about 12 percent of Hispanic students ages 25 and 34 had graduated, compared with 24 percent for the entire population.
The dimensions of the problem are magnified by the fact that school-age Hispanics are the fastest-growing segment of the American population. The Education Department calculates that they accounted for 10 percent of the total in 1986 and that by the year 2000 there will be some six million Hispanic students, constituting 12 percent of the total student population.
As the rest of the work force ages and as lower birthrates persist among other ethnic groups, these Hispanic children will be an essential source of rejuvenation for the work force. Some economists and business executives predict a "skills mismatch" because the most productive jobs require ever- greater skills and the pool of new workers has less and less education.This crisis has been developing for well over a decade, but in the last year, in ways large and small, it has been moving toward the top of the nation's education agenda. Maccario did his part by helping to lead a student walkout at Austin High School in Houston's predominantly Hispanic East End in September 1989. More than 1,000 students hit the streets and complained before TV cameras about the poor quality of education they were receiving. School officials eventually judged the protests justified and acceded to many of the demands, including the principal's removal.
The most significant expression of concern came from President Bush on Sept. 24, when he issued an Executive Order on "Education Excellence for Hispanic Americans," and with a stroke of the pen seemingly reversed many of the attitudes, if not the specific policies, of the Reagan Administration in this area.
The order mandated the creation of a Presidential advisory committee on Hispanic education to develop Federal efforts with an emphasis on "enhancing parental involvement; promoting early-childhood education; removing barriers to success in education and work, particularly limited proficiency in English, and helping students to achieve their potential at all educational levels." All executive departments and agencies were ordered to become involved in achieving these goals.
The President's action constituted a "180-degree turn from what has been Federal policy in recent years," said James J. Lyons, executive director of the National Association for Bilingual Education, a Washington-based research and advocacy group. "We now have thePresident on the record in a document that has the force of law calling for action to remedy the crisis in Hispanic education," Mr. Lyons said. "What remains to be seen is how this is implemented,"
The executive order might seem an innocuous document that states obvious goals without creating new rograms or providing new financing. But Hispanic groups nationwide who have so eagerly praised it say they view it in historical context.
Although bilingual education represents only one, limited aspect of the school problems facing Hispanics, in recent years it has been a major political battleground. In 1985, William J. Bennett, then Education Secretary, announced that the high Hispanic dropout rate was proof that bilingual education had failed. Thereafter, he led a fight to limit Federal financing for bilingual education. A result of the Reagan Administration's efforts was legislation that restricted overall financing, allowed greater spending on English-language programs and restricted the length of bilingual programs to three years.
 
 
 Cavazos Calls for Reassessment
 The current Education Secretary, Lauro F. Cavazos, came into office with the Bush Administration proclaiming his belief that bilingual education was an effective means to help young students make the transition from schooling in their native language to learning in English. More significantly, perhaps, he has called for a reassessment of Hispanic education that goes beyond the bilingual issue. And he has turned from the debate over whether linguistic diversity threatens America's national identity to concentrate on more strictly educational questions.
A wide range of issues is being examined to find out what has gone wrong. For example, a study on the causes of the dropout crisis published last year by the Aspira Association, a community-based Hispanic youth organization, argued that there was a consensus among educators for concentration on early childhood. It posed the need to remedy many ills of urban poverty before schooling begins.
At the same time, a growing body of research has linked dropout rates to problems at the elementary-school level when Hispanic students are held back more often than others. Studies have repeatedly shown that in high school, students who are older than the norm are more likely to drop out.
There is also a substantial group of educators, with research in hand to back them up, who argue that lack of opportunity in higher education and the dearth of Hispanic professors on the faculties of the nation's colleges and universities deserve high priority.
Maccario Garcia, for example, did manage to hang on until graduation, but he was not able to enroll in a four-year university this fall as he had hoped. Instead he had to find work. He is taking some courses at a community college and continues to hope that he will eventually make it to college.
"You can't just blame the students or teachers for what's going on," he said. "You can't blame the administration either. You can't blame the parents. I suppose it's a whole system that's not working very well."
