HEADLINE: Guide Dogs and Masters Practice on Familiar Turf

BYLINE: By CAROLYN BATTISTA

 BODY:
ELI walked briskly along Farmington Avenue, in West Hartford. He skirted the benches, trees and planters that dotted the sidewalk; he looked both ways before crossing the street. Kathryn Mobley held the strap to Eli's harness and followed him.
Ms. Mobley, who has been blind since childhood, was on a training walk with Eli, her new guide dog. "Eli's becoming part of my life," said Ms. Mobley, who is an assistant attorney general for the State of Connecticut. "This afternoon, we'll go to my office." 
 Ms. Mobley and Eli were matched by the Fidelco Guide Dog Foundation, in Bloomfield, the only guide dog training school in New England. One of only 10 such schools in the country, Fidelco is the only one that provides all training in the blind person's community.
At the other schools -- including the Seeing Eye Inc., in Morristown, N.J., and Guide Dogs for the Blind, in San Rafael, Calif. -- blind people stay for several weeks to train with their dogs. Officials at these schools said they found such residential programs to be most effective and economical.
 
Three-Week Program
 Fidelco, however, brings the dog and a trainer to the blind person's usual surroundings. "The Fidelco program is quite well regarded," said Steven Crecco, supervisor of mobility for the Connecticut Board of Education and Services for the Blind. "And as a total concept, I think it is unique."
A Fidelco trainer, Jan F. Bednarz, and an Fidelco apprentice, Mark J. Tyler, strode along the avenue with Ms. Mobley and Eli, occasionally giving instructions. "Keep in a straight line when you hear the traffic," advised Miss Bednarz.
The walk was part of a three-week training program that began with Eli's acclimation to Ms. Mobley's home in Wethersfield, progressed to quiet neighborhood walks and continued with visits to busier and more distant spots, like Farmington Avenue, lined with shops.
"Eli went to a church meeting with me last night," Ms. Mobley said. "And we went to a baby shower in a restaurant." Also scheduled were rides on the bus that Ms. Mobley takes home from work when her husband does not drive her, and a trip to New York City, where Ms. Mobley sometimes argues cases and attends meetings.
Ms. Mobley noted that she had worked for nearly a dozen years with another guide dog, from the Seeing Eye Inc., where she had attended a three-week training program. She liked the dog and the training, she said, but when the dog died recently, she faced a problem.
"Now my life style has changed," she said. "I didn't want to be away from my home and office for three weeks."
 
Custom-Tailored Training
 Fidelco's director of training, John Blyfield, noted that some blind people simply cannot leave such responsibilities as jobs or small children to attend residential schools. Fidelco can reach those people and can provide custom-tailored training, he said.
Andrea Giudice, a junior at the University of Connecticut, in Storrs, has had her Fidelco dog, Duchess, since her senior year in high school. "First we conquered Simsbury High, then we came up here" to the campus, she said.
Ms. Giudice, blind since birth, noted that Miss Bednarz helped her learn the layout of the UConn campus. "Now I give Duchess a series of commands that will get us to classes," she said, noting that Duchess knows how to behave everywhere -- in her dormitory, at shopping malls, at the movies.
James Waddington, of Darien, trained with his dog, Vegas, around town and on his commute to Manhattan, where he works for Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
"Vegas has become a seasoned commuter," said Mr. Waddington, who has always had severely limited vision. "He gets me to the station, onto the train and finds me a seat." Before he had Vegas, he used a cane, he said. "But that was extremely slow. I can get places much faster with Vegas. It's very satisfying to go at a more realistic pace."
He added that his office colleagues had welcomed Vegas with gifts, like a rug to lie on while Mr. Waddington works.
 
'Durability of Character'
 The founder and president of Fidelco is Charles H. Kaman, president of the Kaman Corporation, in Bloomfield, a company with diverse products, including helicopters and electric guitars. Mr. Kaman's wife, Roberta, is vice president of Fidelco and heads its breeding program.
Long interested in German shepherds, the Kamans said they began in the 1960's to develop a variety particularly suited to be guide dogs. Beginning with animals selected "for durability of character and health," Mr. Kaman said, the breeding produced intelligent, stable dogs that are a bit smaller than other German shepherds.
At first the Kamans donated their dogs to guide schools and police departments. After a trip to Germany, where they observed a trainer who brought guide dogs and instruction to blind people, they opened Fidelco's school in 1981 to bring similar training methods to New England and New York.
Fidelco's program includes raising puppies that are placed, at eight weeks of age, with families that help them get used to living and traveling with people. On Saturday mornings, the families also bring the dogs to Fidelco, in a modern building on the Kaman Corporation grounds, for basic obedience training.
At 14 to 18 months old, the dogs return to Fidelco for six to nine months of formal training, in locations from backyards to subways.
"We prepare the dogs in different environments," said Mr. Blyfield. And, noted Mrs. Kaman, the training keeps growing in complexity. "As blind people become more mobile, more demands are placed on the dogs," she said. "The dogs need to be up to the challenge."
Trained dogs are matched with people on Fidelco's waiting list. The school has placed about 200 dogs since 1981 and expects to place 40 this year. Each costs $17,500 to raise and train, but a recipient is asked for only $150. The nonprofit foundation's budget -- $1 million this year -- comes from fund-raising events and contributions from individuals and businesses.
One recent Fidelco graduate, Mark Morrissette, of the Mashantucket Pequot reservation in Ledyard, is undertaking his own fund-raising effort for Fidelco. Last year, at age 26, Mr. Morrissette was blinded by a cerebral hemorrhage.
When he lost his sight, "I lost faith in myself," he said. "I felt useless." he said. But after he received his dog, Barrett, and training from Fidelco, "they gave me mobility and a second shot at life," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jan F. Bednarz and Mark J. Tyler, employees of the Fidelco Guide Dog Foundation, as they worked with Kathryn Mobley and her new guide dog, Eli, in West Hartford.
 (Bill Burkhart for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:
LOCAL LENDING
 How local lending institutions might be persuaded to finance larger numbers of local small businesses, and other innovative methods of putting neighborhood entrepreneurs on a solid financial footing, will be explored in a program at the Wainwright House in Rye from 7:30 to 9:30 P.M. Friday and from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Saturday.
 The Friday lecture and Saturday workshop, "Using Local Resources for Local Needs: Bioregional Economics," are rooted in the work of the 
 E. F. Schumacher Society of Great Barrington, Mass. The society, founded in England on the ideas espoused in Mr. Schumacher's book "Small Is Beautiful," published in 1973 by Harper & Row, is dedicated to reversing the prevailing concept that large organizations are more efficient and produce a better product than small ones.
 Mr. Schumacher died in 1977 before elements of his vision materialized in the debacles caused by corporate takeovers in the 1980's.
 An American Schumacher Society was formed in 1980 by its current president, Robert Swann, who will conduct the lecture and workshop with Susan Witt, the director.
"In Westchester the key problem is affordable housing," Ms. Witt said. One of the society's programs for dealing with it elsewhere is a community land trust, a nonprofit development corporation that purchases land, builds housing with the sweat equity of the buyers and sells the houses but only leases the land to the new owner on a 99-year term, restricting the land use to low-cost housing.
 Another program supplies low-cost loans through a credit union to people who work with locally produced food: farmers, restaurants and wholesalers. "Production should occur out of local resources for local needs rather than transporting products for long distances," Ms. Witt said.
 "In rural areas there are still small, locally owned banks that are willing to finance small businesses," she said. "In other areas banks are required to re-invest a certain amount in their own area."
 Admission to the lecture is $10, admission to the workshop is $45 and the combination costs $50. Call 967-6080 for reservations or more information.
 
CRIME IN THE SUBURBS
 "Suburban crimes are the same as city crimes," said Kenneth Gribetz, District Attorney of Rockland County, "but to a lesser degree." He will give a talk titled "Crime in the Suburbs" at the New Rochelle Public Library Friday at 7:30 P.M.
 Much of the material will be based on cases that he prosecuted, outlined in a book he co-authored with Paul Jeffries, former news director at CBS-Radio. The book, "Murder Along the Way," was published last year by Pharos Books in Manhattan.
 "We are trying to break down stereotyped images that people in the suburbs have about narcotics and crime being an inner-city problem or a problem of the poor," he said. "They still don't believe that upper-middle-class youths are involved."
 Mr. Gribetz was assistant district attorney from 1972 to 1974, when he was elected to the post in which he has served for five consecutive terms. He was assistant district attorney in Manhattan from 1968 to 1972.
 While he has "no magic answer," he said, he will cite some of Rockland County's anti-crime efforts that have had positive results, including sensitizing training for police involved in domestic-violence cases, family shelters and intervention programs for batterers. Admission is free. Call 632-7878 for more information.
 
FIRST LADIES
 Page Hedden Wilson specializes in writing and performing dramatizations of America's First Ladies, and she will present a one-woman program called "Wives of the White House: Companions in Love," at the Greenburgh Town Hall today at 2:30 P.M.
 Her monologues catch Dolley Madison at the point of packing up and leaving Washington as the British approach and the White House is about to go up in flames; Mary Todd Lincoln in self-imposed isolation just before she was subjected to a public insanity hearing in court that was engineered by her son Robert; and Edith Wilson, dubbed by the press "The Iron Queen," having to decide whether she can assume her husband's presidential powers while he recovers from a stroke.
 Ms. Wilson has performed her work throughout the Northeast and in Scotland. The Greenburgh Town Hall is next to the library at 300 Tarrytown Road in Elmsford. Admission is free. Call 993-1610 for more information.
 
SCHOOLS AND HOLIDAYS
 The League of Women Voters has organized a forum on "The Dilemma of Religious Holidays in Our Public Schools," to address the issue of separation of church and state in terms of Christmas decorations, religiously inspired holiday music, arts and crafts that depict religious holiday symbols, and myriad traditional practices from an increasingly long list of denominational beliefs. The program is scheduled at 7:30 P.M. Wednesday in the Katonah Public Library on Route 117.
 Whether schools are actually promoting religions, celebrating them, inspiring tolerance, or educating those of one belief about other beliefs, are among the questions to be raised and discussed by a panel of religious, legal and educational professionals. They include Dr. Paul Kelleher, Superintendent of the Bedford Central Schools; Jessica Bacal, a Katonah lawyer, and clergymen from local Episcopal, Roman Catholic and Presbyterian churches and Jewish temples.
 Admission is free. Call 764-4345 for more information.
 
WOODPECKERS
 Woodpeckers, as many homeowners are aware, are terrific insect detectives. That telltale rat-a-tat-tat against the exterior siding is a sure sign that the woodpeckers are dining on an infestation of carpenter ants or some similar treat.
 The Greenburgh Nature Center is collecting data on Westchester's abundant supply of woodpeckers for a January exhibition that will draw attention to their crucial role in maintaining a balance in the forest ecosystem, and the importance of preserving their habitat. The fragmentation of suburban woodlands has already resulted in the disappearance of many native wildlife species.
 To help research material for the exhibition, the center is seeking the participation of woodpecker watchers at 10 A.M. Saturday when they will walk the grounds to identify various species of woodpeckers. They may expect to find downy woodpeckers, flickers, red-bellied and pileated woodpeckers, red-headed and black-backed, three-toed woodpeckers and yellow-bellied sapsuckers, under the guidance of a center naturalist.
 Admission to the walk is $2. The nature center is on Dromore Road off Central Avenue. For more information, call 723-3470.

HEADLINE: Raise Adopted for U.S. Workers

BYLINE: By States News Service

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FEDERAL workers in northern New Jersey will be receiving some financial relief now that Congress has passed legislation that ties government employees' salaries to living costs.
"In New Jersey, the Federal Government has become a training ground for the private sector, where salaries are as much as 30 percent higher for comparable, skilled positions," said Representative Dean A. Gallo, Republican of Parsippany-Troy Hills and an advocate of pay parity. "As a result, we are losing our most skilled employees and our middle managers, including engineers, F.B.I. agents and medical professionals." 
 In the last days of the 101st Congress, the House and Senate approved a bill that raises Federal salaries 5 percent annually across-the-board from 1992 through 1994. In addition, the bill calls for an 8 percent pay increase between now and fiscal year 1994 for Federal employees in three high-cost urban areas: Los Angeles, San Francisco and the New York metropolitan region, including portions of northern New Jersey.
In New Jersey, about 40,000 Federal workers will qualify for the 8 percent increase. They include nonpostal, white-collar workers in Essex, Bergen, Passaic, Morris, Hudson, Union, Somerset, Monmouth and Middlesex Counties. The increase was incorporated into the bill, titled the Federal Employees Pay and Comparability Act, after President Bush proposed financing to relieve workers in those high-cost areas in his 1991 budget.
 
Adjustment in 1994
 The legislation also calls on the Bureau of Labor Statistics to adjust pay for all Federal workers nationwide starting in 1994, based on comparable private sector salaries and regional living costs. In New Jersey, where a two-bedroom house in Hunterdon County can cost $160,000 or more, Federal workers said stagnant salaries had led to high turnover and five-hour commutes for some workers forced to live in more affordable areas, lik Pennsylvania.
"The nominal pay for Federal employees in this region is inadequate," said Ron McWold, a personnel officer for the Veterans Administration Medical Center at Lyons, in Somerset County, who has been active in the locality pay fight. Mr. McWold said V.A. sites in Lyons and East Orange had seen turnover rates as high as 25 percent in recent years, making it an uphill battle to hire nurses, occupational therapists and other medical personnel.
New Jersey's V.A. medical sites have increased salaries for some 80 percent of employees as a result of emergency pay increases from the V.A. in Washington, Mr. McWold said. But other New Jersey Federal workers, from customs inspectors to tax agents, have not been so fortunate.
"The last several years have been extremely frustrating, not only for myself but for other chiefs of personnel in other Federal agencies," Mr. McWold said. "And we now see an opportunity to increase wages and do what we are supposed to do: serve the public."
The legislation authorizes Congress to set aside $3.5 billion to bring Government salaries closer to private sector wages over the next three years. In 1994, an additional $1.8 billion will be made available to close the public-private gap even further.
 
Seen as Boosting Morale
 In Washington, the American Federation of Government Employees applauded the move, saying the legislation will bring Federal workers' salaries to within 95 percent of private sector salaries over the next 15 years. The legislation will boost morale among Federal workers and help combat recruitment and retention problems, said Diane S. Witiak, a spokeswoman for the federation.
"We feel that it's a major breakthrough in the process to reform what we term the crumbling Civil Service pay structure," Mrs. Witiak said. "And we hope that the legislation will provide a vehicle to not only stop the gap from increasing, but to close that gap."
Mr. Gallo said the 8 percent increase for North Jersey workers was "a major step forward." He has long pressed for pay increases for Government workers in high cost-of-living areas like New Jersey, he said, and has written his own locality pay legislation. Mr. Gallo said the bill Congress approved accomplished much of what his bill sought.
"I have been fighting for two years to arrive at a fair locality pay policy, and I believe that this plan meets most of my criteria for fairness," he said. "Private industry does not make the mistake of overpaying workers who live in Terre Haute, Ind., while starving those who work in high cost of living areas such as New Jersey."

HEADLINE: N.R.C. Modifies Stand On Closing Shoreham

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
AS always with Shoreham, the legal decisions are slow and thick, but in a decision last month the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission appeared to be laying the groundwork for approving the decommissioning of the reactor.
The Long Island Power Authority hopes that by the end of the year Lilco's operating license can be demoted to a "possession only" status, for the radioactive material, and transferred to the New York Power Authority, so detailed planning can begin for the decommissioning. But those who want to preserve the reactor are minimizing the importance of the most decision. 
 The N.R.C., slicing a complicated issue thin, handed a victory to opponents of the plant by limiting the subject areas that an Environmental Impact Statement would have to cover before decommissioning could proceed. Opponents of the February 1989 settlement agreement, including the Department of Energy and the White House, had called for such a statement, which can take a year to prepare and can be subject to litigation afterward.
 
Independence of Agency
 Last month the Council on Environmental Quality, a White House office that enforces Federal agencies' compliance with environmental laws, sent a letter to the chairman of the N.R.C. saying that approving decommissioning would constitute a Federal action and that such actions have to be studied with such a statement. An impact statement would have to examine alternatives, the opponents said, including the alternative of running the plant.
But the five commissioners, who are appointed by the President but run an independent agency, carved out a narrow role for themselves.
"Lilco is legally entitled under the Atomic Energy Act and our regulations to make, without any N.R.C. approval, an irrevocable decision not to operate Shoreham," said the decision. Running the plant as a reactor or converting it to another fuel "are alternatives to the decision not to operate Shoreham and thus are beyond commission consideration," the five members added.
The decision noted that the case of the Shoreham case has taken the Commission into new ground, because approving a decision not to run a plant was not envisioned in the Atomic Energy Act.
What the commission would review, the decision said, was the method for decommissioning, not the underlying decision whether to run the plant. That alternative was beyond what anyone was required to consider in an environmental-impact statement, because running the plant would require a change in Government policy, the decision said.
At Scientists and Engineers for Secure Energy in Manhattan, a group that is suing to keep Shoreham alive, the executive director, Miro M. Todorovich, said he had found irony in the narrow approach of the N.R.C. When the Long Island Lighting Company was struggling to obtain an operating license for Shoreham, he said, the commission construed all issues broadly, slowing the process. Now, he said, it takes them bit by bit, without confronting the larger wisdom.
 
'The Watershed Decision'

Supporters of decommissioning see the new decision as a sign that Washington is beginning to step out of the way of decisions on the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station, and they said they saw a conclusion on the horizon.
"We believe that was the watershed decision," said Thomas A. Twomey Jr., a member of the Long Island Power Authority and chairman of its decommissioning committee. "We are very confident the license-transfer approval will be issued by N.R.C."
The commission might require the Long Island and New York Power Authorities to produce an Environmental Impact Statement on the method of decommissioning, he said. But he added, "We think that's unlikely."
On Wednesday the lawyer for two groups seeking to preserve the plant filed an appeal of the commission decision and tried to minimize it.
 
Anticipating Results of Study

James P. McGranery Jr., representing the Shoreham-Wading River School District and Scientists and Engineers for Secure Energy, said an Environmental Impact Statement could be very revealing, even if it did not consider operating the reactor.
"It would be able to set out all the costs, environmental and economic, of replacing Shoreham with the settlement agreement's proposed oil and gas plants, in contrast to the use of Shoreham," he said, adding that the decision had "nothing that would prevent us from putting all the relevant info before the public, so they can see what an atrocious proposal this is."
The appeal he filed argued, among other points, that the decision was "an abdication of the N.R.C.'s obligation to assure that its licensing decisions are consistent with protection of the environment."
The roles in the battle over the plant, which began 23 years ago, are now reversed. Opponents of the plant had used the skills of bureaucratic delay.
Now, according to Mr. Twomey, delay costs $8 million a month, mostly in labor costs, to preserve a reactor that will never run. The fuel is in the spent-fuel pool, and the reactor has been drained of water.
The Long Island Power Authority would like to put the fuel in dry casks, a method requiring less maintenance and fewer mechanical systems to assure safety and and leading to sharply lower costs. The hope is to sell the fuel to another utility, although there has been no market for slightly used fuel.
 
Specter of Iraqi War

Those who want to preserve the plant muse that if the standoff with Iraq turns to war, Shoreham may win another chance.
"If those wells in Kuwait become burning holes, we are ready to go to the President of the United States and ask that he simply declare that he has the power to put the plant into operation," said Dr. Todorovich.
Although many of the workers who would operate the plant have left, replacements could be found at other reactor sites, he said. "If it were the time of F.D.R. or Harry Truman, I know they would would quickly find the skillful operators in other places," he said.
Shoreham would save nearly 40,000 barrels of oil for each day it ran.
But Mr. Twomey said: "We think it's a remote scenario. It raises all sorts of constitutional issues that would be litigated for years and years and years."
 
Problems With Full Operation

Mr. McGranery said he was hoping that Shoreham would be given a stay of execution, in the form of a decision to do nothing. "Maybe in this case it would be appropriate to consider a mothballing, which would make the reactor available in case of future need," he said. Future events, he said, "might cause people to reconsider."
Others are also anxious to preserve the option to use the reactor to generate power. As recently as last month, the Energy Secretary, James Watkins, whose desk in Washington is marked with a bumper sticker reading, "Another Environmentalist for Nuclear Power," expressed hope that Shoreham would run.
But what little experience the civilian nuclear industry has with mothballed reactors is mostly bad. When the Three Mile Island 1 plant was shut for six years after the accident that destroyed Three Mile Island 2 in March 1979, technicians found extensive corrosion.
Another major problem is the workers' skills. Developing the teams of operators and technicians to run a plant usually takes years and begins long before construction is finished.
In addition, Three Mile Island 1 was under surveillance and maintenance for the shutdown, as is required under the operating license. At Shoreham, the Long Island Power Authority wants to end the expense of guarding, testing and staffing the plant, arguing that the money could be put into conservation or other activities.
If the license is transferred to the authority, even without the dismantling taking place. The authority is barred by law from operating a nuclear plant.

(The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 12; Page 1; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1483 words

HEADLINE: Dislodging Incumbents Is Growing Harder

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
THE elections for six House of Representative seats on Long Island are more a matter of incumbent versus non-incumbent than Democrat against Republican.
Despite the Republican political coloration of the Island, Democrats hold four of the six seats, and that mix is not likely to change on Tuesday. The six incumbents have in common huge campaign war chests, while their opponents are underfinanced and seemingly unappreciated by their own parties. 
 The House, State Legislature and judicial races highlight Tuesday's election, in which New Yorkers also will select a governor and three other statewide officials. Four of the statewide candidates are Long Island residents, but all are decided underdogs.
Just as he did in 1986, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is favored to sweep Long Island, thus providing a potential boost for other Democratic candidates. As for the Republicans, they are confronted with an admittedly weak state ticket headed by Pierre A. Rinfret, a ticket that could be further weakened by defections to Herbert London, the Conservative candidate for governor.
As a result, Republicans in both Long Island counties are downplaying Mr. Rinfret and promoting local Republican candidates and the Republican Party itself.
All polling places in both Nassau and Suffolk will be open on Tuesday from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.
A total of 681,373 Nassau residents and 625,206 Suffolk residents are registered to vote. But politicians of both parties are fearful that as few as 50 percent of the Island's eligible voters will go to the polls. The conventional wisdom holds that a low turnout favors better-organized and -financed incumbents who can identify and "pull" their supporters to the election booths.
The breakdown of registered voters by party for both counties is:
NASSAU: Republican, 328,577; Democrat, 208,932; Conservative, 9,935; Liberal, 3,778; Right to Life, 2,217, and Independent, 123,408. Void and missing party designations account for the rest.
SUFFOLK: Republican, 275,135; Democrat, 158,754; Conservative, 15,274; Liberal, 3,537; Right to Life, 2,834, and Independent, 168,570.
Heading the ticket are the statewide candidates. They include:
*Bernard Smith of Northport, a former State Senator and District Attorney, who is the Republican-Conservative candidate for Attorney General.
*Anthony DiPerna of Smithtown, the Conservative candidate for Lieutenant Governor.
*Gertrude Manning of Baldwin and Robert F. Nolan of Huntington, the Right to Life candidates for Lieutenant Governor and Attorney General, respectively.
Voters in both counties will choose six State Supreme Court judges. They also will select District Court judges in both counties and three County and one Family Court judge in Nassau. Republicans dominate the judiciary in both counties.
Suffolk voters will also decide the future of two countywide Republican incumbents: Comptroller Joseph Caputo, who is opposed by Robert DeGregorio, and County Clerk Edward Romaine, whose Democratic opponent is County Legislator Sondra Bachety.
But most of the attention on the Island is centered on the highly visible Congressional races. There, the almost unassailable power of incumbents -- short of conviction or death -- is evident, just as it is in most parts of the country.
 
How Politicians View Suffolk
 Politicians of both parties view Suffolk as a particularly glaring example of the power of incumbency. This is because the county, which is predominantly Republican, has three resident Democratic Congressmen, or more than Manhattan or the Bronx, the supposed Democratic strongholds.
The three are Representatives George Hochbrueckner of Coram, Thomas J. Downey of Amityville and Robert J. Mrazek of Centerport. All three started out by barely winning their first terms and then becoming the targets of strong challenges for the next election or two.
Mr. Downey, seeking his ninth term, is considered even by Republicans to be unbeatable. Mr. Mrazek, seeking his fifth term, is rated a very heavy favorite, while Mr. Hochbrueckner, running for his third term, is now moving into the nonmarginal category.
In 1988, when he defeated Mr. Romaine, the County Clerk, Mr. Hochbrueckner won with only 51 percent of the vote. But this year, Republicans could not persuade any well-known officeholder to challenge Mr. Hochbrueckner and his $600,000 campaign treasury.
James Needham, a former member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was eventually nominated, but he dropped out of the race in mid-July, leaving party leaders in the lurch.
A second search, with various Republicans again publicly rejecting the nomination, ended with a politically unknown and underfinanced retired Army officer, Francis W. Creighton of Jamesport, as Mr. Hochbrueckner's opponent in the First Congressional District. It extends from Brookhaven eastward to the end of the Island.
 
A 'Boy Wonder' at 25
 Mr. Downey, once a boy wonder as a Suffolk County legislator and first elected to the House at age 25, is now the seventh-ranking majority member of the powerful House Ways and Means Committee, which handles tax legislation.
He won with 62 percent of the vote in 1988, and even Republicans anticipate similar results against another Republican neophyte making his maiden run, John W. Bugler of Oakdale.
An engineer with the State Department of Transportation, Mr. Bugler also was "drafted" after several better-known Republicans declined to take on Mr. Downey and his $700,000 war chest.
In the Third Congressional District, which stretches along the North Shore from Smithtown to Port Washington, the election has the same cast as in 1988. In that contest, Mr. Mrazek defeated Robert Previdi, a Manhasset bank executive, with 57 percent of the vote.
Unlike other losers who usually lick their wounds rather than run again immediately, Mr. Previdi started his current campaign two years ago.
He has raised nearly $200,000 and is trying to capitalize on the unusually strong anti-incumbent sentiment that has shown up in polls across the country. Mr. Mrazek, usually less of a big spender and fund-raiser than his two Democratic colleagues, is likely to double Mr. Previdi's campaign kitty.
 
Incumbent's Liberalism Scored
 Like the two other Republican aspirants for the House, Mr. Previdi has built his campaign on the theme that the incumbent is too liberal for his constituents and has not done enough for the defense industry, which is critical to the Long Island economy.
Although the Nassau Republican Party is known for its fat treasury and ability to raise money, it has provided little cash for Mr. Previdi because, party leaders said, of the restrictions of the Federal campaign finance law.
Mr. Previdi has a Democratic counterpart in the Fifth Congressional District in Nassau, where a first-time candidate, Mark Epstein, an environmental lawyer, has raised $200,000 to finance an aggressive campaign against Representative Raymond J. McGrath.
Mr. McGrath, who is seeking his sixth term, won with 65 percent of the vote in 1988. The district covers southwestern Nassau.
Mr. Epstein has emphasized his environmental background and his support of abortion rights and gun control, issues that make this campaign more ideological than the others. But he has also criticized Mr. McGrath for what Mr. Epstein calls taxpayer-financed junkets as a member of the House Ways and Means Committee.
Embarrassingly close to the election, both Mr. McGrath and Mr. Downey were targets of an ABC-TV documentary on their recent trip to Barbados, together with their wives, at taxpayer expense. Both were secretly photographed at leisure, not at work, under the sun.
 
A Repeat Challenge to Lent
 In the adjacent Fifth Congressional District covering southeastern Nassau, Francis T. Goban of Hicksville, a plastics engineer and business executive, is challenging for the second time Representative Norman F. Lent, a Republican who won with 70 percent of the vote in 1988.
Mr. Goban, who has no illusions about his chances, expects to spend less than $5,000. Ironically, he is a member of the Coalition to End the Permanent Congress which, among other things, favors a ban on political action committee contributions. Such donations are major factors in the war chests of all six Long Island Congressmen.
The sixth House member, James H. Scheuer, represents a district, the Eighth, that is mostly in Queens and the Bronx. Many politicians expect the district to be eliminated in the redrawing of Congressional and Legislative district lines next year.
Mr. Scheuer's district includes a slice of Nassau in the Kings Point area. He was unopposed in 1988, and in 1986 he defeated Gustave Reifenkugel of Queens, a retired businessman, with 90 percent of the vote. Mr. Reifenkugel is running again, with even his own supporters anticipating a similar result.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
A French Firm With a Nose for Bargains

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
IN contrast to the British, Japanese and Canadian real-estate concerns pouring millions into this country in the last decade, few French firms have moved in.
A notable exception is Auguste-Thouard, a leading full-service real estate concern founded in Paris in 1922. And, in another divergence from the foreign investment crowd, it has shunned high-profile markets like midtown Manhattan and concentrated on hunting for bargains in industrial suburbs. 
 The reason has nothing to do with the firm's size. Auguste-Thouard's revenues from 25 regional offices in France total some $2 billion a year. In the last decade, it has established branches in the United States, Spain, England and Germany, and one is to open soon in Italy.
Its Manhattan office opened in 1982.
"At that time the socialists came to power in France," said Alain Lebleu, president of the American branch, which moved its headquarters to 39 Lewis Street in Greenwich in 1986. "It created a kind of paralysis. Earnings were down, companies were losing money, interest rates and taxes were high. The idea of expanding overseas was beginning to emerge in the French mentality."
 Today, with a square foot of commercial property on Avenue Montaigne in Paris priced at $1,200, compared to $400 a foot on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue, it is not surprising that France's real estate companies are reaching out.
 With the purchase of a 155,000-square-foot building in Shelton in January, Auguste-Thouard now owns about 500,000 square feet of commercial and industrial buildings, valued at about $50 million, on Long Island, and in Westchester County and Connecticut. The latest acquisition, put up by ITT in 1981 at 1 Research Drive off exit 12 of Route 8, affirms its interest in the Route 8 corridor.
Once Connecticut's industrial heartland extending from Bridgeport to Waterbury, the area is slowly reviving. Other buildings that Auguste-Thouard acquired and renovated in Derby and Trumbull are rented to small manufacturing firms. The two-story ITT building on 15 acres is the company's largest project to date in this country.
"It's a wonderful site overlooking the Trap Falls Reservoir," said William Leroy, Mr. Lebleu's American partner. But the building, he added, was badly designed and had deteriorated.
 The cracked pressed-concrete exterior was torn off and replaced with 8- by 30-foot panels of salmon pink and mocha ceramic tile. It was an unorthodox choice for a commercial structure, but the best alternative for complying with zoning regulations that, as a precaution against earthquake damage, prohibit adding more than 5 percent to the weight of an existing building.
INSIDE was a vast warren of ITT research cubicles, which Auguste-Thouard demolished, leaving open floor space that tenants may subdivide. The main entrance is at the back, confusing visitors who have to approach a blank wall from the road. It will be replaced by a new entrance on Research Drive.
Other major elements in the $3 million renovation include a glass-ceilinged atrium restaurant and a day-care center.
 ITT sold the building in 1986 to Alcatel, a French telecommunications company that resold it to Auguste-Thouard in 1988.
"Other buyers were interested," said James Fagan, the Coldwell Banker realtor who handled the transaction, "but they couldn't get financing. We went with Auguste-Thouard because we knew they would deliver. They were willing to make a large, nonrefundable down payment and they had the cash to close the deal."
 After eight months of negotiations, the company got the building for $5.6 million. The asking price had been $12 million.
 Auguste-Thouard is financed by Credit Chimique and Caisse Centrale des Banques Populaires, two French banks it has dealt with for decades. "They don't know this market," said Mr. Lebleu, "so they trust us to do so. We are glad to have them, because we don't know whether American banks would do business with us."
 The company is pursuing in America the same policy it said made it attractive to banks in France: avoiding hot markets, bargaining hard, sticking to properties it considers underpriced -- even if it has to renovate them heavily -- and borrowing as little of the purchase and construction costs as possible.
"One typically American thing that we have not done is over-leverage our investments," said Mr. Leroy.
Mr. Lebleu declined to say how much was borrowed for the ITT building, but added: "It is far less than the full amount."
Five years ago, when the building boom was in full swing, the two men decided New York City's suburbs would be their turf.
"We decided to focus on nondescript industrial-commercial properties that had no glitz, but nevertheless met a demand, in good locations, expandable, and adaptive to another use," said Mr. Lebleu. "Our observations led us to renovate existing buildings rather than buy raw land and build, because it is tougher and tougher to get approvals for new construction, especially in the Northeast."
 The ITT building was already zoned for mixed office and light manufacturing, and the site can accommodate 250,000 more square feet. When it reopens this spring, unfinished space ranging from 8,000 to 100,000 square feet will be offered at prevailing local rentals, which are now $13 to $15 a square foot. Gas heat will replace the oil furnace and a French air-conditioning sytem will save energy by freezing small ice balls during off-peak hours at night, then using them for cooling during the day.
 Fletcher Thompson, the Bridgeport architectural-engineering firm that designed the renovations, will be available to design and complete tenant spaces.
SHELTON has too much office space already, but Elaine Liberto, director of development, said the demand for manufacturing and research space is strong.
 Mr. Fagan feels that Shelton is a sensiblelocation for large users of back-office space.
"It has affordable housing, which Stamford does not," he said, "and when someone is looking for 50,000 square feet, Stamford doesn't make sense because of the expense."
 Looking to the future, Mr. Lebleu says: "We are not anxious to buy heavily. We are very selective, small, and maybe the French are more cautious. There are no gimmicks in real estate as there are in manufacturing cars. It performs well when you do it professionally, quietly, with input from the right architects."

GRAPHIC: Drawing: Drawing of former ITT building in Shelton after renovation for Auguste-Thouard, French realty concern. (Fletcher Thompson)

HEADLINE: ART;
Sallies Fly at a Bronx Gallery

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

DATELINE: THE BRONX

 BODY:
HUNTS POINT may be to greater New York what Les Halles was to Paris, but picturesque it is not. Then again, there is something exhilarating about this large tract with its strung-out warehouses and auto-glass dealers and coveys of tractor-trailers.
Nevertheless, the art that traditionally proceeds urban redevelopment has long been at hand in the form of the Krasdale Foods Gallery and this, directed by Sigmund Balka in cooperation with the Lehman College Art Gallery, is growing ever more ambitious. Its second outdoor sculpture exhibition is imminent and a Krasdale gallery "II" is scheduled to open in White Plains next year. 
 The present show of paintings, sculpture and works on paper by 42 artists is ambitious enough in that it investigates -- to quote the title -- "Humor, Satire and Irony." Acting as an overture to this is a group of painted lifecasts that properly belongs to the forthcoming sculpture display. Taken from South Bronx residents by John Ahearn and Rigoberto Torres, the busts, smiling and straight-faced, hang high on a wall in the ground-floor lobby, observing the "game" of business as if from the bleachers.
On the second floor, where the show begins in earnest, are posted guidelines for distinguishing between humor, satire and irony. But they aren't meant as cue cards because few of the works fit just one category. Nor should visitors worry when the sallies elude them, for some require a background in art history to be appreciated while others are dated (the miscellany spans more than 60 years) or else downright obscure. In other words, this is a salad bar where visitors may graze as they wish.
At the more literal end of the spectrum are canvases like those by Jerry Kearns and Sidney Goodman. An image that looks printed rather than painted, Mr. Kearns's combines the head of an Indian brave in red with horses galloping through water in blue and black. The irony -- or is it satire? -- is in the title, "Manhattan Project No. 2025." Mr. Goodman's "Western Drive" is a painting that is straight Southwestern landscape under a lowering sky except for a few details. One is the huge ultramodern building perched incongruously on the mesa at center stage; others are the posts among the cattle in the foreground that augur more construction. An alternative title might be "Apocalypse Any Minute Now."
Admirable as their intentions are, these artists seem concerned with proclaiming their own earnestness rather than the plight of their subjects. Even Goya knew to leaven moralizing with humor. Rodney Alan Greenblatt is no Goya but he gets nearer the mark with his cartoon in wood of a jugheaded youth who looks at a loss as he sits among garbage that may be of his own making.
At a guess, Paolo Pelosini's female torsos cut from crumpled metal and placed on filing cabinets are comments on the dehumanizing effect of the "system." Faith Ringgold's portrait of the Carter family as soft dolls is perfectly clear -- note the sequins that make the former President's eyes sparkle. Ms. Ringgold should be retained as official artist to the White House.
John Sloan holds his own in the cartoon department with etchings proving that tourists and connoisseurs of art were every bit as fatuous in 1927 and 1905 as they are now. All the same, nothing reflects a time more accurately than humor, and the influence of Surrealism, itself a report on human disintegration, is very obvious in the more recent ironies.
Alive, Max Ernst became famous after World War I with his bizarre collages; dead, he is everywhere in this show. The master's deadpan spirit is especially noticeable in Larry Blizard's lithograph of bananas caught, flagrante delicto, in a hotel bed, the clothes they never wore scattered on the floor, a banana version of Manet's "Dejeuner sur L'Herbe" hanging on the wall.
It is also in William Wegman's mock daguerreotype of his Weimaraner, Man Ray, playing a piano with the help of a squirrel and, again, it is present in a lithographed drawing of a man standing in a flooded room. The work of Glen Baxter, a New Yorker cartoonist, this is captioned "I would have chosen carpet for the hall. But clearly Brenda had other ideas."
Bernarda Bryson tackles political phoniness (circa 1935); William Gropper, legal lassitude (1969). In his pair of three-dimensional lithographs, Red Grooms has sport with, respectively, Little Italy and Salvador Dali. Barbara Marco sums up life in her collage of three cans labeled "sex," "power" and "money." Gary Bachman does the same with two large Pop paintings of an explosion containing the word "new." They are identical except that one panel is rimmed with flashing lights to draw attention to the "improved" that has been added to the "new."
On view through Dec. 18, this show is provocatively good but those wondering if art can be funny and still remain art are advised to check their concern at the door. Krasdale Foods is at 400 Food Center Drive and, as usual, prospective visitors must call before coming (212) 378-1100, extension 2125.
There is humor, too, in "Current Events" -- with a title like that how could there not be? But the tone is politically sardonic, as well it might be at the Bronx River Center and Gallery which, being a storefront at 1087 East Tremont Avenue, is closer to the front lines than Krasdale.
Still, the best work in the show is almost folk art, namely Peter Gourfain's banner mourning the late prime minister of Grenada, Maurice Bishop. A highly partisan work, it shows Bishop standing at the left and surveying Grenada's progress under his administration. New houses cluster among palm trees; a fishing fleet plys in blue water; and the famous airport is under construction.
A schoolteacher writes on a blackboard, "We are a light to the poor of the Caribbean." Painted in clear, strong colors outlined in black, figures and scenery mingle with words and the whole thing flows in an orderly fashion from one end of the banner to the other, recalling African compositions carved in wood.
Other striking works are Tenesh Webber's black-and-white photograph of a female squatter who stands in front of a newly wrecked building symbolizing the downscale side of the East Village, and the relief-painting, "Silver Curtains," by Rikki Asher. Done in bright metallic colors, this consists of three raised chevrons painted with thick serpentine strokes laid on a background that is executed in larger rhythmical dabs of impasto. Organized Abstract Expressionism is one way of describing this. Also worthy of attention is Diane Townsend's abstraction of many rectangles, shiny and matte, illuminated by one of creamy white.
The humor, such as it is, can be found in Willie Birch's "Solid State Racism Is on the Rise" and "Your Time Is Up" by George Smith. The first is a crudely simulated television beaming a blond anchorwoman and symbols of the Ku Klux Klan and decorated on the back with relief of a lynching party. The second is Uncle Sam, carved, African style, wearing clothes of red, white and blue but hair that is made of straw.
The show closes Saturday; gallery hours are 3:30 to 6 P.M. Tuesdays through Fridays; 1 to 6 P.M. Saturdays.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Tya Scott," above, a photograph by Tenesh Webber on display at the Bronx River Center and Gallery. "Siesta Time at the Tub of Blood," below at left, by George Luks, and "Nightmare No. 2" by Kathy Freeman at the Krasdale Foods Gallery in Hunts Point (Photographs by Suzanne DeChillo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Campus Life;
Asian Languages Gain A Growing Following

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
With the emergence of Japan and Korea as world economic powers, East Asian languages are getting more attention at universities across the nation.
The University of Chicago, the University of Wisconsin at Madison and the University of California at Berkeley have long offered a wide assortment of languages. Now they are among a growing number of schools offering more classes and spending more money on Asian languages, particularly Japanese and Korean. 
 Student interest in foreign languages in general has increased in recent years, but the largest increase has involved Asian languages, administrators say.
"The biggest change in the language picture has been the Eastern languages," said Richard Strier, master of the humanities collegiate division at the University of Chicago. "The most serious crowding we've had was in Japanese and Korean last year."
Data being collected by the National Foreign Language Center, an independent research organization based at Johns Hopkins University, shows that enrollment in Japanese language study has risen 68 percent since 1986 at the 171 colleges surveyed.
 
Decline in French
 Jonathan Wolff, a research associate for the center, said that about 50 of the 171 schools had begun offering courses in Japanese since 1986. At schools with more established programs, Mr. Wolff found that classroom space and teaching staffs as well as annual budgets are being strained by increased student demand.
At the University of Chicago, since the 1985-86 academic year, the number of courses in Japanese has increased to 5, from 2, while the number of language courses in French fell to 9, from 17. During that time, the university's overall enrollment increased and a stiffer language requirement was instituted.
Over the last year at Chicago, the number of introductory and intermediate language courses has remained the same in every area except for French, Italian, Portuguese and Spanish, which decreased, and Japanese, in which two sections were added.
Geoffrey Cox, director of financial planning and budgets at Chicago, said that while the total language budget is up 93 percent from 1985, the increased costs in Asian languages has been partly offset by increasing the teaching load of graduate student instructors and professors.
Columbia University, which has one of the oldest Asian studies departments in the nation, is paying for its program, in part, by attracting more outside gifts. In particular, gifts from Japanese donors are on the rise, said Paul Anderer, acting dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences and an East Asian language professor.
 
Classes for Koreans
 At Berkeley, the Oriental Languages Department "can't accommodate all the students who want to take the courses" in Japanese, said Jeffrey Riegel, chairman of that department.
Eric Broque, assistant provost for administration and budget in the College of Letters and Science at Berkeley, said that the budget for Oriental languages is up 10 to 20 percent in the last 10 years, while Romance languages have seen a "modest inflationary growth" of 4 to 6 percent.
The University of Wisconsin at Madison has been cutting undergraduate enrollment in the last five years to decrease class sizes and make the school more selective. This has led to considerably lower instructional budgets in Romance languages: 20 percent lower in French and Italian and 30 percent lower in Spanish and Portuguese.
But in East Asian languages and literatures, the budgets have been increased 75 percent since 1980 and 30 percent since 1985. There have been smaller increases in Semitic languages, African languages, Scandinavian studies, classics, Slavic languages and South Asian languages.
 
Second-Generation Koreans
 Administrators at all three universities pointed to growth in Korean language classes, which they related to the recent influx of second-generation Koreans who often are able to speak Korean but unable to write it.
The University of Chicago introduced Korean in 1985 to meet demand from Korean students, who now make up the university's largest ethnic minority. When Yale introduced Korean to its curriculum this semester, 52 students enrolled, forcing the department to add two extra sections to the one originally planned.
In contrast, most of the students enrolled nationwide in Japanese studies are not of Japanese descent. Mr. Strier at Chicago and Mr. Riegal at Berkeley attributed the increase to growing interest in Japanese culture and international business.
But Akira Miura, a professor of East Asian languages and literatures at Madison, said that the practical concerns prompting students to study Japanese are not often enough accompanied by a cultural interest.
He foresees a "stagnating pool" of new Ph.D.'s in the area because the number of people studying elementary Japanese is not matched by the number interested in teaching it.
"It's really not that interesting to teach people only interested in business," Mr. Miura said. He said he would rather teach people interested in "Japan as a country, not just Japan as a business."

HEADLINE: We Don't Have to Like Rap Music, but We Need to Listen

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We music business executives are increasingly debating ethics. Though we generally engage in less esoteric dialogue, recent controversies have focused our attention on philosophical issues confronting our industry.
Even as 2 Live Crew was acquitted of obscenity charges in Florida, parents' groups continue to pressure record companies to delete objectionable materials; outraged members of the artistic community demand creative autonomy, and we are left to ponder our values and responsibilities in light of the types of music we manufacture and distribute.
Yet amid all the legal activity, the lobbying, the label stickering and talk of the First Amendment, there is an elemental aspect of the situation that deserves more attention: what the music in question is telling us.
Rap music provides a window to our urban culture. Through it we can gauge the realities of life in our inner cities, which would otherwise be obscured, realities that are deeply troubling. To listen is to hear angry and disaffected voices, that are too often comfortable with violence and drunk on machismo. To listen is to hear from a population desperately in need of attention, slipping headlong into despair and destruction.
Almost 30 years ago, Michael Harrington wrote of the other America, the underclass in this country that lives in the shadows of high-rise society. Since then, the gulf between the two Americas has widened to new levels of disproportion. Never has the sting of poverty seemed so fatal; never has poverty seemed so insurmountable. Yet there is music sounding out from this other America, and its message is cautionary, filled with information, warning and, yes, rage.
We may wish that the music contained no violent allusions, hateful connotations or antisocial messages, but we live in a disturbing world. While we may prefer the old melodic standards to today's syncopations, we must face the fact that this is not a world of "polka dots and moonbeams," but a fractured society battling social and economic problems.
The music can be frightening. It is angry and subverts aspects of order. It is violent and hard to understand absolutely. Much of modern life is like that. Music and its lyrics reflect a reality that can't be censored. One can work to keep from being reminded of it, but it is there.
Our eyes must be open; our ears must be open. We must confront that reality, however it may offend or disturb.
 
ROBERT J. MORGADO
Executive Vice President
Warner Communications
New York, Oct. 26, 1990

HEADLINE: Gorbachev Steers Middle Course on Lithuania

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "To Oslo, Via Vilnius" (Op-Ed, Oct. 17), John Budris says that few in Lithuania celebrated news of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Nobel Peace Prize.
President Gorbachev's embargo of Lithuania, an action usually considered a form of economic warfare, was a moderate course. The policy signaled his refusal to yield outright to secessionist pressures, while he avoided a costly exercise in martial law and presidential rule. Moreover, it was probably the only course that would not jeopardize perestroika.
The imposition of an economic blockade to force Lithuania to follow the rules on seceding allowed Mr. Gorbachev to tell the left that he did not oppose secession (as long as it was handled legally) and to show the right that he was not about to let Lithuania (or any other republic) walk away from the Soviet Union.
Paradoxically, despite the damage to Lithuania's economy, and the delaying of Lithuania's sovereign aspirations, the imposition of an economic blockade will be seen as a good policy. By not imposing presidential rule, by not using the military to crush "counterrevolution" and by preventing the Soviet Union from imploding into chaos, President Gorbachev has increased the likelihood that the political and economic gains of perestroika will continue. By choosing embargo, Mr. Gorbachev has kept the Soviet Union on the path of peaceful reform -- social, economic and political.
How should we judge Mr. Gorbachev's Lithuanian policy? Winston Churchill supposedly remarked that he did not become the king's first minister to oversee the dismantling of the British Empire. In this same vein must Mikhail Gorbachev's actions on Lithuania be seen. As the first President of the Soviet Union, he designed his Lithuania policy to promote and protect the policy of perestroika, thereby assuring that the first Soviet president would not be the last.
 
NATHANIEL RICHMOND
Asst. Professor of Political Science
Utica College, Syracuse University
Utica, N.Y., Oct. 23, 1990

HEADLINE: Senators Urge Bush to Lift Vietnam Embargo

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and seven other Democratic and Republican Senators have written to President Bush requesting the lifting of the 15-year-old trade embargo on Vietnam.
The letter comes at a time when the Administration is slowly building relations with Vietnam, having recently opened talks with Hanoi to help resolve the Cambodian civil war and reinvigorating joint efforts to identify and return American servicemen still unaccounted for from the Vietnam War.Two weeks ago, the Vietnamese Foreign Minister, Nguyen Co Thach, became the first Vietnamese official of Cabinet rank to visit Washington since the war. 
 The chairman of the committee, Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, and Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, who is probably the most influential Republican in the Senate on foreign policy matters, complimented the Administration's efforts "for the expansion of contacts," but said it was time to quicken the improvement.
"The time has come for putting the Vietnam War behind us and opening anew chapter in U.S.-Vietnam relations," said the letter of Oct. 29, which was also signed by Senators Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, and Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon. "We urge you to act promptly to lift the U.S. trade embargo on Vietnam and we pledge our full support."
The Administration had no immediate comment on the letter. It has consistently said normalization of diplomatic and economic relations canoccur after Vietnam helps account for 1,677 American servicemen still listed as missing and the Cambodian civil war is settled.
Washington has urged Hanoi, the primary backer of the Cambodian Government, to push Phnom Penh to join three guerrilla groups in an interim coalition Government until United Nations-sponsored elections can be held.
The letter from the Senators said the Administration was mistaken to link the Cambodian conflict to an improvement in relations with Vietnam.
"We should not allow the prolonged end game in the Cambodian peace negotiations to prevent us from taking the next step of lifting the trade embargo with Vietnam," it said. "Conclusion of a comprehensive peace in Cambodia, establishment of a substantial U.N. presence, and conduct of free andfair elections in war-torn Cambodia could take years."
The Senators wrote that they were not entirely satisfied by the Vietnamese position on the war dead and prisoners of war, but that "we have seen considerable progress in recent months."
The letter continued: "In addition, we are heartened by the significant support for market economic principles that has been demonstrated by some members of the Vietnamese Government. These developments warrant a significant U.S. response."
The letter should reinforce increasing pressure from a growing number of American business executives and economists who argue that Vietnam could become a significant trading partner.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Bleak Days for British Banks

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
AS a group, British bank stocks have been among the world's best performers in the banking sector this year, far outstripping their counterparts in the United States. Five of the top 10 banks in S. G. Warburg Securities' index of world bank stocks are British. And five of the nine major banks in England have outperformed the British stock market.
But much of this performance was built on overly optimistic earnings forecasts earlier in the year and large dividend increases this summer. The bigger payouts look more than a little generous after the economic fallout from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and dividend cuts by several major American banks. 
 What's more, the stocks have performed unevenly. Only two, Abbey National Bank and TSB, have actually risen. The other "good" performers have simply declined less than the rest of the British market.
Now, reality -- and probably a recession -- are settling in. Last month's bank stock rally after Britain joined the European Monetary System and cut interest rates ended quickly. Last week, Barclays de Zoete Wedd, the London-based securities firm, sharply downgraded the earnings estimate for its parent company, Barclays Bank, and for National Westminster. It plans to do the same for Lloyds Bank, the third of the four big clearing banks. The forecast for the fourth, Midland, has already been cut sharply. These downgradings followed the surprisingly poor earnings reported for the sector in August.
"You could bring your forecast down almost every day," said Julian Robins, the firm's bank analyst for Britain, reflecting on the deteriorating economic outlook as business failures continue to rise.
Most of the bank sector should be off limits for investors, many analysts now say. If you are not in, stay out, they warn; if you are in, look for the opportunities to sell. Even the stocks that have fallen the most are not ready to be plucked up because more declines are expected.
Some banks, like Midland and Standard Chartered, have very attractive dividend yields that outperform the bond market. But analysts take these yields as warning signs of troubles ahead. Some even think the unthinkable -- that a British bank may actually cut its dividend; Standard Chartered is the best bet to do that. Other analysts just expect the increases next year to be much smaller.
And provisions for bad loans, which made the August results for most banks so dismal, are rising, as is the index for company failures. Even Abbey National, the bank that is still widely recommended, might be expensive now as the flight to quality this year has already pushed its stock up by 16 percent.
Abbey's secret is that it just recently converted from a building society to a bank. This means that all of its loans are mortgages, leaving it unexposed to the commercial and personal loans that are beginning to go sour. TSB has a somewhat similar advantage, with about 40 percent of its loans in mortgages.
Of the big banks, Barclays seems to be the choice over Lloyds, if you have to own something in the banking sector. John Aitken, director of bank research at County Natwest Securities, which is part of National Westminster, likes Barclays, especially because of its strong capital position. But it is still just the best of a bad lot. "It's becoming quite apparent," added Christopher C. Ellerton of S. G. Warburg, "that one thing you can't have too much of is capital."
Mr. Aitken is selling National Westminster, which has suffered severely from the downturn in business in the United States through its National Westminster USA. The American subsidiary has been hurt like others in the Northeast from declining real estate, which forced the parent bank to add more than $100 million in bad-loan provisions in the first half of the year. And these provisions are expected to rise further.
Midland, it seems by almost all accounts, is just in dreadful shape. The only thing going for it is the continuing prospect of a merger or some other association with the Hong Kong Shanghai Bank.
The banking sector, concluded Mr. Robins of Barclays, "may hit bottom soon. But it will stay on the bottom for a long time." Stay away, he says, until at least February, when the results for 1990 start to appear.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
The Economy: More Than the Sum of Its Parts

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
THE American economy did surprisingly well in the third quarter of 1990. And the businesses that make up the economy did surprisingly poorly.
That is the conundrum Wall Street faced last week as tallies of corporate profits showed more disappointments while the Government put out a guess that economic growth in the period was well above what most seers had expected. 
 The explanation for that divergence may be a simple one. What drove up the reported real gross national product figure -- to a 1.8 percent annual rate of growth from 0.4 percent the preceding quarter -- was not that Americans were spending and making all that much extra money. In terms of actual current dollars, the ones everyone spends, the nominal rate of growth edged up just two-tenths of a percentage point. But with a lower inflation rate, real growth showed a bigger gain.
That lower inflation rate -- if it stands up to the inevitable revisions -- may itself be a reflection of the economy's problems. Companies are simply unable to pass on higher costs, because demand is weakening across the board. That helps to boost real growth figures, at least for a time, but it does not provide the money companies need to pay their bills. It is a recipe for lower profit margins.
In that same third quarter, reports Richard Bernstein, a quantitative analyst at Merrill Lynch, 36 percent of the companies reported earnings significantly below Wall Street expectations, while 24 percent exceeded the forecasts.
Although the Bush Administration hailed the G.N.P. report as signifying there is no recession, the odds are that an unusual one has begun.
 "This time it's a balance-sheet recession," said economist A. Gary Shilling, "not an income-statement one. But it will get to the income statement." What he means is that the downturn is being set off by crumbling asset values, not by the normal erosion of demand.
Mr. Shilling, who runs his own consulting and money management firm, began shorting bank stocks heavily in May, and has prospered from the strategy. He says it is far too early to cover, notwithstanding the fact that financial stocks rallied at the end of last week, leading a move that pushed the Dow Jones industrial average up 54.70 points, or 2.2 percent, to 2,490.84. The N.Y.S.E. financial index gained 3.5 percent, its best showing in nearly six months, but is still down 30 percent this year.
There are hopes on Wall Street that the Federal Reserve, which pushed rates down ever so slightly early last week, will be able to move more aggressively soon, amid such indications of economic weakness as falling manufacturing orders and rising unemployment.
Lower interest rates are supposed to stimulate borrowing and business activity. But banks and many other businesses now seem less interested in seeking new investment opportunities than in scrambling for safety by reducing their exposure to risk.
The phrase for what happens when the Fed eases and nothing happens is "pushing on a string."
