HEADLINE: It's Tough Slogging in the Japan Markets

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
THE startling news that Matsushita Electric was negotiating to buy MCA Inc., the movie-maker, hit American securities houses here recently like a thunderstorm after a drought. Deal-parched investment bankers focused not on the proposed buyout's meaning for an ailing America or a Hollywood starry-eyed for Japanese money, but on one detail: Matsushita had not yet hired a financial adviser.
"Every carpetbagger with a suitcase has been to Osaka," said one banker, referring to Matsushita's hometown. 
 The unseemly scramble to get into the MCA megadeal was a sign of the times in Tokyo, where such multibillion-dollar transactions, with their multimillion-dollar fees, have been far rarer than most Americans expected.
Every part of the securities business here, in fact, has turned out to be more difficult than billed. American firms have established beachheads in such areas as securities and options trading, and they have generally enjoyed greater success in Japan than Japanese firms have on Wall Street. But progressing into the rich heartland of the markets and corporate Japan is still a distant dream.
Under American pressure, some regulatory barriers have been removed, such as a bar on foreign members in the stock exchange and in the syndicate that distributes Government bonds. The intricate cultural and financial links joining Japanese banks, securities firms and corporations have made Japan tough to crack, however.
Most important, the flood of Japanese capital pouring into the United States and other foreign markets, the largest such outflow in history, has slowed, perhaps to less than $80 billion this year, compared with $137 billion in 1987. Brokering that trans-Pacific movement of capital was to have been the core of the firms' business here. The plunge in the Japanese markets in this troubled year has also set back efforts to expand.
"This has been a transition year," said Randy A. Harris, president of Merrill Lynch Japan. "Everything that was so strong before has changed."
 
New View of the Globe
 Indeed, with the roaring boom of the 1980's having come to a screeching halt back home, anxious Wall Street firms are trying harder than ever this year to turn their Japanese operations into key profit centers. It simply is not happening as quickly as many would like.
The disappointment follows the overly optimistic projections of some executives five years ago, who imagined that "globalization" really meant most world markets would look more and more like Wall Street, where they enjoyed unassailable advantages. Because the markets here have remained stubbornly Japanese, the major American firms have been forced to temper their global ambitions and rethink what being "international" means, a process hastened by Tokyo's harder times. The slice of the Japanese markets really accessible to the foreign firms is still small, which means the competition for those modest spoils is keen.
"There are a lot of people chasing the pot of gold here," said Maynard Toll, the newly named president of a revamped CS First Boston (Japan) and one of the few top American executives who speaks the language and has some background in the country. "One of my biggest jobs is going to be managing the expectations of the people in New York and Europe about the potential here."
Evidence of the new order of diminished expectations is everywhere:
* With business slow, the heads of the merger departments here for CS First Boston, Shearson Lehman, Salomon Brothers and Merrill Lynch have either left recently or plan to do so soon. The most surprising news was the recently announced departure of Toby S. Myerson, head of Wasserstein, Perella & Company's Tokyo office and a Japan specialist who arrived with great fanfare just a year ago. "Anybody who thought they were going to come here, make some big fireworks and then return home didn't understand this business from the beginning," Mr. Myerson said.
* The market in Japanese stock warrants -- options that give the right to purchase shares at a fixed price by some date in the future -- has all but dried up since the Tokyo stock market began a steep slide last spring. That shut down a big source of profits for foreign and domestic firms.
* Japanese purchases of American stocks and bonds have dropped. In fact, Japanese investors were net sellers of $8.9 billion worth of American securities in the first half of 1990, a dramatic reversal from their purchases of $17.4 billion worth in the second half of last year.
* Even some seeming boons have turned sour for the American firms. When the Tokyo stock market exploded out of its lethargy several weeks ago for its largest-ever one-day gain, the stock index futures market shut down for two sessions as circuit-breakers were tripped. That cut off program trading, a major moneymaker for some.
 
'A Lot of Tire-Kicking'
 To be sure, all the American firms insist they will continue to ply the takeover trade actively here, and Mr. Myerson, who will not be replaced for the time being, said he was leaving because he wanted to return to practicing law. But his move was still taken as a potent symbol of the disappointment many clearly feel.
"What's happening is that there is a lot of tire-kicking going on as Japanese companies analyze potential targets, and we're getting some retainers to do that," Mr. Myerson said. "Those will pay a lot of light bills, but they don't always please the big bosses. We get paid when the deals close."
Added John Ehara, a partner in the merger department of Goldman Sachs, one of the more successful here: "This is a very tough climate and, if you have a short-term view, you won't focus on M.& A. now. But in the long term, it will be important."
And when there are deals, as the Matsushita maneuverings have demonstrated, the competition has been cutthroat. The Japanese are eagerly pursuing the business along with the Americans. (Morgan Stanley, which has been a leader in mergers and acquisitions, is believed to have the best shot in the race for Matsushita's business, although a deal with MCA has not been concluded.)
"This market is overbanked," said Deryck C. Maughan, chairman of Salomon Brothers Asia, the most profitable Japanese operation of the 52 foreign securities firms -- 22 of them American -- doing business in Japan.
One result is that the huge growth in staffing at the American firms has been slowing this year. Though Salomon Brothers has just spent about $30 million to move into a sleek new building in Otemachi, Tokyo's main business district, Mr. Maughan said the firm would not grow much more than its current 600, which is up from 100 people in 1985.
As for Goldman Sachs, "We will continue to grow, but the rate will slow," said Bracebridge H. Young Jr., co-head of the firm's Tokyo office. Goldman's Japan operation has expanded from 330 at the beginning of last year to 450 now.
For its part, CS First Boston is still emerging from a wrenching process of bringing in new managers and laying off some staff. Allen Wheat, the new head of the Pacific region, said the firm has reduced its staff by about 40 and is now at about 400, where it expects to stay.
Morgan Stanley's staff has jumped to 650, but the growth rate is slowing, executives there said. Merrill Lynch is the only foreign firm trying to build a retail branch system in Japan, and it opened its sixth office recently. But Mr. Harris said the overall head count of 600 would not expand much further.
Expatriates account for roughly 10 to 20 percent of the staff of the American firms.
While the mood of the Americans is sober, it is far from pessimistic. That is largely because the American firms here still have an important edge that has generally made their operations profitable. That edge is ideas -- for new financial products, trading strategies and approaches to acquisitions. Most of these innovations require a savvy use of technology; indeed, if the emblem of Wall Street in the 1980's was a flashy pair of red suspenders, in Tokyo in the 1990's it is the greenish glow of computer screens.
 
How Japanese Have Done
 In addition, the American houses, not surprisingly, have far better client bases in the United States than do Japanese firms, and the Americans exploit those links in brokering cross-border transactions of all kinds. Those links are one reason that the Big Four Japanese securities firms -- Nomura, Daiwa, Nikko and Yamaichi -- have performed even more poorly in the United States than the Americans have in Tokyo.
In some ways, the major American securities houses have done better in Tokyo than in London. There have been few disasters to rival those that have jolted the firms in London, such as the plunge in various businesses after the Big Bang in 1986, major layoffs several years ago and the losses in the wake of the 1987 market crash.
Another key advantage the American firms enjoy is their willingness to use capital in taking risks. A number of them, including Salomon Brothers, Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, have combined their technological skills with their penchant for risk-taking to churn out handsome profits from the complex futures and options markets. One of the changes initiated by CS First Boston's new managers was to begin trading more actively with the firm's own capital.
The Japanese earn so much from essentially riskless businesses -- by far their largest source of revenues is simple stock commissions -- that they have traditionally neglected trading with their own capital. In a market that still has fixed commissions, taking those risks has not been necessary. Thus, exploiting the price differentials that regularly show up in the crevices of the Japanese markets is left to the Americans.
One of the biggest breaks for Salomon, the biggest trader here, was the introduction of futures on Japanese Government bonds in 1985. "I don't think we could have succeeded here without that," Mr. Maughan acknowledged. "The Japanese had too big a client base and too big a share of the market to let us in without something new."
 
On the Fringes
 That has generated steady profits. But it also has left the Americans on the periphery, making do with the scraps. The most lucrative core businesses, such as Japanese stock sales and underwritings, remain almost the exclusive terrain of the Big Four.
"This has been and continues to be an oligopoly," said Mr. Harris of Merrill Lynch. "That's why Japan is still not a market where one competes on price, which is obviously not what we're used to."
Despite the progress, Americans and other foreigners continue to complain about the tight formal and informal regulations that make it difficult for them to compete. The Government has not permitted development of a bond repurchase market, a financing technique that is essential to certain kinds of sophisticated trading. The short-term money market and securitization, the process of creating bonds from other financial obligations, remain in their infancy. And the underwriting process is hobbled by outdated regulations and Government interference.
At one time, the American firms took their complaints to Washington and tried to use governmental pressure to force the Japanese to open up. They altered that tactic a little more than a year ago, however, when the firms began to worry that the profitable niches they had carved out might be threatened by too much pressure.
Most executives at the firms and other experts say they have run into the reality that there are effectively two kinds of markets here: international, to which they have access and can compete, and domestic, the most lucrative, from which they have been largely barred.
"The markets have become global from the point of view of buyers and sellers of securities," said Samuel L. Hayes 3d, a Harvard Business School professor and co-author of a recent book on international investment banking. "But they are not global from the point of view of the vendors in the middle. There is not much evidence that the American firms have made real inroads into the domestic marketplace in Japan."
Indeed, Mr. Toll, who arrived in June with the assignment of rebuilding CS First Boston's Japanese operations, makes no bones about the fact that the firm wants to become a good niche competitor and "stay out of places where we'll just get in trouble."
"To me, that means we will never grow to a great size here," said the 48-year-old Mr. Toll, who first came to Japan as a student at Keio University in 1961.
Mr. Myerson, the departing Wasserstein Perella executive, is equally low key. "Every once in a while there will be a megadeal, but what you should be doing here is building relationships," he said.
Mr. Myerson, 41, also went to university in Japan and speaks the language. As a lawyer in New York, he spent 18 years developing a coterie of Japanese clients. Despite that experience and the splash he made when he arrived, he and his firm, which is 20 percent owned by Nomura Securities, have not been racking up billion-dollar deals. He has been, as he said, still laying the groundwork.
Where the Americans have succeeded is in using the most complex financial instruments. When CS First Boston was looking for a new executive to head its Pacific region, it ended up hiring practically an entire department from Bankers Trust that focused on high-technology investment products, customized interest-rate swaps and options.
 
Closing the Gap
 All the same, the Japanese are catching up. Executives at the American firms concede that the Japanese are spending more on computers and are recruiting specialists to develop these new products. Daiwa wasted no time in crowing publicly that Harry M. Markowitz, who shared in this year's Nobel award in economics, was a consultant.
"The product life cycle is so short that the Japanese can have a new product in six weeks," said Patrick J. Ward, head of the equities department at Goldman Sachs.
Those realities have persuaded most of the American firms here to narrow their focus and to recruit and lean much more heavily on Japanese professionals.
"The next year in my view is going to be painful, and some people are going to say that it's not worth it and could pack up," said James M. Walsh, the newly named president of Prudential-Bache Japan, who is trying to re-energize the operation.
Others were more optimistic, if still realistic. "We're not here swinging for the fences," said Goldman's Mr. Ward. "We're building a business, and that will take time."

YOUNG JAPANESE ON AN AMERICAN FAST TRACK

 AT 30 years of age, Koji Tsubouchi is the sort of bright young man who, if he worked at a Japanese securities house, would probably be at a regional sales office pumping the phones by day and drinking with colleagues by night to insure an unimpeded but slow passage up the corporate ladder.
At Goldman Sachs (Japan), however, he is a no-nonsense manager of a key operation and a representative of a new breed that is helping American firms secure a place in the difficult Japanese market.
As head of Goldman's Japanese Government-bond trading desk, Mr. Tsubouchi has far more responsibility than he would at a Japanese firm, earns much more and, with his hot track record, is a big profit center. He does this in a most un-Japanese way: he takes risks.
"Typically, our exposure is 5 billion yen or so, but it can get up to 100 billion or 200 billion," Mr. Tsubouchi said nonchalantly of the calculated bets he and his traders, who are all Japanese, place in the market. (A billion yen is a bit less than $8 million.)
"The biggest risks we have in Japan are in Koji's book," said Bracebridge H. Young Jr., co-head of Goldman's Tokyo office.
By straddling the two cultures, Mr. Tsubouchi is also helping Goldman transform itself from an American firm into a new kind of international entity whose character changes slightly from one country to another.
A poised young man who is nearly six feet tall, Mr. Tsubouchi is a 1982 economics graduate from Waseda University, one of Japan's more prestigious training grounds. He joined Goldman after receiving an M.B.A. from Cornell University in 1985.
Mr. Tsubouchi returned to Tokyo in 1986 and by late 1987 was trading Japanese Government bonds, using computers to locate and exploit small price differentials between different bonds. More important, he was not simply executing company policies decided by committees; he was given a lot of capital to trade with, using his own judgment. He was given a chance to succeed, as well as fail.
When Mr. Tsubouchi joined Goldman, the move was considered somewhat unusual. But suddenly, many graduates of top Japanese universities are looking for jobs with the high-paying American houses.
"It's become sort of fashionable for young Japanese to talk to an American firm," Mr. Tsubouchi said. "When I talk to these people I try to let them know that there is also a downside. They're not used to that."
He added, "Japanese institutions generally allow a transition period from college. You have two or three years to go from a kid to a businessman. At an American firm, you're a businessman from the first day. It's tough for young Japanese to do that."
Another downside: Working for an American firm makes movement to a career track at a major Japanese firm all but impossible.

HEADLINE: All About/Exercise Machines;
The Fitness Boom Ends Up at Home

BYLINE: By BARRY SCHIFFMAN

 BODY:
THE Marines still do their pull-ups.Heavyweights jump rope. But these days more and more ordinary Americans are trying to get in shape with elaborate and expensive home exercise equipment. Last year, they spent $1.73 billion, triple what they spent in 1980.
Exercise machines are the latest in the fitness boom, suitable for an aging, family-minded generation. 
 Richard Miller, owner of Cutler Owens, the Gym Source, says his New York store began as a full-line sporting goods retailer that catered to runners and tennis players in the 1970's. He started selling exercise equipment in 1981 and gradually eliminated everything else, concentrating on higher-end products. "I figured the ultimate would be in the home," he said. "People were in the health clubs, they got married and had kids, and they are staying at home."
In National Sporting Goods Association consumer surveys, retail sales of home fitness equipment grew 22 percent in 1988 and 19 percent in 1989. The equipment accounts for about 15 percent of sporting goods sales, more than any other category except hunting. The products range from a bottom-of-the-line exercise bicycle, for less than $100, to computerized treadmills for more than $3,000.
Some in the industry wonder if the growth can continue. How many people will keep sweating in the privacy of their homes? they ask. And if more machines end up in closets, will fewer new ones be sold?
 
A Fickle Business

Matching Trends Is a Key to Success
 Exercise equipment fads can be fleeting. Rowing machines were the rage several years ago; now, sales are slow. Treadmills and stair machines are popular, but for how long? Several companies are bringing out weight machines, for those less interested in endurance than in strength.
Manufacturers have learned that buyers can be quick to rebel when they don't get results, said Wayne Sales, merchandise manager for sporting goods at K Mart. In the mid-1980's, he said, sales stagnated. "We saw a lot of equipment that was gimmicky." Since then, he added, "There has been a resurgence of basic, fundamental equipment."
Pamela Miller, fitness editor at Sportstyle, a trade magazine, says consumers who are fickle about equipment usually retain their dedication to good health. When they become discouraged with one machine, they try another, she said. But others in the industry fear that the boom will end as buyers consign their machines to the closet.
Manufacturers always stand ready to provide new products. Those companies that keep up with the trends lead the industry. Most are privately held, keeping even their sales figures to themselves. But Sportstyle reports that Diversified Products of Opelika, Ala., was the industry leader last year with sales of $220 million, up 22 percent. Weslo Inc., of Logan, Utah, and its sister company, Proform Fitness Products Inc., are growing even faster, with a 94 percent gain, to $204 million, last year.
These companies prosper by offering a range of products at all prices. They rely heavily on giant retail chains like Sears, Roebuck & Company and the K Mart Corporation, which account for an increasing share of industry sales. After the leaders, about three dozen smaller companies tend to be more specialized.
The largest of the more specialized companies is Nordic Track, of Chaska, Minn., a unit of the publicly held CML Group Inc. Its machines mimic the action of cross-country skiing, allowing skiers to train without snow and lame runners to pile up their mileage without torturing their knees. Nordic has relied exclusively on mail order, but it is about to open its first retail outlet, in Washington. Nordic's revenues have risen from $14 million in 1986, when CML took over, to $85 million for the fiscal year that ended in July.
Not every exercise equipment company can keep up with the industry's pace. Last year, Escalade Inc., of Evansville, Ind., a maker of recreational products and office equipment, acquired 55 percent of Marcy Fitness Products, a financially troubled manufacturer of weight benches and related goods. John Wilson, secretary-treasurer of Escalade, explained that Marcy had tried to expand too quickly and failed to control expenses. Although the takeover kept Marcy in business, the company's sales failed to pick up, and the financial drain has left the parent concern in the red.
 
Threats to Sales

Flimsy Equipment, Bored Customers
For many home athletes, buying fancy machines is much less taxing than using them. Do most buyers keep on rowing, running, skiing or lifting long enough to generate more sales? "That is the proverbial question," said Bill Smith, vice president of marketing for Diversified Products. "Interest does tend to wane." But in a survey, he found that equipment use was surprisingly high, with more than half of all buyers remaining consistent users of the products.
Nordic Track attempted to telephone 1,209 buyers who had owned its machines for five years. Of the 207 reached, 69 percent said they were still using the equipment, averaging three and a half workouts a week of 25 minutes each.
Some say that boredom and flimsy low-priced machines threaten the industry's success. Steve Onder, general manager of the Sports Training Institute in Manhattan, a personal training and physical therapy center, said the most popular, lower-priced equipment "doesn't support a long-term training program." A cheap treadmill does not have a motor capable of turning the belt fast enough for jogging, he said.
Sebastian Di Casoli, director of marketing services for the Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association, says some buyers give up when they find the machines cannot exercise for them. "A lot of people do it to relieve guilty feelings about their weight," he said. "It does get boring and many machines end up in the closet."
Some makers have found innovative ways of fending off boredom. The Precor 9.4sp treadmill, list price $4,500, can be set for 48 exercise programs in miles, 48 in kilometers, or programs of the owner's choosing. The Walking Center in Beverly Hills, Calif., has another way to make its dozen treadmills -- priced at $2,500 to $3,000, or $95 a month to use them in the showroom -- more inviting. Each is hooked up to a television with an earphone.
 
The Outlook

A Recession Might Even Help Sales
Makers of exercise equipment insist that their sales will remain firm even as the nation's economy sags. In troubled times, consumers usually back away from major purchases. But exercise equipment is so new that few long-term records exist. "Leisure-time goods do fairly well in a recession, but exercise equipment might be different," Mr. Di Casoli said. "There is no data. On top of that, the items that are growing are the more expensive ones like treadmills and stair machines."
Gary Stevenson, a founder and the chief operating officer of Weslo, says workout machine sales will increase as many families find they offer an economical way to sweat out a recession. "People will drop vacations," he said. "They will also tend to stop paying for health clubs, weight-loss centers. There is early evidence they will buy equipment for the home."
Even the Middle East crisis may help, some say. As John Walsh, the exercise equipment buyer for Sears, said, "Usually when times get tough, people will stay at home and more equipment will be sold. We saw this in the gasoline crises of the 1970's."
Fitness industry executives say they also have demographics on their side. As the population ages, the demand for equipment can only increase, they say. Industry statistics show that 35- to 65-year-olds are the biggest buyers. They are usually secure in their occupation, have more money than the elderly or young, and are more resistant to a recession.
For all their marketing and innovations, many makers of fitness equipment say their best sales device might be the mirror. As Phyllis Nwransky, public relations manager at the Weider Health and Fitness Corporation, put it, "If we don't do something, we get fat and lazy and we look funny."
 
 
A MUSCULAR MANUFACTURER
 FOR some entrepreneurs, helping others build muscles seemed like a good way to build wealth. Weslo Inc., one of the fastest-growing manufacturers of exercise equipment, entered the business to balance seasonal sales of wood stoves.
In 1977, Scott Watterson and Gary Stevenson, students at Utah State University, after two years as Mormon missionaries in the Far East, began importing kitchenware and marble products to pay for their educations. Two years later, they added a third partner, Blaine Hancey Jr., to jump on a trend. In the midst of an energy crisis, their company bought the rights to Fire King wood stoves and developed a network of retailers, mostly in the West.
Then the partners looked for something to sell in the spring and summer. They settled on trampolines. That business brought them to sporting goods trade shows. There, Mr. Stevenson says, "We recognized that Americans were looking for a way to stay well."
They began importing simple exercise cycles and then started making treadmills in Logan, Utah, where the company is based. They expanded to a full line of equipment, including elaborate home gyms. Weslo makes 70 to 80 percent of its products in Logan and the rest in Taiwan now.
Weslo bought the rights to the Proform name in 1987, after Nike, the sneaker maker, abandoned exercise equipment. Weslo itself was bought in 1988 by the the Weider Health and Fitness Corporation, a maker of weights and food supplements and publisher of several fitness magazines. The company was founded by Joe Weider, a bodybuilder who helped train Arnold Schwarzenegger.
Mr. Stevenson and Mr. Watterson, still in charge, continue to demonstrate agility as well as strength. Weslo has cultivated the big department stores so well that earlier this year, it was cited by Sears, Roebuck merchandise buyers for products that made outstanding contributions to the stores' sales.
And Weslo is always updating its equipment. Its treadmills now offer computerized monitors for pulse, calorie consumption and equivalent distance. "You need something motivational," Mr. Stevenson said. " Feedback makes the task less mundane."

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
When a Company Promises Service, Does It Mean It?

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
VIRTUALLY every computer maker boasts, one way or another, that its No. 1 goal is to serve the customer. It is no secret, though, that some companies simply pay lip service to the idea, while others do an extraordinary job of keeping customers happy. Unfortunately for corporate customers, it is often difficult to discover which is which until after the equipment is purchased.
Now there is help, in two surveys of business computer users -- one by Dataquest Inc., a market research firm in San Jose, Calif., and the other by PC Magazine, published in New York by the Ziff-Davis Company. The results, which reflect the experiences of thousands of companies, are intriguing. 
 "Although technology remains a crucial factor to business success, it is no longer enough," said Manny Fernandez, Dataquest's president, in a statement accompanying the results of his company's survey. "Whatever competitive edges that might have once been found in this area have long since been diminished in importance. Over the past few years, PC's have taken on all of the characteristics of commodity products."
In other words, a PC is a PC, and one company's 386SX box is generally indistinguishable from another's, as if the computers were television sets or toaster ovens. Significant technical differences today are found mainly in the newest high-end systems, not in the standard-issue PC's on most office desks.
Few corporate buyers are willing to justify spending $10,000 on a premium-brand personal computer when a virtually identical one is available elsewhere for $4,000. Recognizing this, most computer companies have cut prices sharply in recent months. Price cuts will get customers in the door, but to make the sale, computer companies are emphasizing product reliability, service and support.How long will this computer run before something goes wrong? How painless will repairs be? Where can a user get help?
In both the PC Magazine and Dataquest studies, mail-order companies made their customers happier than the big-name companies, with a few exceptions. What is more, the Dataquest survey for the first time put hard evidence behind something that many industry executives suspected. "Vendors who finished in the top third in overall customer satisfaction really gained market share, and those in the bottom third lost market share," said Greg Chagaris, a Dataquest vice president.
Mr. Chagaris declined to identify the companies that finished at the bottom of the survey. He was willing to say only that Compaq, Zenith, Epson, Toshiba, Wyse, A.T.& T, Unisys, Grid and Wang finished "in the bottom two-thirds."
Dataquest, a subsidiary of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, asked more than 1,000 corporate buyers how satisfied they were with the PC's they used most often. The companies that led Dataquest's customer satisfaction list were, in order:
* CompuAdd, of Austin, Tex.
* Hewlett-Packard, Palo Alto, Calif.
* Dell Computer, Austin
* Tandy, Fort Worth.
* AST Research, Irvine, Calif.
* Everex Systems, Fremont, Calif.
* International Business Machines, Armonk, N.Y.
* Apple Computer Inc., Cupertino, Calif.
Two of the top three, CompuAdd and Dell, are primarily direct-sales companies, taking orders by phone, mailing out the goods and answering the buyers' phone calls. Joel Kocher, a senior vice president at Dell, said the impressive showing by some mail-order companies underscored a major shift in the personal computer industry. "PC buyers are moving away from traditional retail stores and to distribution channels that are tailored to their particular needs," he said.
 In its survey, PC Magazine, whose readership is heavily weighted toward computer buyers in the corporate community, received nearly 20,000 responses to its questionnaire on customer satisfaction. Those readers also said direct-order companies provided superior service and support.
Swan Technologies Inc. of State College, Pa., had a remarkably strong showing in the PC Magazine survey, finishing first in three of four categories: overall repair service, overall technical support and percentage of respondents who said they would buy more computers from the same company. But PC Magazine editors noted that Swan, a small company formerly known as Tussey Computers, had relatively few responses in the survey, which did not provide as reliable a statistical base as the other companies. In the fourth category, overall reliability, Hewlett-Packard was first, echoing its impressive standing in the Dataquest survey. Close behind Swan in overall satisfaction were Dell and Northgate Computer Systems Inc. of Eden Prairie, Minn.
In what is perhaps the most telling category of the PC Magazine survey -- the percentage of those who said they would buy more computers from the same company -- Swan was followed by Hewlett-Packard, Dell and Northgate.
Unlike Dataquest, PC Magazine reported the worst performers in each category. The mail-order companies PC Brand Inc. and Austin Computer Systems were rated worst in overall reliability, followed by Packard-Bell, Wyse and Gateway 2000. Commodore Business Machines of West Chester, Pa., finished last in both technical support and repair service. It also had a small number of responses in the survey, which may have skewed the results.
The loser in the PC Magazine poll was Compaq, which has a longstanding policy of referring all customer inquiries and problems to its dealers. Compaq finished next-to-last in technical support and fourth from the bottom in repairs. For a company whose prices are typically the highest in the industry and whose reliability rating in the survey was only average, those results are striking.
Michael Berman, a Compaq spokesman, said the company had not seen the Dataquest survey, and he challenged the PC Magazine findings. "Our information is very different from what PC Magazine reflects," he said. Compaq did its own survey of management information service executives who typically oversee large corporate computing systems, he said, "and they said Compaq was unsurpassed in overall satisfaction."
Compaq recently announced that it was beefing up its training of authorized dealers. "Our research shows that the dealer channel is the way to go for distributing and supporting our products," Mr. Berman said.
In contrast to customers' experience with Compaq, Dell and Northgate customers report that their calls are occasionally answered by the chairmen of the companies. At CompuAdd, a red "hot line" in each of the company's retail stores rings just outside the Austin office of the company's director of sales, in case the customer is not getting waited on or has a question the store personnel cannot answer.

HEADLINE: A World in Flux Means Steady Work for Risk Analysts

BYLINE: By ROBERT SCHULMAN; Robert Schulman is a New York-based freelancer who often writes on business topics.

 BODY:
JUDGING by the number of crises in the world lately, profits must be soaring in the political-risk business.
From the Soviet Union to Eastern Europe to Kuwait, the geopolitical map has been stretched, ripped and tossed on its side during the past 18 months. New markets have been created while existing business ventures have been shaken. Eager to get their bearings, American companies have been turning with increasing frequency to consultants who assess the potential risks and rewards abroad by analyzing the political, social and economic conditions of a particular country or region. 
 No one keeps track of the exact dimensions of the political-risk industry. But clearly these are boom times.
"What we've seen this year is twice as many new members as all of 1989," said George Barnes, executive director of the Dallas-based Council for International Business Risk Management. The council, known as the Association of Political Risk Analysts until last year, now has about 175 members.
Since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August, "the phones have been ringing off the hook with people looking for protection in the Middle East," said John Salinger, head of the political-risk division at American International Group, the insurance and financial services company. American International insures companies against certain risks abroad.
For risk analysts, it is the second time that a crisis in the Persian Gulf has sent their fortunes rising.
Political-risk analysis first flowered in the United States in the late 1970's in response to the Iranian revolution. "That caught many people by surprise," said Mr. Salinger. American business lost billions of dollars, he said, and "for the most part they were uninsured losses."
The events in Iran highlighted a deficiency in American corporate culture, according to Paul Sacks, president of Multinational Strategies Inc., a New York-based risk firm. American business traditionally concentrated on the large domestic market and considered overseas markets of secondary importance. The political-risk analysis industry grew to meet the need for detailed knowledge about the outside world.
BUT the 1980's were not kind to the business, Mr. Sacks said. Corporate risk units were cut back, first because of sluggishness in international business and then, in the second half of the decade, in response to the foreign debt crisis.
Then came the upheavals in Eastern Europe and the Middle East. This time around, however, few believe that corporate political-risk units will be reconstituted on a large scale. There are "now many more opportunities to tap an outside consultant," said Mr. Barnes of the business risk council. And consultants are less expensive than a full-time staff.
One of the best-known firms is Kissinger Associates. Founded by former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, the New York-based concern is the white-shoe firm of political-risk analysis and generally deals with chief executives.
Other well-known firms include Multinational Strategies; Political Risk Services of Syracuse, a unit of International Business Communications, a British concern; Probe International of Stamford, Conn., and London-based Business Risk International Inc., part of the Economist Group holding company, which also owns The Economist magazine.
The traditional function of the political-risk analyst has been to provide "insight into what's going on in the country in question" and to set up introductions with local worthies, said Dov Zakheim, president of SPC International, the consulting arm of the System Planning Corporation of Arlington, Va.
But over the last decade, political-risk analysis, or country-risk analysis as some now call it, has broadened its focus to include economic and market analysis and elements of management consulting.
"Country risk is a management issue," said Barbara Samuels, vice president for country-risk policy at Chase Manhattan Bank. "If you put the assessment function separate from management, it won't work."
Risk analysts agree that knowledge of a country's history and dynamics is fundamental to good assessment. This includes understanding government structure, the interests of elites, ethnic and religious groupings and economics. Analysts often have a network of experts they can call on for specialized knowledge. Political Risk Services, for example, says it consults 250 such specialists, as well as 13 of what it calls senior advisers. Mr. Sacks' firm has 18 "desk officers" on retainer, each a country specialist.
THE art of the exercise is in synthesizing information, what Benjamin Weiner, president of Probe International, calls "grinding it up and coming up with something that we think is pertinent." Synthesis is crucial if consultants want their advice to be heeded. "We don't give our clients 'on the other hand' studies," Mr. Weiner said. "That's not of value to the business community."
There are methodological differences among risk analysts, the main one being responsible for dividing the industry into what might be called the traditionalists and the quantifiers.
Traditionalists travel to areas of interest and speak with academics, officials and journalists in an attempt to get a feeling for developments. They collect statistics, read the pertinent literature and grind it up.
Some analysts stress particular indicators. Mr. Weiner, a former diplomat, pays close attention to ethnic tensions and "people flow" as indicators of social stability. He forecasts, for example, that South Africa will be rent by civil war after majority rule is attained. This is based on his conclusion that the African National Congress is essentially a tribal organization, a fact he said is obscured by the struggle against apartheid.
Among the quantifiers, Political Risk Services has perhaps the most structured, formal approach. Founded in 1979 by William D. Coplin and Michael K. O'Leary, professors at the Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs at Syracuse University, the firm uses a computer model to quantify risk factors.
The model identifies the three most likely political scenarios for each of 85 or so countries and assigns a probability to each scenario, said Marylou Walsh, the company's managing director. For example, the firm's current 18-month forecast for Brazil identifies a center-right coalition as the most likely outcome -- at 45 percent -- of congressional elections to be held later this month. Slightly less likely -- at 40 percent -- is a center-left coalition. A military takeover -- at 15 percent -- is considered unlikely. The model also identifies various risk factors such as turmoil, investment conditions, trade barriers and economic policy. The numbers are supplemented by a narrative report.
Quantification raises the hackles of some traditionalists. "I'm profoundly skeptical of attempts to quantify political possibilities," said L. Paul Bremer, managing director of Kissinger Associates and a former State Department official.
Stanton Burnett, director of studies at Washington's Center for Strategic and International Studies, objects to quantification because "it conveys the charm of competence." He meant that numbers tend to dazzle the beholder, obscuring the often-fuzzy assumptions on which they are based.
Mrs. Walsh responded to these criticisms by saying, "We're providing a service whereby someone can look at many countries and compare them on the same scale."
For some, political-risk analysis is a preliminary, though important, part of their primary business.
Richard V. Allen, who served in the Nixon Administration and as Ronald Reagan's first national security adviser, is a trade consultant whose main business is setting up joint ventures. "Typically, we are inserted between major companies trying to bridge a gap," he said. An example is his effort at helping a South Korean manufacturer set up a plant in what was until recently East Germany. This necessitated an analysis of the German market and was particularly tricky, said Mr. Allen, since the Germans have very little experience with the Koreans.
As in any business where so much depends on experts and personal contacts, and where the product is an intangible like advice, the political-risk industry is marked by a certain amount of inflated self-representation and the occasional character who talks a good game but cannot deliver.
"The business is not immune to hucksterism,," said Mr. Zakheim.
Kenneth DeGraffenreid, a Washington consultant who headed the intelligence section of the National Security Council staff for six years, said that he knew of two retired "senior U.S. intelligence agents" who sold what he considered essentially worthless data bases to an American company for more than $100,000. "There are a lot of people who lead others to believe that they have secret sources," he said. "Secret sources are pretty hard to come by."
ALSO hard to come by in political-risk analysis is accurate prediction. For every anecdote about farsightedness, there is another about myopia. "Have we ever been caught with our pants down?" Mr. Sacks asked rhetorically. "Yes, everyone in this business has."
Not many foresaw the invasion of Kuwait, after all. Political Risk Services' report on Kuwait, dated May 1990, contains the sentence, "Outright invasion by either Iraq or Iran is possible but not likely." But, says Mrs. Walsh, "We're talking about one sentence in a 50-page report."
Indeed, flubbed predictions, according to some, are a false issue in political-risk analysis. The analysts may have misgauged the timing and the pace of the opening to East Europe, Mr. Sacks said, but "we can talk about the broader ramifications."
And that is an invaluable contribution, the analysts say. American business, for example, has a nearly limitless capacity for self-delusion in regarding the Soviet Union and China as places to make large amounts of money, Mr. Allen said.
Their job is to rein in such corporate enthusiasm, the analysts add, and without them far more companies would be shooting themselves in the foot.

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about political risk analysis misidentified two companies. Business International is the London-based subsidiary of the Economist Group; Business Risk International Inc. is based in Nashville. They are not connected.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard V. Allen, a trade consultant (The New York Times); Henry Kissinger, the former Secretary of State (The New York Times); Benjamin Weiner, president of Probe International. (Associated Press)
 
The Price of Information
 FEES for political-risk analysis can range from less than $500 to well into six figures, depending on whether a client wants an off-the-shelf report on a single country or a view of the world through the eyes of a former Secretary of State.
Political Risk Services will sell one of its country reports for $390. Other offerings include a monthly newsletter ($375 a year), semi-annual forecasts ($495 for two issues) and the company's top-of-the-line "World Country Report Service." For $5,750, a client receives a veritable avalanche of information about all 85 countries the firm studies plus consultations with the company's directors and researchers.
If you are more interested in the global outlook several years down the line, Kissinger Associates will fill you in for around $200,000, which includes at least one meeting with Henry Kissinger himself.
Some smaller consulting firms charge by the day or by the project. "It is not inexpensive," said Benjamin Weiner of Probe International Inc., who like several others did not want his fee schedule publicized.
Paul Sacks of Multinational Strategies Inc. said that his firm bills at the rate of $2,500 a day plus expenses for work by one of the firm's three principals. Staff work goes for $1,200 a day. Mr. Sacks was quick to add that the firm does a lot of work for the Federal Government, which pays considerably less.
Richard V. Allen, a trade consultant whose work includes risk assessment, said his fee is directly related to a company's willingness to provide equity in a business project that he works on. Failing that, he charges a "simple success fee at the end of the project if it is successfully completed." Mr. Allen said he has never figured out what an hour of his time costs.
He did remember, however, when he first realized that there was money to be made in consulting. In 1967, Mr. Allen, an academic at the time, happened to sit next to the chairman of the Boise Cascade Corporation on an airplane. Their conversation led Mr. Allen to write a memorandum for the chairman, for which he charged $150. The executive thought the bill was ridiculously low and paid him $500, Mr. Allen said.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN;
For House Republicans, Analysts Change Forecast From Gains to Losses

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
As recently as this summer, Republicans thought they might gain seats in the House of Representatives this year, trimming the Democrats' 83-seat margin and perhaps paving the way for Republican control of Congress later in the 90's. But that optimism evaporated with the budget and tax melodrama of the last few weeks, and now analysts are asking how many seats the Republicans will lose.
With a possible recession looming and President Bush's popularity dropping in public opinion polls, some say the Republicans will do well to avoid a rout. 
 "A few weeks ago, I think the Republicans would have been happy with a net loss of three to five seats," said Charles E. Cook Jr., a political analyst and editor of The Cook Political Report, a highly regarded nonpartisan newsletter. "Now, I think if you offered them a loss of 10 seats, they'd take it and run."
Analysts are comparing 1990 with 1982, the first Congressional elections after Ronald Reagan swept into office with the support of all but six states. At that midterm point, the country was in the middle of a recession and the Reagan coattails were clipped, as Republicans lost 26 seats to Democrats.
 
Shorter Coattails
 Nobody expects the Republicans to lose that many seats this time. For one thing, Mr. Bush's coattails in 1988 were not nearly as long as Mr. Reagan's in 1980. For another, the economy is not nearly as bad. Still, Mr. Cook said a loss of more than 15 seats was likely this year "if the anti-Bush sentiment really clicks in." Democrats outnumber Republicans 258 to 175, with two vacancies.
It is not that the Democrats are invulnerable. The savings and loan crisis, ethics investigations and voter anger over things like constituent service have left many Democrats either trailing in the polls or ahead with a precariously slim margin.
Democrats also say they are approaching a kind of saturation point in the House: there are just so many districts left that have the potential to switch from Republican to Democratic.
But to the extent that Democrats face problems in individual races, Republicans face the same problems, plus the effects of the mood shift against the President. One Republican strategy, analysts say, is to predict a rout in Tuesday's elections. That prediction might galvanize wavering Republicans to get out and vote. It might also enable the party to claim victory if it loses only a few seats.
Democrats, by contrast, are playing down their possible gains, hoping to keep Republicans away from the polls and enabling their party to claim victory if their victory is bigger.
 
Departures Leave Tossups
 As with all Congressional elections, most of the races for the 435 House seats are uncontested or the challengers so poorly financed that incumbents are considered shoo-ins.
In a recent issue, the weekly journal Congressional Quarterly said 215 Democratic seats and 138 Republican seats were "absolutely safe," leaving only 82 competitive races.
The number of open seats, created by House members' retiring or running for other offices, is 29 this year, up from 24 in 1988 but lower than the average of 40 in recent elections.
Eight House Republicans are running for the Senate, making otherwise secure House races tossups.
"It has left us with some very tough seats," said Gary Koops, head of public affairs for the National Republican Congressional Committee. "It will come down to turnout."
 
Measuring Voters' Mooss in the
 A big question is the extent of the voters' anti-incumbency mood. Richard Bates, executive director of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said: "The mood out there is that people hate the Congress, make fun of the Congress, but like their local Congressman, because he is their liaison with the Government, gets them their Medicare payments, gets them into West Point."
Stuart Rothenberg, editor of The Political Report, a newsletter that follows races, says the Administration's handling of the budget crisis could be particularly damaging to Republicans this year. "The Republicans could always claim that they were the party capable of handling the economy," he said. "That was their life raft. But the abandonment of the tax promise, the budget mess and the falling apart of the economy have undermined that entire argument."
 
Consequences of S.& L. Debacle
 The savings and loan fiasco has contributed to the anti-incumbent mood, but it has been a leading issue in only a few races, and Democrats as well as Republicans are vulnerable.
In California, Representative Charles (Chip) Pashayan Jr. is considered one of the most vulnerable Republicans because of campaign contributions from Charles H. Keating Jr., former head of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, and because of his efforts to intercede for the executive with regulators. Lincoln Savings is now defunct.
And in Oregon, Representative Denny Smith, another Republican, is in jeopardy because he was a board member of a savings institution that was seized by Federal regulators.
Ethics is another issue whose impact is being felt by both parties. In Maryland, Roy Dyson, a Democrat, is struggling to overcome charges that he improperly took large campaign contributions from military contractors while he was a member of the House Armed Services Committee.
Finally, a number of candidates struggling for re-election may be particularly vulnerable to the anti-incumbency mood: They are accused of serving their home districts poorly or of being out of touch.
 
Spotted Owls and Guns
 Jolene Unsoeld, Democrat of Washington, is considered vulnerable for having advocated the protection of the spotted owl in a district that depends heavily on the lumber industry.

HEADLINE: James River's About To Invent Itself Again

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

DATELINE: RICHMOND,

 BODY:
DON'T call the James River Corporation a paper company when Bob Williams is around. Never mind that its nearly $6 billion in sales derive almost exclusively from paper products. Never mind that only paper analysts cover the company. Never mind that for a long time Mr. Williams was awfully proud that James River, which he co-founded 21 years ago, has grown to be one of the world's largest paper companies.
None of that matters to Robert C. Williams, who last month took over the chief executive's slot from Brenton S. Halsey, the other co-founder. James River, Mr. Williams hastens to point out every time he hears the dreaded P-word, is a consumer-products company, with its future tied to such branded products as Northern bathroom tissue, Brawny towels and Dixie paper plates and to the bags and boxes surrounding Kellogg cereals and Frito Lay potato chips. 
 "We have totally changed our emphasis to consumer products," Mr. Williams said.
Mr. Williams is not just whistlin' through a Dixie cup. In August, James River announced a major restructuring into three businesses: consumer products, communications paper and packaging. Conspicuous by its absence from the new lineup: specialty papers, the industrial high-technology products on which the company was founded, which accounted for $1.3 billion in sales last year, and which Mr. Williams is actively trying to sell.
Although the current economy is not particularly conducive to selling anything, James River and AEA Investors, a group formed to buy the specialty business, have ironed out most of the details for the transfer.
THERE is little doubt what Mr. Williams wants to accomplish. James River's stock, which seems mired in the low- to mid-$20's, sells at only 8 times earnings -- typical for a paper company. Consumer products companies, in contrast, generally command earnings multiples of 18 or higher. Consumer packaging companies rarely dip below 16.
Moreover, as more economists predict recession, paper companies are likely to be valued even lower by the market.
"On a tonnage basis, paper is not highly cyclical, but on a profit basis, it is," said Benjamin Slatin, chief economist at the American Paper Institute. That is one reason that Robert S. Palm, the paper analyst for Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, will not recommend James River stock, despite his enthusiasm for its restructuring. "Earnings for all paper companies will deteriorate over the next several quarters," he said.
To Mr. Williams, such logic proves his point. "Analysts just don't give us credit for the businesses we're really in," he said.
Wall Street will be a hard sell. James River, for years one of the paper industry's highest fliers, ended its fiscal year on April 29 with a meager $221.6 million in income. That represented a 13.1 percent plunge from 1989 despite a 1.3 percent increase in sales. Capital expenditures were down 16 percent, to $575 million, although many aging plants sorely need repair.
George B. Adler, Smith Barney's paper analyst, put a "buy" recommendation on James River stock last month -- but with reservations. "It is wonderful that they are getting rid of specialty operations," he said. "But this company hasn't performed the way it used to for quite some time."
Mr. Williams must find even such lukewarm support welcome at what is, at best, a bittersweet time. The sale of specialties marks the transition from an era of gloriously unlimited growth and technological emphasis to one of retrenchment and emphasis on a function in which neither Mr. Williams, 60 years old, nor Mr. Halsey, 63, has ever excelled: marketing.
From day one, the two partners had a practical division of duties. Mr. Halsey, a tall, distinguished-looking man with a courtly, Virginian manner, was the consummate Mr. Outside. The shorter, scrappier Mr. Williams was the operations whiz.
They specialized in buying ailing companies for 50 cents per dollar of sales. Mr. Halsey would handle the financial negotiations, the media, all of the external arrangements. Mr. Williams would check out the target's processes, equipment and staff.
For close to two decades, James River, which went public in 1973, grew in almost geometric progression. Return on equity routinely topped 20 percent, the highest in the paper industry. Compound growth in sales and earnings often hit 50 percent.
Then, in 1980, James River made the acquisition that would change its course forever: It bought the Brown Paper Company.
The original plan was to retain only Brown's extensive pulping operations, shape up its lackluster tissue and towel, food and beverage service products and paperboard packaging businesses, and resell them. But by the time the Brown facilities were deemed salable, the 1982 recession had hit. James River's mainstay specialty papers businesses were in the doldrums; Brown's recession-resistant consumer products businesses were doing fine. The seeds of the combined company's metamorphosis were sown.
James River bought American Can's paper facilities in 1982, which gave it the Dixie cup and Northern toilet tissue brands. And in 1986 it bought Crown Zellerbach, which made consumer and communications papers.
Crown was a $1.6 billion, all-stock buy, which forced down James River's return on equity. It was the first company for which James River paid more than rock bottom. And it was huge -- too huge to digest without stomach pains. "It took a lot longer to consolidate than we had expected," Mr. Williams conceded.
As James River struggled to absorb Crown Zellerbach, pulp prices started an inexorable march upward. For 14 consecutive quarters, James River, which still bought more than 15 percent of its pulp, saw its margins shrink as the price of its raw material rose. "Being a net buyer of pulp was just terrible," said Ernest S. Leopold, executive vice president of communications papers.
Earnings and return on assets went into free fall. James River no longer had the money to upgrade plants. "It was too many mouths and not enough food," said Norman K. Ryan, the packaging business's executive vice president. By 1988, both Mr. Williams and Mr. Halsey had come to an emotionally wrenching conclusion: Specialty papers, the company's growth-machine-turned-earnings-drag, would have to go.
T he specialty business is not the only James River mainstay slated for disappearance. Mr. Halsey is retaining the title of chairman, but is expected to phase himself out of the business soon.
He will be sorely missed -- especially by Mr. Williams. The two partners' public "arguments" were legendary, giving rise to sporadic rumors of trouble at headquarters. In fact, those who know the men say they revel in a debating-club style of strategizing, taking opposite sides of an issue just to make sure they have viewed all aspects.
"They use each other as devil's advocate," observed Mr. Leopold. Charles E. Eberle, the new consumer products chieftain, has this take on the relationship: "Bob's mind would be racing at 100 miles an hour, and Brent would balance his impetuosity."
DESPITE anticipated nostalgia for Mr. Halsey, the heads of the new businesses seem delighted with the reorganization.
Mr. Leopold said it "puts the accountability where the action is." Mr. Ryan sees it as a communications tool. "It becomes easier to decide how you will move forward, set priorities, apply resources, if you are in similar businesses," he said. His group, which is currently scattered across the country, is building a new headquarters in Cincinnatti.
In the short term, Mr. Eberle has the most daunting task. He is pursuing joint ventures in Europe, where the consumer paper market is growing twice as fast as in the United States. And he is trying to get his colleagues to think in marketing terms -- something they must do if James River is to go up against Scott Paper, Procter & Gamble, Kimberley-Clark and the other marketing powerhouses that dominate consumer paper.
That is not going to be easy. Mr. Williams approaches management like a true technocrat. He and his staff do methodical studies, with charts and graphs, of every product the company makes, complete with comparisons' to competitors' costs and quality. He sees Northern bathroom tissue, for example, rising or falling on its strength and softness; in fact, most marketing experts say that Northern's future rests more on whether consumers are most tickled by White Cloud's animated cloud, Charmin's Mr. Whipple, or Northern's little girl with the sore backside.
James River is woefully short of people who understand that. And that makes succession a problem. Mr. Eberle, an ex-Procter & Gamble executive, is the only high-level person in James River with extensive consumer products experience. But at 62, he is not a candidate for the top, and he doubts that anyone in his group is succession material.
Mr. Leopold, 56, who hails from Crown Zellerbach, and Mr. Ryan, 54, who joined the company with Brown, are both well-regarded paper executives, but know little about consumer products. If Mr. Williams plans to rotate either of them through the consumer business before he retires, he is not saying.
"The James River people must realize they should make only what they can sell, not figure out ways to sell what they can make," Mr. Eberle said.
It will probably take some time before Wall Street is certain they have done just that. Thus, Mr. Williams may remain dissatisfied with his "consumer products" company's stock price for a while yet.
 
 
HEADED FOR SPINOFFS?
JAMES RIVER's decision to split into three stand-alone businesses raises an obvious question: Will it soon put the final touch on that independence, and spin off the businesses as separate companies?
So far, the heads of the new units have no unified public stance on the issue.
Ernest S. Leopold, executive vice president of communications papers, which supplies some paper to the packaging sector and shares four plants with the tissue makers, says it is out of the question: "There is no thought of the three businesses spinning off, because none can divorce itself completely from the others."
Charles E. Eberle, executive vice president of the consumer business, is not so sure: "There is no question that the board will periodically evaluate the data to see if it's time for them to become separate businesses."
Norman K. Ryan, the packaging business's new chief, wants to table the question: "Spinning off is an intriguing possiblity, but first we have to find ways to utilize our plants and people better."

HEADLINE: FORUM;
The Coming Squeeze on Capital

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HORMATS; Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs International, was Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs in the Reagan Administration.

 BODY:
IN every international political crisis since World War II, the dollar has strengthened -- until now. Since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the dollar has fallen sharply. It is no longer the most important safe-haven currency.
The dollar's current weakness should serve as a warning that in the international competition for capital of the 1990's, the United States risks coming up short. Faced with a tightening of bank credit, the savings and loan crisis and cuts in foreign investment, Washington confronts a critical question: Will sufficient capital be available to finance vigorous growth in the decade ahead? 
 Urged on by the United States and others, Japan is spending more on domestic consumption and infrastructure investment. Once major lenders to the rest of the world, Japan's banks now have capital problems of their own due to declining stock and real estate values.
German capital flows will also be constrained. The reconstruction of Eastern Germany will require more than $50 billion annually for several years, leading to higher budget deficits in Bonn and a curtailment of capital outflows.
Higher oil prices will also cut into capital exports from Germany and Japan. At the same time, the Soviet Union, the new democracies of Eastern Europe, a number of Latin American countries and the dynamic economies of Asia are all seeking billions of dollars of new investment.
Despite the Federal Reserve's recent easing of interest rates, intense global competition for capital will give rates an upward bias. This is likely to coax out new sources of capital, but even so, overwhelming demand will enable lenders to demand high returns and tough conditions.
This will pose a serious problem for the United States. Even with the new budget agreement, the United States will still have to import $100 billion annually from foreign sources to finance the Federal deficit and new private investment. But in recent months, the inflow of long-term capital has plummeted as foreign investors have sold their stocks, dramatically cut their purchases of bonds and sharply curtailed direct investment.
How can Washington insure sufficient capital to finance growth and investment in the 90's?
* The new budget agreement must be faithfully implemented over the next five years to reduce the government's call on private savings and to free up funds for private investment.
* The integrity of the financial system must be bolstered by resolving regulatory conflicts, eliminating impediments to financial competitiveness and correcting abuses.
* In spite of pressure, the Federal Reserve must sustain its efforts to control inflation and maintain a stable dollar. Big price increases, or the adoption of an artificially low dollar policy, will discourage capital and force up long-term interest rates.
* If the United States cannot generate savings sufficient to meet domestic investment needs, it needs to attract substantial foreign capital or suffer lower growth. To sustain domestic support for an open-door investment policy, the United States should secure from other nations a similar degree of openness to investment.
* In current world trade negotiations -- the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade -- the United States and its partners should dismantle trade barriers that distort resource flows. They should also slash the multibillion-dollar subsidies they provide to agriculture and to other sectors of their economies. In a savings-tight environment, such waste is particularly damaging to growth.
If we follow these prescriptions, the competition for capital is more likely to go our way.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
A Company Gives Up on New York

BYLINE: By STUART MEYERS; Stuart Meyers, a principal in Brothers Communication, is moving his business to Connecticut. He is also writing a novel.

 BODY:
FOR more than 20 years, my brothers and I have run a small, family-owned business in Manhattan that installs and maintains telephone systems and offers consulting services. But now we are moving out. We have finally lost our appetite for the Big Apple.
In the past five years, 30 percent of our customer base has gone out of business, downsized their city operations, or relocated out of the city. Crime -- violent and otherwise -- a crumbling infrastructure, rising taxes, soaring costs and mounting social problems do not describe occasional events. They define the conditions that for us, and other small businesses, have called into question the logic of staying in New York. Modern telecommunications technologies have made it possible to locate our business anywhere. 
 The city's social problems took on a new and vivid meaning for me a couple of years ago when an employee showed up after an unexplained absence of four days. When I asked him what had happened, he calmly said words that I will never forget: "I killed someone," he explained.
But Jan. 5, 1990, proved to be our high-water mark in the city. On that day, a water main on Fifth Avenue and 19th Street cracked open, flooding the basement of the building that houses our offices. The flood took out the utilities and elevator service. Faced with the prospect of having to climb 10 flights of stairs to an office without heat or working toilets, our small office staff quit.
After the flood, only 2 of our 14 telephone lines remained in service -- a big handicap if your business is telephones. We could no longer solicit new business and only with great difficulty could we take care of our existing customers' needs. Soon cash flow became a trickle and our losses mounted. Without a staff or enough telephone lines, we had to visit our customers in person. Despite its herculean efforts, the New York Telephone Company took until May to repair the bulk of the damage.
One night shortly after the flood, feeling exhausted, I decided to go home and wait until morning to copy the data files in our computer. It was a bad mistake. Our offices were burglarized that night by thieves who -- unlike our departed staff -- were willing to walk up the 10 flights of stairs to our cold, waterless offices. Among the items stolen was the computer. Because our office had been burglarized twice before, our insurance premiums had become too high; to cut expenses, my brothers and I had allowed the policy to lapse. Another bad mistake. Over the years our vans were broken into with regularity. They also became too expensive to insure.
One night, when one van had mechanical trouble and could not be started, we were forced to leave it on the street. The following morning, my brothers and I discovered that the van had not only been vandalized -- which did not surprise us -- but also had been ticketed for being illegally parked. What was odd was that the thieves who vandalized our dead truck had somehow managed to move it up onto the sidewalk. Of course, tools and equipment were stolen. Yes, there were more delays incurred by our workers when they went out to find replacements. And, of course, we had to pay the ticket.
In New York, like all small businesses, we had to pay taxes on our commercial rent and our gross receipts. There was also the Metropolitan Transit Authority surcharge, a utility surcharge, and the tax on each spouse's out-of-state income. But what do we get for these taxes? I am not unique in feeling that I have been ripped off.
These direct and hidden costs have made small companies based in New York less competitive than those elsewhere. Over the years, sadly, they have also transformed doing business in New York from fun into a constant hassle.
For us, the issue was never so grandiose as "Can New York City survive?" -- the question the magazines ask. We are certain it will. The issue for us was simply: "Can we survive in New York?" We decided that we could not.

HEADLINE: Managing;
The Trickle-Down Effect in Perks

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
PEPSICO INC. is giving its hourly workers the same stock options that top management gets. "We tell our people to act like owners, so it seemed right to give them the rewards of ownership, too," said David E. Scherb, Pepsico's vice president of employee benefits.
Workers at Borden Inc. get bonuses of up to $1,000 if their plants hit targets of safety, quality and productivity. "For too many years, only general managers got incentives for plant performance," said Allan L. Miller, Borden's chief administrative officer. 
 Long John Silver's Seafood Shoppes Inc. is rolling out a "gain-sharing" plan that awards hourly workers quarterly bonuses on the basis of improvement in their specific restaurant's bottom line. "One of the best ways to create a spirit of teamwork is to reward it economically," said R. William Flock, the restaurant chain's senior vice president of human resources.
Slowly but surely, American companies are starting to give lower-level employees financial goodies that were once considered the sole purview of management. According to a recent survey of 644 companies conducted by Sibson & Company Inc., human resource consultants in Princeton N.J., nearly half the companies with variable pay plans -- bonuses, profit sharing and the like -- include hourly employees in those plans. That is an increase of 20 percent over 1989, and most experts say more companies are hopping on the egalitarian bandwagon every day.
"Companies are recognizing that they must motivate and reward top performing employees at all levels," said Charles Cumming, a Sibson principal. Wendy B. Gray, a benefits specialist at the Conference Board, a New York business research group, put it more bluntly: "Employees are more likely to come up with suggestions if they see what's in it for them."
Apparently, the pendulum has swung back to its starting point. Back in the 1960's and early 1970's, American managers routinely assumed that any morale problem or productivity lag could be solved with a raise. When that didn't work, those same managers embraced the idea that participatory management, public praise and other methods of showing respect would motivate workers far more than cash.
In fact, they do -- to a point. But now, many companies are admitting that it really does take money, as well as pats on the back, to keep a workforce humming along.
"If you want to have all of your people working toward the same goals, management-only incentive programs must go by the wayside," said Peter H. Forster, chairman of DPL Inc., which owns Dayton Power and Light. For the last few years, the utility has been setting specific objectives -- say, that equipment should be running 90 percent of the time -- and giving bonuses, up and down the line, in the same percentages of salary for meeting them.
AT most companies, the goals and financial incentives for lower-level people are comparable to, but not identical to, those for higher-level ones.
At Long John Silver, the top 3,000 managers already participate in a cash bonus plan that is tied to the value of the company's stock and that pays out once a year. Come Christmas, the 16,000 store-level people will start getting quarterly bonuses, based on revenue and profit increases, if any, in their restaurant over the same quarter a year before.
"Managers are expected to have a longer time horizon, and to have an impact on the entire company's performance," said Mr. Flock. "We want the crew people to be rewarded for things they can control, and to get paid immediately, in cash."
Clearly, the workers welcome that attitude. James E. Stahl, a customer service specialist at a Long John Silver restaurant in Austin, Tex., says the crew in his restaurant already is doing more "upselling" -- trying to interest customers in larger portions or more expensive items -- and more "suggestive selling" -- persuading customers that they want, say, an ear of corn or a piece of pie or a larger drink with their shrimp.
"Now we feel that every piece of pie we sell gives us more money," he said. "It won't be a lot, maybe an extra $25 a week. But even that little bit is a new pair of pants or a night out on the town."

 
WHAT'S AVAILABLE IN THE FRINGES
 MONEY is not the only management perk moving down the corporate ladder. Fringe benefits once reserved for only the whitest of collars also are filtering through the work force.
Dayton Power and Light, for one, has made training sessions and executive wellness programs available to employees at all levels. And it has extended its career preference program, which matches jobs with employees' interests, downward as well. According to Peter H. Forster, DPL chairman, 340 of the 450 lower-level people who have applied for job changes in the last two and a half years have gotten their first choice.
Financial planning assistance has become a more common, if still stratified, perk, too. "Many of the large companies that provide financial planning services to upper-level executives are providing lesser amounts to lower-level people," said Wallace L. Head, director of Arthur Andersen & Company's individual services practice.
One example: The Monsanto Company, which has long offered paid-for financial planning to its executives, now is offering a truncated version for all employees, as part of its new flexible benefits plan. "We have felt for a long time that deciding who needs what benefits is a bit too paternalistic," said J. R. Walters, Monsanto's manager of compensation and benefits.
