HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
The Ultimate in Bears and Bulls

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:

JAMES M. BENHAM, chairman of the Benham Capital Management Group, in Mountain View, Calif., remembers what it feels like to be poor. His father supported 10 children on a minister's salary, and at dinner, he said, the rule was, "Pass the potatos, no stops." That's because if each child took an extra scoop, the bowl would be empty before it made it around the table. By the time he went to college, on scholarship, he wanted "to major in money on the theory that some would rub off on me," he said.
Perhaps that explains a bit why Mr. Benham, whose firm now manages $6.6 billion in 21 mainly fixed-income funds, is particularly sensitive to economic downturns. For him, the current bear market looks unusually vicious and unlikely to retreat soon. 
 Mr. Benham is perhaps the biggest bear in the industry, and the bleakness of his view sets him at odds with most of his colleagues. Chief executive officers, economists and money managers at 10 large mutual fund groups, asked by The New York Times to assess the economy and the markets, agree that the bottom has not been reached yet. But beyond that, a solid majority sees better times by the end of next year or early in 1992. Indeed, the most optimistic -- Jon S. Fossel, chairman of the Oppenheimer Management Corporation -- predicts a rally marking the start of the turnaround early in 1991.
Mr. Fossel said he believes the stock market will bottom out in the next three or four months. In the 25 worst-performing months since World War II, he said, the Dow Jones industrial average fell an average of 12 percent. During the market free fall in August -- one of those 25 months -- the Dow dropped 11 percent. Historically, he said, it has taken one year for the stock market to fall from peak to trough. During that time, the market lost an average of 25 percent of its value.
Using those gauges, he said, there is still room for the Dow to fall. It has dropped about 20 percent in three months from its peak of nearly 3,000 in July. Furthermore, Mr. Fossel said, six months after the market hits bottom, the Dow traditionally rises 12 percent; a year later, it is up 23 percent and after 18 months, it has risen 34 percent.
That may all sound nice, Mr. Benham said, but it's humbug. Looking at the past is useless, he said, because "we've never been here before." Mr. Benham says that there are factors at work that pull the current environment out of the historical framework. The "wealth effect," for example, which arises when consumers feel poor, will be so profound as to cause a ripple effect through the 90's. The wealth effect in this case has arisen because of the declining value of peoples' homes -- and it will cause consumers to cut back on their spending.
It's a new idea for many Americans that homes -- generally a person's biggest investment -- can lose value. Real estate values have risen so steadily and for so long that this sudden reversal will have a dramatic impact. The heady spending spree that marked the 80's has come to an abrupt halt, replaced by frugal savings and consumption patterns.
Mr. Benham favors specialty funds, like gold equity index and target maturity funds, and "his are very good at what they do," said Don Phillips, vice president of Morningstar Inc., Chicago-based mutual fund consultants. So when Mr. Benham says there is more bad news, people listen.
 For instance, he pointed out, Americans are borrowing more but producing less. Last year, 70 percent of corporate income was used to pay interest on debt. There were record-breaking numbers of personal bankruptcies.
The result, he said, is that the recession we are entering will not be like any we have seen before. The slowdown in real estate and the huge national debt, compounded by the oil shock, means "it doesn't look comfortable to me in the 90's," said Mr. Benham. He gives 4-to-1 odds that there will be a worldwide depression. "After every long party, there's always a hangover," he said.
Given this gloom-and-doom outlook, what's an investor to do? He suggests lightening up on stocks. Build a big cash cushion and stash it safely in money-market funds or Treasury bills. Put part of it into bond funds.
If there is a recession without higher inflation, interest rates will drop to about 5 percent for short rates, and 7 percent at the long end of the yield curve, he said. Investors in bond funds, especially zero-coupon bonds, would profit. But if the recession is coupled with higher inflation, short-term rates will stay at about 7.5 percent and long rates could rise toward 10 percent. He advises people to stay with mid-range maturities of about four to seven years.
The bottom line: "I founded this company with the knowledge that the 'full faith and credit' pledge is more than a paper promise," Mr. Benham told investors recently. In the event of a worldwide collapse, real wealth -- gold reserves, as well as mineral and timber resources -- backs American Government securities. His conclusion: "That's a solid fallback position."
 
When Risk Doesn't Pay Off
THE more risk you assume, the higher the return, right? That has always been a basic investing assumption, but the results shown in the accompanying chart set that fundamental rule of investing on its ear.
Ten years should be enough time to smooth out market quirks. But this particular 10-year period reflects an historical anomoly: a time when high-risk funds underperformed the low-risk ones.
What happened? During most of that time, the smaller-capitalization stocks favored by the high-risk funds took a beating. Under such conditions, the portfolio managers simply could not do well.
For investors, there are two lessons, according to Charles Trzcinka, associate professor of finance at the State University of New York at Buffalo, who analyzed the data. First, he said, fund categories do not always deliver what they promise. Second, the riskier the fund, the longer you should plan to hold your shares.

HEADLINE: Predators Kill Maine's Caribou Restoration Effort

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 3

 BODY:
The organizer of a private effort to restore caribou to the wilds of Maine, where that deer species has been largely extinct for about 80 years, says the project has failed, a victim of predators.
The organizer, the Maine Caribou Project Inc., announced Wednesday that it was abandoning the four-year-old effort. Project officials said they doubted that they could raise the money needed to transplant enough caribou to create a self-sustaining herd. 
 Of the 32 caribou released in Maine, 25 are confirmed dead -- 12 killed by bears or coyotes. The remaining seven are unaccounted for, but biologists believe that only two or three are alive and that the caribou have apparently lost the radio collars used to keep track of them.
Four caribou calves were born in the wild. Two died of unknown causes; the others were killed by a bear and a bobcat.
 
Excessive Hunting and Disease
 Caribou once were so abundant in Maine's north woods that a city was named after the animal. But excessive hunting and disease left them extinct in Maine more than 80 years ago.
The restoration effort, which began with a caribou roundup in a remote corner of Newfoundland, was the second since 1963.
When the latest caribou releases were planned, the project leaders' principal concern was the brainworm, a deadly parasite.
Richard B. Anderson, a project spokesman, said none of the biologists had anticipated how critical the threat of bears threat would be.
"I think it's possible to restore the caribou to its former range," he added. "But you need a lot of animals."
But that would take more money than project leaders believe they can raise in a weakening economy.
Biologists believe they would need 50 to 100 more caribou to succeed, but it would cost $300,000 to capture, transport and monitor that many animals. The project officially ends Dec. 31.
 
Need Is Seen for Wide Support
 "We have come to realize that only under an extraordinary set of circumstances would it have been possible to complete a project of this magnitude without organizational and financial support of Federal or state wildlife agencies," project leaders said.
The project's failure shows that money "is far better spent to conserve Maine's endangered species today, while they still exist," they said.
The leaders said they would share information with officials in Minnesota, Wisconsin and Idaho, where similar projects are proposed or under way.
The last caribou from a native Maine herd was sighted on mile-high Mount Katahdin in 1908.
In 1963 two dozen caribou were released in Baxter State Park in northern Maine. All of them disappeared because of poaching, disease, predators and natural dispersal, biologists believe.
In 1986 more than two dozen caribou in Newfoundland were shot with tranquilizer darts and transferred by helicopter and in trucks to enclosures at the University of Maine in Orono, 1,200 miles away.
Biologists kept this "nursery herd" in Orono to breed young caribou to be released in the state. Of the dozen released in Baxter park in April 1989, only one was known to have survived by the end of that year.

HEADLINE: New York Rates Banks on Serving the Poor

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
For the first time, New York City is ranking banks eligible to do business with the city on how responsive they are to the needs of low-income communities.
The policy, which became effective late last week, is part of a broader strategy by the Dinkins administration to achieve what it calls "economic justice" for low-income New Yorkers. 
 Black and Hispanic residents of some low-income neighborhoods have long complained that discrimination prevents them from securing mortgages and business loans.
"The community-banking ratings provide a powerful incentive for banks to increase their commitment to our neighborhoods," Mr. Dinkins said.
 
Chemical Bank Scored Highest
 The city's Department of Finance ranked 28 banks on factors like the number of mortgages and business loans they offer in low-income areas, the extent of bilingual services, the number of branches in poor communities and the services offered to people on welfare.
Among big banks -- defined as those with assets of $10 billion or more -- Chemical Bank scored the highest, with 67.61 points out of 100. The other scores in the big-bank category were Citibank, 56.77; Manufacturers Hanover, 47.87; Chase Manhattan, 46.15; Republic National, 40.63; National Westminster, 21.65; Marine Midland, 18.05; Morgan Guaranty, 14.56, and Bankers Trust, 8.83.
Morgan Guaranty and Bankers Trust scored poorly because, unlike retail banks, they do not handle individual accounts.
Among small banks, New York National Bank, which is the smallest and is minority-owned, had the highest rating.
 
Criteria Called Unfair
 Thomas Parisi, a senior vice-president for Bankers Trust, said that given that it is not a retail bank, the criteria for rating comparisons were unfair. He said the bank has shown its community commitment in other ways, including making money available for low-income housing.
"We're disappointed that the rating system didn't reflect fully what we're doing," Mr. Parisi said. "We have no opportunity to score on those things like branches and bilingual services. We recognized awhile ago that as a wholesale bank we'd have to look at community support in a different way."
Marleen Bishop, a spokeswoman for Chemical Bank, said that the bank would begin publicizing its first-place rating.
Last year, the city did $38 million worth of business with 15 of the eligible banks. The new rankings account for 10 percent of the overall score those banks will receive when they compete to provide services to any city agency. A bank must submit to an annual community-banking rating to be eligible to bid on city banking contracts.
 
'Tear Down Artificial Barriers'
 Each city agency defines the financial and business criteria for its particular needs, but the community-service criteria are the same for each city department and must be included in every request for proposals issued by city agencies to banks.
"We want to tear down artificial barriers separating people from the credit they need to buy homes, build businesses and help live meaningful lives," said Carol O'Cleireacain, the city's Commissioner of Finance.
Ms. O'Cleireacain said the new rating system could make a difference between winning and losing a contract. She said bids are often separated by only two or three points.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN;
Rinfret's True Opponent Isn't Cuomo

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Nov. 2

 BODY:
In the angry depictions of many Republican leaders, Herbert London is a man bent on wounding, perhaps even destroying, the Republican Party in New York State. But Mr. London, a registered Republican who is running for governor as the nominee of the Conservative Party, insists that the opposite is true.
"I'm not in this race to poke my finger in the eye of Republicans," a hoarse Mr. London told a campaign rally today, against the Art Deco backdrop of Buffalo's City Hall. "I'm in it because I believe I'm the prince, there to resuscitate a sleeping beauty called the Republican Party." 
 With Election Day almost at hand, there is wide agreement that the Republican's official gubernatorial nominee, Pierre A. Rinfret, is locked in a dogfight -- not with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, to whom he is expected to lose lopsidedly, but with Mr. London.
A poll of 1,032 voters, released this week by the nonpartisan Marist Institute showed Mr. London and Mr. Rinfret in a virtual dead heat, each about 50 percentage points behind Mr. Cuomo. The poll, which had a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points, showed Mr. Rinfret with 13 percent and Mr. London with 11 percent. Mr. Cuomo had 64 percent, the Right-to-Life nominee, Louis P. Wein, had 3 percent, and the rest of the voters were undecided.
 
The Only True Conservative
 Mr. London's campaign emphasizes conservative economic policies, support for the death penalty and a "voucher" plan that would give parents greater latitude to choose between public and private schools.
Although Mr. Rinfret's campaign includes many of the same themes, Mr. London insists that he is the only true conservative in the race. Where Mr. Rinfret has talked about freezing government spending, Mr. London often points out, he has called for deep spending cuts.
His television commercials have sought to label Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Rinfret as liberals -- "Tweedledee" for the Governor and "Tweedledummer" for Mr. Rinfret. And in recent days he has barnstormed the state, urging voters to select him as the one rational alternative to the "bankrupt" policies of Mr. Cuomo and the "laughable" campaign of Mr. Rinfret.
But the real contest in this race, it seems, is not so much for first place as for second. If Mr. London does finish ahead of Mr. Rinfret, the Republican Party would lose its spot on the second row of the ballot in New York State for the next four years, and it would also forfeit joint control, with the Democrats, over every county Board of Elections in the state.
 
'Wake Up' the Party
 But far from being a calamity for Republicans, Mr. London tells voters that such a jolt is precisely what is needed to "wake up" the Republican Party and, in his view, to help compel its transformation from "the party of Nelson Rockefeller to the party of Ronald Reagan."
In any event, he adds at rallies and in an interviews, it is "patronizing" for Republican leaders to urge a vote for Mr. Rinfret, as some have done, simply to help preserve the privileges the G.O.P. now enjoys as the number two party in the state.
"When they say, 'Hold your nose and vote for Row B,' that is the worst form of condescension to rank-and-file Republicans that I could possibly describe," he said at a news conference here. "I mean, can you imagine Abraham Lincoln running on an independent line in this state and Republican leaders saying, 'Don't vote for Honest Abe, Vote for Row B'?' Come on." Row B, the second line on the voting machine, is now reserved for Republicans.
 
The Study of Classic Texts
 The 6-foot-5, Brooklyn-born Mr. London, who attended Columbia University on a basketball scholarship, is on leave as a dean of the Gallatin Division of New York University, which specializes in the study of classic texts. He ran briefly for Mayor of New York City last year.
In stump speeches he tends to emphasize his anti-tax, anti-spending stance, but in interviews he adds more complex economic proposals, including a "means test" for state university students seeking to take advantage of the system's low tuition, and abolition of rent controls in New York City for people making more than $150,000 a year.
Unlike Mr. Rinfret, who supports abortion rights, Mr. London says he is staunchly opposed to abortion, although he says that "in order to get legislation passed" he would tolerate exceptions in cases of rape, incest or when the life of the pregnant woman is at stake.
In response to questions from The Village Voice last month, Mr. London acknowledged that he had supported his wife's decision to have an abortion 13 years ago, when none of those factors was at issue, but he says he has since undergone a "personal odyssey" that led him to regret that decision and to change his position on abortion.
 
'Unequivocally Pro-Life'
 "There are two kinds of people in life," Mr. London said in an interview today. "Those who learn from their experience and those who don't. I learned, and that's one of the reasons why I am unequivocally pro-life."
Mr. London is also a staunch advocate of the death penalty, which he said is a necessary deterrent even if it leads to "rare cases" in which an innocent person is executed.
Despite the intensity of the sub-campaign involving him and Mr. Rinfret, Mr. London said today that he would use the remaining moments of the campaign -- including a debate Sunday in New York City -- to push for victory over all three of his opponents. "I'd like very much to be the Governor," he said. "And between now and Tuesday, I'm going to do everything I can to win. I'm going to be peripatetic. I'm going to go as fast and as far as I can."

HEADLINE: Peace Hopes Dim in Londonderry

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Before last week's attacks in which the Irish Republican Army forced civilians to act as "human bombs," the people of the city had dared to hope that they might be allowed to pioneer what Northern Ireland longed for most: peace.
Two years of relative calm and a series of successes in persuading companies from the United States and elsewhere to build factories, offices, stores and a hotel had given rise to a spirit of optimism among Roman Catholics and Protestants. 
 But the optimism has given way to foreboding since Oct. 24, when the I.R.A. forced three Catholic civilians whom it accused of collaborating with British security forces to drive vehicles carrying remote-controlled bombs to border checkpoints near Londonderry and Newry and a British Army camp at Omagh.
While the I.R.A. had forced civilians to deliver its bombs before, in the past the drivers were given time to escape.
 
A Wave of Revulsion
 The attack here was the most devastating. Five British soldiers and the driver, Patrick Gillespie, a 42-year-old kitchen worker at an army camp, died. Six other soldiers were seriously wounded.
Throughout Northern Ireland, the attacks generated a wave of revulsion among Catholic nationalists who want a united Ireland and Protestant unionists who want Northern Ireland to remain part of the United Kingdom. Adding to the gloom, a British Government attempt to get political talks going seems near collapse. Such talks would be aimed at devising a Government structure that could end 18 years of direct rule from London.
More than 2,000 Catholics and Protestants packed a church for Mr. Gillespie's funeral last Saturday. In one of his most vitriolic attacks on the I.R.A., Bishop Edward Daly said at the Requiem Mass that the I.R.A. had "crossed a new threshold of evil."
 
Fear of a Wave of Terror
 The widespread fear in this city, and throughout Northern Ireland, is that what was widely seen as the callous ruthlessness exhibited by the I.R.A. in the human-bomb attacks could herald more terror and destruction.
 Security officials also seem worried by the I.R.A.'s successful use of remote-controlled bombs. That indicates the I.R.A. has developed a capability to thwart the army's and police's electronic countermeasures, which for years have protected patrols and bases from remote-controlled attacks.
 
Surge in Number of Deaths
 There has also been a surge in the number of deaths in the last month or so. [A killing on Friday pushed this year's toll in the province to 64, two more than the total killed in all of 1989.]
One fear in Londonderry is that the I.R.A. will step up attacks on the economic targets and scare off investments that the city desperately needs, Mayor David Davis, a conciliatory unionist, said.
While Northern Ireland's unemployment rate is 14.1 percent, the rate is 22.3 percent in Londonderry, the second-largest city in Ulster. In some Catholic neighborhoods here, mill unemployment is as much as 60 percent.
 
Working Together
 That explains why nobody expects mass resignations by Catholic civilians employed by the police and army. "It's not clear people have choices," said Mark Durkan, an aide to John Hume, the Catholic leader of the nonviolent Social Democratic and Labor Party who lives here. "Obviously Patsy Gillespie's circumstances didn't let him get out." In 1986, Mr. Gillespie had been forced to deliver to the same army base an I.R.A. bomb, which was defused.
While there are divisions between Protestants and Catholics here, there is not nearly as much antagonism as in Belfast. Pragmatic Catholics and Protestants here have managed to put aside their political differences to work together to attract investment to restore the city, which had been ravaged by bombings in the 1970's and early 1980's.
About 60 percent of Northern Ireland's population is Protestant and about 40 percent is Catholic but here Catholics account for about two-thirds of the nearly 100,000 people. The biggest party is the S.D.L.P., which also is supported by most Catholics.
 
Fear of More Divisions
 There are worries that any sustained increase in violence will widen divisions between Protestants and Catholics. But for the moment, the I.R.A.'s new tactic and damage and wounds inflicted on a mixed working-class neighborhood by the same bombs seem to have united many in outrage.
"There are more and more people saying, 'no way am I giving in to that kind of intimidation,' " said John W. Adams, local head of the Ulster Unionists, Northern Ireland's biggest Protestant party.
People with contacts in the poor Catholic neighborhoods where republican support is the strongest say Mr. Gillespie's death has sparked a backlash against the I.R.A. But they were skeptical that it would result in a significant erosion of support for the I.R.A. or its political arm, Sinn Fein.
"All the British have to do is raid 20 or 30 houses and start coming down heavy again" on republican areas and support for the I.R.A. will bounce back, said Patrick McArt, editor of the Derry Journal, a twice-weekly newspaper.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN;
At End, More Pressure on Feinstein

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Nov. 2

 BODY:
They were the kind of voters Dianne Feinstein had to motivate to win, elderly Mexican-Americans at the Casa Ramona Community Center here amid the vast suburbs east of Los Angeles. "I need your help -- we need to mobilize our vote," the Democratic candidate urged them on Friday, after a lunch of tamales, beans and rice.
But as the heated race for governor of California nears an end, the newest opinion polls carry ominous signs for Ms. Feinstein in her battle against Senator Pete Wilson. 
 Experts say the former Mayor of San Francisco is being hurt by rapidly changing world events, a worsening economy, a well-financed opponent, an effective Republican get-out-the-vote drive and what some say is an unfocused Democratic campaign.
In the nonpartisan California Poll, conducted Oct. 26-30, Senator Wilson had widened his lead to eight percentage points, 47 to 39 percent, in a sample of 1,248 voters; the margin of sampling error was three percentage points either way. A poll of 1,993 registered voters, taken over the same period by The Los Angeles Times, said Mr. Wilson was ahead, 43 to 42 percent, within a three-percentage-point margin of sampling error. But Mr. Wilson's lead grew to five to seven points when poll takers weighted the numbers to assume, as many experts do, that Republicans are more likely to show up on Election Day.
 
Seen as 'Underdog'
 After lunch here, Ms. Feinstein acknowledged to reporters she was behind in the polls, but she added: "I've always had to run as the underdog. People said, 'You cannot win.' I've heard it for better than 20 years. People always projected I would lose. But we won."
She then set off on a final campaign blitz around the state, including an old-fashioned whistle-stop train tour on Saturday through the agricultural Central Valley, where in polls she runs far behind Senator Wilson. For his part, the Republican was getting a heavy boost from two Republican Presidents: a rally with President Bush on Saturday morning in Thousand Oaks and another with Ronald Reagan in Alta Loma the same afternoon. Mr. Wilson appears to be benefiting by the steadily growing Republican makeup of the California electorate.
The Feinstein campaign planned to base its final effort on intensifying her image as the energetic candidate of change, with a final barrage of television commercials tying Mr. Wilson to the Republican Governor, George Deukmejian, and the ills of smog, traffic and rapid growth. "The election is essentially going to be about a comfortable old shoe who represents the status quo and the candidate who clearly articulates change from the last eight years of Republican rule," said Ms. Feinstein's campaign manager, Bill Carrick.
 
Rain on a Candidacy?
 But change may be just what the voters do not want now, said Mervin Field, director of the California Poll, saying that the economy and the Persian Gulf crisis had made voters cautious. "These external events tap deep-seated views of the public," he said. "They are less willing to make changes in political leadership. The public opts for a steady hand on the tiller, and not just chauvinistic men feel that way. The darkening economic clouds rain on the Feinstein candidacy."
Joseph Scott, editor of The California Eye, a political newsletter, said: "She started with fire, a lot of press, glitz, star quality. But I do not see a possibility of her winning this race. Her issues -- education, environment, social issues -- are just not cutting. Given the economic situation and the possibility of war, this is not a take-a-chance climate."
Ms. Feinstein assailed what she called the "sex stereotyping" that has placed a "glass ceiling" above female candidates, keeping them out of the top jobs in politics. "Men are looked on as better managers," she said, adding, "I'm a good manager -- I take responsibility."
But close analysis of the latest survey results was not encouraging to the Democrat. Her appeal to women is not nearly as strong as had been widley anticipated. In the California Poll, Mr. Wilson led by 46 to 40 percent among women, compared with 48 to 36 percent among men; The Los Angeles Times poll had Ms. Feinstein leading among women by 6 points, but Mr. Wilson ahead among men by 9 points.
 
Wilson Camp 'Ecstatic'
 "We have been showing there is no gender gap," said Mr. Wilson's press secretary, Bill Livingstone, who said the Wilson camp was "ecstatic" about the polling data.
Mr. Wilson appears to be benefiting heavily from the growing Republican character of California and the more loyal voting patterns of Republicans. Ms. Feinstein's efforts to portray herself as a political centrist at odds with liberals, as tough on crime and a proponent of the death penalty, do not appear to have altered basic political perceptions in a state that, though otherwise dominated by Democratic elected officials, twice elected Mr. Reagan and Mr. Deukmejian as Governor and Mr. Wilson as Senator.
The California Poll said Mr. Wilson got the support of three-quarters of Republicans while only 12 percent defected to Ms. Feinstein. Ms. Feinstein had only 62 percent of Democrats; one in four Democrats said they would vote for Mr. Wilson.
Ms. Feinstein's strongest support came from California's liberals, only 20 percent of voters, while Mr. Wilson had heavy leads among those in the middle and on the right.
 
'Viewed as a Liberal'
 "Despite her record as a moderate, she's still viewed as a liberal," Mr. Field said. "She suffers from the public's stereotypical view of Democrats as liberals."
Geographically, Senator Wilson leads in polls of voters in his home area, San Diego, where he was once Mayor, in conservative Orange County, and in the agricultural Central Valley. Ms. Feinstein is well ahead in the Bay Area. Ominously for Ms. Feinstein, The Los Angeles Times poll said she was ahead by only 2 points in populous Los Angeles County, where a large minority population normally gives Democrats a good plurality.
Working against the Democrat are rapidly changing demographics. Democratic registration has been dropping steadily in recent years. According to the Secretary of State, registered Democrats this year outnumber Republicans by 49.5 percent to 39.2 percent. But many political experts say this exaggerates Democratic strength and that, on Election Day the actual turnout is likely to show a 48-to-42 percent balance.
 
Republican Outspend
 Moreover, the Republicans have outspent the Democrats by $5 million in getting out their vote. They have sent absentee ballot applications to every registered Republican, while the Democrats have done that only for occasional voters. One in five Californians now votes by mail.
Against all this, political experts say, Ms. Feinstein has not been able to ignite the public enthusiasm with which she overwhelmingly won the Democratic primary last June against Attorney General John K. Van de Kamp.
"The race is still fluid, but objectively, I have to give the edge to Wilson," said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, a political analyst at the Claremont Graduate School, who is a Democrat. "I just have not seen her give people a strong enough reason to vote for her."

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN;
Weld Hopes Personality (His Opponent's) Will Help Him in Massachusetts

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
William F. Weld, the Republican candidate for governor, stood in the African Meeting House, the oldest black church in the country, to receive endorsements on Friday from an array of well known local liberals, including feminists, union leaders, blacks and homosexuals.
A tall, patrician Harvard graduate whose ancestors first landed in Boston in 1630 and whose father was a New York investment banker, Mr. Weld seemed an unlikely choice for some of the speakers, most of whom said they had never voted for a Republican before. 
 But one after another, they explained that they were frightened by Mr. Weld's Democratic opponent, John R. Silber, the president of Boston University, whose acerbic comments about working women, drug dealers and homosexuals have offended many people.
"This is a contest for governor between two Republicans," said Jerome Grossman, a former Democratic national committeeman. "I disagree with both of them on many issues, but I am voting for Bill Weld, because I believe John Silber is temperamentally unfit for public office. The issue here is character, not politics."
Anne Bernays, an author from Cambridge, said Dr. Silber had made statements "that are not only inappropriate, they are off the wall" She added, "He's not only unfit to be governor, I think he's unfit to be the head of Boston University."
 
'Dr. Know-It All'
 And Domenic Bozzotto, president of Local 26 of the Hotel and Restaurant Workers, said this about Dr. Silber: "Dr. Know-It-All is nothing more than George Wallace with a brain."
Throughout the proceedings, Mr. Weld, who is 45 years old, applauded with awkward enthusiasm and smiled a schoolboyish grin, blushing slightly under his bright red hair.
The endorsements came as Mr. Weld pressed Dr. Silber in the one area where he has shown vulnerability -- what is called the temperament issue. With only two days left before Tuesday's election, Mr. Weld was closing in on Dr. Silber, who had held a narrow lead in the polls.
While Mr. Weld turned in a lackluster performance in their final debate Tuesday, he has been buoyed this week by a strongly worded endorsedment from The Boston Globe, generally regarded as sympathetic to liberal Democrats.
 
Party Has Huge Edge
 Democrats outnumber Republicans in Massachusetts by 4 to 1, and the Republicans have not won the Governor's office since 1970. So it is important for Mr. Weld, a former United States Attorney, to cut into Dr. Silber's base among Democrats.
In this year of enormous public anger over Massachusetts's economic decline and a prolonged state budget crisis, the Republicans have their best chance to win in years. But Mr. Weld has been somewhat overshadowed by the tempestuous, argumentative Dr. Silber.
By contrast, Mr. Weld comes across as more modest, with a quirky Brahmin sense of humor and an amiable if preppy charm. In the early stages of the campaign, Mr. Weld, who has put more than $1 million of his own fortune into the race, looked stiff and ill at ease in public, but he has relaxed and become more self-confident.
Like Dr. Silber, Mr. Weld is hard to categorize politically. He was once a member of the American Civil Liberties Union. But he also supported Philip Crane over Ronald Reagan for President in 1980 because he found the former Illinois Congressman more conservative.
 
'Attila' on Crime
 Mr. Weld is moderate to liberal on social issues, favoring abortion rights, strict protection for the environment and the distribution of condoms in high schools to prevent AIDS. Liberals also cite his 1987 resignation as an assistant attorney general in protest over the ethical problems of his boss, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d.
He opposes restricting the use of semiautomatic assault rifles. And he favors the death penalty, saying he would stop coddling prison inmates by taking away their television sets and make them break rocks. "On crime issues, I'm Attila the Hun," he remarked last year. "There's no room to my right."
Mr. Weld is also a strong fiscal conservative, backing a tax-cutting ballot measure that would force the next Governor to cut the $13 billion state budget by $1.2 billion in the first six months of 1991 and another $2.4 billion in the following year. Dr. Silber argues that the proposal would be a "fiscal disaster," imperiling many state programs and services.
Mr. Weld at first strongly supported the initiative, which was wildly popular among many voters, especially conservatives and Republicans. But as the state's economy has continued to decline and state revenues have dropped, the tax-slashing plan has lost some of its support, and Mr. Weld has said he would delay putting the cuts into effect. But Dr. Silber still has tried to use the issue to keep moderates and liberals from defecting to Mr. Weld.
 
Where He Would Trim
 In an interview this week, Mr. Weld insisted he could make the budget cuts. He would find the excess, he said, by going into what are known as the "budget busters," expensive programs like Medicaid and state employee pension plans that are fixed by law. "They are not untouchable; there are more efficient ways of managing them," Mr. Weld said.
A summa cum laude graduate of Harvard College, as well as a graudate of the Harvard Law School, Mr. Weld is married to a law school classmate who is a great-granddaughter of President Theodore Roosevelt. The Welds live with their five children in a large early-19th-century Federalist house off Brattle Street in Cambridge, normally a liberal address. He is an enthusiastic hunter and fisherman.
During his stint as United States Attorney in Boston, Mr. Weld developed a reputation as a tough prosecutor, winning convictions against officials of former Mayor Kevin H. White's administration, as well as members of Boston's organized crime family.
In the campaign, Mr. Weld's brand of literate, upper-class humor sometimes left reporters confused. Once, when asked where he got his money, Mr. Weld paraphrased an old Boston joke about a Beacon Hill matron: "We don't get money, we have money."

HEADLINE: Higher Bond Costs Seen for New York

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Even if Mayor David N. Dinkins can reassure investors that New York City's finances are well managed, the city will probably pay sharply higher interest costs the next time it tries to raise money in the bond market, financial experts say.
Mr. Dinkins will face an important test on Thursday, they say, when the administration is to release a revised financial plan, showing how it will begin to grapple with a worsening economy and growing budget deficits. 
 In the unlikely event that the city's financial monitors and the credit rating agencies find the plan inadequate, the city could have trouble selling the $950 million in bonds that it plans to issue next month, bond traders and analysts say.
But even if Mr. Dinkins passes this test -- and he has already taken a series of increasingly harsh steps in the last few days to reassure the financial community -- the traders and analysts say the city's credibility with investors remains damaged from an earlier period of confusing signals and commitments.
 
'There Is Skepticism'
 "I think the city is going to come through," said Thomas Caffrey, a bond broker and president of Titus & Donnelly. "It is a matter of what they are going to have to pay."
One underwriter of city bond issues, who asked not to be identified, observed, "There is skepticism about the city's sincerity, its ability to deal with the budget gaps in a fiscally responsible way."
Already the City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, is forecasting that a $1.3 billion short-term note sale later this month will cost the city $7 million more than previously planned this year, because of rising interest costs.
The city could be forced to pay tens of millions of dollars in higher interest costs on its next sale of long-term bonds, even after taking into account overall changes in interest rates, analysts said.
City officials say they are aware of the concerns of investors and planning an extended information campaign to convince them that the city is capable of managing its affairs even in the face of an economic downturn.
"If the city develops a credible plan, we will have access to the markets at a reasonable price," Ms. Holtzman said. "The fact that the administration knows it will have to run that gantlet is an important discipline."
 
Bond Sale Postponed
 The city's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, said the administration was focusing on those concerns as it made a major effort to prepare what is usually a routine revision of its financial plan.
Because of concern over the next bond sale, Mr. Dinkins and Ms. Holtzman agreed to postpone it by a month, until December, to give them more time to reach out to investors.
The city is planning to go ahead with a sale of $1.3 billion in short-term notes later this month. But rather than holding an auction, as it has in the last few years, it will negotiate the interest rate with the city's underwriters.
Aides to Miss Holtzman said the city's strategy was governed by the concern that it had a complicated story to tell investors. Since-tax exempt notes are usually bought by institutions rather than by individual investors, the story is easier to convey.
 
Unsettled Municipal Bond Market
 Similarly, they said, when a note is a known commodity, auctions often produce lower interest costs. But when sales are large or complicated, or the market is in flux, negotiations may allow the city to sell bonds paying slightly less interest. City officials are hoping that with few other note sales scheduled this month, the notes will do well -- and thus ease the way for the bond sale next month.
One backdrop to the city's worsening credit picture is an unsettled municipal bond market, in which investors are forsaking riskier investments in cities with problems in favor of safer, higher-rated issues. This has driven up interest costs for cities with problems.
Another is New York City's special place in the bond market. It is the largest borrower in the municipal bond market, it is home to much of the municipal bond industry and its brush with bankruptcy in the 1970's was one of the seminal events in the industry. Bad news about New York travels fast.
During one confusing week in early October -- in which Mr. Dinkins agreed to a 5.5 percent salary increase for teachers, announced a plan to hire thousands of police officers and warned that 15,000 city workers might have to be laid off -- the price of New York City bonds fell sharply, and the yields rose.
 
Cut in Rating Is Possible
 The administration's confusing signals confounded the bond market. They came two weeks after the city completed its most successful bond sale, in which the city had to pay the lowest interest rates since Mr. Dinkins took office. Bear Stearns, the lead underwriter, either lost money or narrowly broke even on the deal. Underwriters, usually a group of investment banks, agree before a bond sale to buy the whole issue and then try to resell it at a profit.
After the bond prices fell, Standard & Poor's put the city's $13 billion of outstanding bonds on its Credit Watch list, and warned that if the city did not get on top of its fiscal problems, it could see its rating drop from A to BBB -- the lowest that is still called "investment grade" by the rating services, just above what would be, in effect, "junk bonds."
In the next few weeks, as the administration rushed to reassure the financial community by cutting spending, warning of as many as 35,000 layoffs and pressuring unions for lower wage settlements, bond prices stopped falling. But they remained close to the high levels of early October.
 
Lower Return
 On Friday, long-term city bonds were yielding a return of about 8.6 percent, after going as high as 8.8 percent in some transactions, traders said. Traders said New York City bonds were already trading as if they had a BBB rating or lower. In early October, they were selling to yield 8.25 percent. A bond's yield is what the investor who buys it gets on it. This can be more or less than the interest paid by the borrower. If the yield is higher, the buyer will pay a lower price, less than the face value of the bond. If the yield is lower, the buyer will pay more than the face value of the bond.
One way of measuring the city's declining credit is to compare the difference between the yields on New York City bonds and the yields on other municipal bonds today and when the city last sold bonds, on Sept. 14.
In September, the city sold 21-year bonds with a yield of 8.05 percent, while other similar A-rated municipal bonds were yielding 7.65 percent, according to the Delphis Hanover Corporation.
 
Sensitive to the City
 Today, New York City bonds are trading at a yield of 8.6 percent, while similar bonds are trading to yield 7.5 percent. So by this standard the city's interest costs increased by seven-tenths of 1 percent.
That translates into $7,000 in extra interest costs each year for each $1 million in bonds sold. Assuming the city paid the same extra interest for an entire year's borrowing of about $4 billion, and all the bonds matured in 15 years, the city would pay $420 million in extra interest costs. City bonds have varying terms ranging up to 30 years.
Since many bond traders and investors live or at least work in New York City, they are especially sensitive to the political and social currents in the city, from homelessness to dirty streets and from fear of crime to City Hall skirmishes.
"The markets like predictability and routine," said Alan J. Proctor, executive director of the state Financial Control Board. "The environment of the last month was unpredictability. The administration is now making extraordinary efforts to show that it is going about a predictable process."
 
'Very Blunt Instrument'
 He said the "difference between the first week of October and now is like the difference between night and day."
But Kurt van Kuller, managing director for research at Lebenthal & Company, said that even if the city takes strong action and keeps its A bond rating from Standard & Poor's, the bond market might not react for a long time.
"The bond market is a very blunt instrument," Mr. van Kuller said. "The way it moves is in big swings. I don't think that one bit of news will make a difference."
And even if the Mayor calms concerns about the city's management, Mr. van Kuller noted that other problems remain. "The issue will focus not so much on what is he doing next year," he said, "but on the general problem of resources and the city's economy."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Baker Off to Mideast to Put Muscle Behind Bush Threats

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHANNON, Ireland, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today he would be consulting with Arab and European allies to lay the foundations for a possible joint military operation to force Iraq out of Kuwait if diplomacy does not work.
Setting off on a weeklong tour to the Persian Gulf and Europe, Mr. Baker made it clear that his main goal would be to intensify the threat against the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, by discussing how, when and against what targets military force might actually be used, as well as how sanctions and other United Nations resolutions could be made to squeeze Iraq more severely. 
 In essence, Mr. Baker appears to be trying to put some muscle behind President Bush's recent declarations that he is growing impatient with Iraq's behavior and is prepared to use military force if that proves to be the only way to evict Iraq from Kuwait.
Mr. Baker's foreign tour, which began with a refueling stop in Ireland, will include talks with leaders of Bahrain, Kuwait, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Britain, the Soviet Union and France, as well as the Foreign Minister of China, who will be in Cairo. Mr. Baker will also be visiting American troops in Saudi Arabia.
 
Convincing Saddam Hussein
 The underlying logic of the Baker trip is that unless President Hussein is convinced that he has only two options -- to stay in Kuwait and risk a military strike or to leave and survive -- he will not seriously consider unconditional withdrawal. Without saying so out loud, the Bush Administration has concluded that the Iraqi leader is not quite convinced about the credibility of the threat against him, and that more concrete steps must therefore be taken to demonstrate the seriousness and unity of the anti-Iraq coalition.
"The overall purpose of the trip," Mr. Baker said, "is to discuss with our coalition partners strengthening the full range of measures that we have employed to isolate Saddam Hussein -- political measures, economic and military measures -- and thereby to lay the foundation for the possible future exercise of all options."
This, he added, "will improve the prospects for a peaceful resolution and at the same time permit us to be prepared to consider all options, if peaceful ones don't work."
Alluding to a possible use of military force, Mr. Baker said he would be discussing with the coalition partners "some questions that need to be answered if certain options need to be considered." The United States, he added, would like to know "under what conditions and subject to what constraints" its coalition partners "would be willing to consider certain types of actions."
 
Questions to Sort Out
 Mr. Baker will apparently be trying to sort out several questions with Washington's partners: How long should sanctions be given to work before the military force option is exercised? If force is used, should it only be against the 430,000 Iraqi troops in and around Kuwait or also against military targets in Iraq proper? If shooting starts, how should command and control be organized?
The Secretary of State is expected to sound out Turkey on hosting American forces on its border with Iraq or opening a second front with its own troops against Iraq in the event of war.
He also suggested that he would be asking the Saudis and other Arab Gulf states about their preparedness to continue financially supporting "this mutual effort as it moves forward and the time frame becomes one of months rather than weeks."
 
$12 Billion Already Put Up
 Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates have already put up $12 billion, half of which has gone to support American troops and half to support frontline states like Turkey and Egypt who have been hurt economically by the conflict.
Mr. Baker said he would ask the coalition partners -- particularly the other members of the United Nations Security Council -- for their opinion on whether military force could be used under provisions of the United Nations Charter or whether a specific authorization should be sought.
Mr. Baker made clear that Washington still has not made up its mind on whether to seek an authorizing resolution.
In pursuing the confrontation with Iraq, President Bush "would like to maintain as much of the international consensus as he can and his actions to date make that clear," Mr. Baker said.
But he then quickly added that despite a desire for consensus, the United States believed it already had the legal authority to use force under Article 51 of the United Nations Charter, if it chooses to go it alone.
 
Many Want a Resolution
 Article 51 of the charter says that any United Nations member may ask another member for assistance in reversing aggression against its territory. While the United States, Britain and France believe this gives them all the legal authority they need, the Soviet Union and most other United Nations members have indicated that they could support a use of force or send troops themselves only if the Security Council specifically authorized the operation.
Britain, in particular, is against a resolution, which it fears could tie the hands of the coalition if it chooses to use force by making the force subject to the Security Council members. Bush Administration officials say they are sensitive to the British argument, but they appear even more sensitive to the need to keep the Soviet Union on board at every step in the crisis. Given that priority, it seems likely that Washington will push for a Security Council authorization of military force.
Once the Security Council resolution is passed, a senior Administration official said, it could be undone only by another resolution, which the United States could veto if it found it too restrictive of military movements.

HEADLINE: Harvard Looks for New President and New Ideas

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 3

 BODY:
Midway through its task, the search committee seeking a successor to Harvard University's president, Derek C. Bok, has produced many names, but so far no clear favorite has emerged for what is often considered the premier academic job in America.
"It is very slow going," said a Harvard official familiar with the committee, which began its work in early July. The committee is scheduled to pick a candidate by March, with Mr. Bok set to retire in June after 20 years in the post. 
 The search process has touched off a dispute among Harvard's students; in the past two weeks, more than 1,000 of the school's 6,592 undergraduates have signed a petition complaining that students are excluded from the committee.
At most other leading private universities, including Princeton and Dartmouth, recent presidential searches have included students and faculty members. Harvard's search committee, in keeping with the school's tradition, consists only of six members of the Harvard Corporation, the university's governing body, and three members of its Board of Overseers, who are elected by the alumni.
 
Disturbing Lessons?
 "I find it very disturbing that Harvard doesn't put enough faith in its students to include them," said Colleen Ryan, a freshman from Danvers, Mass. "What is Harvard trying to teach us? Complacency, obedience and apathy?"
Friday, at a rally in Harvard Yard, the consumer advocate Ralph Nader, a graduate of Harvard Law School, told some 300 students: "You have to break that vise of authoritarian control that they have over this university. They'll be proud of you later."
Members of the search committee have consistently refused to discuss any aspect of their work, citing a need for secrecy. But talks with a number of prominent professors and administrators indicate that the committee, in addition to looking for a new president, is taking a broad look at Harvard and its future.
On one hand, a senior official said, the committee has already concluded that "people are very satisfied with Harvard under Bok." He pointed out that Harvard's yield on admissions of freshmen -- the percentage of those accepted who actually enter -- was 73 percent, well above other top schools, which run around 60 percent.
 
Change With Changing World
 On the other hand, the committee has heard a plethora of suggestions about issues facing Harvard, the official added. These include ways to improve the quality of teaching for undergraduates, whether Harvard should become involved in trying to improve secondary education across the country, and how Harvard should internationalize itself as society becomes more global.
There are also the problems of rising costs and rising tuition rates. Each department in Harvard's Faculty of Arts and Sciences was recently ordered to cut its budget by 6 percent.
Harvard's quest for a new president has been complicated by the fact that not only is the president's job open, but so is the second-most important post, that of dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences. A separate faculty committee, headed by Mr. Bok, is looking for someone to fill the dean's office by next spring, with the final decision up to the new president.
The overwhelming choice of many Harvard professors and administrators to succeed Mr. Bok as president, Henry Rosovsky, is theoretically disqualified. Mr. Rosovsky, the acting dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences, is a member of the presidential search committee and has formally withdrawn his name from consideration.
 
At This Point, Speculation
 Moreover, Mr. Rosovsky, 63 years old, is thought to be too old, since Harvard wants a new president who can serve at least 10 years. An economist, Mr. Rosovsky earlier served as dean of the faculty for 11 years, becoming well known for developing Harvard's basic "core curriculum" and for turning down the presidency of Yale University.
But Mr. Rosovsky has not said he would refuse to serve if picked, and so much speculation still centers on him. "The problem for the search committee is that it will be very hard to find someone better than Henry," said the president of another Ivy League university.
Among others most often mentioned as leading candidates to succeed Mr. Bok are George Rupp, the president of Rice University and a popular former dean of Harvard's Divinity School, and James O. Freedman, the president of Dartmouth College and a Harvard graduate.
Those at Harvard thought to be under consideration include Jeremy R. Knowles, a professor of chemistry, Philip Leder, a professor of genetics, and Robert D. Putnam, dean of the John F. Kennedy School of Government.
 
Asking Around for Names
 Others outside Harvard who have also been mentioned include Louis W. Sullivan, the United States Secretary of Health and Human Services, who once taught at Harvard Medical School; Thomas Ehrlich, the president of Indiana University, who is a Harvard graduate, and Gerhard Casper, the provost of the University of Chicago.
If Harvard were to choose a woman -- which most people here doubt will happen -- the two most highly recommended candidates are Nan Keohane, the president of Wellesley College, and Adele S. Simmons, the president of the MacArthur Foundation and also a Harvard graduate.
The final choice, however, may still be someone whose name has not yet surfaced. This month, the search committee mailed 200,000 letters to all Harvard alumni, faculty and students, soliciting names and suggestions.The search committee is also interviewing 300 to 400 Harvard professors and leading educators around the country, seeking names and ideas.
A senior Harvard administrator said the characteristics sought are someone in his or her 40's, with management experience, an ability to raise money and preferably a Harvard connection. Since Mr. Bok was dean of the Harvard Law School before becoming president, many believe a non-lawyer is being sought.
 
A Vote for a Scientist
 Various professors and administrators have their own favorite qualities as well. John E. Dowling, a professor of biology, said, "I hope we have a president who is more on the academic side of things, and I would love to see a scientist."
A professor of history, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity, said he felt "the university is adrift" because Mr. Bok had focused too much of Harvard's energy and resources on the professional schools, especially the John F. Kennedy School of Government, which Mr. Bok helped create. "You have only to look at the Kennedy School," he said, "to see what happens: you end up with a school of ambition, and much shallowness and confusion."
He added, "I would like to see the next president be just a teeny weeny bit more convinced that the College and the Faculty of Arts and Sciences are the center of the university."
David Reisman, a professor emeritus who has just written a book on university presidential searches, denied that the lack of faculty and student participation is a liability. "Each Harvard professor is a polar bear on his or her own ice floe, representing themselves," he said. And Professor Dowling said there was concern that students could jeopardize the secrecy of the process.
Mr. Reisman noted that although the search committee is far smaller than that at most universities it is more diverse than the white male group that chose Mr. Bok in 1970. The current search committee contains two women, including Hanna H. Gray, the president of the University of Chicago and a black, Wesley S. Williams Jr., a Washington lawyer.

Simmons, president of the MacArthur Foundation, and Gerhard Casper, below, provost of the University of Chicago. (The New York Times; Associated Press)

HEADLINE: U.S. Cuts Aid to Zaire, Setting Off a Policy Debate

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Resisting persistent lobbying by the Bush Administration, Congress has cut all military and economic aid to President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire, a longtime United States ally in Africa.
As it adjourned last weekend, Congress denied the Administration's request for $4 million in military aid and stipulated that $40 million in economic aid be funneled through humanitarian agencies not affiliated with the Zairian Government. Its decision was based on human rights violations and accusations that Mr. Mobutu's vast wealthwas largely stolen. 
 The Congressional action and the Administration's attempts to control the inevitable damage in American-Zairian relations illustrates a classic foreign-policy problem: What kind of relationship should Washington have with dictators who arguably work to promote American interests? Can friendly dictatorships best be reformed through quiet diplomacy or overt pressure?
Many American conservatives have charged that the ouster of dictators like Anastasio Somoza Debayle of Nicaragua and Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines with Washington's tacit approval ultimately failed to pacifythose countries and damaged American strategic interests.
Liberals, however, have countered that such dictators are unworthy allies. They say that American support for dictators inevitably associates Washington with repression and encourages anti-American feelings.
The potential importance of Zaire further complicates the problem. The country has major untapped reserves of copper, cobalt and uranium. It has nearly half of Africa's remaining rain forests, as well more than half of the world's hydroelectric potential.
While the Congressional action denying arms aid to Zaire has received littleattention outside Washington, it caused great concern at the State Department.
Mr. Mobutu has received hundreds of millions of dollars from the United States since he took power in 1965. But allegations of a massacre of at least 12 students at the University of Lubumbashi in April and reports that he has a fortune estimated at $2.5 billion tipped the scales against him in Congress.
"What jeopardizes the prospects of regional stability is the existence of a kleptocracy in Zaire that has driven the standard of living lower than it was at the time of independence three decades ago," said Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn.
State Department officials concede that Zaire has a tarnished human rights record, but they worry the opposition in the Central African country will use the aid cutoff as a propagandatool to undercut what they consider Mr. Mobutu's cautious reform efforts. They say that Mr. Mobutu's lifting of a ban against opposition parties and the appearance of independent newspapers this year should be taken seriously. They say these steps are, in part, the product of Washington's diplomacy.
State Department officials also argue that Mr. Mobutu has worked to calm tribal tensions in his country and has performed diplomatic and military services.
Mr. Mobutu was the first black African leader to recognize Israel after the 1967 war. He sent troops to Chad to counter a Libyan invasion. He served as a mediator to bring the Angolan Government and guerrillas to the peace table. Last month, he sent troops to bolster the Government of Rwanda against a guerrilla insurgency.

HEADLINE: News's Loyal Readers Are Split on Strike, Too

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Mickey Heit walked out of his neighborhood candy store with a copy of The New York Post tucked under his arm, barely glancing at a stack of yesterday's Daily News that lay free for the taking on the corner. Although he is a regular News reader, he said that picking up a free copy had a higher hidden cost.
"I feel bad; I don't want to cross the picket line," said Mr. Heit, 64 years old, who works at a car dealership and is a member of the United Auto Workers. "The News had good pictures and good reporters, but I can't see them hiring these outside people." 
 While Mr. Heit chose to turn his back on the papers, other passers-by in the Kingsbridge Heights section of the Bronx sauntered over to the stack and stooped to grab copies.
As the strike entered its second weekend, the sentiments of many readers in the newspaper's traditional blue-collar bastions are divided.
 
Support and Opposition on Strike
 To many older men and women for whom a union card is as much a symbol of passage into adulthood as marriage or military service, the strike signifies a mortal threat to organized labor. They have vowed to boycott the paper until the strikers are rehired.
But many other readers -- some, union members themselves -- have soured on the union-inspired violence and intimidation of newsstand vendors and replacement workers. They have continued to read the paper when they can find it, and most said they had not seen much difference in its quality.
Whether out of ideology or necessity, those who have turned to New York's other tabloids or radio and television for their news said they looked forward to once again buying the newspaper that was as much a part of their day as a cup of coffee and a subway ride.
John Tanner, the owner of a frame store on 231st Street in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx, usually buys a copy of The News on his way to work. Yesterday morning he opened his shop without it.
 
'Trying to Gain Too Much Power'
 "It's a paper I've been reading for the last 20 years of my life, and it's hard to turn something like that off," he said. "What's a Sunday without The Daily News?"
Mr. Tanner said he has been buying The Post and other papers only because he had difficulty finding The News in his neighborhood. He has been able to read it at his mother's house, where she has it delivered.
He added that he was not concerned that the paper was being published by nonunion labor. "I think the unions in the long run are trying to gain too much power and are dragging the whole economy down," he said.
Down the block, Dawn Burgos folded one copy each of The News and The Post as she walked away from a newsstand that stocked both.
 
'Totally Different Paper'
 "I see no difference and have always bought The News no matter what type of reporters they have," she said. The copy of The Post she carried was for her husband, a member of the Teamsters, who refuses to buy The News.
"He says it's a totally different paper," Ms. Burgos said.
Some readers who have continued to seek out the paper have also noticed a difference. "The quality is a lot less," said Steve Shenkman, as he picked up a free copy of the advance sections of Sunday's News from a large pile that had been dumped outside Alexander's department store on Fordham Road in the Bronx. "When you have those reporters who are not New Yorkers, you're not going to get the New York view of things."
Mr. Shenkman, who works for New York Telephone and belongs to a union, said that while he was bothered by reading a nonunion newspaper, he continued to do so. "The unions have no right to be violent," he said.
 
Violence vs. 'Union-Busting'
 But other former News readers said they were more outraged by how the paper's management was behaving.
"To me, their tactics smack of the original union-busting tactics," said Jeffrey Warren, who said he now reads The Post.
Mr. Warren said he would resume buying The News only after the strike was settled. "But only if they settle their problem with the unions equitably and compensate the people who went on strike," he said.
Even those who were boycotting The News out of solidarity said they were eager for their newspaper's return.
 
Speaking on Their Terms
 "All the news I wanted was in there," said Alfey Nelson, a construction worker from Trinidad who was on 231st Street and sported a button that read, "Give a Damn."
"You would get your morning cup of coffee and it would make you feel good, then you'd get your Daily News and it would be the same feeling," he said.
For many of its readers, The News is an institution. They see it as a paper that speaks to them on their terms and with a feisty voice that they have come to appreciate. To them, the ultimate decision has little to do with labor issues, but where they can find the paper. To them, The News has no peer.
Except one, perhaps.
"As long as they can attract readers, I will still read The Daily News," said Samuel Nahabedian, a Bay Ridge resident. "I'm a religious man and when I don't read The News, I read the Bible."

Watching was Celia Shapiro, who said she does not read The News. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)
