SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 2009 words

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN;
As Election Day Nears, Poll Finds Nation's Voters in a Gloomy Mood

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
As Election Day draws near, Americans are more pessimistic about the future than at any time in a decade, according to the latest poll by The New York Times and CBS News.
The dour mood coincides with deepening pessimism about the economy and is also linked to a collapse of faith in the ability of government and politicians to make things better, the telephone survey of 1,445 adults found. 
 For the first time since the days of stagnant economic growth and high inflation in the Administration of Jimmy Carter, a plurality of Americans surveyed, nearly 4 in 10, said they expected things would get worse in the country over the next five years. Only 3 in 10 said things would get better in the poll, conducted last Sunday through Wednesday.
 
Cynicism Grows Deeper
 Substantial majorities of Americans said that they believed the economy is in bad shape (66 percent) and that it was harder to make ends meet (57 percent). And in the face of this hardship, 77 percent of those surveyed said they believed government is run by a few big interests looking out for themselves rather than for the benefit of all the people. That was the highest figure ever recorded in the quarter of a century that various researchers have been taking this measure of cynicism toward government.
The pessimism is in sharp contrast to the upbeat days after the Los Angeles Olympics and Ronald Reagan's 1984 re-election when nearly half of those polled said they thought things would be getting better and only 2 out of 10 thought things would get worse.
"Things were better five years ago, I reckon, but I guess that was the time that we spent and borrowed too much," Vivian J. Martin, a retired poultry farm worker from Boones Mill in southwestern Virginia, said in an interview after participating in the poll. "Now, the future doesn't look too bright. We owe too much and we've gotten ourselves in a bad way."
This dark mood forms the backdrop for the first election of the 1990's. Both President Bush, who will not be on the ballot on Tuesday, and members of Congress, who will, have fallen precipitously in the public's esteem over the last few weeks, a period marked by wrangling over the Federal deficit and a standoff in the Persian Gulf.
But many voters also made it clear in interviews after the poll that their anger, which they expressed forcefully, would not translate directly at the ballot box on Tuesday, either because they viewed their own politicians as an exception or because they did not really know who was up for election.
Amid this prevailing mood, President Bush's approval rating has taken one of the worst slides in public approval of any modern President. In The Times/CBS News Poll, Mr. Bush's handling of his job was approved by 52 percent of the public, in the low point so far in his Presidency and a 21-point decline in little more than a month, compared to a Gallup Poll in mid-September.
That fall is at least as great, although perhaps not quite as sudden, as the decline in President Gerald R. Ford's approval rating after he pardoned former President Richard Nixon for his conduct in the Watergate scandal and the tumble that President Ronald Reagan took after disclosure of the Iran-contra affair.
The fall in Mr. Bush's approval has been all the steeper because of the rise he enjoyed in August as the public rallied around him after his decision to send troops to the Mideast in the wake of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. At that point his approval rating stood at 76 in The Times/CBS News Poll.
Mr. Bush's still stands higher than the 42 percent approval rating that Mr. Reagan received in a Gallup Poll at this point in his first term at the depths of the 1982 recession when unemployment topped 10 percent as against the current jobless rate of 5.7 percent. President Carter, just before the 1978 midterm elections, had a 49 percent approval rating in a Gallup poll, only marginally different from Mr. Bush's latest rating.
When Mr. Bush took office in January 1989, the nation's mood was considerably more buoyant than now, with just under 4 in 10 Americans saying they thought things would get better and 3 in 10 expecting they would get worse.
 
Mideast Support Improves
 The latest Times/CBS News survey was conducted just after Congress finally adjourned its longest election-year regular session since World war II and as Mr. Bush began an effort to refocus American attention on the Persian Gulf confrontation.
Support for America's commitment in the Gulf improved slightly in the latest survey, but approval of Mr. Bush's handling of foreign policy, always his strength, continued to slip.
The survey should be accurate, according to statistical theory, to within plus or minus 3 percentage points of what would have been found if it were possible to seek out and try to ask the same questions of all Americans.
Albert H. Cantril, a public opinion analyst, said the nation's pessimism is particularly stark because Americans are historically an optimistic bunch with a "can-do spirit" of faith in their nation's ability to muster ingenuity and resources to solve problems.
"When that spirit runs up against intractable sets of issues, whether it's the deficit or gridlock in the Gulf, it's a very difficult situation for the public to deal with," Mr. Cantril said.
 
Mood and Elections
 The nation's mood is an important -- and many would say the most important -- factor in the outcome of elections. The last time polling measured pessimism this deep was in 1979. In the elections in 1980, the Democrats lost the White House as well as 37 House seats and 12 Senate seats. In 1982, with the nation in the depths of a recession, the Republicans lost 26 seats in the House.
Politicians have not been forecasting such dramatic changes this year, but with four days until the election they remain edgy in the face of a country obviously dissatisfied with the status quo.
Fred Steeper, a Republican poll-taker, said that this year remained different from previous years when the nation was in a bad mood, the most recent ones being 1982, 1980 and 1974. In all three of those years, voters directed their anger clearly at one party,-- the Republicans in 1974 and 1982 and the Democrats in 1980, Mr. Steeper said.
While many poll-takers and politicians have reported a trend toward Democrats in recent weeks, Mr. Steeper said that the general anger remains far more bipartisan than in any of the past years. This makes it harder to predict how it will influence individual races, he said.
Disapproval of Congress reached an all time high for the 16 years in which both The New York Times and The Gallup Poll have been asking the question. Sixty-nine percent of the public said they disapproved of the way Congress was doing its job and 23 percent said they approved.
Congressional leaders are fond of pointing out that Americans may hate Congress but still like their individual representatives. "It's hard to throw the other rascal out," Thomas S. Foley, the Speaker of the House and a Washington Democrat, said Friday.
But the standing of individual members has suffered, too, in recent weeks, although they still stand higher than Congress as an institution. Only 51 percent of those surveyed said they approved of the way their own representative is handling his or her job. Thirty percent said they disapproved and 19 percent said they did not know.
Most incumbents will still be re-elected, either because they have no real opposition or because even with all the disaffection they may still look better than the alternative. But the figures raise real fear for those members who in past years might have won narrowly.
In the new poll, without being told the names of the candidates in their district, 44 percent of the probable electorate said they would vote for the Democratic House candidate, while 39 percent said they would vote for the Republican candidate.
Americans are in one of their gloomiest moods when asked about faith in their government; this is why political challengers all across the country this year have been trying to tap this mood with attacks that paint incumbent office holders as tools, puppets and handmaidens of political action committees.
Pessimism about the country's future and cynicism about government were linked in the latest survey. The deepest pessimism about the future of the country was found among Americans who also said that candidates for public office are less qualified today than they were 10 years ago.
 
Deepest Negative Feelings
 Since 1964 researchers have been asking Americans whether they thought government was run by a few big interests looking out for themselves or for the benefit of all the people. They have never measured a result as negative as the one in the latest New York Times/CBS News survey.
In 1964, before Vietnam and Watergate, only 29 percent said the government was run for special interests and 64 percent said for all the people. But the number responding special interests reached 70 percent in the economic troubles of Mr. Carter's last year of 1980, and then retreated into the mid-50's and low 60's during the Reagan years, as measured in polls by the University of Michigan.
The public's overall mood was measured in The Times/CBS New Poll by a series of questions that asked people to rate "the way things are going in the United States" on a scale of 1 to 10 -- with 1 the worst and 10 the best. They were asked to do this for the present, as well as for five years ago and five years in the future.
The public gave an average overall rating to the nation's current situation of 4.91, the lowest since November 1979, when the public rated the national situation at 4.83 on average.
The public gave the future a 4.96 rating on average, showing little sign of optimism that the future would be better than today. Asked to look back five years, the public saw a better time, rating conditions at the start of Mr. Reagan's second term at 6.25 on average.
 
HOW THE POLL WAS TAKEN
The latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 28-31 with 1,445 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened to limit calls to residences.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of residential telephone lines and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age, and education.
Some findings are reported in terms of an overall "probable electorate" which uses responses to questions dealing with voter registration, voting history, and the likelihood of voting in 1990 as a measure of the probability of particular respondents' voting on Election Day.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults. The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for blacks it is plus or minus nine percentage points.
For the question that asked respondents to rate on a scale of 1-to-10 the way things are going in the United States at the present time, the margin of sampling error was plus or minus 0.10; that is, in 19 cases out of 20, a mean rating of 4.91 would be no lower than 4.81 and no higher than 5.01. For means based on smaller subgroups the margin of sampling error is larger.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN;
Irate Voters Approach Ballot Box With Sharpened Axes

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Leo W. Charland is so angry at politicians that he plans to march to his polling place in Punta Gorda, Fla., on Tuesday and help vote them all out, including one of Florida's Senators, Connie Mack.
"Mack is part of the in-crowd, and I think it's time we broke up some of those," Mr. Charland said. 
 The only problem is that Senator Mack will not be on the ballot. Mr. Mack, a Republican, was elected in 1988 and will not be up for re-election until 1994, something Mr. Charland, an independent, did not realize because he moved to Florida only last year.
Politicians have been nervously watching the gathering mood of rage and pessimism among Americans and have struggled to define it with phrases like angry electorate and anti-incumbent fever. They remain edgy and uncertain about how, or whether, this pessimism will display itself at the ballot box.
A New York Times/CBS News Poll this week made two things clear. First, Americans are in their most dour mood in a decade. But, second, in interviews after the poll, these same people indicated that their rage would not fully translate at the ballot box because they barely knew who their own representatives were or believed they were an exception to the general problem.
"Our economy is headed downhill," said Harold J. Milota, a 38-year-old letter carrier in Collinsville, Ill. "After all this growth, I see a long slide. I don't see Congress doing anything to change this. They're part of the problem. We need to get new ones in office."
But he said he would still vote to re-elect Senator Paul Simon, a Democrat, on Tuesday. "He's definitely an exception to the rule," Mr. Milota said. "Paul Simon's done an awfully good job."
Jane R. Howard, a 55-year-old bank vice president in Universal City, Tex., a suburb of San Antonio, said she had already voted by mail. The country needs a new set of leaders, she said, and she cast her ballot for "mostly new ones, though I don't have a whole lot of hope."
At first Ms. Howard, a Republican, said she could not remember any of the people she voted for except in the governor's race, in which she voted for Ann Richards, a Democrat, because she said she hated the Republican candidate, Clayton Williams.
She also remembered that she had voted for the incumbent Representative, Albert G. Bustamante, a Democrat. "He's done some things for San Antonio," she said. Some of her motivation for voting against candidates of her own party might have been anger at another Texan, President Bush. "I'm not pleased with how he's done," she said.
In the Moreno Valley of California, Hank Kirchner, 33, a sales manager for a janitorial supply company, worries about a declining economy. He is a Republican, but he has decided to reject two proposals on the California ballot to limit the terms of the state's elected officials. Both measures have been endorsed by Republican leaders as a way to break the Democrats' grip on the Legislature.
"It's not an effective way to improve the situation," he said. "A guy could come in, see that he only has six years ahead of him and decide that he's going to take what he can. It all depends on the individual who has been elected. I would rather leave it to the voter to decide who should be in office."

HEADLINE: Which Westchester Is This, Anyway?

 BODY:
Perhaps the Westchester Weekly on Oct. 14 coincidentally included Denise Apuzzo's essay on the Opinion Page ("Why One New Yorker Is Leaving Home") and quotes from a speech by Rosemary Scanlon ("Dispelling the Gloom Over the Economy"). Is it possible both women are talking about the same county?
Ms. Apuzzo writes of Westchester: "Thirty years ago, this was the place to be. I'm not so sure right now that this isn't the worst place to be." Ms. Scanlon says statistics "don't support the gloom; the national economy is worse off than the economy of the region which includes Westchester." 
 But if the economy is worse elsewhere, why are people moving out of instead of into Westchester? And why, as Ms. Apuzzo writes, has New York's reputation as a "United Nations of cultures" become a mockery, with group prejudices increasing and not decreasing? How does it happen that Westchester, the sixth wealthiest county in America, has the largest number of homeless per capita of any county in the country?
Answers to these Whys? may lie partly in William T. Knowles's remarks to the same group that Ms. Scanlon addressed. He laments that the Federal Government will probably not finance a "tri-state economic strategy." The only hope Mr. Knowles sees is for Connecticut, New Jersey and New York to take the lead in saving themselves. But he does not think that we can expect "individual local officials" to offer direction. "Widespread involvement is essential," he says. How can you have "widespread involvement" without "individual local officials?" And for what reason do we elect officials at any level of government, if not to provide solutions to problems?
We have apparently now reached a point in our national history when the best that businessmen and politicians can tell us about what to do when the economy turns sour is to pass the problem to another branch or level of government. Mr. Knowles implies that the present impasse is Washington's fault. A few weeks ago, County Legislator Paul Feiner wrote that we should not blame the County Legislature for its inability to deal with Westchester's budget, that we should blame Albany.
Possibly Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has not heard from any of his friends and supporters in Westchester. Like Mr. Knowles, he blames Washington.
 
MILTON GOLDIN
Tarrytown

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Why the Japanese Find It So Difficult To Unsheath Swords

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
FOR four decades Japan's leadership has gone to extraordinary lengths to keep one issue off the country's political agenda: the real meaning of the famous "peace clause" in Japan's American-imposed Constitution. Over the years, the Government has gained a kind of grudging public acceptance that Japan needs what it carefully terms the Self-Defense Forces, despite the Constitution's clear prohibition that "land, sea and air forces, as well as other war potential, will never be maintained." But that acceptance has hinged on an oft-repeated assurance -- aimed at Asian neighbors as much as Japan's own populace -- that the military would never again stray from Japan's shores.
In the last two weeks Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has gotten a rude awakening about how seriously the usually docile Japanese electorate views that restriction, and how much distrust of the Government and the military lies bubbling beneath Japan's placid exterior. 
 Ever since Iraq invaded Kuwait, Japan's leadership has felt intense pressure from the United States -- some real, some exaggerated when broadcast here -- to contribute people and skills to the gulf effort, beyond the $4 billion Japan has pledged.
But after weeks of promises, contradictions, and contorted logic, the whole thing blew up this week in Mr. Kaifu's hands. The turning point was his sudden "reinterpretation" of the Constitution that, had it succeeded, could have paved the way to send Japanese troops into combat for the first time in 45 years.
When people took to the streets, Mr. Kaifu backed away from his constitutional proclamations. But it was too late to save a Government plan to provide transport, medical care, communications and maintainance -- anything but firepower -- to the troops in Saudi Arabia. That bill is now effectively dead. "It was mishandled at virtually every step," said a senior Government official who contributed his share to the botched effort. "The worst part is that even with the bill gone, the fundamental issue still haunts us, and no Government will want to discuss it directly for a long time."
Indeed, the gulf crisis has provided the best evidence yet that Japan is still far from ready to carry the non-economic burdens of a true superpower. What has happened is a spectacular collision between Japan's commitment to "kokusaika," which loosely translates as international responsibility, and its postwar abhorrence of anything that even sniffs of the militarism that started gloriously with the Russo-Japanese War and ended disastrously with Nagasaki. Kokusaika lost.
The debate centered on an ideal -- Article IX of the Japanese Constitution, which renounces "the threat or use of force as a means of settling international disputes." Nobuyoshi Ashibe, a constitutional scholar and a professor at Gakushuin University, says the Japanese "are immensely proud of that provision, and I think they regard it as unique among nations." Some of his students add that it sets a national tone, one far different from what they regard as America's trigger-happy response to crises.
Listening to the debate over the last few weeks, one is struck by the stark differences in the way Americans and Japanese talk about the purposes of Article IX. The provision, an American diplomat said, should be viewed according to its original intent: To prevent Japan from again venturing out to disturb the peace. The Iraq crisis poses the opposite challenge, of course: Japan is being asked to join in restoring the peace and enforcing international law.
 
A Disastrous Precedent
 But to many Japanese, Article IX acts as a vital restraint against a Government and a military that have yet to win their trust. Polls show that a majority of Japanese view any overseas military mission as a potentially disastrous precedent.
Article IX is so clearly worded that most Japanese constitutional scholars express little doubt that the mere existence of the Self-Defense Forces, with 240,000 troops, 1,200 tanks, 400 fighter jets and an expanding budget, is blatantly unconstitutional. Japan's conservative and plodding Supreme Court, however, has sidestepped every opportunity to rule on the issue, declaring it a "political question." That happens so often that, as a top Government official said, any interpretation of the Constitution is possible as long as the people go along.
So, when Mr. Kaifu began to fear that Japan's military alliance with the United States could begin to crumble if Japan failed to act in the Gulf, he proposed creating a "Peace Cooperation Team" made up of volunteers who would play strictly noncombat roles. As conservatives in the party tinkered with the bill, however, the proposed civilian team took on a much more military air, the volunteers being replaced with lightly armed military personnel. Mr. Kaifu made matters worse when he suddenly offered his constitutional reinterpretation, saying Japan could even send fully armed troops under United Nations command if the United Nations decided to enforce "collective security" under its charter.
"It was a very Japanese solution to the problem," said Yasuhiro Okudaira, a constitutional scholar at International Christian University. "It would be impossible to amend the Constitution. So he chose to pretend that the status quo remains, and simply amend the interpretation."
But the effort was immediately undercut, chiefly by Mr. Kaifu's own Cabinet Legislation Bureau, a group of bureaucrats who put forth the Government's official view of what is and is not constitutional. Its refusal to go along gave the opposition everything it needed.
In retrospect, Mr. Kaifu's initial instinct in August, to send volunteers but no military personnel, probably would have kept him out of trouble. And he may yet find a way to send Japanese to Saudi Arabia, though they are most likely to be volunteers who may get in the way more than they help. But it will be months before Parliament can try again. And it will be years, it seems, before ordinary Japanese will trust their Government to find a way to back up its interests with the sword as well as the yen.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week In Review Desk

LENGTH: 1073 words

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
For the G.O.P., The Race Is to Win Second Place

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
NORMALLY, when politicians are stuck with a loser at the top of their Election Day ticket, they abandon ship rather than go down with it. The provincial message in such cases is usually something like, we don't care who you want for governor, senator or president, just vote for our local candidates.
But hapless New York State Republicans, already reconciled to a total rout by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, don't even have that option Tuesday, because if Pierre A. Rinfret, their obstreperous candidate for Governor, drops too far in the vote tally he will take their party down with him. That could mean the loss of the State Senate majority, the state comptroller's office and -- for the first time in state history -- the crucial second line on the ballot. The ramifications of such an electoral disaster include not only a precipitous decline in patronage, but also an involuntary, rightward shifting of political agendas. 
 The Conservative tail could wag the Republican dog just as minor parties have attempted to do -- uniquely in New York State -- for decades.
First there was the Liberal Party, founded after World War II, which in its heyday in the 1960's and 70's often had veto power over Democratic statewide candidates. But as the Democratic Party moved to the left, the raison d'etre for the Liberal Party has faded.
The Conservative Party, which was founded in 1962, has also paid the price of success in declining votes as the Republicans moved to the right in the Reagan era. And the newest of the minor parties, the Right to Life Party, has also slid recently.
But, now one of the minors threatens to become a major party.
The worst fears of Republican leaders -- that the erratic political amateur, Mr. Rinfret, could be overtaken by the Conservative Party candidate, Herbert London -- were reinforced last week. The independent Marist Institute poll showed the Governor running away with the election and, far more surprisingly, that Mr. Rinfret, an economist, and Mr. London, a New York University dean and a Republican himself, were running neck and neck for second place with about 11 percent each. Mr. Cuomo was actually winning twice as many Republicans as his opponents in the poll. A fourth candidate, Louis Wein of the Right to Life Party, who is competing with Mr. London for anti-abortion votes, polled a nearly invisible 2 percent. The Marist results were echoed by two private Republican polls.
To compound the bad news, Mr. Rinfret, who is known by 73 percent of those polled by Marist, is not especially well liked. Only 13 percent rated him favorably, 39 percent negatively. It doesn't get much worse than that.
 
Jockeying for Position
 The significance goes beyond the race for the Governor's office. The gubernatorial results determine ballot position for all elections for the next four years. The party that wins the State House has top billing; second place gets Row B, and on. The order now is Democratic, Republican, Conservative, Right to Life, Liberal.
In addition, the two major parties, determined by the same gubernatorial results, control every board of elections from the state to the county to the polling place level. It has never been anything but Democratic and Republican. From a politician's viewpoint, the boards are among the most vital government agencies because they control patronage jobs, voting lists, poll inspectors and a candidate's access to the ballot.
 
Pleading and Scaring
 That grim prospect has Republicans from Buffalo to Long Island swallowing hard and rallying this weekend to promote Row B, a vote for Mr. Rinfret. The Westchester County leader, Anthony J. Colavita, even went on the radio to plead for Republicans to vote the ticket. In the Albany area, Assemblyman John Faso, who was Mr. Rinfret's campaign manager until he quit over the candidate's attacks on Republicans, is using the $2 billion environmental bond issue, which is also on the ballot, to scare most Republicans to the polls.
On the other side, Mr. London and the Conservative Party have husbanded their scarce funds to sponsor a $50,000 radio and television advertising campaign that portrays him as the real Republican and the genuine conservative battling two liberal peas in a pod, the Governor and Mr. Rinfret. The latter is hardly liberal, but Mr. London has seized on Mr. Rinfret's support of abortion rights and past criticism of Ronald Reagan's tax program to paint the Republican as a liberal and "a joke." The London commercials also feature endorsements by two prominent Republicans, Jack Kemp, President Bush's Secretary of Housing and Urban Development who was a member of Congress from Buffalo before joing the Administration and Lewis E. Lehrman, the party's gubernatorial candidate in 1982.
Mr. London is also counting heavily on the second and last debate of the campaign today at 1 P.M. on WNBC-TV. Many politicians believe he benefited from the first encounter in Syracuse last month and that it started his upward movement.
In contrast, Mr. Rinfret, who has sharply curtailed his campaigning because "the pace was too hectic," he said, has no advertising scheduled except the Republican organization's self-defense radio ads upstate. The commercials are certainly not motivated by affection or admiration for Mr. Rinfret, who has regularly pummeled Republican leaders as idiots, Benedict Arnolds and bedmates of the Governor. Only last week, he said he would not vote for State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, the only statewide Republican official, because he has been "a patsy" for Governor Cuomo.
 
Recalling a Moment of Glory
 Michael Long, the Conservative Party state chairman and the London campaign manager, predicted that the Conservatives would run up a vote second only to their previous moment of glory in 1970 when James L. Buckley was elected to the United States Senate on the Conservative line as liberal Republicans and Democrats split the moderate to liberal vote. Mr. Buckley lasted one term, and his election had no effect on the party lineup in the state or a Republican Party then dominated by Nelson A. Rockefeller.
That is not the case Tuesday, and Republicans and Conservatives are predicting a new post-election struggle over a diminished Republican Party as emboldened conservatives renew their efforts to push the G.O.P. farther to the right with a new state chairman and a sharper conservative ideology.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
A Stronger New Profile For the European 12

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
ONE year after the crumbling of the Berlin wall, as Washington struggles to maintain NATO's traditional importance and Moscow talks wistfully of a new pan-European security structure, the 12-nation European Community has quietly and confidently asserted itself as the central pillar of the new Europe. The emergence of a stronger community underlines how swiftly economic development has replaced military confrontation as the region's main concern. But it also reflects how Western Europe has turned post-cold war uncertainties into opportunities to speed its own moves toward closer economic and political unity.
The first challenge was posed by the unification of Germany. But Bonn has tightened its bonds to the community, calming the fears of its partners that it might choose an independent role in Europe. The Persian Gulf crisis then exposed the community's continued reliance on Washington's security umbrella, but it has also awakened the 12 to the need for their own defense capability. 
 The eventual shape of an integrated community is still unclear, not least because Britain continues to resist surrendering any more sovereignty. Yet at the latest summit meeting of community leaders in Rome last weekend, all but Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain committed themselves to achieving a single European currency and a common foreign and security policy in the 1990's.
Further, in December in Rome, two parallel conferences -- one on economic and monetary union, the other on political union -- will start revising the Treaty of Rome, which created the Common Market in 1957. And with France and Germany contemplating a federal Europe in the 21st century, the momentum for change is enormous.
 Not surprisingly, the rest of Europe is watching the community with a mixture of envy and hope. Austria, Turkey and Cyprus have applied for membership; Sweden announced plans to do so last week and Norway may soon follow suit. Eastern Europe's new democracies are seeking association with the community as a step toward eventual membership, while the Soviet Union is looking to the community to finance its own economic transformation.
New members, though, will have to wait. Consumed by its existing plan to create a single regional market by the end of 1992 and by its new blueprint for economic and political union, the community wants to work out its own rules for the future before it lets in those countries able and willing to play by them, some time in the mid-1990's. But even to outsiders, the community is already the principal point of reference in Europe.
In contrast, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which for four decades enjoyed that position, is now gripped by an acute identity crisis. With the Soviet Union no longer a threat, NATO has tried to redefine its security role in political, economic and even environmental terms, but so far with little success. And when the gulf crisis seemed to come to the rescue by posing a military challenge this summer, NATO was forbidden by its charter from acting outside Europe and North America.
The United States, though, still views the 16-nation alliance as vital to preserving trans-Atlantic ties and, above all, its own dominant position in Europe. Britain also values NATO as the place where the United States sits alongside Europe. Thus, the Americans and Britons have reacted ambivalently to the community's plans to develop an independent defense capability.
Washington has also shown little interest in Moscow's idea of using the 34-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe to provide the new architecture of Europe.
When President Bush and the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, join 30 or more Europeanleaders at a splashy summit meeting on European security in Paris on Nov. 19, the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe will be amply praised for its past role in promoting democracy and human rights in the East Bloc through the 1975 Helsinki Final Accords. But it will not be turned into an institution capable of answering Europe's immediate or future needs.
As much through initiative as by default, then, that role has been assumed by the community. Looking for an anchor in the West, Moscow has proposed a broad cooperation agreement with the community. And while the United States still prefers to speak to Europe through NATO, it too has begun a direct dialogue with the community with a view to signing a formal treaty.
The community itself, however, is still advancing along an uncharted road, with Mrs. Thatcher complaining at every step that the pace is too fast, and the direction is wrong. "How," Mrs. Thatcher recently wondered aloud, "can I possibly go to the Queen and tell her that her head is no longer to appear on our banknotes?" Last week, her outspokenness prompted her longtime ally Sir Geoffrey Howe to resign in protest as deputy prime minister and leader of the House of Commons.
The community must also lift Greece, Portugal, Ireland and Spain out of backwardness before it can consider itself homogeneous. Entrenched interests are still stronger than pledges of unity. And the community cannot afford to waver in helping former Communist countries to become market economies even though the cost will be high.
For the moment, however, with the United States obsessed by its own economic problems and unsure of its future role in Europe, the community has had no choice but to take up this challenge. And while it would prefer to concentrate exclusively on its own integration, it has recognized that, in the new Europe that will be one year old on Friday, it can enjoy security only if its neighbors also enjoy prosperity.

HEADLINE: Seasonal Discontents;
In an Unsettled Time, Feelings of Unease

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
PRESIDENTIAL campaigns often speak to the voters' hopes, to their yearning for clarity, as when Jimmy Carter promised to never lie and Ronald Reagan offered his vision of America resurgent.
Midterm elections, on the other hand, often serve as a forum for the nation's anxieties and disappointments. They give voters a chance to slap down a President, shake up a statehouse, pass an initiative, simply say that they do not like the way things are going, while at the same time calmly returning most incumbents to office. 
 Even before a single vote is cast in Tuesday's general election, this midterm has been angrier than most. Even if most incumbents manage to hunker down and survive the storm, as they are expected to, politicians around the country predict that the voters' discontent will echo into 1992 and beyond.
This campaign season has been marked by deep divisions within the Republican Party and serious frailties in the Bush Presidency. It has seen the Democrats' first, lurching attempts to shape a message that could lift the party out of the defensive crouch that characterized it throughout the Reagan years. At the same time, it has highlighted an electorate that polls show is increasingly cynical, disengaged and disgusted with politics and politicians.
All of this has been spurred by remarkably unsettled times. Voters will go to the polls on Tuesday with a growing threat of war in the Persian Gulf, with the economy in an ominous slump, with a President who seems puzzled that his popularity plummeted after he broke his most memorable promise of the 1988 campaign. Candidates and their handlers have had to scramble to adjust. "Events rather than politicians have put important issues on the table," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic polltaker.
The two parties are in a state of flux. The Republican right is in outright rebellion against their President and what they view as a disastrous break with Reaganomics, the pursuit of economic growth through lower taxes. Even more telling is the deep concern among centrist Republican regulars who are quietly worried about the party's path. How does the Republican Party, which labored for decades to dispel its reputation as the party of plutocrats, define itself when the central debate is not whether to raise taxes at all, but whose taxes to raise and whose benefits to cut?
For their part, the Democrats are showing tentative signs of recovering after a decade of debilitating defeats. Party leaders say they found in the budget negotiations a vehicle for the kind of economic message they longed for during much of the Reagan era: that Democrats will insure equity for the middle class, in taxes, services and domestic issues like day care and the environment, while Republicans cater to the rich. They say this theme registered quickly in surveys in the final days of this campaign and helped catalyze a pro-Democratic trend.
"It may be the turning point from the '80s into the '90s, from one set of ideas to a new one," said Richard A. Gephardt, the House Majority Leader, in an interview last week. "We've basically been on the Reagan-Bush program for ten years now and it's not worked so well. People are beginning to ask what's next."
Mr. Gephardt tried similar themes in his unsuccessful campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination two years ago. But now, with the economy shaking, with the deficit forcing the nation into a grim zero-sum game around the budget, the time might be right for economic populism. This, at least, is the view of Kevin Phillips, the conservative analyst whose account of the inequities of the Reagan era, "The Politics of Rich and Poor," became Democratic gospel this year. "I think we've seen the last flag factory now," Mr. Phillips said a few days ago, alluding to the politics of patriotic symbols that played such a central role in the 1988 campaign. "Once the real meat and potatoes is out there, the old stuff isn't going to work anymore. This is not to say the Democrats won't overdo it and mess it up, but I think they've finally figured out where to begin."
Where this new dialogue will end is another question. Many Democrats acknowledge that the "fairness" debate is only the first step. "We Democrats have to prescribe a sensible program for the revitalization of the country's economy," Mr. Gephardt argues. "And that's going to require us to describe what government's role in that revitalization should be."
Mr. Bush's plunge in the polls this fall has added further volatility to the political scene. The most recent New York Times/CBS News poll showed Mr. Bush with a 52 percent approval rating, the lowest of his Presidency. Suddenly, Democrats are perking up, looking at the 1992 Presidential election as something more than a political root canal, another exercise in pain.
Charles Black, the chief spokesman for the Republican Party, dismisses Mr. Bush's declining popularity as a short-term fluctuation and brushes aside the Democrats' calls for economic "fairness" as standard fare for a midterm election, without lasting consequence. Still, he acknowledges, "If we're in a recession, if the economy is bad in '92, they can make it into a real contest." This is exactly the scenario the White House hoped to avoid, however, by forging a budget deal this year, even if it meant having some Republican candidates suffer for it.
One of the loudest echoes from this midterm campaign will come from the voters, who in survey after survey and in some key primaries this year have already shown themselves to be disgusted. "In all the focus groups I sit in there is this huge schism between the people and their elected officials," said Don Sipple, a top Republican consultant.
The latest poll by The New York Times and CBS News found Americans with little faith in their institutions. More than three-fourths said they believe government is looking out for the special interests rather than for all the people, a record for the quarter of a century that researchers have been taking this measure of American attitudes.
Disapproval of Congress reached an all-time high for the 16-year period that The New York Times and the Gallup Poll have been asking the question, with 69 percent saying they disapproved of the way Congress is doing its job.
Analysts have long worried that voters, feeling politics was irrelevant to their lives, were simply dropping out of the system. But this year the voters have acquired an edge, their anger has become more active than passive.
Reflecting this mood is the growing movement to limit terms for legislators and other officials. Such a measure has already passed in Oklahoma, is on the ballot in Colorado and California, and is gaining attention on the Federal level. The mood is also evident in the sort of insurgent, anti-incumbent campaigns such as the ones being waged by Harry Lonsdale in Oregon against the 24-year Republican incumbent, Mark Hatfield, and by Paul Wellstone in Minnesota against Republican Senator Rudy Boschwitz.
Says Mr. Wellstone in one of his end-of-campaign commercials: "I speak in our schools, and kids tell me politics is fake, corrupt, phony. I tell them politics doesn't have to be that way. This is our government, and together we can take it back."
Similar themes are struck from Louisiana, where a Republican house member simply notes that he is "home every weekend," to Indiana, where the Democratic Senate challenger, Baron Hill, asks in his television commercials, "Are you fed up with what's happening in Washington?"
There is an irony to all this advertising, appealing to a cynical mood that some analysts believe has been created, in part, by political advertising -- the slashing attacks that have become such a part of modern campaigns. "We're kind of like a dog eating its own tail for nourishment," said Ray Strother, a Democratic media consultant. "Cynicism is feeding cynicism right now."
All of this turmoil will probably not result in momentous change on Election Day, particularly in Congressional elections, analysts say. "You've got all this trauma, discontent, angst, coming up against an electoral system that makes unlikely any truly dramatic expressions of that angst," said Thomas E. Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution.
Incumbents have huge advantages in fundraising and the perquisites of office, and neither party sensed the surly public mood early enough to recruit the kind of candidates who could capitalize on it this year. Still, this mood is not expected to ease any time soon, and will likely frame the politics of the next few years. It could be felt in force in 1992, when redistricting and retirements are expected to produce as many as 80 open seats in the House of Representatives.
As a result, even safe incumbents are nervous these days. Politicians in both parties are realizing that this may not be just another midterm election. It may be signaling the start of post-Reagan politics. And the voters are restless out there.

HEADLINE: VIEWS OF SPORT;
Germany's 'Miracle Machine' Is Left in the Blocks

BYLINE: By PETER HERRMANN; Peter Herrmann is a German journalist who lives and works in what was once East Berlin.

 BODY:
FOUR days before its 41st anniversary, on Oct. 7, the German Democratic Republic -- East Germany -- disappeared from the map. Founded as an experiment to establish socialism on German soil and as a counterbalance to the Federal Republic of Germany -- West Germany -- East Germany failed for all kinds of reasons, political, economic, ecological and cultural. But to put it in one sentence: the capitalism of West Germany was stronger.
What are the lasting impressions of 41 years of East Germany? 
 The American movie director Stanley Kramer, who is also well known in Europe, once said: "Socialism is good. Capitalism is faster." This observation reflects an accurate portrayal of East Germany in all respects but one: its sports system, or "the miracle machine" as it was called in the title of a book written more than 10 years ago by a Canadian author, Doug Gilbert.
Indeed, it was a miracle machine, working more effectively and much faster in producing champions, medals and records from the assembly line than its counterpart in West Germany even though it was managed in a socialist manner.
This chain of success, unmatched in the history of sport by any other country of comparable size, was predicated on very sound principles: early, concentrated promotion and development of talents, methodical building up, solid education and/or vocational training, and last but not least, guaranteed social security for every athlete after retirement. All this was guided and directed by the ruling Communist party; without its consent, nothing began and nothing progressed.
 Two months ago, Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, visited the East German national Olympic committee for the last time. Shortly before leaving, he implored its officers to "please take care with your possibilities that the G.D.R. sports not get ruined."
This is the point. The unification of the sports organizations of the two German states is not a unification of two equal partners. To date, it has been the dismantling of the smaller one, at the cost of its experience, its coaches, its officials. The process would better be viewed as a gobbling up of East Germany by West German officials who favor their own people.
Some examples? The East German track and field team had the best results ever from the recent European track and field championships, winning 34 medals, including 12 gold. West German athletes won a total of seven medals. But none of the East German coaches received a job offer in the new German track association. Quite a number of them, including the chief coach of the national team for many years, Werner Trelenberg, left Germany altogether.
In swimming, East German athletes have excelled and often dominated; however, the national team will be led by three West Germans at the world championships two months from now in Australia, according to Wolfgang Richter, the chief coach of what had been the East German swimming federation.
The list goes on of coaches excluded, mostly because they are East German. Jutta Muller, who guided Katarina Witt and other figure skaters to more than 50 medals in international championships, will not coach the new German figure-skating team. Instead, she is fighting to survive as coach of a club team.
As a journalist I have accompanied East German teams to national and international stadiums for more than 20 years. It was really impressive to experience how the athletes of this small country with only 16.5 million people became an equal competitor of the two superpowers, the United States and the Soviet Union, sometimes ending a competition with even more medals than the big two. At the 1976 Olympics in Montreal, East Germany won more gold medals than the United States, as it did 12 years later in Seoul, South Korea. I was always proud when the East German flag was raised and its national anthem sounded.
Yet I also know that athletes and their successes were shamelessly misused by the leadership of the country to enhance its worldwide image and to distract East German citizens from the harsh realities of their own lives. When the economic and ecological situation in the country became worse and worse, the success of the athletes became the only pretense for socialism. During the last weeks and months before unification, I asked myself repeatedly how the 37 gold medals won by the East German athletes in Seoul can help the country to solve its problems.
While history has given the answer -- socialism under the colors of East Germany no longer exists on German soil -- I can't help wondering why valuable methods and people must be discarded? German citizens, not only those from the East, are angry and bitter about this situation.
West Germany, one of the richest countries in the world, is not willing to sustain any aspect of the East German sports organization. This is not true of some of the top East German athletes, such as Ulf Timmermann, Heike Drechsler, Wolfgang Hoppe or the new track star, Katrin Krabbe, whose careers are assured by adequate sponsors.
But the foundation of the East German sports system, the 16,000 small sports clubs, which had been supported by state-owned factories, are in trouble. This concerns me because there is no money for physical education and care for tens of thousands of children and teen-agers. Also, the future is doubtful for the national sports college in Leipzig.
With the selection of Atlanta as host for the 1996 Olympic Games, the chance for Berlin's becoming the host in 2000 has been increased. But if the Games come to Berlin, they should become not only an organizational success but also an athletic success. The urgent warning of the I.O.C. president should not go unheeded: "The damage to the high performance sports of the G.D.R.," he said, "would be not only a damage for Germany but also for whole Olympic movement."
To make sure that does not happen, the successful methods of an unliked, now nonexistent state should be preserved and not end up in the garbage can.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
For Dinkins And Unions, Friendship Has Its Price

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
MAYOR DAVID N. DINKINS, a friend of labor who won office with its overwhelming support, now finds himself the target of labor's scorn and disbelief. That's bad news for any politician in a city with more than 300,000 workers on the payroll, the equivalent of 1 in 10 registered voters.
But the problem is especially painful for Mr. Dinkins, who is in trouble in tight fiscal times because he agreed last month to a 5.5 percent raise for the teachers' union -- an increase that almost everyone now tells him he can't afford to give to the scores of other unions whose more than 100 contracts remain to be settled. 
 The leaders of those unions, themselves elected, can't afford to go back to their members and tell them there's no money left. The easiest thing for them to do is attack the Mayor. Some of them did so last week in a protest vigil outside Gracie Mansion, and others are staging a big rally at City Hall Wednesday, the day before Mr. Dinkins is to present his plan for keeping the budget balanced.
"It's a crisis of confidence in the Mayor," said Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the largest city union, with 140,000 members.
Barry Feinstein, president of the 12,000-member Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said the negotiations that he and Mr. Hill joined in were "the most inept in my 33 years of dealing with government." Their unions suspended formal talks last week.
Torn by his debt to the unions and his duty to city residents and bondholders and beset by conflicting advice from his own aides, Mr. Dinkins must also confront a compelling reality: some city employees, like teachers and health-care workers, are actually underpaid in comparison to the demand for their services or to their counterparts elsewhere. Yet others are not. For example, more than 100,000 people are scheduled to take the test to fill 2,000 jobs as sanitation workers over the next four years. The starting salary for new teachers is $25,000 a year; for a sanitation worker, it is $23,000.
The pattern in city wage settlements has long produced roughly comparable raises for all, and Mr. Dinkins's timing in settling with the teachers first was no way to break it, even if he wanted to give them the most in the end. The United Federation of Teachers' raise also applies to the 20,000 non-teaching school employees, including teachers' aides, it represents. Other employees in the similar jobs are represented by Mr. Hill's union, making it hard to justify giving them less.
"I really do think Dinkins has a very special problem, which may be exacerbated by his closeness to the unions, but is a problem all the same," said Dick Netzer, a professor of economics and public administration at New York University. "And that is that we're at a point where some groups in the city service are badly underpaid.
"The teachers' contract turned out to be a tactical disaster, but the idea of giving teachers a sizable increase is not crazy," Mr. Netzer said.
The agreement, however, did not seem to take into account the tactical implications of settling with the teachers first or the city's tight overall fiscal situation. The city faces a budget gap of more than $300 million in its current fiscal year and more than $1.5 billion in the next fiscal year, which begins next July. Indeed, just days after announcing the teachers' contract, Mr. Dinkins warned of the possibility of laying off 15,000 workers, a figure his administration now says might reach 35,000.
"They created a politically impossible situation for their labor friends to help them in," said one former city labor official. "If there weren't a teacher contract, the other unions would be out there trying to help Dinkins. Now he's created a series of almost caged animals. They've got no way out."
The labor vote has long been a big factor in city politics, preceding the rise of unions. In the 19th-century heyday of Tammany Hall, Mr. Netzer noted, the "payroll vote" was considered a major bloc.
The dynamic is hard to ignore, even for administrations not considered friendly to labor. Mayor Edward I. Koch added some 80,000 workers to the city payroll in his 12 years in office, often in the name of restoring services depleted by the layoffs and fiscal crisis of the mid 1970's. Others were hired to provide social services required by law, or to guard a jail population that tripled in a decade.
Mr. Dinkins suggests the city is still paying the price for the school cutbacks of the 1970's through a lost generation of young criminals and drug abusers those cuts spawned, and he says over and over that children are the future and deserve good teachers.
The endorsement by the president of the United Federation of Teachers, Sandra Feldman, gave Mr. Dinkins credibility in his campaign last year with a much-needed consituency.
When his opponents complained that Mr. Dinkins would give away the store to his friends in labor, he replied that his friendship gave him the clout to persuade the unions that the money wasn't there. Now the Mayor has the worst of both worlds: He is faulted for giving the teachers too much of a raise, while the other unions don't believe the fiscal situation is as bad as he says.
Mr. Hill and Mr. Feinstein have made noises about job actions and threatened the Mayor in terms reserved for enemies. How Mr. Dinkins will get out of the stalemate remains unclear.
"A difference between New York and other places in this respect," Mr. Netzer said, "is that New York does more things and has a more activist budget and more employees" since it is both a city and county government.
"Everything focuses in terms of negotiations on the Mayor," he said. "It produces a paradox. In a constitutional sense, you have a more powerful mayor, but in a very real sense, a more vulnerable mayor. There's no place to hide."

HEADLINE: The Cost of Divorce to Staten Island

 BODY:
"Shall a charter commission to provide for the separation of the borough of Staten Island from the City of New York and for the establishment of the City of Staten Island be created?"
That question will appear on the ballots of Staten Island voters on Election Day; unfortunately, the outcome is a foregone conclusion. Misled by their own passions and self-serving politicians, the majority of Staten Islanders have long favored secession and intend to vote yes. 
 But so far they've been fueled more by emotion than information. What New York City's least populated borough needs now are facts and figures about the true cost of divorce. It's therefore imperative that the Governor and legislators appoint a responsible charter commission, and that the new panel, in turn, insist on expert, objective analysis of secession's economic and social consequences.
Staten Islanders, who have long felt ignored and abused, are even more worried now that the Board of Estimate has been abolished. That cost them some of the power once shared equally with the other, larger boroughs. The vision of freedom from the obligations and problems of a huge city has thus grown increasingly seductive.
Elected officials, including Gov. Mario Cuomo, turned deaf ears to the argument that all five boroughs deserved a voice in the 92-year-old city's fate. The result was a law passed last year in Albany that allowed Staten Islanders to vote to establish a commission. The commission's recommendations will be put to another vote by Staten Islanders in 1993; if approved, the recommendations will go to the State Legislature for final approval or rejection.
The cost of independence remains a guess. Secessionists envision living in a Staten Island unburdened by city hospitals, shelters, jails and other unpopular facilities; they would make money by charging the rest of the city for the Fresh Kills landfill, and would receive state and Federal aid directly, bypassing City Hall.
But questions abound. How would Staten Island maintain its preferential property tax rates without Manhattan's commercial tax base? How would it finance schools, buses and road repairs? There's an even larger question, which Mr. Cuomo and others who so cavalierly authorized the process might take a moment to ponder: What if other predominantly white, middle-class enclaves try to follow suit?
With political leadership, this costly, potentially divisive exercise could have been avoided. NowJU
the only way to minimize the damage is to be sure that the people of Staten Island can make their ultimate decision on the basis of facts and reasoned discussion.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Washington Is Tiring of Supporting All Those Spies

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE Pentagon, it turns out, was not the only Federal behemoth rescued from Congressional budget-cutters by Saddam Hussein. When Congress adjourned last weekend it left behind a top-secret 1991 espionage budget that not only is said to approach $30 billion -- just a nick below current levels -- but also resists deeper cuts that the House and Senate armed services committees are looking for.
American officials say the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait reminded Congress that the nation's intelligence agencies, like its armed forces, have duties beyond guarding against a Soviet military threat that is evaporating daily. 
 But they add that the Persian Gulf crisis only postpones a reordering of espionage spending and responsibilities that may leave some agencies reeling. After encouraging a decade of growth, Congress is questioning whether the alphabet-soup spy organizations are not performing make-work, duplicating each others' efforts to justify their budgets.
"The plethora of separate facilities, separate communications operations, separate data processing centers, separate training facilities, and separate support and warehousing operations is ripe for consolidation," the House Armed Services Committee stated in a largely secret report in August on the Pentagon's spying programs.
"A lot of our members feel we should be looking at a top-to-bottom scrub of intelligence -- a hard look at what we're doing, what we should be doing and who ought to be doing it," one Congressional aide said.
Those who still regard espionage as a tight club of trench-coated spies with shoe-phones would be astounded at the depth and breadth of the intelligence bureaucracy. The best-known spying outfit by far, the Central Intelligence Agency, spends perhaps 11 percent of the total espionage budget on its 30,000 or so spies, analysts and scientists. That amounts to $3 billion to $3.5 billion a year. The really big spenders are the National Security Agency, which conducts and analyzes electronic eavesdropping on an annual diet of $5 billion or so, and the National Reconnaissance Office, which launches and manages satellites on a budget that some say approaches $8 billion a year, but others say is smaller.
That does not include the Defense Intelligence Agency, a Pentagon office with thousands of military intelligence analysts; individual intelligence agencies in the Army, Navy, Marines and Air Force; counter-espionage offices in the four services, the Energy Department, the C.I.A. and the Federal Bureau of Investigation; a staff of State Department analysts, and an independent 250-person executive branch office that is supposed to make sure that they all mesh.
Too often, critics say, they do not. In theory, the services gather tactical intelligence -- "find out what hill the bad guy's behind," in one official's words -- and the Defense Intelligence Agency looks at bigger pictures, surveying adversaries' overall strategies and determining which new weapons best exploit enemy flaws. In practice, critics charge, the two regularly overlap, with Air Force intelligence officers, for example, producing intelligence to justify purchases of new weapons that the Air Force wants to buy.
Moreover, analysts at the D.I.A. and C.I.A. examine the same cables from overseas spies and review the same electronic intercepts, which, in turn, have often been independently analyzed by the N.S.A. The turf fights can become vicious.
Some duplication is valuable, especially when it spurs healthy debate over an important piece of intelligence, such as signs of Iraqi troops massing near Kuwait. But with deficits growing and the Soviet threat fading, even the spymasters concede that some cuts are in order.
"It's not any big secret: some intelligence agencies are getting a little bit fat," a senior Pentagon official said in an interview earlier this year. "There are a lot of important capabilities we've bought in the last decade. But everyone's got to give at the office."
The question is where. Congress would like to force the Pentagon and the civilian espionage agencies, headed by the C.I.A., to combine operations more often, especially now that the military is becoming more deeply involved in activities like drug interdiction and economic intelligence-gathering.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's senior aide for intelligence spending, Duane Andrews, is reported to be close to finishing a Pentagon cut-and-paste proposal for the intelligence agencies. Congress has ordered Mr. Cheney and the Director of Central Intelligence, William H. Webster, to produce a joint report on reorganization by March.
But the rival bureaucracies have resisted streamlining before, and the impatient House and Senate armed services committees propose to force upon them one equitably painful remedy: a 25 percent personnel cut in both Pentagon and civilian spy agencies between 1992 and 1996.
That is more than the 22 percent cut now contemplated for military personnel alone, and both the spies and their overseers on Congress's intelligence committees reject it outright. More likely, officials say, the agencies will have to cut and reorganize where the money is: in the Pentagon espionage agencies, in the N.R.O.'s hugely expensive satellite programs and in the N.S.A., all of which grew at double-digit rates in the 1980's.
Already, the latest intelligence budget is reported to have killed at least one expensive satellite that was designed to monitor the Soviet Union, and troop withdrawals from Europe will reduce a huge N.S.A. and military intelligence presence along the old Iron Curtain.
Congress would prefer that the Defense Intelligence Agency inherit control of many tasks that it now shares with the military. But the services, always skilled at protecting their own, are likely to resist fiercely.
"Defense has got the least justifiable budget of anybody," one former senior intelligence official said last week. "Most of what they do is duplicative, and most of that is aimed at the Soviets."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC & PRIVATE;
Staying Alive

BYLINE: By Anna Quindlen

 BODY:
I love newspapers. I know that's like a butcher telling you steak is great, but the butcher is right and so am I.
Every day, the people I work with produce fast history you can hold in your hand. Market research tells us that more and more people are relying on television news instead, but television news and newspapers aren't the same thing at all. Newspapers are portable and reusable. If you don't get the gist the first time, you can reread. If you don't care about one gist, you can turn to another. And when you're through with gist, you can pack up old dishes and line bird cages.
 
 I especially love tabloids. I suppose that's like the butcher confessing that his favorite food is fish. In a world that has become a little finicky and refined for my taste, a good tabloid isn't. It stands up on its hind legs and shouts "Get a load of this!" A good tabloid is fast and mean and cheap and low and vivid and street-smart. It plays dismemberments and mob hits big. It is also easy to read.
 All this is a way of saying something simple: Don't let The Daily News die.
I don't even know whom I'm talking to when I say that. The accidental strike at The News is so complicated and convoluted, made up of so much bad faith and errors of judgment, that even people in the midst of it don't know who could settle the thing, or if a settlement is even possible.
You have to make sure of three things before you call any strike. The first is that management cannot do without your labor. The second is that the moral force of a picket line will keep others from working. And the third is that there is some obvious middle ground between their position (less) and yours (more).
None of these things were certain at The News.
There's remarkably little talk of the standard negotiated settlement, the one that the unions can live with and management will accept. Instead people speak with terrible resignation of three scenarios:
The workers go back, those that management will take, and theyJU
eat any bad deals that management puts on their plate.
The workers are permanently replaced.
The Daily News goes under.
All three of those scenarios involve breaking the backs of the unions, and there has never been a more obvious time for the company to try. Management types in all industries have studied Air Traffic Controllers 101, the short course that has made a strike more perilous to workers than ever before. The economy is in tatters, you can find replacements on any corner, and executives who have been poor-mouthing since time immemorial are telling the truth when they say things are tough. Old union work rules have never seemed more like antiquated indulgences to the front office. New machines make hard jobs simple and people a luxury.
Two of the scenarios include the death of The Daily News. One is using replacement workers in the newsroom. The Tribune honchos can fly in reporters from Florida and Illinois all they want, but those reporters aren't going to be able to put out the real Daily News, the one that knows Brooklyn without a map and has cop connections that are indelible and unbeatable. Some guy from Orlando isn't going to replace Jerry Capeci on the mob or Marcia Kramer on the Mayor. A newspaper is given its voice by the people who write and edit it. Ventriloquists won't cut it.
There is also talk about simply shutting down the paper. The suits in Chicago insist that is not the plan. But I have watched as, year after year, the tabloid readers have moved to the suburbs, and the advertisers have closed their doors. Korvette's. Ohrbach's. S. Klein. Gimbels. All gone now. A newspaper is one organism that is dying if it becomes svelte. Upscale, that dissonant manufactured word, has become the mantra of the people who run newspapers, and the people who market consumer goods, too.
A real tabloid is never upscale.
"Don't it always seem to go," Joni Mitchell sings, "that you don't know what you've got 'til it's gone." You can still hear the occasional lament for The New York Herald Tribune, although it's been gone for years. Some people still miss The Philadelphia Bulletin. I'm one of them.
Maybe The News would have gone belly up anyhow. Maybe something can still be worked out, if both sides can forget the violence and the vitriol. There's a special kind of light shed by a paper as big, as unruly, and as unpretentious as The News. And if it dies, or if only its shell remains, it will be a dark day for this city, and this business. Perhaps some group will be able to say it won. But it won't be the readers.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
A Bad 'Budget Deal'
<

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
This week's alarming employment statistics -- 68,000 jobs lost in October, after 52,000 disappeared in September -- not only suggested further national slippage into recession but that the celebrated new "budget deal" was the wrong economic medicine.
That's not merely because the President and Congress agreed, more or less, on an arrangement that is supposed to reduce the Federal deficit, when a looming recession seems to call instead for economic stimulus. Defenders of the budget deal insist that the $40 billion in putative deficit reduction scheduled for this fiscal year is not enough to trigger a recession. 
 Even if they're right (and to some of us, $40 billion seems quite enough of a straw to break the camel's back), the overall five-year program of deficit reduction is aimed supposedly at expanding private investment. Instead, it may actually reduce such investment because higher taxes and curtailed Federal spending will re<ll14duce demand or retard growth in demand. But studies show, and even the President's Economic Report concedes, that demand and its rate of growth are the factors to which private investment is most responsive.
Arcane statistics support this common-sense notion; if the public demands more, business will seek to provide it. But if falling demand causes investment to decline, employment will decline too. That will mean lower Government revenues and higher Government outlays to ease the plight of the jobless and their families. And that in turn will mean an increased Federal deficit, not despite but because of the budget deal.
Beyond that, a strong argument can and should be made that it is not private but public investment that is most in need of expansion -- public investment for the tangible, such as roads and bridges and sewage disposal plants, and for the intangible, education and research and development. Sadly, the budget deal was aimed at deficit reduction, including spending cuts, and a balanced budget, rather than at increased public investment.But how, skeptics ask, could we spend more when we already owe so much? Aside from the question of whether the Federal deficit and the national debt are all that large (when measured against gross national product), spending more makes ample sense if the added expenditures are aimed at increasing employment. For every percentage point by which unemployment is reduced, the Federal deficit would be cut by about $40 billion, because of higher revenues from more people working and lower explenditures for fewer unemployed people and their families.
The budget dealmakers must have overlooked the significant fact that unemployment stood at 10.7 percent at the end of 1982, and still was more than 8 percent at the end of 1983. Since then, it has declined rather steadily to 5.7 percent today. The economist Robert Eisner asked pertinently, in an article in Challenge for May/June 1990:
"How explain the extended recovery in the last seven years, cutting that unemployment percentage in half? Was it really unrelated to the initiation of huge deficits and the swing back to [easier money] by the Fed in 1982?"
Mr. Eisner, the Kenan professor of economics at Northwestern University, pointed out that during roughly the same years -- 1984 through 1989 -- "inflation has run successively at 3.7, 3.0, 2.6, 3.2, 3.3 and finally 4.1" percent. In other words, the stimulative deficits that helped reduce unemployment did not produce runaway inflation or anything approaching it.
In the past two years, moreover, gross private domestic investment averaged, in real terms, 17.6 percent of G.N.P. -- which is equal to or above the ratio of investment to G.N.P. a decade ago. So the borrowing needed to finance the deficit has not really "crowded out" private investment, doomsayers to the contrary.
Nor has the national debt -- not to be confused with the deficit -- ballooned, if properly viewed against the size and growth of even a sluggish U.S. economy. National income and G.N.P. have been growing at about 7 percent a year; so has the national debt.
This debt-to-G.N.P. ratio permits an annual deficit as large as 3 percent of G.N.P. While that ratio, reflecting a sensible balanced-growth policy, is maintained, the problem is not how much the Government spends, though that's what the budget deal primarily addressed. The problem, rather, is what the Government spends for. Stay tuned for another article on this important question.
