HEADLINE: Feasts & Celebrations;
Time vs. Money Three Plans for a Brunch

BYLINE: BY FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
WHEN ENTERTAINING IS meant to be informal, affordable and on a large scale -- say 20 guests, some with children -- nothing beats brunch. Increasingly popular, a brunch offers many options, from doing it yourself to purchasing prepared dishes from a carryout shop or even hiring a caterer. These three approaches have been contrasted here with estimates from across the country -- New York City, suburban Connecticut, Seattle, Washington and Pittsburgh.
The meal itself, lower in calories and cholesterol than the traditional egg-based fare, sacrifices nothing in flavor or festivity. It begins with a smooth curried tomato soup, a non-alcoholic alternative to a Bloody Mary. The main course, picadillo, a Latin American minced-meat hash, is usually made with pork or beef, but in this version, with seasoned ground turkey. Accompanying it are a chunky relish (made from eight diced avocados mixed with the juice of five limes, a cup of chopped coriander, two jalapenos and salt), plus a simple saffron pilaf and a colorful salad of black beans and corn in a Sherry vinaigrette. Dessert is a homey cobbler of apples and dried fruit plumped in tea, topped with a simple cake batter. Instead of whipped cream or ice cream, sweetened whipped skim-milk ricotta is served on the side. 
 DOING IT YOURSELF. The most lengthy, but also the most economic and personal approach, is to take care of everything, from marketing to serving, on your own. To save time, all the dishes except the relish and dessert can be prepared a couple of days in advance, and the cobbler can be made the night before. Although using paper or plastic tableware will keep the work minimal, china and glassware are more gracious and convenient for guests. Extra plates, cups and glasses can be borrowed, or rented for 35 cents to $1.50 each from a party-supply company, which only requires the tableware to be rinsed before pickup.
 
TAKEOUT. For those with a tighter schedule, carryout is a good alternative, but also more expensive -- it can be about two to three times the cost of cooking at home. The food, however, can be just as nutritious; many carryout shops across the country offer dishes similar to those on the menu. In fall, for instance, the Hay Day markets, a group of specialty-foods stores in Greenwich and Westport, Conn., often have a ginger and carrot soup and a turkey meat loaf. In Pittsburgh, Rania's To Go offers a fat-free baked apple compote with a yogurt topping, a dessert in the same spirit as the cobbler. "We get so many calls for this kind of food, we felt we should go with it," said Rania Harris, the owner. For large orders, many shops will place the food on platters supplied by the host.
CATERING. For the least time and, yes, the greatest expense -- sometimes nearly twice as much as carryout -- a caterer can be hired. Yet as catered parties go, a brunch like this is still one of the least expensive. If it is fully catered, a chef will come to take care of preparation, last-minute cooking, refilling platters and cleanup. Rates vary around the country, and will also depend on the service and rentals desired.
DRINKS. While a caterer will often arrange for beverages, few have liquor licenses, so the choices, in any event, will be up to the host. The options include an easygoing wine, beer or perhaps a bottle of spirits -- probably vodka -- along with mixers. If only wine is to be served, buy a case, but if you are offering additional beverages, eight bottles will probably do. (The accompanying box lists good reasonably priced wines.) If you're opting for only beer and soft drinks, purchase a case and a half of beer. Even with both wine and beer, the total drinks bill, including mixers, coffee and ice, should not exceed $125.
STAFF. A brunch buffet does not call for much help -- a local teen-ager can be enlisted to help replenish serving platters and clean up -- but professional assistance is an option. Depending on the area, bartenders and waiters usually charge $10 to $20 an hour. Caterers, service agencies (typically for a $15 to $40 fee) and even some schools and colleges can supply the help. Often, there is a three- to five-hour minimum.
 
PAUL NEUMAN'S CURRIED TOMATO SOUP
 
 1/2 cup corn or canola oil
 2 large onions, minced
 2 tart green apples,
 peeled and minced
 2 tablespoons minced fresh ginger
 2 tablespoons minced garlic
 1 jalapeno, seeded and minced
 2 tablespoons curry powder
 2 tablespoons ground cumin
 1 1/2 teaspoons turmeric
 1 1/2 teaspoons ground cardamom
 1 1/2 teaspoons freshly ground pepper
 4 28-ounce cans crushed tomatoes
 2 tablespoons light brown sugar
 1/4 cup cider vinegar
 Salt to taste
 10 cups chicken or vegetable stock.
1. Heat the oil in a large, heavy saucepan over medium-high heat. Saute the onions and apples until tender and golden, about eight minutes. Add the ginger, garlic and jalapeno and cook a few minutes. Stir in the curry powder, cumin, turmeric, cardamom and pepper, and saute a minute or so more.
2. Stir in the tomatoes and simmer for 45 minutes. Stir in the brown sugar and vinegar, then season with salt. Cool and refrigerate.
3. Before serving, place the soup mixture in a large pot, about eight-quart capacity, and add the stock. Bring it to a simmer and adjust the seasonings. The soup is best not quite piping hot.
Yield: Twenty to 25 servings.
 
TURKEY PICADILLO
 
 8 pounds ground turkey
 2 cups dry Sherry
 1/2 cup extra-virgin olive oil
 3 cups minced onion
 3 cups minced green pepper
 1 tablespoon minced garlic
 2 cups chopped pimento-stuffed olives
 1 cup tomato paste
 6 tablespoons capers
 1 tablespoon chili powder
 2 teaspoons oregano
 2 teaspoons ground cumin
 Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste
 1 cup slivered blanched almonds, toasted.
1. Marinate the turkey in the Sherry for 30 minutes.
2. Heat the oil in a very large, deep skillet, at least seven-quart capacity, or in a heavy roasting pan placed over two burners. Saute the onion and green pepper over medium heat, stirring constantly, until they are lightly browned. Stir in the garlic.
3. Add the turkey and saute, stirring until crumbly and the excess liquid has evaporated, about 10 minutes.
4. Add all the remaining ingredients except the almonds and cook over medium-low heat, stirring occasionally, about 15 minutes. Set aside.
5. If needed, reheat the picadillo on top of the stove and keep warm in a covered casserole. Just before serving, sprinkle with the almonds.
Yield: Twenty to 25 servings.
 
SAFFRON PILAF
 
 2 teaspoons saffron threads, crushed
 9 cups hot chicken stock
 1/3 cup extra-virgin olive oil
 1 cup minced onion
 6 cups short-grain rice
 Salt to taste.
1. Steep the saffron in two cups of the stock for at least 30 minutes.
2. Heat the oil in a large, heavy casserole. Saute the onion over low heat until very tender but not brown. Stir in the rice, increase the heat to medium and cook, stirring, for several minutes, until the rice begins to whiten.
3. Stir in the saffron mixture and the remaining stock. Salt if necessary. Bring to a simmer, then cook, covered tightly, over very low heat for about 17 minutes, until the liquid is absorbed. Remove and set aside, covered, for 10 minutes.
4. Transfer the pilaf to a serving dish. It can be served at once or cooled slightly. It can also be refrigerated overnight and brought to room temperature, then reheated for 30 minutes at 300 degrees in a covered baking dish.
Yield: Twenty to 25 servings.
 
BLACK BEAN AND BELL PEPPER SALAD
 
 2 pounds dried black beans
 2 1/2 cups chopped red pepper
 2 cups cooked corn kernels (fresh, frozen or canned)
 1 cup chopped yellow pepper
 1 cup chopped green pepper
 1 cup minced red onion
 3/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil
 1/2 cup Sherry vinegar
 Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste
 Large pinch cayenne pepper.
1. Clean the beans. Cover with two inches of water and soak four hours or overnight. Drain, place in a large pot and cover again with two inches of water. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer. Skim for a few minutes to remove any foam, and cook, partly covered, for about 50 minutes, until they are tender but still hold their shape. Drain and cool.
2. Mix the beans with the remaining ingredients and refrigerate if desired. One hour before serving, bring the salad to room temperature, mix gently and adjust the seasonings.
Yield: Twenty to 25 servings.
 
DRIED FRUIT AND APPLE COBBLER WITH SWEET RICOTTA
 4 pounds mixed dried fruit (pears, apricots,
 peaches, cherries)
 4 cinnamon sticks
 2 quarts hot strong tea
 16 Granny Smith apples,
 peeled, cored and cut into chunks
 1 cup plus 3 tablespoons
 light brown sugar, packed
 2 teaspoons ground cinnamon
 1 3/4 cups unsalted butter, at room temperature
 4 cups flour
 2 teaspoons baking powder
 1 teaspoon nutmeg, preferably freshly ground
 1 teaspoon salt
 2 cups granulated sugar
 6 large eggs
 1 cup milk
 2 teaspoons vanilla extract
 4 cups skim-milk ricotta
 Grated rind of 2 oranges
 3 tablespoons fresh orange juice
 Confectioners' sugar.
1. Steep the dried fruit and cinnamon sticks in the tea for at least two hours to plump the fruit.
2. Drain, reserving any remaining tea. Place the tea in a small saucepan and reduce to about one-half cup. Pour back into the fruit.
3. Combine the apple chunks, one cup of the brown sugar, the ground cinnamon and the fruit.
4. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. With about two tablespoons of the butter, grease two four- to five-quart baking dishes.
5. Sift the flour, baking powder, nutmeg and salt together and set aside. Spread equal amounts of the fruit mixture in the two dishes.
6. Cream the remaining butter with the granulated sugar until fluffy. Beat in the eggs, one at a time. Combine the milk and vanilla. Stir a small amount of the flour mixture into the butter mixture, alternating with some of the milk mixture, until well blended. Drop the batter from a large spoon over the fruit, covering the top. Spread it to close any gaps.
7. Bake about one hour to one hour and 10 minutes, until the top is puffy and brown.
8. Meanwhile, mix the skim-milk ricotta cheese with the orange rind, orange juice and the remaining brown sugar. Place in a food processor or blender, and process about 30 seconds, until smooth. Refrigerate.
9. Cool the cobblers an hour or two before serving. If they have cooled longer, warm them for about 20 minutes in a 200-degree oven. (Do not refrigerate.) Dust with sifted confectioners' sugar and serve with the ricotta.
Yield: Twenty-four servings.

The host or hostess will only have to warm the food when necessary, and transfer it to serving bowls

A Seattle caterer estimated that a catered party with this menu would cost about $20 per person. In New York City, Neuman & Bogdonoff figured the cost would not exceed $30 per person, which included their coordinating the purchase of beverages and any rentals of tableware and/or chairs. HEADLINE: Reputation by Citation

BYLINE: By Paul A. Freund; Paul A. Freund is Carl M. Loeb University Professor Emeritus at Harvard Law School.

 BODY:

CARDOZO
A Study in Reputation
By Richard A. Posner.
156 pp. Chicago:
University of Chicago Press. $18.95. 
 REPUTATION and merit are not always the closest of companions. John Chipman Gray, a professor of law at Harvard at the turn of the century, conferred this encomium on his early predecessor Joseph Story: he was "a man of great learning, and of reputation for learning greater even than the learning itself."
In "Cardozo," a study of merit and reputation, Judge Richard A. Posner displays the same affinity for dual relationships that has characterized his highly influential work on law and economics as well as his provocative writing on law and literature. The present compact and unflaggingly interesting volume, drawn from lectures at the University of Michigan, is bound to be provocative in its methodology.
Benjamin N. Cardozo, the Chief Judge of New York's highest court, was appointed to the United States Supreme Court by President Herbert Hoover in 1932, against all the conventional political wisdom: there were already two New Yorkers (Charles Evans Hughes and Harlan Fiske Stone) and another Jew (Louis D. Brandeis) on the Court. It was probably the most popular act of Hoover's Presidency, though that may be faint praise. When the appointment was announced, Felix Frankfurter remarked privately that Cardozo, whom he would succeed seven years later, could not possibly retain the unanimity of acclaim that his accession inspired. (The prophecy, it turned out, proved more accurate for Frankfurter himself.) How deserved, how enduring, is Cardozo's reputation, and why?
To answer these questions, Judge Posner has wisely confined his inquiry to Cardozo's career as a state judge, an office he filled for 18 years and in which his reputation was made. After a review of Cardozo's leading opinions, Judge Posner's verdict is distinctly positive. Cardozo had his flaws, including a tendency to state the facts of a case with an emphasis and selectivity calculated to buttress the legal outcome (a characteristic hardly peculiar to Cardozo among appellate judges, as the author observes). But this is a critical study, by no means a debunking one.
Whether Cardozo's writing style -- somewhat florid, inverted, marked at crucial points by the teasing word -- was a demerit or an asset is analyzed dispassionately. Like Hoover's violation of conventional political canons, Cardozo's flouting of the cautionary canons of opinion writing has produced a living legacy, and Judge Posner cites, as an example, Cardozo's definition of fiduciary duty, surely pertinent to this day: "A trustee is held to something stricter than the morals of the market place. Not honesty alone, but the punctilio of an honor the most sensitive, is then the standard of behavior." It is a style, like Henry James's, easy to parody but difficult to replicate. Whatever the message it encases, the rhetoric adheres in the same way as the language of those, denounced by Thomas Henry Huxley, "who would plaster the fair face of truth with that pestilent cosmetic, rhetoric."
Cardozo's literary style, Judge Posner maintains, is a major element in his reputation. The other principal element is substantive. Cardozo is commonly recognized as a progressive judge who gave new direction (or was it only decisive momentum?) to the development of basic areas of the common law, notably the law of contract and tort. How novel his contributions were can only be assessed, Judge Posner acknowledges, by a more extensive survey of the precedents than was possible in these lectures. What is evident is Cardozo's avowal of continuity in the law even as it changes, and his caution about extending a legal principle to what Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes (Cardozo's "master") called a dryly logical extreme. Although these attributes of moderation might have risked defections among true believers, they serve, in Judge Posner's view, to buttress Cardozo's reputation, along with the indelible imprint of his style, the widespread perception of a gentle, noble character and his graceful extrajudicial writings on the process of judging. After taking account of all that can be said to the disadvantage of his subject, Judge Posner concludes that "among state court judges of this century Cardozo has no peer."
But Judge Posner offers more than his own hard-wrought judgment of his subject. One chapter, "Cardozo's Reputation: Measures of Magnitude," presents a quantitative assessment based on a computer-driven search for law review articles and judicial opinions in which Cardozo's name is mentioned, and here problems small and large emerge. Perhaps the smallest is the computer's incapacity in its search for names to differentiate upper-case and lower-case letters at the beginning of a word. Presumably "Frankfurter" caused no serious difficulty, and "Cardozo" none at all, but (Justice Hugo) "Black" and (Judge Learned) "Hand" definitely did. The author's solution to this problem required some human intervention: Judge Posner took a sample of the questioned word's appearances, found the ratio of the upper-case to lower-case references, and applied that ratio to the word's aggregate appearances.
Other problems are more serious. What exactly is meant by reputation? For his purposes Judge Posner defines it as to be " 'widely regarded in a good light,' and thus as practically equivalent to fame." But while the volume of name references in various publications may be a good measure of attention and fame in the broader sense, it does not necessarily signify a ranking in a good light, a badge of merit or approval. Witness names like Napoleon, Marx and, yes, Holmes. Judge Posner is fully aware of the limitations of the quantitative method. Still, he is unfazed in his eagerness to have it applied more broadly.
Quantitative research may have either of two values: to provide new or counterintuitive information, or to affirm what we "always knew" but now we know. With Cardozo, the data are of essentially the latter kind.
But above and beyond the figures stands the Figure. In the case of Benjamin Cardozo, what is most needed is a full-bodied scholarly biography, toward which the present study, illuminating in itself, will serve as a significant contribution.

HEADLINE: Breaking Up Was Hard to Do

BYLINE: By Neil McKendrick; Neil McKendrick is a Fellow and Director of Studies in History at Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge. His recent books include "The Birth of a Consumer Society" and "Business Life and Public Policy."

 BODY:

ROAD TO DIVORCE
England, 1530-1987.
By Lawrence Stone.
Illustrated. 460 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press.
$29.95. 
 WE live in a conjugal age. Marriage is the standard against which we judge our most intimate relationships. Moralists praise it, poets celebrate it, politicians support it, commerce panders to it, advertisers exploit it, children play at it. It is a most pervasive ideal.
But if in most Western societies most people marry, more people also divorce than ever before. For, paradoxically, we also live in a divorcing society. The popularity of entering marriage may still be growing, but the popularity of leaving it is growing much faster.
From being a scandalous and sinful rarity, virtually impossible for most people to achieve, divorce has become a morally neutral commonplace, available to all. From being a sanctified and indissoluble contract, marriage has come to be a socially popular convenience -- so easily escaped from that one American woman was legally divorced 16 times in 11 years.
The pursuit of happiness and the escape from misery through divorce have been greatly aided by legal change, by rising standards of living and the decline of religion, by the incidence of war and the struggle for female equality. These and much else have made divorce, as Lawrence Stone puts it in his major study, "Road to Divorce," as much a part of contemporary life as death and taxes. The principle, first adumbrated by Milton, that a marriage without love or respect is dead and should be legally buried as soon as practicable, has become the law of the land.
Nor does the revolutionary change end there. The ancient injustices that confined the availability of divorce to an opulent masculine elite have been swept away -- the poor now have equal access to the divorce court with the rich, as do wives with husbands. After centuries of deprivation, those denied divorce are now only too eager to indulge in it. In England, as Mr. Stone points out, more women file for divorce than men, and the working classes have recourse to it four times as much as the professional middle classes.
As "Road to Divorce" illustrates, the rate of increase in the incidence of divorce over the last century is quite breathtaking. Perhaps the most vivid way to express it is to remember that whereas in England and Wales in 1857 only four divorce decrees were granted, the figure for 1985 was 160,000. The great expansion is a 20th-century phenomenon. Fivefold increases with each world war and a further threefold increase since Britain's no-fault divorce legislation of 1971 mark the major turning points. The experience of divorce is now so pervasive that it is estimated that a third of all marriages in England will end in divorce. (The figure is even higher in the United States, where half of all married couples divorce.)
In the face of such figures Mr. Stone can reasonably claim that "the metamorphosis of a largely non-separating and non-divorcing society, such as England from the Middle Ages to the mid-nineteenth century, into a separating and divorcing one in the late twentieth, is perhaps the most profound and far-reaching social change to have occurred in the last five hundred years."
Voltaire was less than accurate when he wrote that divorce is as old as marriage. It was the need for divorce that arrived with the wedding ceremony, not access to it. Fielding was closer to the mark when he wrote in 1734, "Many a man wants a wife, but more want to get rid of one." The all too frequent human tragedy for both spouses was their inability to achieve the riddance. So inevitably and quite properly, this book is as much concerned with marriage as with its dissolution. If one does not appreciate the essential social, economic and political role of marriage in early modern England one will not understand why the opposition to dissolving marriage ties was so violent and so effective. Satisfying the need for love, affection and procreation, and gratifying the needs of lust, were important, but for many these were secondary to such vital functions as achieving a viable family economy, cementing alliances between families and kin groups, or simply transferring property. As Mr. Stone puts it, "emotions are . . . more ephemeral and volatile than interests."
The first purpose of this book is therefore to identify and explain the extraordinary laxity and ambiguity of the English laws of marriage that endured up to the Marriage Act of 1753, the equally extraordinary strictness of the laws of separation and divorce that lasted until the Divorce Reform Act of 1857, and the even more extraordinary ways the public tried to exploit the ambiguity of the former and undermine the rigidity of the latter. The ingenuity involved in both was impressive, and Mr. Stone points out that the history of connivance and collusion survived well into the 20th century, as A. P. Herbert's "Holy Deadlock" and Evelyn Waugh's "Handful of Dust" made hilariously clear. Even the infamous wife sales -- in which wives were taken to market with halters around their necks and sold by their husbands to the highest bidders -- were usually prearranged as to both price and successful bidder (although one unfortunate wife was recorded as being sold for a leg of mutton).
The other major objective of "Road to Divorce" is to trace the slow and irregular evolution of moral values between the Reformation and the present day. The route is one from unabashed patriarchy to tentative equality, with most of the progress compressed into the present century. It is difficult to overestimate the revolution in mental and behavioral attitudes involved. As Mr. Stone writes, "It is easy to forget that under the patriarchal system of values, as expressed in the enacted law as it endured until the nineteenth century, a married woman was the nearest approximation in a free society to a slave."
Given a male-dominated society, women faced a long battle for liberation from total legal subordination. Male lawyers, male clergy and the male elite were all highly resistant to change. Governments -- dominated by males -- were usually happy to leave well alone. But as Mr. Stone also points out, upper- and middle-class women, no less than men, have been traditionally fearful of any relaxation of the divorce laws. As one of the women fighting the introduction of divorce into Ireland, which was decisively defeated in 1986, said: "A woman voting for divorce is like a turkey voting for Christmas."
For the general reader, the divorce revolution of the last 30 years will probably be the most fascinating part of this book. It is not the sixfold increase in the English divorce rate since 1960 that is most arresting, but the fact that this explosion has done no more than cut the duration of marriage back to its traditional length. The present-day high divorce rate merely does what a historically high mortality rate used to do. The duration of marriage is remarkable more for its stability than its change in 20th-century England -- an average of over 30 years per marriage between 1900 and 1945. Indeed, the average proportion of life spent married marginally increased in that period -- from 52 percent to 56 percent.
There are many such gems to be found in this volume, perhaps the most surprising being that marriages preceded by a trial period of living together are more likely to end in quick divorce than those where the couple did not live together. Practice no more makes perfect in these cases than it does in those of people who remarry after divorce.
Another surprise is that England has the highest divorce rate of any country in the European Community. To this and many other variables -- from the current spectacular levels of illegitimacy to the increased economic independence of women -- "Road to Divorce" offers a sure-footed and fascinating commentary.
Lawrence Stone is one of my favorite historians. Given his originality, his creativity, his sheer productivity, he ought to be favored by more of our profession than he is. Yet his monuments to scholarship inspire as much outrage as they do respect. His hyperbole provokes correction. His hypotheses provoke challenge. His errors provoke fury. His ideas provide employment for whole armies of academics, all chipping away at the great landmarks with which he has dotted the historical landscape.
This latest work will probably be more respectfully received than most. It is admirably solid. It is soundly researched. It would establish the reputation of a lesser man. But by Mr. Stone's standards it is less challenging, less path-breaking, less provoking than usual. Roderick Phillips's "Putting Asunder: A History of Divorce in Western Society" (1988) is a more comprehensive and in many ways a more satisfying book.
Is the enfant terrible becoming an eminence grise at last? As Mr. Stone (until his retirement this year, the Dodge Professor of History at Princeton University) moves from his brash neolithic youth to his serene paleolithic maturity, are we to look forward less to disturbing monoliths and more to imposing and enduring megaliths? If so the historical lithographists can spend more time on Stone-polishing than Stone-breaking. A few Stone worshipers may even appear. For as the historical Stone-work builds up to pyramid-like proportions, few will be able convincingly to deny that Lawrence Stone is now our most impressive living historian.

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1665 words

HEADLINE: For Russians, Firsthand Lessons In Capitalism

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
A GROUP of Soviet executives, including the chief accountant of a Siberian tire plant, a lawyer and a division chief for a machine-building plant, have arrived in the county to study firsthand the dynamics of America's market-driven economy.
Thirty-eight men and three women began a monthlong executive management program two weeks ago at Iona College in New Rochelle. It is being conducted by the faculty of the college's Hagan School of Business, in partnership with Sinerghia, a Moscow-based management-training organization, and the Institute of the National Economy in Moscow, the largest educational research center in the Soviet Union. 
 Dr. Vitaly Ivanovich Vidyapin, who has been the rector of the economic institute for 10 years, said: 'I myself am now a student, and I am glad of the opportunity. But we brought many young people in our delegation because they are the ones who represent the future. Our 13,000 students make up the generation that will enter the market economy, so I am here to learn more about it.'
 
'Who Would Have Dreamed?'
 Charles F. O'Donnell, dean of the Hagan School, said, 'Who would have dreamed a few years ago that we would be teaching Soviet business leaders how to move into the free enterprise system?'
The program is under the direction of Dr. Eduardo S. Paderon, assistant dean of the business school, and includes courses taught by Dr. O'Donnell and Dr. Paderon. These cover the fundamentals of marketing, finance, accounting, United States business law, economics, management and business strategy. Some are being taught in Russian, others in English with the help of translators.
'Guest lecturers from industry, including the president of Nynex International and the head of Stella D'oro Biscuit Company, are also going to address the group,' said Dr. O'Donnell. 'But it's not going to be all classroom work.'
The Russians especially want to visit American manufacturing plants and to see how Fortune 500 companies operate, so several tours of companies in the metropolitan region are planned. 'We're going to the General Motors plant in Tarrytown, International Business Machines plants in Fishkill and Poughkeepsie and to Avon headquarters in Rye,' Dr. O'Donnell said.
The group will also visit two bastions of capitalism: the New York Stock Exchange and a New Jersey shopping mall.
 
Tickets to a Broadway Show
 Also included in the itinerary is a trip to Brighton Beach in Brooklyn, to visit the large Russian community there, and tickets to the Broadway show, 'Black and Blue.'
'Of course we're delighted to be playing a role in the training of Soviet business leaders,' Dr. O'Donnell said, 'but the man behind all of this is Dr. Eheil Ash.' Dr. Ash, a native of Russia, has been a professor of accounting at Iona since 1980.
He was invited to lecture in the Soviet Union last summer, and developed the contacts that led to the program. 'There was a lot of red tape involved,' Dr. O'Donnell said, 'but in July three heads of the Russian group came over and met with us on campus and we hammered out the program together.'
Dr. Ash, who once was a professor of accounting at the Institute of the National Economy, is the author of nine books on accounting practices that are still used as authoritative textbooks in the Soviet Union. But in 1972, he said, he was dismissed from the faculty, when it was revealed that he wanted to emigrate from the Soviet Union.
'My wife and my son and I left the Soviet Union in 1973,' Dr. Ash said. 'We first went to Israel and three years later we came to the United States. Accounting here is completely different, so I started taking courses in accounting and English. Seven years later, I became a professor of accounting at Iona. '
In June, Dr. Ash and his wife, Lily, returned to Russia for the first time since they had left.
'We were very excited and just a little apprehensive,' Dr. Ash recalled. 'We went because I was invited by my old colleagues at the institute to give three lectures on the free-market economy in order to prepare big companies in the Soviet Union for private ownership and joint ventures.'
At the end of the lecture series, Professor Ash said, Dr. Vidyapin expressed interest in sending representatives from the largest manufacturing companies in Russia to the United States to learn more about private enterprise practices.
The state institute 'was founded in 1904 by Russian merchants,' Dr. Vidyapin said. 'It is probably one of the oldest business schools in the world. We have a faculty of 500 professors -- scientists and economists who are the equivalents of American Ph.D.'s.'
 
Next Program Planned
 Now Dr. Vidyapin and Dr. Mikhail Ioffe, who is the general manager of Sinerghia, are leading the first group. A second monthlong program with another Soviet group has been planned with Iona for November. And in December, a delegation of top-level representatives from the Soviet Petroleum Ministry is coming for two weeks.
'We hope to take them to Texaco headquarters in Westchester,' Professor Ash said, 'and perhaps go for a few days to one of the oil-producing states, either Texas or Oklahoma, if their budget allows it.'
The Russians, he said, are paying their own way, with each particular enterprise in the Soviet Union paying for its own representatives to come to the United States. 'Every group will probably spend a total of $175,000 to $230,000 here,' he said.
The tuition fee paid to Iona by the Russians 'covers our costs,' Dr. O'Connell said. 'We don't want to make a profit -- we only want to come out even.'
Dr. Ioffe, who helped design the program with Dr. Paderon of Iona, said he hoped to be able to organize regular exchange programs between the Soviet Union and the United States.
'For the first time in 60 to 70 years of Soviet history, leaders of different Soviet enterprises are establishing contacts with the West,' Dr. Ioffe said. 'We are anxious to investigate American business methods. Especially, we want to learn more about how to become entrepreneurial. We are economists ourselves, so for us it is perhaps not too difficult to understand the dynamics that govern a free marketplace.'
 
The First Visit, for Most
 With the exception of Dr. Ioffe and Dr. Vidyapin, none of the members of the Soviet group had visited the United States before. The group is diverse -- it includes executives from the chemical and timber industries, an electrical engineer from the Ukraine, and representatives of the construction industry, for example. Few speak English. And yet, at a reception for the delegation at the Tarrytown Hilton Inn that was attended by local and county officials and Iona faculty members, the Russians eagerly gave their first impressions of the United States.
With the help of a translator, Zinaida Alexandrovna Dorozhkina, the accountant from the tire plant in Siberia, said that she could already see how the United States economy differed from that of the Soviet Union.
Others said the sights they had seen on a bus tour to Manhattan had amazed them.
 
Impressions of America
 Speaking in English, Valeria Louchinkova, a lawyer with the Sinerghia venture, said: 'I could not believe the skyscrapers. There were so many of them, so imposing, so beautiful. But I could not believe what we saw when we rode through Harlem, either. The United States has many contrasts.'
And the chief of a division of a machine-building plant, Anatolij Shevchouk, emphasized that he found the people from Iona 'to be warm and sincere -- and many speak Russian, which is good.'
The reception ended with gifts presented by the Russians to the Americans and then speeches were made.
'We are talking a lot,' Dr. Ioffe said with a smile, 'because in a free economy that is how it is done. You talk and talk and talk and no one can stop you. Right?'
 
MOSCOW ON THE HUDSON
 A DELEGATION of 41 Soviet executives is staying at the Tarrytown Hilton Inn, which was chosen in July by the group of Russians who helped plan the free-enterprise study program being conducted with Iona College in New Rochelle.
'We took them to see several hotels, but the Tarrytown Inn -- with its view of the Hudson River -- bowled them over,' said Dr. Eduardo S. Paderon of Iona. 'The hotel is also supplying us with classrooms. Many of the courses are held right on the premises. We go back to Iona when we need to work on the computers.'
Val Reyes, the general manager of the hotel, said the Russians were getting a 'competitive' hotel rate.
 
'Extremely Nice Guests'
 'We are glad to have their business,' Mr. Reyes said. 'They're extremely nice guests. Very appreciative of anything we do for them. For instance, the other day we lent several of them tennis racquets so they could use our courts, and we were thanked so profusely.'
The indoor pool at the inn is also a favorite of the Russians, Mr. Reyes noted. 'They use it a lot and seem to really enjoy it,' he said.
With few exceptions, the Russians are sharing rooms. 'They are paying us in dollars, which are very scarce, I understand, in the Soviet Union,' said John Cunningham, director of sales at the Tarrytown Inn, 'Just for fun they've been handing out rubles to the staff. We've included two meals, a full American breakfast and a big buffet lunch, in the rate. They're on their own for dinner.'
 
Orange Juice Is a Favorite>HE>
And what do the Russians like to eat?
The executive chef, Jacques Metrailler, said the delegation was especially fond of stews, potatoes, bread and cake.
'They can't seem to get enough orange juice and they drink a lot of soda,' Mr. Metrailler said. 'We've noticed that although they seem to enjoy all our American foods, they don't like anything with tomatoes.'
Mr. Metrailler said recently that he would be serving borscht and a special Russian salad at lunch a few days later.
'By that time,' he added, 'they will have been here long enough to want something that tastes like home.'

HEADLINE: Utility Seeks Surcharge For Conservation Effort

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
LAST year, Northeast Utilities fell $11 million short of its goal to provide $24 million worth of conservation services to its customers in Connecticut. The power company found that few people wanted to hear about energy efficiency.
This year, with the onset of colder weather and the continuing standoff in the Persian Gulf, energy conservation is suddenly popular again. The utility said it expects to spend about $38 million this year on the conservation program of its subsidiary, the Connecticut Light and Power Company; it expects that will rise to more than $60 million next year. 
 Based on commitments made in recent weeks, the company said, its main conservation program for commercial customers will grow from $3 million this year to about $16 million next year.
The conservation effort has grown so quickly that the utility decided to ask the State Department of Public Utility Control to attach a 2 percent surcharge to its bills to pay for conservation measures, company officials have said.
 
First Request of Its Kind
 "Certainly the timing has had something to do with" the conservation program's success, said Jeffrey R. Kotkin, a spokesman for the utility, which serves most Connecticut towns. "Since the Middle East crisis began, people are thinking about conservation for the first time in years."
Judith K. O'Reilly, a spokeswoman for the State Department of Public Utilities Control, which will consider the request for the surcharge, said no utility in the state has ever requested a rate increase solely to pay for conservation programs.
 Joseph A. Belanger, director of research and policy development for the energy division of the State Office of Policy and Management, said Connecticut has probably been quicker than other states to embrace conservation because of its heavy reliance on oil. About 57 percent of the state's energy comes from oil, he said, compared with a national average of about 43 percent.
The oil price increases since Aug. 1 have forced Connecticut consumers to pay about $1.75 billion more than they would have if oil prices had remained the same, Mr. Belanger said, and the cost of oil as a percentage of the state's disposable income has jumped to 11 percent from 7.5.
"It's raised everyone's consciousness, not only about conservation but also about our energy vulnerability," Mr. Belanger said.
 Daniel L. Sosland, a staff lawyer with the Conservation Law Foundation in Boston, one of the organizations that cooperated with Northeast two years ago in drafting the conservation effort, said the foundation would help the utility refine the programs.
 
Looking for Incentives
 Mr. Sosland noted that while Northeast charges small commercial and industrial customers for conservation consultations, the New England Electric System in eastern Massachusetts offers the same services free.
"The better the incentive, the more likely people are to participate in a conservation program," Mr. Sosland said.
The state's consumer counsel, Eugene M. Koss, said he has been generally pleased with Northeast's conservation efforts over the past two years. Still, he said, he will be reviewing the surcharge request carefully.
"These measures do have to be paid for, no question about it," Mr. Koss said. "But our office would not necessarily agree that the numbers add up to a 2 percent surcharge."
 Bruce J. Wall, head of Northeast's residential-conservation program, said that requests to wrap water heaters with insulation, one of the most effective cost-saving measures, have quadrupled since Aug. 1. He said the company offers its water-heating customers a free conservation service that includes wrapping the water heater and reducing the temperature to 120 degrees, insulating eight feet of pipe leading from the water heater, replacing shower heads and faucet aerators with low-flow devices and cleaning refrigerator coils. The service can save customers up to $150 a year, Mr. Wall said.
 
Efficient Bulbs
 The utility said it received more than 9,000 requests for a new catalogue of energy-efficient light bulbs, and several hundred customers placed orders within the first few days.
"Most customers are not aware of these products," Mr. Wall said. "What we're trying to do is create the demand in the marketplace."
The company also began a new service this month, hauling away customers' old refrigerators.
"What we've found is that if people have one of these old refrigerators, they have it plugged in, even if they're only using it to cool a six-pack of their favorite beverage," Mr. Wall said. The company estimates most people will save $100 a year by getting rid of the refrigerators.
In the first week of the program, the company collected 200 refrigerators; by the end of next year, Mr. Wall estimated, Northeast will have hauled away 12,000, saving consumers a total of $1.2 million annually in electrical costs.
Mr. Kotkin said the company's commercial and industrial conservation programs have been similarly successful in recent weeks, although he said that it could be attributed as much to a softening in the Connecticut economy, prompting companies to look for areas to cut energy bills, as to the invasion of Kuwait. Still, he said, based on the growth the company has seen since Aug. 1, it now expects to spend more than $20 million this year, and almost $40 million next year, on commercial conservation measures.
 
'Money Adds Up Quickly'
 The bulk of its commercial-industrial budget, Mr. Kotkin said, will go to the company's Energy Action program, which increases the efficiency of heating, air-conditioning and ventilation systems.
"There, the money adds up quickly because you may be spending hundreds of thousands of dollars on a single building," he said. The company said it will spend about $3 million on the program this year, but next year it expects an increase to $16 million.
 Mr. Kotkin said another part of Northeast's conservation program will spend $6 million this year and the same amount next year on state buildings, yielding an estimated savings of $3.6 million annually in energy costs.
 He said that in addition to the immediate returns to consumers, the overall conservation program will yield long-term benefits as well. If energy use had continued to increase at the pace it increased through the 1980's, he said, the company would have had to start planning now for costly new generating plants.
 Mr. Kotkin said conservation measures already in place have reduced peak demand by 200 megawatts, and conservation measures that will be enacted by the mid-1990's will save another 400 megawatts. The total, 600 megawatts, is the output of a nuclear plant the size of Connecticut Yankee in Haddam.
 
'A Bit of Self-Promotion'
 But regulators, while saying they are pleased with the progress on conservation, said they are still concerned about electric rates.
Mr. Koss said he is particularly concerned because the conservation spending will have only a fraction of the impact of other Northeast programs. The utility still has to phase in 30 percent of the cost of the Millstone 3 nuclear power plant in Waterford and 20 percent of its share of the Seabrook nuclear plant in New Hampshire, he said.
"I think there's a bit of self-promotion going on here to get people to forget what might be driving the company's rates," Mr. Koss said. "And you've got to be careful about how quickly you build up a program like this.
"Just because $24 million of conservation is a good thing, it doesn't necessarily follow that $60 million of conservation is more than twice as good. A glass of wine before dinner is good, but a whole case of wine before dinner isn't."

LENGTH: 815 words

HEADLINE: Please, Not Another Failed Presidency

BYLINE: By Bert Lance; Bert Lance, President Carter's first director of Management and Budget, is the author of "The Truth Of The Matter."

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
A political observer who suggested any similarity at all three months ago between the Presidencies of George Bush and Jimmy Carter would have been referred somewhere for examination -- but that was then.
This is now: hostages held by a madman ruler in the Middle East; runaway oil prices; skyrocketing gasoline prices; high interest rates and a budget deficit that generates more complaints than the weather, and as much effectiveness in doing something about it. All that plus a President who is campaigning hard against Washington "insiders" while his approval rating in the polls drops faster than the Dow Jones average -- from 80 percent earlier this year to below 50 percent in one national poll last week. Even their symbolic attempts to right the ship of state are similar: Carter turned off the lights around Washington's statues and shrines. Bush turned off the government itself. 
 But Carter was an aberration to the system, an outsider who believed he should make his Presidential decisions in the best interests of the nation, never minding what Washington's insiders might say. He thought the public would applaud him and re-elect him. He did it his way and lost his bid for re-election.
Bush is the classic insider, despite what he says on TV and on the campaign trail: the son of a U.S. senator, a Congressman himself and then chairman of the Republican National Committee; Ambassador to the United Nations, director of the C.I.A. and Vice President for eight years. People ask where Bush is really from -- Connecticut, Maine or Texas? The answer is none of the above. George Bush is from Washington, D.C.
The truth is that Washington relies on a system of reward-or-punishment. Carter understood this, but refused to abide by it. Bush should understand it better than anyone. He is the latest victim, at least temporarily, of this system.
Liberal Democrats believed Carter was one of them, so they rewarded him with their support. When they found out that he wasn't as liberal as they wanted, they punished him by withdrawing support, which became a factor in his defeat in 1980.
Bush rewarded conservative Republicans by saying what they longed to hear: "No new taxes," a pledge he didn't have to make because he was going to beat Michael Dukakis anyhow. But he gave them that reward.
Now that he has had to break his promise, which was his fate from the moment he made it, the conservatives are punishing him, opposing the deficit reduction package which he endorsed and putting distance between their candidates and the President in this year's campaign.
The similarities are haunting. Both Presidents stumbled over taxes -- Carter when he decided we didn't need a $50 tax rebate for every American because the economy was improving without it; Bush because he made a commitment that he couldn't keep forever. Both Presidents are highly intelligent and astute political analysts, but despite those skills both were seen by voters as vacillators.
Even the White House organizational structure comes into play. Carter didn't have a chief of staff until too late in his Presidency. To a great extent, he was his own political advisor. Bush, with the sharpest political instincts of any President in this century and maybe in any century, has been preoccupied with the Middle East, and so has his chief political adviser, Secretary of State James Baker. Another key advisor, Lee Atwater, has been available only on a limited basis because of illness.
For domestic policy, Carter relied on Hamilton Jordan, who had worked closely with him in Atlanta but who was tagged as an "outsider" by the Washington establishment.
Bush's chief advisor for resolving the budget crisis was his chief of staff, John Sununu, the former Governor of New Hampshire, who has yet to be nominated by anyone in Washington for the "Mr. Congeniality" award. One thing we've learned is that the basic training for running the Federal Government isn't any better in New Hampshire than it is in Georgia.
Ronald Reagan avoided the vacillation charge the obvious way: He was firm and decisive, even when you thought he was wrong. His standing never weakened, and he remained a strong President. Bush now faces Carter's problem -- an Administration whose foreign policy is stuck in the sand of the Middle East and whose domestic program is bogged down in a debate over his policies and his strength or weakness as a leader.
Within the last two weeks, the dreaded term "failed Presidency" has been mentioned in some quarters for the first time in Bush's term. That kind of talk does America no good, because in politics perception has a habit of becoming reality.
A failed Presidency is not what this country needs. What we need instead is for this President to regain control of his foreign and domestic agendas so he will, to paraphrase the Reagan years, be Bush again.

HEADLINE: CUNY Students Have a Role in the Quality of Their Education

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As faculty members deeply concerned about the City University of New York, and as economists, we urge reconsideration of a tuition increase to deal with the massive budget cuts facing the university. The possibility of a tuition increase has apparently been dropped in the face of last year's student protests. We believe this politically easy decision will prove disastrous for the university. 
 The critical issue of quality of education -- which should be of interest to students (and their parents) -- was noticeably absent from the discussions last year, and so was an appreciation of the monetary value to students of a CUNY degree.
Student discontent focused on the proposed $200 a year increase in tuition. CUNY students, however, pay only half the typical tuition charged in comparable universities. Compared with CUNY's $1,250, the average annual tuition last year among a sample of public universities in urban industrialized areas was $2,475. For example, Rutgers charges $2,576, and the tuition at private universities, of course, far exceeds these amounts.
CUNY's tuition, moreover, is a small fraction of the earnings students may expect over their working lives because of a CUNY degree. The value of a college degree to the average American student is roughly $400,000. Since students receive so much benefit from a CUNY degree, it is reasonable to expect them to share the costs of their education.
Low-income students, moreover, will be shielded from any increase through tuition assistance. The higher charges will not deny them access to the university. Needy students in private universities in New York State receive considerably more than $1,250 a year in public tuition assistance because of the higher tuitions these institutions charge.
CUNY students have traditionally benefited from excellent employment opportunities on graduation because employers perceive that a CUNY degree implies a level of training comparable to some of the best universities in the country. The quality of a CUNY education has declined substantially as a result of budget cuts in the last two years and will decline further with future cuts. More than half of all classes (now significantly larger) are taught by part-time faculty members, fewer courses are offered, and libraries have been told to stop buying books.
Another consequence of budgetary cuts must be the loss of CUNY's best faculty members, depriving students of intellectual challenge and excitement. CUNY's tradition of providing New York City residents with an outstanding education at a nominal cost could be lost.
CUNY may be expected to share in budget cuts arising from the state's fiscal difficulties. It is reasonable to expect students to share in restoring the high quality of a CUNY education.
MARJORIE HONIG, HYMAN SARDY
New York, Oct. 13, 1990
 
The writers are chairmen of the eco-nomics departments at, respectively, Hunter and Brooklyn Colleges. The letter was also signed by the econom-ics chairmen at Baruch and Queens Colleges and the College of Staten Island.

HEADLINE: Head Injury Claims Too Many Young Lives

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You report that fatal accidents in the United States have decreased as the public has become vigilant (front page, Oct. 7).
 While encouraged that the death rate has fallen by 21 percent, I must point out that an interagency task force from the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke, National Institutes of Health, reported in February 1989 that by conservative estimate, the figure for traumatic brain injuries (assault to the brain) is more than two million a year, with 500,000 severe enough to require hospital admission.
The same report states that traumatic brain injury is the leading killer and cause of disability in children and young adults.
While deaths are down from accidents, which is good news, the need for rehabilitation and appropriate education of people with head injury is greater than ever. As more children and adults with severe-to-profound head injury are saved, the need for community-based care grows. Of those who survive each year, approximately 70,000 to 90,000 endure lifelong debilitating loss of function. An additional 2,000 will exist in a persistent vegetative state.
The loss in happy, fulfilling lives is staggering and sad. The economic costs are staggering, approaching $25 billion a year; one more chilling fact -- child abuse accounts for 64 percent of infant head injuries. At the National Head Injury Foundation, we call this the silent epidemic.
What can be done? Public education and awareness aimed at prevention is the first step. Community and special education programs need to be established in our schools to integrate people with traumatic brain injury into the mainstream. Vocational training, rehabilitation, supported employment and jobs that recognize the training and skills of a survivor of a traumatic head injury are needed, along with appropriate community housing.
 
GEORGE A. ZITNAY
President
National Head Injury Foundation
Washington, Oct. 17, 1990

HEADLINE: How to Make U.N. Ready for the 21st Century

 BODY:
To the Editor:
For far too long have the affairs of the United Nations been confined to the corridors and conference rooms of the elegant building on the East River in New York. Much of humankind has tended to look upon the organization either as a necessary nuisance or as an opportunistic option. The world at large has shown a benign neglect, bordering on callous indifference, to vital issues of organization and management, leaving them largely to the dynamics of diplomacy and the bonhomie of bureaucracy. 
 With the sweep of stateless economic forces, the velocity of technological change, the growing endangerment of earth and enfeebled sovereignty, traditional concepts like security, interdependence and development need to be redefined. The question that needs to be addressed is how far the United Nations is structurally and managerially capable of commensurate response to the looming challenges of the future. The bulk of the work of the United Nations is in the nonsecurity and political fields. While the present Secretary General has shown remarkable dexterity in taking advantage of the end of the cold war in the political and security fields, leadership in fields such as economic development leaves much to be desired.
Any secretary general will give priority to issues of war and peace. The international community has to consider how to insure that effective leadership is provided to other areas. Bereft of any process, selection of a secretary general of integrity and intellect is pretty much now left to good will and Godspeed. The suggestion that the secretary general should have only a single term of seven years bristles with complications, akin to the debate in the United States about the constitutional bar on the President's seeking a third term. Equally flawed is the idea of a troika of three deputy secretaries general. That will only create another level in a heavy hierarchal structure.
What is more important is to define the character of the political culture that permeates the organization and to draw a clear line between top-level political executives and international civil service. Political appointees should serve for no more than four or five years and should be rotated among groups of countries.
No civil servants should be elevated to the cabinet. This would avoid the arbitrariness that governs their
appointment and remove a major element of staff demoralization. There is also need for reform and streamlining in intergovernmental machinery and priority setting to reflect emerging national and global priorities.
 Reform in the United Nations should also include a neglected dimension: how countries are represented and how business is conducted. Given the range and complexity of issues discussed, the practice of staffing missions with diplomats should yield to greater diversity and expertise. The culture of intergovernmental negotiations should shift from resolutioning to reconciliation.
Most of all, it is clear that basic structural and managerial changes cannot come through introspection. Only through the support and scrutiny of the public and the news media can real reform take place.
 
C. B. RAU
New York, Oct. 18, 1990
 
The writer is a senior officer at the United Nations.

HEADLINE: Several Issues in This Week's U.S. Sales

 BODY:
The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week consists of a record supply of Government securities for sale, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. And for the remainder of the week the Treasury will be busy with its quarterly refunding, consisting of three- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds.
There will also be an auction of 161-day cash management bills on the same day the 30-year bond is sold.
By late Friday the three- and 10-year notes were trading on a when-issued basis at prices to yield 7.84 percent and 8.55 percent, respectively. The long-term 30-year bond was offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 8.69 percent. In the bill market, the outstanding three- and six-month bills were bid at 7.09 percent and 7.05 percent, respectively.
New Government agency issues expected this week include a $850 million, two-part sale of callable debentures by the Federal National Mortgage Association. Fannie Mae interest rates will be announced tomorrow for the $400 million in five-year debentures callable in 1993, and for the $450 million of 30-year debentures callable in 1995.
The Student Loan Marketing Association today plans to price $650 million in floating-rate notes due May 9, through various securities dealers. The Sallie Mae notes will be priced at a spread to the bond-equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill, with the interest rates adjusted the day after each weekly Treasury bill auction.

HEADLINE: Auditors Adjust to Desperate Times

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Crazy Price Waterhouse. Its prices are insane!
To win new clients in these toughening economic times, the blue-chip accounting firm is practically giving away auditing services worth as much as $25,000. In one recent case, it even agreed to do an audit free of charge.
These are desperate times for many accounting firms. The spate of acquisitions and mergers over the last decade has shrunk the number of companies to audit, forcing several of the nation's top accounting firms to combine in the last two years. Now, the weakening economy is making it harder for firms to sell tax and consulting services, the added lines that helped many sustain double-digit annual growth over the last several years.
 
Nonrecurring Work
 "Today, as much as half of your work is nonrecurring, so our practice is much more sensitive to the economy than it was 10 years ago," said J. Michael Cook, chairman of Deloitte & Touche, one of the six largest accounting firms. "And when it slows down, we slow down." 
 Offering bargais on audits is only one consequence. Many national accounting firms have also thinned their ranks, and more layoffs are expected. Among other things, it means harder times for New York City, where many firms have their headquarters.
Spicer & Oppenheim, for example, a midsize New York firm, is behind on its rent and appears to be on the verge of breaking up; partners at Deloitte & Touche and Ernst & Young will be taking home less money this year, and Laventhol & Horwath, a midsize firm in Philadelphia, has cut its employees' pay by 10 percent,
Many firms are also naming fewer partners and are hiring fewer college graduates, and some are resorting to unusual money-making tactics. KPMG Peat Marwick, the industry's leader, is even advertising idle conference rooms for rent in New York and Chicago.
This squeeze has some business executives and investors worried that auditors might be tempted to take shortcuts on the job to trim costs. That is particularly ominous today, when business failures are on the rise and audited financial statements serve as added comforts for skittish investors.
 
Recovering Costs
 Competitors and other accounting experts wonder, for instance, how Price Waterhouse will recover its costs on bargain-priced audits of Cowen & Company, Lipper & Company and Kalb Voorhis & Company, three Wall Street clients it secured.
Arthur Andersen, Deloitte & Touche, Richard A. Eisner & Company and Price Waterhouse all wanted the Kalb Voorhis job, worth anywhere from $120,000 to $140,000 a year in audit fees. And all but Price Waterhouse had high-ranking partners with close personal ties to Mark Richard Feller, the senior partner of Kalb Voorhis. But the three-year assignment went to Price Waterhouse.
Though Price partners deny it and Mr. Feller declined to comment, several people in the industry said Price Waterhouse agreed to do the job free of charge for the first year. Even more surprising, they said, was that Kalb is on a calendar-year cycle, meaning that Price will be doing the work during its peak season.
 
Willing to Lose Money
 Accounting firms have increasingly chosen to lose money on audits, hoping to make up the loss by selling a client tax or consulting work later. They may also hope to lower the cost of providing the service by improving the company's own internal controls or record keeping. Or they may see providing free services as a way to win a new client.
Still, giving away one's services may not buy customer loyalty and can backfire, as clients take advantage of what they see as the increasing interchangeability of those who perform their audits.
Kenneth Lipper, the chairman of Lipper & Company, said he gave his business to Price Waterhouse on the condition that the firm guarantee to do the work at the same price for an additional year.
It is not hard to understand why accounting firms that only 10 years ago could haughtily sit back and wait for clients are being humbled now.
"There are fewer businesses being started, fewer takeovers, fewer mergers and more people going out of business," said Richard A. Eisner, the head of the large accounting firm in New York that bears his name. "Plus, when the business community feels a recession, they're reluctant to spend the kind of money on accounting that they did in the past."
 
Little Change in Rules
 At the same time, the two lines of business that were once the heroes of the profession, tax and consulting, are no longer so high and mighty. Tax departments that thrived on the avalanche of takeovers and underwritings in the 1980's have less to do these days between major tax reform bills. The new budget accord is expected to rekindle demand only slightly because it hardly changes the rules on corporate taxes.
Consulting is hurting, too, as companies put off discretionary projects and bargain hard on those jobs they keep going.
The changing economics has hurt even the firms that were once the most prosperous. For the first time in recent memory, for example, several Big Six accounting firms have been slow to publish their annual earnings, suggesting that the news is not glowing. Mr. Cook of Deloitte & Touche, the firm created by a merger last year, said his firm would not release fiscal 1990 results because it would require relying on pre-merger figures that are not comparable -- an unusual reason for an accounting powerhouse with experts who have overcome more challenging hurdles.
 
Some Casualties Expected
 The story in the profession's second tier is grimmer, and some midsize firms are not expected to survive. These firms, like Laventhol & Horwath and Spicer & Oppenheim, are generally unable to attract the large public companies, most of which prefer a Big Six signature on their books. And yet they compete for the smaller clientele with local firms that have much lower overhead.
Of course, not all firms are faltering. Partners at Kenneth Leventhal & Company, a midsize West Coast firm that specializes in troubled real estate investments, are believed to be still outearning their counterparts at larger firms thanks to clients like Donald J. Trump.
And some large firms are doing well: Arthur Andersen & Company S.C., the Swiss-based parent of the American firm, saw its United States revenue grow by 14.5 percent last year, to $2.3 billion. Price Waterhouse earned $258 million last year, up 14.2 percent, on United States revenues of $1.2 billion, up 9 percent. Those earnings provided Price's 935 United States partners with an average income of $276,000 last year.
 
Stories of Lost Jobs
 Far more typical of the slowdown are stories of lost jobs. The big firms named 12.4 percent fewer new partners this year than they did in 1989 and are letting older partners go by the hundreds. Recently, Michael J. Christensen, a 45-year-old partner in Ernst & Young's Milwaukee office who had put in 23 years with the firm, dashed to Chicago expecting a promotion and instead got a pink slip and an earful about the tough times.
"I guess it's like seeing what your clients have been through eventually catching up with your own business," Mr. Christensen said.
The firms are also cutting back campus recruitment efforts. "My hunch is they'll probably be looking at fewer numbers," said Lois Meerdink, the director of placement at the University of Illinois business school.
 
Erosion of Quality?
 But the competitive pressures are of concern not only to accountants. The more auditors are forced to lower their fees, the more some people worry about eroding audit quality.
"Boards want some assurance that audits are done appropriately, and you shouldn't have those kinds of questions going in because you're not paying for it," said Barbara Hackman Franklin, who sits on the audit committees of seven big public companies.
To cope with the difficult times, accounting firms are busy reinventing themselves. Nearly all the leading firms now have sizable practices devoted to bankruptcies and reorganizations, litigation support and environmental services. They are also zealously competing for the millions of dollars in contracts being awarded as part of the Government's savings industry bailout. And they are putting pressure on Washington to require audits of the more than 300 Federal agencies, departments and offices. The profession is also scrambling to open offices in places like the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
 
Inventing New Services
 Another popular strategy is to offer services that clearly pay for themselves. Coopers & Lybrand's "Dr. Claim" team, for instance, will check medical bills for insurers and employers for accuracy; Price Waterhouse is pushing a service to help multinational companies get full use of their foreign-tax credits, and Arthur Andersen will scrutinize companies' state and local tax obligations for possible savings.
"Originally, we went into these businesses because we saw our clients needed help in these areas," Mr. Eisner said of his firm. "Now we realize it's lucky we've gone into these other areas because this is the future of the profession."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Foreign Flavor for Publishing Leadership

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Whatever else the 1990's bring for book publishing, they are already shaping up as the decade of the foreign-born executive. The appointment last week of Harold Evans, a native of Britain, as president and publisher of Random House is only the latest example.
Earlier this year, Alberto Vitale, who was born in Italy and spent part of his childhood in Egypt, became chief executive of Random House Inc. When Harold Miller retired last spring as chief executive at the Houghton Mifflin Company, he was succeeded by Nader F. Darehshori, who was a teacher in his native Iran before joining the Boston publisher. 
 Also at Random House Inc., Fred Jordan, a native of Austria, became publisher of Pantheon Books earlier this year, joining Sonny Mehta, the Indian-born, Cambridge-educated president of Alfred A. Knopf, another Random House division.
 
'Much Greater Understanding'
 "The global publishing village has shrunk in the last few years, and heads of houses now have to have a much greater understanding of different markets and different economies," said Alun Davies, the Welsh-born president of Bantam Doubleday Dell's international division.
The growing international profile of the American trade book industry stems from a heightened realization that foreign markets can yield increased profits -- something educational and scientific publishers have known for years. In fact, some American houses now earn more than 20 percent of their sales and profits overseas, compared with 5 percent about 10 to 15 years ago.
About a half-dozen American houses have sister companies in Britain, Canada, Australia or New Zealand, and are entering into co-publishing arrangements in Japan, Hungary and elsewhere. Buying world rights to books, they can coordinate publishing schedules and even author tours.
It does not require a foreign-born executive to oversee that coordination, of course. But when George Craig, who was born in Scotland, took over at Harper & Row three years ago and forged it into a trans-Atlantic publishing operation with William Collins Sons in Britain, he succeeded because "he came from an environment where publishers have succeeded because they were forced to sell books beyond the British Isles," said William M. Shinker, president of the HarperCollins trade division.
 
Chief Executive at Rizzoli
 The foreign flavor is also apparent at other houses. Gianfranco Monacelli, who was educated in Italy and Paris, is the chief executive of New York-based Rizzoli International Publications and Rizzoli International Bookstores Inc., which are owned by Rizzoli Editore, the Milan-based publishing company.
"I have trouble believing executives are picked for reasons of their passport," said Peter Mayer, the American who is the chief executive of the Penguin Group, based in London. "You pick them for their insight, vision and intelligence. But there is an international component to large-scale trade publishing today, and some of those qualities are inherent in people who have international backgrounds."
Donald S. Lamm, the president of W. W. Norton & Company, said Mr. Evans might have been selected to head the Random House publishing division for reasons in addition to his vision and intelligence.
"Random House may be looking over its shoulder at the relationship between HarperCollins here and in London," Mr. Lamm said, "and saying maybe we ought to firm up the linkage between Random House here and Random Century in London -- to yoke together two parts of the same publishing empire."
Some people who have worked with the foreign-born executives say they are not sure to what extent the executives derive strength from their culture. But Walter Weintz, who was vice president at the Atlantic Monthly Press when Mr. Evans was its editor in chief in 1984, said Mr. Evans's background was an advantage.
 
Journalistic Background
 "He has the kinds of international contacts that few Americans in publishing can approach," Mr. Weintz said, "and because of his journalist background, he would immediately pursue a good book or promising project. That kind of speed is not typical of the way large, stratified companies in this country work."
Similarly, Mr. Mehta is intensely curious about other people and other cultures, and he is skilled in devising ways to sell more books, said Lee Goerner, the publisher of Atheneum, who previously worked at Knopf.
Many Americans are similarly curious. But, Mr. Goerner said, "My hunch is that if you are from outside the predominant culture, you may spend more time studying, to see how it works, and may then go beyond the usual ways of doing things."
 
Importance of World Rights
 Mr. Vitale, who was a Fulbright scholar at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, did not come from a publishing background. Before joining Bantam in 1975, he worked for I.F.I., the Italian company that owns Fiat. But when he became head of Bantam, he expanded its international profile and emphasized the importance of acquiring English-language world rights.
Paul Neuthaler, Mr. Vitale's successor at Bantam Doubleday Dell, said it was natural and reasonable that foreign executives were making an impact in American publishing. "You cannot avoid thinking globally in this business anymore," he said.
