HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
The Painful Reckoning for Australia's Economy

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN

DATELINE: MELBOURNE, Australia

 BODY:
This is a nation famed for its entrepreneurial titans, larger-than-life empire builders like Rupert Murdoch and Alan Bond, and the Government is now turning to its entrepreneurs for help in bailing out faltering state companies and banks.
But the appeal for assistance and the plans to turn some state companies into private enterprises come as many private companies are themselves facing a crisis. 
 Mr. Bond has been forced to resign from his flagship company, the Bond Corporation; Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation is selling on the Australian stock exchange near its three-year low, and the entire economy is confronting fundamental new problems.
 
'You Almost Need Bad Times'
 In response to a financial squeeze affecting many institutions and companies, the Labor Government finally budged in the last two months on the issue of ownership and announced it would privatize significant portions of the nation's utilities and industry.
"You almost need bad times to get changes around here," said Alexander D. Erskine, chief economist for Citicorp Australia Ltd. "If something's not broke, don't fix it. But once the wheels fall off, you need to make changes."
Australia's financial community, with its handful of swashbuckling financiers from Australia's west, is undergoing a painful reckoning. Many economists and politicians blame excessive spending during the go-go years of the 1980's and a looser regulatory environment.
 
Struggling to Stay Alive
 Many corporate giants and smaller companies are struggling to stay alive, searching for foreign buyers and wrestling with their bankers for extra time to repay loans.
Some companies, like Broken Hill Proprietary Ltd., the largest industrial company in the country, are still earning high profits. Some, like Elders IXL Ltd., which makes Foster's beer, have been able to find Japanese partners that paid cash for substantial stakes in the business.
Still, in the 12 months to June, Elders had a loss of $1.09 billion (United States), the second-largest annual loss in the history of corporate Australia. Bond Corporation Holdings, from which Mr. Bond recently resigned, reported the largest loss, of $1.8 billion.
 
Murdoch's Debt: $8 Billion
 Mr. Murdoch, who is now an American citizen, has been able to expand his media business by selling a few assets to raise cash. Nonetheless, in addition to the depressed stock price of the News Corporation, its debt stands at more than $8 billion.
Australia's financial community received another severe blow in early September -- the death of Robert Holmes a Court, a shrewd investor who built an empire from nothing and for a time in the 1980's was Australia's richest man. Mr. Holmes a Court had been working doggedly to rebuild much of an empire that had collapsed after the 1987 stock market crash. His estate is being managed by his wife, Janet.
But others are being forced to unbundle their empires much faster than it took to put them together. Men like Mr. Bond, who built an international network in media, beer and property; Christopher Skase, the head of the Qintex Group, which tried unsuccessfully last year to take over MGM/UA, and Laurie Connell, who ran the Rothwells merchant bank, are at the forefront of the troubles brought about by the economic squeeze.
 
Expanded Too Quickly
 Analysts say these men borrowed excessively and expanded too quickly, and when interest rates soared and the economy soured, they were unable to meet the rising debt payments and cushion themselves against their falling sales.
"It was a share-asset boom," said Saul Eslake, chief economist at McIntosh Hamson Hoare Govett Ltd. in Melbourne. "The rise of share assets led to paper and property entrepreneurs, rather than creating real wealth."
Wiliam J. Shields, chief economist at Macquarie Bank Ltd. in Sydney, described the underlying problem: "The economy has already hit the wall."
Australia's economy grew 3.3 percent in the 12 months to June 30 of this year, and the Government expects that to slow to 2 percent in the current fiscal year. While the Government maintained a remarkable budget surplus in the last fiscal year, much of that will go to repay its portion of the country's net foreign debt of about $98 billion. Australia also continues to suffer from a widening current-account deficit of $16 billion and an inflation rate of about 7.7 percent.
 
'All a Matter of Risk'
 "There was in 1987 and 1988 a great sense of growth and power, that things could be bought and sold at tremendous values," said Tain P. Tompkins, economic counselor at the United States Embassy in Canberra, the capital. "It's all a matter of risk. If you play with the bull, you may get the horn."
Mr. Bond, a renegade financier whose yacht won the America's Cup in 1983 and who paid about $53 million for van Gogh's painting "The Irises," is in the process of negotiating the sale of his company's breweries to reduce his debts -- a total of more than $4 billion, with substantial portions to foreign banks and bondholders.
On Sept. 26, he resigned as chairman of Bond Holdings, although he still retains a majority of the shares in the Bond Corporation through his private company, Dallhold Investments. After years of aggressively acquiring properties, he has recently had to put some on the block at distress prices.
Kerry Packer, the media billionaire from whom Mr. Bond bought the Channel 9 television network, bought back control of the property for about a fifth of the price. Mr. Packer, who recently suffered a heart attack, is one of the few whose finances have worked out well recently.
 
Government Institutions
 The companies of Mr. Skase and Mr. Connell are facing scrutiny in the wake of their collapses, and even Government institutions are not exempt from difficulties. The Government bailed out the State Bank of Victoria, whose merchant bank arm had accumulated nearly $2 billion in bad debts, and announced its sale to the state's Commonwealth Bank of Australia. But to finance the sale, the Government said it would sell about 30 percent of the Commonwealth Bank to private investors.
The move toward privatization is alarming labor unions, which are worried about the threat to the substantial gains they made during the last few years. Workers' benefits are so hefty that when they take their annual leave they receive not only their full salary, but also a 17 percent bonus to compensate for missed overtime.
The Government has also decided to sell shares in the telecommunications and airlines industries, with the aim of injecting greater competition and efficiency into them.
 
Airlines Privatized
 Australian Airlines will be fully privatized, and Qantas Airlines will sell 49 percent of its equity, with a cap on how much may be sold to foreigners. The Government will also merge its domestic and overseas telecommunications carriers and sell Australian Satellite, or Aussat, to private investors.
While the Government is turning to financial liberalization to help ease its economic difficulties, such measures in the past probably contributed to the problem in some respects. Officials acknowledge that the wave of deregulation, in the mid-1980's, set off a boom in borrowing that is now behind some retrenchment.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Elite Magazines Compete for a Place at Home

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
Home is where the heart is, to be sure. But home may also be where the money is these days, as Americans put away their dancing shoes and come back home again.
At least, that is what publishers of the elite home-design magazines are betting on. These sumptuous publications, which are to home decorating what haute couture is to sewing, include Knapp Communication's Architectural Digest, standard-bearer for the category; Conde Nast's HG, known until two years ago as House & Garden; Hearst's House Beautiful, granddaddy of them all at 94 years old; Meredith's Metropolitan Home, and Hachette's stylish newcomer, Elle Decor. 
 As advertising pages continue to decline while the economy deteriorates and with marginal magazines struggling for their lives, the industry is bracing for a shakeout in categories with too many similar magazines. On the theory that a reader might be hard pressed to differentiate between, say, House Beautiful and HG, these magazines would appear to be prime candidates.
 
Hard Cores of Readers
 But media directors and advertisers think differently. They say that despite similar demographics and the same kinds of lavish layouts, each magazine has an individual appeal and its own hard core of readers.
"Certain ads will draw better in one magazine than another," said Michael Dugan, the president of Henredon Furniture Industries. "House Beautiful seems to have carved out an editorial niche that emphasizes the country look. HG has a more urbane, elegant look. Elle Decor is visually terrific and may have appeal to the younger reader. Met Home has a very clear identity and a lot of reader interaction. Architectural Digest is the best magazine we advertise in."
Nonetheless, the home furnishings market is down and many department stores are feeling the pinch.
Cheryl Smith, media director at William B. Johns & Partners, a New York ad agency, described the home furnishing market as "a little bit flat right now," but said advertisers with the most expensive goods were the least affected by the economic slump.
"If you continue advertising and stay visible, you can gain market share," she said. "Recession or not, you have to remain visible."
Recession or not, the magazines are now edited for readers who are scaling back. They are running more service pieces, more articles on how to refurbish existing interiors instead of redecorating from scratch, more features on less-expensive items.
In the first nine months of the year, advertising pages fell 9 percent in House Beautiful and 8 percent in Metropolitan Home, while Architectural Digest posted a 4 percent increase and HG a stunning 10 percent gain. Elle Decor began publication in March so no comparative figures exist, but its publisher, Polly Perkins, said the nine 1990 issues had a total of 468 advertising pages, well above the projected 350 pages.
The circulation leader is House Beautiful, with 932,377 subscribers last year, followed by Metropolitan Home at 701,015, Architectural Digest at 632,302 and HG at 619,920. Ms. Perkins said Elle Decor's circulation, as yet unaudited, was 200,000.
All five magazines have a lustrous quality about them. With their depictions of perfectly appointed rooms, designer furniture, elegant gardens and oh-so-handsome couples presiding over impeccable preserves, the publications present a world that is more fantasy than reality.
 
Ultimate Voyeur Experience
 Architectural Digest, edited by Paige Rense, is considered to be the dominant magazine. Its critics call it pretentious, but with four-color issues of more than 300 pages each and more than 1,800 ad pages last year, it is the ultimate voyeur experience into the houses of the rich and famous.
"A couple of hundred years from now, if you want to get a sense of how affluent America lived in the latter half of the 20th century, you could do no better than a copy of A.D.," said Thomas P. Losee Jr., the publisher.
Or any of its competitors, for that matter. Nine-year-old Metropolitan Home likes to distance itself from the others with its motto, "Journalism, Not Voyeurism," although it, too, runs its share of glamorous homes.
For instance, one article entitled "Why You Can't Buy a Sofa in America" examined why most good furniture is sold "to the trade only" and must be purchased through decorators. The piece also explained how to read the price code that hangs off sofas. As a result of this article, Metropolitan Home was barred from a major furniture show.
 
Bare-Knuckled Competition
 Although the magazines eye each other warily, there has not been the kind of bare-knuckled competition that occurred in the mid-1980's when Conde Nast brought in Anna Wintour, the British editor, to reposition House & Garden. The result confused readers, alienated advertisers and brought a flood of criticism. Under the editorship of Nancy Novogrod, HG has settled down and is back in favor with advertisers.
House Beautiful, which manages to be both elite and mainstream, probably carries the most consumer articles. Tony Hoyt, its publisher, describes the magazine as "very 203," the area code for Fairfield County, Conn., one of the wealthiest suburbs in the United States.
The industry is watching Elle Decor, the latest entrant. Modeled after the hugely successful French magazine Elle Decoration and riding on the name recognition of its sister Elle, the magazine has succeeded in attracting coveted younger readers.
Whatever their individual drawing cards, the magazines are hoping that the 1990's will be the decade of the home. "There are going to be millions and millions of couch potatoes, and you're going to need lots of couches," says Theodore V. Kruckel, Elle Decor's marketing director.

HEADLINE: American Lawyers in Soviet Thicket

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
At Baker & McKenzie's office just off Pushkin Square, the phones are modern. But as one of the four lawyers there put it, "They're hooked into the Soviet system, so we're at the mercy of that."
The same might be said of the level of commercial law practiced by American firms here. It is sophisticated, especially by Soviet standards, but eventually it must hook up with the Soviet legal system -- and that connection is not easy.
"The Soviets publish their laws sporadically and with great delay, so you hear about drafts through rumor, through the grapevine," said Mark Vecchio, a 31-year-old Columbia Law School graduate who is with the Moscow branch of New York-based Coudert Brothers. "You have to be in touch constantly." Coudert's clients include Estee Lauder.
 
Clarifying the Law
 Paul Melling, a 33-year-old British lawyer who has headed Chicago-based Baker & McKenzie's office here since it opened last year, says he keeps up with legal changes "mostly through friends who are Soviet lawyers and through reasonably good contacts with the ministries." He also reads the Soviet newspapers Pravda and Izvestia every day. (Like most of the other lawyers at American firms here, he is fluent in Russian and has an interest in Soviet culture.) 
 Clarifying the law, which, the lawyers say, is especially murky on currency and property deals, is a preoccupation for the dozen-or-so lawyers working for the American firms here: Coudert; Baker & McKenzie; Chadbourne & Park of New York, and Steptoe & Johnson of Washington.
Their latest concern is the country's move toward economic and political decentralization, which produced a jumble of new laws and new domains that sometimes clash. "Our office now spends 30 percent of its time on problems of legality and authority," said Richard Dean of Coudert, who has headed the Moscow office since it opened in January 1988, a year after the passage of the joint-venture law that allowed foreign investment in the Soviet Union if a Soviet partner was involved. Foreigners can now invest here without Soviet partners as a result of a decree issued recently by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
For example, Pepsico, which Baker & McKenzie represents, recently had its two Pizza Hut restaurants in Moscow temporarily closed. A newspaper said the outlets were caught in a crossfire between local authorities.
Space Shortage
Beyond the body of law are other challenges. Office space is cramped, and commercial rents are as high as $75 a square foot, more than twice Manhattan rates. Other challenges include an apartment shortage, a dearth of experienced Soviet lawyers and a recent spate of political and economic crises that could make the most stalwart Western client jumpy.
Perhaps the biggest challenge is learning how to negotiate commercial deals in the Soviet Union. Soviet lawyers are gaining business and international experience, and some have even gone through American Bar Association training classes. But they and their clients have long been isolated from the legal traditions of free-market societies.
"The Soviet side sometimes won't get basic stuff, like calling an entity the same thing throughout the contract; they may say, 'Let's vary it; it's getting boring,' " said Robert Langer, a 30-year-old graduate of Tulane Law School who is the American lawyer at Chadbourne, Hedman, Raabe & Union of Soviet Advocates CCCP -- a joint venture of American, Finnish, Austrian and Soviet lawyers.
Sometimes, to the horror of American lawyers, the Soviets will simply bring a sample contract with blank spaces for names, dates and products and suggest that it be used as the legal basis for a joint venture.
Most Soviet lawyers believe there is a "standard way of doing things, that it's not possible to diverge from that standard without causing yourself difficulties," said Alexander Papachristou, a 32-year-old Harvard Law School graduate at Steptoe's joint-venture firm, Lex International. (U S Sprint and Du Pont are two clients from the American side; Lex, the private law firm on the Soviet side of the venture, brings the Bolshoi Ballet, among others.)
Mr. Papachristou and others say the uncharted commercial climate here often makes them act as business strategists for clients, and in this role they come up against other problems.
 
Lack of Understanding
 Confidentiality, for example. "New Soviet businesses don't understand about trade secrets," said Aleksandr Minakov, Mr. Papachristou's Soviet colleague at Lex International. "When we do joint ventures with them, we have to be sure to put in a non-disclosure clause."
Mr. Papachristou and the others seem happy to be here for a number of reasons beyond business. Many of them have studied Russian and Soviet culture since their college days. Some have Soviet roots; a few have Soviet spouses.
"It's not as lucrative as other areas," Mr. Melling said. "But it's a unique time to be living here. You watch the news every night and realize history is being made."
Mr. Langer said he spends evenings with Soviet friends.
"I don't have ESPN though," he said, referring to the American cable television sports network. "If somebody's addicted to ESPN, they shouldn't come here."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Cuts in Rates Called Vital For Economy

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Credit market analysts say the Federal Reserve will need to be much more aggressive in lowering short-term interest rates to help prevent what looks like the start of a mild recession from turning into a much steeper, more prolonged downturn.
Such aggressiveness would be a significant shift for the Fed, whose chairman, Alan Greenspan, has been extremely cautious in his application of monetary policy. 
 The analysts acknowledge that speedier cuts in interest rates would not be free of risk. Inflation remains a worry, even though prices, particularly in industries that produce goods, are stable or falling. So, too, is the dollar, which could lose even more of its value on foreign exchange markets if rates are pushed down too quickly.
 
Risks Viewed as Minimal
 When measured against what seems to be going on in the economy, however, those risks appear minimal, analysts contend. "There comes a point where economic weakness becomes broad enough and financial difficulties distressing enough where monetary policy has to become more stimulative," said Richard M. Kelly, president of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a primary dealer in government securities. "In my view, we are at that point."
Last week, the Fed indicated that it had lowered its target on the overnight Federal funds rate by one-quarter of a percentage point, to 7 3/4 percent. Analysts said that another quarter-point reduction was very likely after Fed policy makers meet in Washington on Nov. 13. Such a move could be followed by another reduction in December, they added.
The growing sense that a recession has, in fact, begun intensified last week. Important soundings on how the economy fared in October, especially a very weak employment report, suggested spreading weakness. And reports from Detroit, where the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation announced plans to close 21 assembly plants and idle more than 50,000 workers, offered no suggestion that November would bring an improvement.
"When the oil-price shock first hit in August, the economy was stunned, and growth flattened out," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. "But in October the economy started to dive. If the Fed wants to make this a short recession, then they will have to lower interest rates dramatically."
To stimulate activity in devastated sectors of the economy, like construction, a full-percentage-point decline in short-term rates would be needed during the next few months, Mr. Yardeni and other economists said.
 
Disposable Incomes Cited
 In addition, "there has to be positive momentum in consumer disposable incomes, which have been hit hard since gasoline and heating oil prices started to rise," said William Melton, a vice president and chief economist at IDS Financial Services Inc. in Minneapolis.
Exports, which have been growing at about a 2 percent pace so far this year, need to continue to rise, Mr. Melton added. And business inventories have to remain lean. "Even with those four conditions, we are still looking at a two-quarter recession," he said. "If some of those factors either don't materialize or disappear, it could be longer than that."
The heightened sense among credit market participants that a recession has begun should help alleviate some anxiety about the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions this week.
 
Strong Demand Expected
 Since fixed-income investors dote on bad economic news, demand at the auctions should be strong, even though a record $34.25 billion worth of notes and bonds are to be sold from tomorrow through Thursday.
In light of recent declines in Japanese interest rates, demand from Japanese investors at the auctions may be somewhat stronger than earlier in the year, Steven Axilrod, vice chairman of Nikko Securities International, said.
An improvement would be welcome because Japanese investors were huge sellers of Treasury securities in the first half of the year.
Through the first six months, Treasury Department data show that Japanese sold more than $16.7 billion worth of United States Treasury and Government agency debt at an annual rate. Canadian investors were the second-most-active sellers, dropping just over $9 billion worth of Treasury paper at an annual rate in the first half.
 
'Only Game in Town'
 Even if foreign interest does not appear, demand from banks, pension funds and other domestic institutions should be more than sufficient to sell the securities, analysts said.
"We don't need the foreigners so much, because with private credit demand dead in the water, Government borrowing is the only game in town," Mr. Yardeni said.
Aside from the auctions, the week's biggest economic news will probably not appear until Friday, when producer price data for October are expected to be released. After huge increases in August and September, the October figures should provide some welcome news, if only because the large rise in gasoline and oil prices recorded earlier has abated somewhat.
Because of a slowing in the rise of wholesale gasoline prices and an outright drop in producer prices for motor vehicles, the producer price index is expected to show a rise of six-tenths of a percentage point for October, most economists said, well down from the jump of 1.6 percentage points recorded in September.

HEADLINE: AIRPORTS PLANNING FOR BIG WINDFALL

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Airports around the country are laying plans to spend an enormous windfall provided by Congress, which a week ago passed a law to let them charge airline passengers a boarding fee to finance expansion and modernization.
Although many of the projects are years off, they are likely to have a major effect on airline travel in the United States. Improvements at the principal New York area airports could reduce runway delays and clear up congestion inside and outside the terminals. 
 An expansion program at Lambert-St. Louis International Airport envisions a 50 percent increase in the number of gates. And officials at Los Angeles International Airport say the extra money might help soundproof nearby buildings to cut down on noise complaints.
The fees can be as high as $3 every time a passenger boards a plane and no more than $12 on a round trip, depending on connections. That will give big airports tens of millions of dollars annually, far more than is currently made available to them in Federal grants, and will give them more control over the money.
 
Effects May Be Slow
 "This will put a lot of juice into the system, which is good for the whole system," said Jay Franke, Chicago's aviation commissioner. Congestion at O'Hare International Airport often causes delays that ripple throughout the nation's airways.
It will be about a year before the fees begin to show up on passengers' tickets, and considerably longer before the passengers begin to notice improvements in on-time service, terminal congestion and competition among airlines that could result in lower fares.
But a sampling of airports shows that plans for using the funds are already well along, and the sudden availability of the money is improving the chances for projects that have long been on the boards, like the airport under construction in Denver. At some places, local officials say, the fees will help finance new airports or expansions. At others, they may make airports more efficient.
Airport operators nationwide have estimated that they will need to spend $50.5 billion in the next five years to keep up with demand by travelers. About half of it would be spent by the 29 largest airports, which handle two-thirds of all passengers. The new fees will provide only a fraction of that amount, and the costs will continue to fall on the airlines, concessionaires and other airport tenants, who pass the costs along to passengers.
 
More Choice in Spending
 What airport officials like most about the newly approved charges, which had been prohibited by Federal law, is that the main decisions about raising and spending the money will now be made by local officials. The Federal Government, for example, prohibits airports from using Federal grants to pay the interest on bonds, but they will be able to use the boarding fees for such purposes if they choose.
Federal officials, who will retain the right to review the expenditures, said their main concern would be to insure that proposals expand capacity and allow additional competition.
"We are not going to allow Taj Mahals to be built," said Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner, using the airline industry's favorite pejorative for projects the airlines consider extravagant. A proposed central airport terminal at Kennedy was canceled earlier this year at the insistence of airlines, which said they could not afford to pay for it.
Mr. Skinner said airports would not have to rely as much on their airline tenants to approve expansion. "They will be able to build new gates without going to an airline on bended knee," he said. Existing Federal airport grants cannot be used to build gates at terminals, but the new boarding fees can be.
 
A Small Sacrifice
 Airports that adopt the fees have to forfeit half the Federal airport grants that would otherwise be given to them automatically, a relatively small sacrifice compared to the amounts available from boarding fees at busy airports. The Federal government will consequently have more money for smaller airports, which are less likely to impose boarding fees.
Lambert-St. Louis International Airport, for example, has recently proposed a 15-year expansion program costing more than $1 billion that will add at least 39 gates to the 80 now in service, and airport officials said the passenger fees will be a critical source of funds. The expansion will probably put an end to the airport's dominance by a single carrier, Trans World Airlines, meaning that people who live near St. Louis would have a wider choice of flights. Presumably, the competition will also mean lower fares.
David Plavin, director of aviation for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns and operates the three main airports in the New York City area, said that all of the airports presumably will impose the boarding fees.
He said new spending is not likely to increase the numbers of flights in and out of the region but rather to reduce runway delays and ease congestion in and outside terminals.
 
Some Restrictions Apply
 Based on current traffic at John F. Kennedy International Airport, Newark International Airport and La Guardia Airport, the Port Authority could receive more than $110 million a year from passengers boarding at the three places. The money could be spent at any of the airports, but not for other purposes, like bridge construction or harbor development.
Earlier this year, the Port Authority had to abandon the plan to spend $1 billion on a new central terminal at Kennedy because the airlines would not agree to increased fees for the project. Mr. Plavin said it is too early to say whether this project might be revived, or whether the authority might choose to make other investments using the boarding fees. The authority's entire capital spending has been under pressure because of the regional economic slump.
According to Mr. Plavin, the authority's five-year plan calls for investing $5 billion at the airports from 1989 to 1993. A new plan is being prepared for submission to the governors of New York and New Jersey.
 
Plans for Los Angeles
 At Los Angeles International Airport, Executive Director Clif Moore said boarding fees might be used to build a light rail line, or trolley, to connect with passenger lines being built by the surrounding communities.
Asked if the Federal Government would approve of such a scheme, Mr. Skinner said that the nation's transportation policy now encourages mixed uses of funds previously earmarked exclusively for mass transit, highway, aviation and other uses.
Mr. Moore said that over 10 years his airport might receive $650 million in boarding fees. Some of the money, he said, would be used to acquire property surrounding the airport, or to soundproof buildings in the area.
He said that the airport's current runways are more than adequate to cover the existing flow of passengers -- 45 milion people now arrive and depart there annually -- but that additional construction would be needed to provide parking, gates and terminal space for future increases.
In the Chicago area, the new money could help decide between competing proposals to build a third airport, either in Indiana or in Illinois.

HEADLINE: Deficit-Cutting Plan Would Mean $321 Tax Rise for Average Family

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
A new analysis from a research group financed by labor unions says the deficit-reduction bill awaiting President Bush's signature would cost the average family of four $321 a year in additional taxes, with the increases spread almost evenly among the states.
The changes would take an average 0.6 percent of family income, said the report, by Citizens for Tax Justice. Taxpayers in states with the highest incomes would face slightly higher than average increases and those with the lowest average incomes would pay the least in additional taxes, the report said. "Overall," it went on, "the tax hikes are somewhat progressive": they fall most heavily on those most able to pay. 
 The increase would be within a tenth of a percentage point of the national average in every state but Connecticut (0.8 percent) and West Virginia (0.4 percent). The average increase would range from $151 per family in West Virginia to $578 in Connecticut.
 
A Median Increase of $183
 Half the four-member families would see tax increases of less than $183 and half would see increases of more. This median increase differs from the average increase, which is calculated by dividing all new taxes by all taxpaying families.
The bill, which would cut the deficit by nearly $500 billion over the next five years, includes $137 billion in tax increases. There are higher taxes on gasoline, tobacco, alcoholic beverages, airline tickets, telephone service, and expensive cars and other luxuries. In addition, the plan would raise Medicare payroll taxes on people whose wages exceed $51,300 and income taxes on those with incomes generally above the $100,000-a-year range.
Another organization, the one representing state lawmakers, said the deficit-reduction plan would cost the states $16.9 billion over the next five years.
 
'The Easy Way Out'
 "Once again, Congressional and Administration budget negotiators have taken the easy way out by exporting difficult decisions to the states," said the group, the National Conference of State Legislatures, in a statement. "Many states face severe recessionary and no-growth economic conditions. Knowing this, Washington now decides to invade state revenue bases and at the same time tell states they need to find billions of additional dollars."
The biggest portion of the $16.9 billion -- $10.1 billion -- would come from provisions mandating Social Security coverage for all state and local government employees and raising the amount of wages subject to the Medicare tax. Employers, including governments, are to match employee taxes for Social Security and Medicare.
Other costs include $3.6 billion in lost state revenue because of the higher taxes on gasoline, tobacco and alcoholic beverages, and $3.2 billion that the states would have to spend to meet Federal regulations for Medicare and Medicaid services.

HEADLINE: News Drivers: A Tainted, Tenacious Union

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
It was born as a union of horse-and-buggy newspaper deliverymen at the turn of the century, a stepchild of the fledgling labor movement and New York's yellow journalism wars. Its story is not a sentimental tract on human rights, but an often unsavory tale of rough, insular workers struggling for their own interests.
Along the way, the drivers' union -- now locked in a crucial, perhaps lethal, battle with The Daily News -- has mounted strikes and slowdowns and tolerated violence and intimidation to prod and sometimes cripple employers in its fight for wages, benefits and job security for members who bundle and truck most of the region's newspapers and magazines. 
 The union's history is tainted with corruption that sent some of its leaders to jail, with father-son nepotism that kept black and Hispanic drivers out of its ranks for decades, and with unswerving self-interest that has sometimes engendered mistrust by fellow unions and, critics say, may even have speeded the death of some ailing newspapers.
 
Change With the Times
 But, its defenders say, it is also a union that has changed with the times, evolving in an era of big trucks and modern technology, and has struggled hard to improve members' working conditions, to rid itself of racially disciminatory practices and to bring security, prosperity and a decent life to thousands of working people.
"This union has always wanted the same thing: a better life for its people and theirfamilies," said Michael J. Alvino, who was elected president of the union last year. "The union has never had sweetheart contracts. It has always written good contracts to protect our members, and they have a good economic base.
"You won't see them in fancy restaurants or out spending $200 a night. But they care about their families and save their money. I know men who never took a vacation so they could send their kids to college. They believe in sacrifice, and they believe in this union."
It was a dispute between a driver and a foreman that triggered the strike of nine unions against The Daily News on Oct. 25. Drivers, who say The News provoked the walkout, have been accused intimidating newsstand dealers and attacking replace ment workers, and The News has been unable to distribute its usual 1.1 million copies each day.
A portrait of the drivers' union -- the unaffiliated, 3,000-member Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union of New York and Vicinity -- emerged in recent days from an examination of its history and from a series of interviews with Mr. Alvino and other newspaper union leaders, as well as rank-and-file members.
It is a complex picture, often unflattering, of a tough union in a strong union town, of power and struggle over who gets work and how it gets done. It is also a graphic picture of the drivers themselves: a hard-working, blue-collar brotherhood fiercely dedicated to tradition, strict seniority and long-established work rules.
The drivers' union was founded in 1901 by a group of drivers seeking better pay and working conditions in the rough-and-tumble era of yellow journalism in New York, when Joseph Pulitzer's World, William Randolph Hearst's Journal and a dozen other newspapers competed for readers with shrieking headlines and gaudy accounts of sin, sex and violence.
 
Involved in Circulation Wars
 Most of New York's newsapers were then situated on Park Row, and the streets around City Hall resounded with the cries of newshawkers and the clatter of horse-drawn carts hauling the plethora of journals to newsstands, many of which were soapboxes set up on busy corners.
After World War I, as the horse and buggy gave way gradually to motorized trucks, many drivers were quietly enlisted in a shadowy army of thugs assembled to fight the newspaper circulation wars that rocked the city in the 1920's.
On June 26, 1919, The Illustrated Daily News was founded by Joseph Medill Patterson, the co-publisher with Col. Robert R. McCormick of The Chicago Tribune. Max Annenberg, whose family would later become one of the nation's premier names in journalism and diplomacy, was hired as circulation manager for the new paper.
Soon news dealers were being subjected to threats and violence by rival gangs of goons, who demanded that copies of The Illustrated Daily News be put out front to the detriment or exclusion of other papers. By 1924, The Daily News had a circulation of 750,000, the nation's largest, and by 1929 the total was 1.3 million.
 
'Battles Galore'
 "The original Annenbergs were thugs, sent in by The Tribune," said Theodore W. Kheel, a labor lawyer who has long been an adviser to New York's newspaper unions. "They used the drivers' union to intimidate the news dealers.
"There were battles galore. If you didn't put The News up front, you'd have lots of trouble. This is how it was done by the Tribune Company. They are the ones who are now screaming about intimidation of newsstand dealers. They started it all."
During the Depression, when jobs were scarce, the union books were closed to new members to protect the drivers and their families, and the union's rationale of steady work for its own people gave rise to a rule that no one could join unless he was the son of a member. One result was the exclusion of all minorities for decades.
The rule, which allowed outsiders to get union cards only if there were unclaimed openings for sons and then only after a long period of seeking work by "shaping," or appearing at the workplace and taking any extra work that might be available, remained in force until 1947, when the Taft-Hartley Act outlawed many closed-union practices.
 
Forced to Desegregate
 But preference for sons remained common, and a Federal court fight in 1974 finally forced the union to sign a consent decree to desegregate. Though the decree's goal was a 25 percent minority membership, Mr. Alvino said that 31 percent of today's members are black or Hispanic. Nevertheless drivers say that a quarter of the members, including Mr. Alvino, are sons of former members.
Mr. Alvino, who is 54, began selling newspapers from a box on Park Row when he was 11. "My father, Dominick, drove for The World, The World-Telegram, and The Mirror," he recalled. "I got into the union in 1955 by shaping at Rockaway News Supply. I had three brothers. We all shaped to get in the business."
The union has led only two major strikes -- a 17-day walkout in 1942 and another that lasted 19 days in 1958. But it has mounted countless rule-book slowdowns and other job actions, many of them short and often precipitated by what the union saw as management attempts to change work rules illegally.
Among the 10 New York newspaper unions, drivers assumed a pivotal role after 1974 when the printers accepted no-strike, lifetime job guarantees and took a back seat in negotiations. Drivers, with their power to halt deliveries, became the key to publication, and strikes by other unions were made or broken by the drivers' decision to cross or respect picket lines. An 88-day pressmen's strike in 1978 would not have been possible without the support of the drivers.
 
Some Leaders Convicted
 The drivers' union, always fiercely independent, never joined the powerful International Brotherhood of Teamsters and until a few years ago refused even to join the Allied Printing Trades Council, the umbrella group of New York newspaper unions.
In recent decades a dozen leaders of the drivers' union, including Carl Levy, who was president from 1969 to 1976, and Douglas LaChance, the president from 1976 to 1980, were convicted of accepting illegal payoffs to assure labor peace from companies that deliver newspapers.
Opportunities for corruption in the union have always been abundant. A dozen newspapers, 10 independent wholesale distributors and thousands of news dealers are at the mercy of deliveries, and union leaders and drivers have often profited from threats of "losing" bundles or withholding services.
Only about 1,300 drivers, less than a third of the members, deliver major city newspapers -- 400 working at The New York Times, 700 at The News and 200 at The Post. (New York Newsday is delivered by members of the teamsters' union.) Others deliver smaller newspapers or work for a dozen wholesalers, who have contracts to deliver newspapers, magazines and other periodicals.
 
Average Weekly Pay: $875
 According to Mr. Alvino, the average driver today earns about $875 a week, including overtime pay. The scales call for about $800 a week at The Times and The Post and $730 at The News. But many drivers earn much more on long routes that require a great deal of overtime. A few drivers are said to earn up to $100,000 a year.
The ranks of the drivers include a few women, but the union is a virtual male preserve and the work, while well paid, is hard. About 80 percent of those who work for the newspapers drive delivery trucks. The rest work in mail rooms, minding machinery that bundles and labels the stacks of newspapers as they roll off the presses.
To meet night printing and morning delivery schedules, the drivers begin work between 9 P.M. and midnight and work all night. Tasks vary at each of the papers, but a driver usually loads hundreds of 50-pound bundles on his truck and makes several trips of 80 to 120 stops each at news dealers on routes reaching across the city and out to the suburbs.
 
Hard Working Conditions
 Heavy traffic, cold nights, bad weather are the regular companions of drivers, who often work two on a truck. Drivers for The Post collect money from news dealers at each stop daily, while News drivers collect weekly. The Times bills dealers, and the drivers make no collections.
Many say they see their wives and children only in the evening before going to work, or in the early morning before going to bed, or on days off, which are often in midweek and not consecutive.
"They're good men," said Mr. Alvino. "They believe in hot dogs, the American flag and motherhood. It's like this: You drive a truck at 3 A.M. and deliver a couple of hundred bundles to a hundred different dealers. It's raining and the traffic is terrible. You're not going to be soft. The world is not soft. But they're proud of what they do. They love the newspaper business, and they love this union."

incorrectly in some copies to the drivers at Newsday. They are represented by the Graphic Communications International Union, not the Teamsters.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN;
Taxes in Limelight on Eve Of Elections in New Jersey

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EDISON, N.J., Nov. 4

 BODY:
Candidates for the United States Senate crisscrossed the state today as politicians here wondered how, if at all, the public would express its rage over taxes and uneasiness about the future.
Senator Bill Bradley performed the classic rituals of a statewide Democratic candidate today, visiting a Democratic Party breakfast, an apple farm, a flea market and a Hungarian-American dinner on a day when a new poll showed him holding onto a substantial though somewhat narrowed lead. 
 "We won't vote to raise taxes of middle-income taxpayers to cover the loopholes of the oil and gas industries," Mr. Bradley said this morning at a gathering of Middlesex County Democrats, where he blamed President Bush for the delayed budget resolution in Washington this fall.
 
'The Florio Taxes'
 His opponent, Christine Todd Whitman, dashed though some predominantly Republican areas in the northern and middle sections of the state in the hope of bringing Republicans behind her uphill candidacy. Again she challenged Mr. Bradley to give his position on the $2.8 billion in new and increased taxes proposed this year by the state's Democratic Governor, Jim Florio, and passed by the Legislature.
"How can he fail to recognize that what they want to know about is the Florio taxes," Ms. Whitman said in an interview after a Republican dinner in Union, N.J.
Besides the United States Senate race, there will be elections in the state's 14 Congressional districts, four special legislative races, a host of local contests and a bond issue to provide $135 million for housing for middle- and low-income families and the homeless.
Throughout the fall, Republicans have tried to saddle Democrats with the unpopularity of the Governor's tax package, which has sent his approval ratings to near historic lows in the state. The Republicans are looking in particular for victories in a State Senate race along the Jersey Shore and a Congressional contest in Mr. Florio's district across the river from Philadelphia.
 
A Citizens' Group
 In addition, a citizens' group, Hands Across New Jersey, which was formed in reaction to the Florio tax package, has assailed the bond issue, aimed at providing affordable housing.
But attempts by opponents of the tax package to turn the elections Tuesday into a referendum on state taxes are likely to be muddled somewhat by the fact that Mr. Florio is not on the ballot this year and that most other Democrats have distanced themselves from the Governor. Also, Repubicans say, President Bush's agreement to endorse tax rises in Washington has diminished Republicans' abilities to portray themselves as anti-tax candidates.
Ms. Whitman, a 44-year-old former Somerset County Freeholder and former president of the State Board of Public Utilities, has campaigned in favor of open-space preservation, restrictions on the sale of automatic weapons, a cut in the capital gains tax, and campaign finance reform. But most of all she has pressed Mr. Bradley to take a position on state taxes, something he has rejected as irrelevant to a race for Federal office.
Mr. Bradley, 47, who is running for a third term in the Senate, has stressed his support of environmental and education programs, a program to help care for the elderly in their homes and his hopes of cutting the Pentagon budget over the next five years to increase fundis for domestic spending.
 
Bush Vetoes Criticized
 On the stump today, he placed the blame for the budget deadlock on Republican control of the White House. "You always have a Democratic Congress negotiating with a Republican President," Mr. Bradley said after criticizing Mr. Bush's vetoes of parental-leave and civil rights legislation. "The only answer I can see is in 1992; that we have a Democratic President negotiating with a Democratic Congress."
A poll by the Eagleton Institute at Rutgers University, published in The Newark Star-Ledger today, found Mr. Bradley leading Ms. Whitman by 50 percent to 33 percent, with 17 percent undecided. The poll of 1,000 likely voters, conducted between Oct. 27 and 31, showed a gain by Ms. Whitman, who had trailed Mr. Bradley by 36 percent in an Eagleton poll released one week earlier. The earlier poll had also found the public's greatest concerns centered on the economy and taxes. The most recent poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.2 percentage points.
"This poll shows what I have thought all along," Ms. Whitman said during a brief interview, "that I have the momentum."
The one politician who is running in support of the Florio tax increases is Assemblyman Edward H. Salmon, who is running in a special election for the State Senate in the First Legislative District along the southern Jersey Shore. His campaign has received hundreds of thousands of dollars in support from the Democratic State Committee and has advertised on Philadelphia television stations.
Mr. Salmon has tried to explain the increases in state taxes in 8,000 videocassettes distributed by hand to homes in the district. Mr. Salmon is opposed by James Cafiero, a Republican who was appointed to the Senate seat earlier this year.
Incumbents are expected to win re-election 12 Congressional districts, but the races have turned bitter and hard fought for the state's two open Congressional seats.
 
Unexpected Help
 In the First Congressional District, Robert Andrews, a Democrat and former director of the Camden County Board of Freeholders, is running against Daniel Mangini, who has received unexpected help from the Republican National Committee in the hope of gaining a seat in the district where, until last year, Mr. Florio was the Congressman and the area's most popular political figure.
In the 12th Congressional District, the Democrat, Marguerite Chandler, a Somerville businesswoman, and the Republican, State Senator Richard Zimmer of Flemington, are waging a harsh, negative campaign to succeed Representative Jim Courter, who is retiring after a decade in Congress.
A coalition of religious, business and citizen groups has urged public support for the bond issue that would provide grants and loans to middle-, moderate- and low-income families for downpayment and closing costs for their first homes. It would also provide housing aid to the homeless. The measure has been opposed by Hands Across New Jersey, which argues that government would administer the funds poorly.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN;
In Fiery, Debate, Low-Key Cuomo Let His 3 Opponents Slug It Out

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
In one of the most raucous debates in many years, three opponents of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo -- all Republicans -- spent as much or more time attacking each other as they did the Democratic incumbent and heavy favorite in tomorrow's election.
At times, the three became so vitriolic toward each another that Mr. Cuomo sat back, kept unusually silent and enjoyed the acerbic repartee among his opponents. At one point, he recoiled in mock horror as Herbert I. London, the Conservative Party candidate for governor, pointed a finger across Mr. Cuomo at Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican candidate. 
 "I was trying very much not to laugh," the Governor said later in a hallway outside a studio at WNBC. The studio audience of journalists and politicians was not as successful in stifling laughter. The host, Gabe Pressman, was forced at times to be more like a lion tamer than a moderator.
The hourlong debate capsulized what many politicians say the campaign has been -- considerable heat and not too much light. The well-financed incumbent is considered an unassailable favorite. Two of his opponents, Mr. London and Mr. Rinfret, are competing hard for second place and the third, Louis P. Wein, the Right to Life candidate, is looking for third place.
 
'I'm Not Your Dear Friend'

 The tone was illustrated when Mr. Wein, as is the custom of candidates even when they are attacking each other, called Mr. Rinfret "my dear friend." Mr. Rinfret exploded: "I'm not your dear friend. I think this is the third time I've met you. I don't even remember your first name."
Mr. London, using Mr. Rinfret's Board of Elections registration card as a prop, declared that Mr. Rinfret had not voted for the last four years and re-registered as a Republican only after his nomination.
Mr. Wein said that Mr. Rinfret "is not fit for public life." Mr. Rinfret in turn called his Republican-Conservative running mate, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, "a disgrace" and "incompetent" in certifying the current state budget as balanced.
Mr. Rinfret has endorsed the Democratic-Liberal candidate for Comptroller, Carol Bellamy, even though he referred to her as "that idiot woman" a few weeks ago.Mr. London said the Rinfret endorsement proved that he was a liberal like Mr. Cuomo.
 
Lumping Them Together
 A stunned Ms. Bellamy was silent on the endorsement. Her media consultant, Hank Morris, said that "it has to be deciphered by someone with a psychology degree." Maureen R. Connelly, Mr. Regan's media consultant, referred to the endorsement as being "inflicted" on Ms. Bellamy.
During the debate, the three Republican candidates for governor, whom Mr. Cuomo kept lumping together as conservatives, were most in tandem in attacking Mr. Cuomo's handling of state finances.
Mr. London said he state was on the verge of bankruptcy. Mr. Rinfret declared that New York had "the highest per capita taxes" in the country and that the state faced a deficit of up to $2 billion in the fiscal year ending on March 31 and $5 billion in the next year.
Mr. Cuomo, adopting the stance of a professor dealing with unruly and uninformed students, buried them in statistics that they could not disprove. He said that 33 other states were in fiscal trouble, that the state's deficit was less than 2 percent of its budget compared with 18 percent for the United States and that he had no regrets for spending more on education, prisons, mental health and other programs.
 
'The Limit on Taxes'
 He blamed the national recession and the conflict in the Persian Gulf for the state's fiscal problems, but did not mention that the troubles date back at least three years.
Mr. Cuomo promised no more taxes this year but stopped short of a promise for next year. "We think we have come to the limit on taxes in this state," he said.
Mr. London took most of the heat on an abortion question because he had earlier called for criminal sanctions against women who had abortions. He recently acknowledged that his wife, Vicki, had an abortion 13 years ago.
In the debate, he retreated to civil penalties for a woman having an abortion and criminal charges against the person who performed it. Mr. Wein said flatly that "abortion is murder" while Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Rinfret favored women's rights to abortion.
 
A Clear Correlation
 Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Rinfret questioned the legality of any bill that would require parental consent for an abortion. "I hate to say this but I agree with Mario on this," Mr. Rinfret said.
Mr. Cuomo, reacting to a question on a computerized New York Times study that showed a clear correlation between state contractors and Cuomo campaign donors, declined to return any such funds. He questioned whether any other New York politician would follow his lead on limiting campaign contributions. And he noted that they had not done so in releasing income tax returns for several years, or pledging to return to the state part of their salaries, as he has done.
Mr. Rinfret had promised to match Mr. Cuomo's release of eight years of tax returns but has disclosed only the last year's returns.
The candidates, with the exception of Mr. Cuomo, spent so much time attacking one another that the debate covered only three broad topics, the budget, abortion and campaign finances.
The Governor, who has often criticized debates, said at one point: "They're a joke. I've said that over and over and if ever the population needed proof of how stupid they are, listen to this one."
Mr. Rinfret interrupted him to say "Mario set the rules." Later, Mr. Rinfret who objected to the Sunday afternoon timing of the event said that it was "the ultimate insult to the intelligent people of New York."

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Chemical Industry Faces Oversupply

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
CHEMICAL manufacturers illustrate a troublesome shortcoming of free markets. For three years, they have been expanding operations, even as they worried that their new plants would produce much more than anyone wanted to buy. And, as these plants come on line, their fears are coming true. Chemicals used in the manufacture of hundreds of household items are once again in oversupply.
That hurts. Consumers might soon get a price break on things like drugs, soap, paint and plastic zipper bags, but profits are down at companies like Dow Chemical, Union Carbide and Monsanto, and some new plants are not being opened on schedule. Dow, for example, had planned to open a huge ethylene plant in Freeport, Tex., in 1992 but will wait until 1993. By then, Dow hopes, the demand for ethylene might again exceed the supply. 
 The chemical industry is not alone in going through cycles of abundance and shortage. Similar cycles also afflict steel, paper and other bulk commodities -- and many are entering an oversupply phase today. But chemicals seem to get hit the hardest, perhaps because the industry is so huge and so basic to the rest of manufacturing.
Half a decade might pass before the demand for chemicals catches up again with the supply. This time around, the weakness in the American economy will almost certainly prolong the process. But the main problem is not the economy; it is that alternating periods of too little production capacity and then too much come in cycles that no one seems to be able to control.
Peter Spitz, chairman of Chem Systems, an industry consulting firm, explains why. "Imagine it is 1988," he said. "Demand is rising, chemicalplants are operating at full capacity and people are making lots of money. You are a chief executive of a chemical company and you say, 'My God, someone has to build another plant, and it is very profitable.'
"So you announce a new plant, and one new one is probably okay. But your competitor says, 'I'm not going to let him get ahead of me and steal market share.' So he announces a new plant. And then a third announces. And if you put all these guys in a room, they seem like a crazy industry. But each one has a rationale."
The emerging oversupply, as new plants come on line in the early 1990's, is greatest at the petrochemical end of the industry. Such basic materials as ethylene and propylene are made in huge quantities and then used to produce specialty chemicals like drugs, fertilizers or plastics. Petrochemicals get hit the hardest because the manufacturing process requires high-output plants to keep down production costs.
The new Dow plant in Texas, for example, will produce 1.5 billion pounds of ethylene a year, a quantity equal to nearly 4 percent of current ethylene consumption in the United States, which is 39 billion pounds a year. Put another way, the Dow plant, if it were operating today, would produce enough ethylene to cover, by itself, the 3 percent growth in ethylene sales nationwide that is expected this year. And Freeport is not the only new ethylene plant. Some nine billion pounds of production are being added over the next five years, said John Lillich, Dow's director of investor relations.
The chemical industry also indulged in rapid expansion in the 1970's, resulting in a huge oversupply through much of the 1980's. Operations were closed wholesale and some companies, like Monsanto, switched from commodity petrochemicals to production of specialty items, like fertilizers and synthetic fibers.
By all accounts, the 1980's crisis frightened the chemical industry, and in the current expansion cycle many efforts are being made to keep growth under control. While Dow and other companies have delayed plant openings, Amoco Petroleum, Oxy Petrochemicals and others have simply canceled plans to build plants. "There was an element of poker playing in the plant announcements," said Peter Coombes, editor of Chemical Week. "They frightened each other into not building."
But subduing the chemical industry's expansion cycle might not be easy. Sales are still sufficient to keep plants operating at 80 percent to 90 percent of capacity, well ahead of the nightmare levels of the early 1980's. Big chunks of this production are exported, however, thanks to the weak dollar. And new plants opening in East Asia, Latin America and Europe might soon shrink exports.
The Mideast crisis has also thrown a monkey wrench into the industry. Many petrochemicals are made from petroleum and rising oil prices are forcing the industry to seek price increases for their chemicals -- not an easy task in a weak economy and a period of oversupply.
Perhaps more frustrating, petrochemical exports from Kuwait, particularly naphtha going to Japan, have been cut off. So the Japanese are shopping in the United States, competing with Monsanto, for example, for the naphtha that Monsanto buys to make synthetic fibers.
The upshot is temporary shortages and rising naphtha prices, just when new supplies should be bringing down the price, said R. G. Potter, president of Monsanto Chemical. "Basically, the Mideast crisis is overwhelming the overcapacity issue," he added.

HEADLINE: Few Buffers To a Slump Are Seen

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The nation's economic slump could be deeper and last longer than previous recessions, some bankers and economists are warning, because many of the conditions that normally soften a recession or lead to a recovery will be lacking this time.
For one thing, they say, the nation's banks are so weakened by rising losses on loans, particularly for commercial real estate, that they will be less able to make the new loans the economy needs to pull out of a recession. 
 The end of the real estate boom of the 1980's, which many blame for the onset of the slump, may also delay a recovery. A glut of unfilled buildings on the market in many areas is expected to put off for several years the kind of revival in the construction industry that usually helps turn the economy around.
 
A Recession 'Not Like Others'
 "Because of the excesses in the real estate market and the horrendously weakened financial system, this recession is not like others," said Lawrence Chimerine, senior adviser to Data Resources Inc., an economic advisory firm in Brookline, Mass. "It does not look like a mild or brief downturn."
What is more, the increase in Government spending that normally occurs in recessions will not come if Congress and the President adhere to plans to reduce the Federal budget deficit from the $220 billion for the fiscal year that just ended. The economy would thus be deprived of a stimulus that usually reduces the severity of downturns.
 
Pointing to the Signs
 Certainly, some economists do not see a recession ahead, but many others have concluded that one is inevitable, if it has not already begun. They point to the loss of more than 292,000 jobs in the last four months and steep declines in construction activity and consumer confidence. The increase in fuel prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait is the latest blow to an economy that was already suffering from cuts in bank lending, they say.
The nation's banks, having rapidly increased commercial real estate loans in the last half of the 1980's, are hurting from defaults by developers of the unfilled hotels, shopping centers and office buildings that dot skylines from Boston to Los Angeles.
With as much as 20 percent of the commercial real estate loans of some banks in or near default, bankers are cutting lending for construction and curtailing other kinds of loans to conserve the capital they have available to absorb future losses. Bank profits, which must grow if banks are to increase their lending, fell 34 percent in 1989 from 1988, and have fallen 21 percent in the first half of 1990 from a year earlier.
If the slowdown becomes a recession, as is widely predicted, history shows that loan losses at banks could double from pre-recession levels. Much of the increase could come from the $515 billion in bank loans to businesses, which now account for about a quarter of all bank lending but half of all delinquent loans.
 
Rise in Delinquent Loans
 Bank loans to highly indebted companies, often issued to help finance corporate takeovers, grew rapidly in the late 1980's and are beginning to show rising losses. According to Oppenheimer & Company, a New York securities firm, about 5.8 percent of such loans held by 13 large banks were delinquent or in serious trouble as of June 30, up from 3.2 percent at the end of 1989. Analysts warn that losses on such loans could rise substantially if falling sales make it harder for companies to repay their loans.
Pension funds, insurance companies and wealthy individuals are feeling the effects of falling real estate prices, and are also looking for ways to conserve cash and cut lending.
Mr. Chimerine of Data Resources said a sharp increase in construction activity, which normally spurs a recovery, may be absent for several years because of the glut of vacant buildings and the unwillingness of banks to make such loans.
 
Warning on Spending
 As the downturn in real estate prices spreads from commercial projects to a growing number of the country's 63 million owner-occupied homes, analysts warn of the risk that consumer spending could drop sharply, worsening the recession. "As home prices fall, I expect to see people spending less because of the loss of wealth they have suffered," said George Salem, a banking analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities.
He said the turnaround in consumer psychology could be especially abrupt in California, where the prices of many homes, which had doubled in four years, have fallen 10 to 20 percent in recent months.
A shock to consumers in California, which accounts for an eighth of the national economy, could make the next recession the most severe since the Depression, he said.
But Robert B. Avery, an assistant professor and specialist in consumer finances at Cornell University, said falling home prices might discourage some people from selling, "but are not likely to have much effect on spending patterns of people who do not sell their home." He noted that consumer spending could be reduced by other factors, like the rising unemployment that often occurs in regions where home prices have weakened.
While bankers have not suffered big losses on mortgages for single-family homes, they expect that losses on delinquent commercial real estate loans will continue to rise. In hard-hit states like Massachusetts and New Jersey, delinquent loans on commercial real estate have increased sevenfold or more since 1986.
"We do not expect the economy to grow rapidly enough to quickly absorb the real estate that is overhanging the market," said Ernest B. Smith, executive vice president at the Philadelphia National Bank.
 
Less Need for Buildings
 Mr. Smith said that unlike real estate problems in the mid-1970's, another time when banks were badly hurt by real estate loans, today's troubles will probably not be eliminated by a sustained rise of inflation. Rising inflation in the late 1970's made it easier for borrowers to pay off debts and encouraged purchases of real estate, which was seen as an investment whose value would keep pace with inflation.
The need for more buildings in the 1990's will be reduced by changing demographics, he said. He cited less growth in the work force now that the postwar baby boom generation has been fully absorbed and women are taking jobs in offices and factories at a slower rate.
"This is not a normal real estate cycle," said Thomas Labrecque, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, a big lender for real estate projects. He said it could take five to seven years to absorb the oversupply of new buildings in some parts of New Jersey and Connecticut.
Potential buyers are more willing to hold out for rock-bottom prices, he noted, because they know that many properties are still awaiting sale by the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency handling the growing number of failed savings and loan institutions.
All told, "with falling home prices, rising unemployment and increases in taxes, the worries of the average family have to be greater than anytime in the post-World War II period," said Mr. Chimerine of Data Resources.
 
Delayed Repercussions of Debt
 For many economists, the burden of debt as the economy weakens is an an opportunity to say "I told you so." Their dire predictions about the danger of excessive borrowing by the Government, businesses and consumers sounded hollow as the long-lived economic expansion defied several earlier forecasts of recession. But as signs of a slump mount, the delayed repercussions of earlier borrowing are becoming clearer.
When borrowing was rising, the economy benefited from the extra purchasing power of businesses and consumers who could spend immediately and take years or decades to repay. But when the pace of new borrowing falls, the economy suffers as less is spent. Even more alarming, when lenders demand repayment instead of renewing loans, money that would have been available for spending is diverted to repaying debts.
Henry Kaufman, who left Salomon Brothers, where he was chief economist, in a disagreement with the firm's decision to participate in the market for high-yield "junk bonds," has warned that the weakness of banks is a serious obstacle to a quick recovery from the recession that he thinks is beginning. "In previous recessions, financial institutions were more vibrant and had the capacity to be aggressive lenders and investors and help the economy recover," he said.
Currently, however, the number of bad loans held by banks "is making them more conservative lenders and investors," along with other institutions like pension funds and insurance companies. The greatest threat to junk bonds and loans made to finance corporate takeovers is still to come, Mr. Kaufman said.
Not all economists are convinced that the cuts in bank lending and problems in real estate markets will lead to a deeper recession than would otherwise be expected.
Anthony J. Vignola, chief economist at Kidder, Peabody & Company, the New York securities firm, said forecasts for a relatively mild recession "are still very viable, because the Federal Reserve has already started easing monetary policy and businesses are better prepared for this downturn because they could see it coming a long time ago."
