HEADLINE: Racial Politics in South's Contests: Hot Wind of Hate or a Last Gasp?

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Like a virus that defies eradication, the politics of race is back in full view in Southern election campaigns.
First came the surprisingly strong Senate bid by the former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke, who is now a State Representative in Louisiana. Since then race has become the focus of Senator Jesse Helms's furious counterattack against his Democratic opponent, Harvey Gantt, in North Carolina, and it has also played a role in the re-election campaign of Alabama's Governor, Guy Hunt, a Republican. 
 In the North Carolina race, Mr. Helms has brought up several issues tied to race, including his allegation that Mr. Gantt favors quotas that would benefit blacks. One Helms advertisement shows the hands of a white person crumbling a rejection letter. "You needed that job," the announcer says. "And you were the best qualified. But they had to give it to a minority because of a racial quota. Is that really fair?"
In Alabama, Mr. Hunt has run commercials showing his opponent with black political figures.
 
Appealing to White Resentment
 Some professors and political experts say that what is happening now is more the last gasp of Old South politics than a broader resurgence. They add that the growing influence of blacks in politics will limit the appeal of explicitly divisive racial politics that depend on a landslide of white votes.
But most experts agree that the slumping economy, white resentment over issues like affirmative action and a sour mood in the electorate are contributing to a revival of racial politics, whose future course remains unclear.
"Voters turn out when they're angry," said Bill Barnard, a historian at the University of Alabama who is an expert on Southern politics. "One of the ways to get them angry in the absence of overriding political and economic issues is to appeal to the underlying cultural and social tensions such as race."
Race cuts various ways, and can be used by black candidates as well. Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington, in his campaign for City Council, has lashed out at his prosecution on drug charges, saying it was being racially motivated.
 
National Implications
 And some experts say the issues playing out in the South, particularly those involving affirmative action and allegations of racial quotas, have national implications.
"I think Duke's issues will play in places like Michigan, Pennsylvania, Ohio, anywhere the economy is in a downturn and people are looking for some relief," said James J. Brady, chairman of the Louisiana Democratic Party. "It's like dangling the dadgum meat before the wolves."
But the most dramatic racial politics have come in the South.
Mr. Duke startled political analysts by getting 44 percent of the vote and almost 60 percent of the white vote in Louisiana in a primary campaign that appealed to white resentment. Mr. Duke's status as a fringe candidate, the unusual withdrawal of the designated Republican candidate from the race and the economic distress in Louisiana raised questions about how much the contest reflected broader issues.
But race has become a major issue in tight re-election campaigns by Mr. Helms, who is seeking a fourth Senate term in North Carolina, and Mr. Hunt, who is running for a second term as Governor in Alabama. Both are conservative Republicans.
Democrats say Mr. Hunt has sent a racial message to arouse his conservative followers in television advertisements. The ads show Mr. Hunt's opponent, Paul Hubbert, with the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Joe Reed, a prominent black education lobbyist and Democratic leader. Republicans say the message is about philosophy, not race.
Mr. Helms has transformed his neck-and-neck battle with Mr. Gantt, who is seeking to become the South's first black Senator since Reconstruction, with a barrage of racially explicit advertisements and campaign speeches. Much of the message differs little from Mr. Duke's campaign theme that blacks are getting preferential treatment at the expense of more qualified whites.
Besides the advertisement accusing Mr. Gantt of favoring racial quotas, Mr. Helms has run an ad attacking Mr. Gantt for capitalizing on his own status as a member of a minority group in the purchase of a television station near Charlotte.
In speeches, he has accented other racial messages, like an accusation that Mr. Gantt is waging his own racial campaign by advertising on black radio stations.
"Everything's a smear campaign" to Mr. Gantt, Mr. Helms told reporters last week. "He just can't take it. Mr. Gantt knows how to dish it out, but he can't take it."
 
Support From G.O.P. Official
 Charles Black, the chief spokesman for the Republican National Committee, denied that Mr. Helms was injecting race into the campaign. He said allegations that Mr. Gantt had improperly profited from the television sale had been a past campaign issue against Mr. Gantt, a former mayor of Charlotte. He said Mr. Helms's contention that Mr. Gantt supported racial quotas by backing the 1990 civil rights bill was a mainstream issue. He noted that President Bush had vetoed the bill, claiming that it would result in racial hiring quotas. Supporters of the bill deny that it would have resulted in quotas and say its purpose was to protect victims of discrimination.
"This was a major issue debated before Congress, with Ted Kennedy leading one side and George Bush leading the other," Mr. Black of the Republican National Committee said.
The tenor of the North Carolina campaign was a topic today on the morning discussion programs.
Ronald H. Brown, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, stepped up his attack on the Republicans over postcards mailed in to predominantly minority Democratic precincts. The cards read, in part, that it is a Federal crime "to knowingly give false information about your name, residence or period of residence to an election official." Democrats assert the mailings were intended to intimidate black voters. Republicans say the mailings were intended to insure that only eligible voters vote.
"What the Republican Party has done is absolutely disgusting," Mr. Brown said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation." "It's a repeat of what they've been doing for the last decade, and that is to try to intimidate the poorest and most vulnerable of voters."
On the NBC News program "Meet the Press," John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, was repeatedly asked whether the White House countenanced Mr. Helms's racial message.
"I think in any campaign a racial message of one kind or another is inappropriate and abhorrent, and I don't think you will find anybody in the Administration supporting any campaign aspect anywhere that has that kind of an overtone," Mr. Sununu said. But the chief of staff said he had not talked to the President about it.
Judge Dickinson Debevoise of Federal District Court in Newark scheduled a hearing for Monday to determine whether the Republican National Committee violated a 1982 court order that bars voter intimidation.
 
Intensity of Racial Tone
 Mr. Helms has often invoked racial issues, like his filibuster against the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. holiday that proved the turning point in his 1984 campaign against then Gov. Jim Hunt.
Still, even many people who have long studied or participated in North Carolina politics say they are stunned by the intensity of the racial tone in Mr. Helms's campaign this year.
"This is the ultimate," said Merle Black, a professor of politics and government at Emory University. "I've never seen it played to this extent by him, and he's been the master of it ever since George Wallace got out of the business."
Al From, director of the Democratic Leadership Council, an organization of elected Democrats trying to move the party more to the political center, said racial appeals had taken on greater appeal to Republicans because their main issues of the past decade, like taxes, crime and anti-Communism, were no longer as potent for the party as before.
"The Republicans have traditionally used social and cultural issues as wedge issues to get the otherwise Democratic working-class and middle-class voters," he said. "As Democrats move to the mainstream, and those issues no longer work for the Republicans, they have to be more blatant about the issue which they really like, which is race."
Mr. Black of the Republican National Committee dismissed Mr. From's comments as "utter nonsense."
"What happens about this time of the election cycle, every time the Democrats think they're going to have a bad year, they start screaming about these red herring type issues," he said.
Others see the appeals by Mr. Helms and Mr. Hunt, both locked in extremely close contests, as efforts to energize their supporters and win back those voters who they fear may stray.
 
'The Politics of Panic'
 "I think it's the politics of panic," said David Sink, a political science professor at the University of Alabama at Birmingham.
Mr. Black of Emory said Mr. Helms's brand of politics did not make enough electoral sense to gain wide currency.
"Politicians know how to count," he said, "and they don't want to start a campaign by throwing away 25 to 30 percent of the voters. You look at Thad Cochran of Mississippi, John Warner, Strom Thurmond -- even Southern Republicans don't play it the way Helms does. He's unique. When he's gone, there won't be anyone to replace him."
Before he was stricken with an inoperable brain tumor, Lee Atwater, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, was criticized for injecting race into the 1988 Presidential campaign, with the use of an advertisement that referred to Willie Horton, a black convicted murderer who raped a white woman while on a weekend furlough through a Massachusetts prison program. But he has also said since then that the party needed to reach out to black voters.
If the political avenues are unclear and the chances of electoral success are uncertain, some officials say, racial politics will probably continue its surge.
"There's a general disquiet about race," said Dave Eisenstadt, a spokesman for the Democratic Leadership Council. "It's the great hidden, unwritten theme about almost all American politics, and I think it's something we'll see for a period of time to come."

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN;
GOVERNORS' RACES, CLOSE AND COSTLY, ARE RICHEST PRIZE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
From New England to California, the fiercest battles of this 1990 election are being fought for governor, as voters pick the men, and perhaps women, who will shape policy on items as diverse as taxes and the political districts that House members will serve for the next decade.
At least a dozen races remain tight in this final weekend before Election Day. Candidates for governor made their final appeals from Liberty City, Miami's impoverished black neighborhood, to Fresno, the booming city amid America's richest agricultural land, the Central Valley of California. 
 The political stakes are so high that, when all the accounts are tallied, more than a quarter of a billion dollars will have been spent in the campaigns for the 36 governors who will be elected this year, said Michelle Davis, executive director of the Republican Governors Association.
 
Crucial Redrawing of Map
 Democrats currently hold 29 governorships to the Republicans' 21.
While the Democrats hope to pick up a few on Tuesday, the real issue is not how many governorships each party will hold but who will win the big states, where the drawing of new political maps could swing 40 seats or more from one party to the other in the House.
Voters will decide whether to turn leadership of two of the nation's three most populous states, California and Texas, over to women.
In California, politicians and poll takers report that Dianne Feinstein, the Democratic candidate, is losing ground to her Republican opponent, Senator Pete Wilson.
But in Texas, the Democrat, Ann Richards, was said to be closing in on Clayton Williams, a businessman who has spent $8 million of his own money in the campaign. Mr. Williams got tangled in yet another controversy on Friday night, this time over his admission that he had paid no Federal income tax in 1986 when the state's economy was in a slump.
 
Tight Races in New England
 In New England, the slumping economy and voter rebellion is dominating elections. The Democratic Governors of Connecticut, Massachusetts and Vermont chose not even to run again, triggering competitive contests in each state. The situation in Massachusetts is especially surprising since the state in overwhelmingly Democratic; both the Democratic candidate, John R. Silber, and the Republican, William F. Weld, are running against the current Governor, Michael S. Dukakis.
The Republican Governor of a fourth New England state, Edward D. DiPrete of Rhode Island, seems headed for defeat, and the Governor of Maine, John R. McKernan Jr., also a Republican, is in a tough fight against former Democratic Governor, Representative Joseph E. Brennan.
Across the country the issues of taxes, the environment, crime and drugs are shaping these elections, although each election has its own local flavor. Abortion is important in races in some places, like Florida and Oregon.
Both national parties and their political allies are pouring personnel, money and advice into the states. Governmentally, this intense interest reflects the general increase in influence of governors after a decade of authority -- and financial burdens -- shifting from Washington to the states.
"What's interesting is how much more relevant a governor is today versus 1980," said Mark Gearan, director of the Democratic Governors Association. "Right or wrong, Reagan won in terms of federalism. There's so much responsibity being dumped back on the states."
 
A Republican Redoubt
 But the fierceness of these fights is also driven by the fact that governors will play a central role in drawing the nation's political district map after reapportionment next year.
With most state legislatures controlled by Democrats, and likely to remain so after Tuesday, Republicans in particular see the governor's office in many states as their last redoubt in the battle to keep Democrats from drawing Congressional districts that will help maintain their control of the House of Representatives through the 1990's. Democrats have controlled the House since 1955.
That is why much of the attention and money is being focused on states that will be gaining Congressional seats -- California, Florida and Texas -- as well as some that will be losing them -- Illinois, Ohio and Massachusetts.
Beyond the big states, spirited contests are under way in smaller states, including Alabama, Kansas, Maine, Minnesota, Nebraska and Oregon
 
Worries About Turnout
 Republicans on this final weekend were particularly worried about turning out their supporters. While governors' races are in general less affected than Senate and House races by news from Washington, Republicans fear that anger at President Bush this year will discourage Republican voters, who usually include the youngest and least motivated, while firing up some elements of the Democratic Party's base, the elderly and minority members.
Turnout could be an important factor in several races, notably Florida, a state that has increasingly leaned Republican in recent years. Despite that trend, however, Gov. Bob Martinez, a Republican, is in an uphill fight against former Senator Lawton Chiles.
Mr. Martinez, who stressed his support of the death penalty in his final television spots, campaigned along Florida's West Coast this weekend. Mr. Chiles campaigned in Liberty City, the scene of racial disturbances in 1989, and promised voters to "give the governor's office a little color when we get there."
Anger against "business as usual" politics is also a powerful force in several races beyond Florida.
In four races, campaigns that broke away from the established parties may determine who sits in the governor's chair.
In two of these, Connecticut and Alaska, Republicans running as independents could win the governorship outright.
In Oregon, the independent campaign of an abortion opponent, Al Mobley, appears to be siphoning enough support from the Republican, David Frohnmayer, to provide the margin of victory for the Democrat, Barbara Roberts. Both Ms. Roberts and Mr. Frohnmayer support legal access to abortion.
And in Illinois, black politicians in Cook County have broken from the Democratic fold, organized the Harold Washington Party and fielded candidates for local offices. They do not have a candidate for governor, but many blacks are angry at the Democratic nominee, Neil F. Hartigan, for refusing to support the late Mr. Washington in his campaigns for Mayor of Chicago.
Losing even a small part of the black vote in Chicago, the Democratic Party's base in statewide elections, could cost Mr. Hartigan the election against Jim Edgar, the Republican.
The importance of redistricting in these governors' races was illustrated by the situation in California, whose Congressional delegation alone could swing by a dozen seats depending on whether Ms. Feinstein is elected and Democrats thus control the redistricting process again or Senator Wilson wins and gives Republicans a seat at the table.
California's current Congressional delegation, with 27 Democrats and 18 Republicans, is the byproduct of one of the most legendary political map-makings, in which a Democratic Governor and State Legislature in 1981 painstakingly drew lines across bridges, over rivers and down freeways to create as many districts as possible that would elect Democrats.

HEADLINE: SCIENTISTS URGING GAS EMISSION CUTS

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Nov. 4

 BODY:
A group of scientists considered experts on world climate called Saturday on all nations to take immediate steps to control global warming, regardless of the many questions that still exist about man-made climate change.
The scientists, at the Second World Climate Conference here, completed their report late Saturday and made it public today. They said in a statement that the technology already exists to make substantial cuts in the emission of harmful gases without jeopardizing economic growth. The cuts and changes they are pressing for are far more drastic than any government is now considering. 
 But the unexpectedly strong statement, a consensus reached by more than 700 scientists and environmental specialists, appears to emphasize differences with the Bush Administration, which has problems with the view that governments should lose no time and set immediate targets for cutting back carbon dioxide.
 
The U.S. Position
 The statement is also expected to leave the United States further isolated diplomatically this week when more than 100 environmental ministers will conclude the conference.
In recent days, most wealthy nations, including the 12 countries of the European Community, have set targets for slowing carbon dioxide coming from cars, homes and factories, and some countries have even pledged to cut back on today's emissions.
The Bush Administration holds that it is still too early to decide how the United States, which is responsible for 24 percent of the world's carbon dioxide emissions, should reduce them, suggesting that to do so risks enormous costs and unduly curtailing its economic growth.
While the United States is not the only country that feels uneasy about assessing how man is tampering with the enormously complex system that makes up the world climate, it is almost the only industrialized nation that opposes committing itself to cutbacks in the present.
This week large oil producers, including the Soviet Union, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, have rallied to the American side. Experts said these nations believe they will lose if the world suddenly starts burning less oil, the main source of carbon dioxide.
 
'Between Science and Policy'
 Scientists involved in drafting the strong 13-page conference statement said the document would serve as the framework for future discussions and would be hard for policymakers to ignore. It carries the stamp of the World Meteorological Organization and the world's Oceanographic Commission and a number of United Nations bodies who sponsored the conference. It was unusual because it was the first official call for political action coming from such a large group of climate scientists, among them a number of Americans.
"We are at an interesting edge between science and policy now," said Maurice la Riviere, a professor of environmental biology and the head of the International Council of Scientific Unions. "We hope governments and policymakers will understand what scientists mean. Where we go from here is up to them, but given what we know, there is absolutely no excuse for governments not to save on energy."
The digression from science to politics in the six-day technical conference also made some scientists and specialists uneasy.
"There is a leap here from science to policy that is not comfortable for some people," said Michael Glantz, a social scientists at the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo.
 
Change at an Unseen Pace
 Harmuth Grassl, a German professor of meteorology, said that while "as scientists we are basically here as ruminants, it is very important to get out the main message: That change on earth is now so fast there is no analogy during the last 10,000 years."
For its scientific substance, the conference statement drew heavily on the report released last May by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, which is now considered the most important assessment so far of knowledge available on climate change.
The new report issued here today included these points:
*Notwithstanding scientific and economic uncertainties, all countries should take immediate steps to reduce greenhouse gases and find more ways to absorb excess gases already in the atmosphere.
*Without such actions, global warming will increase between 2 and 5 degrees centigrade over the next century, a rate of change unprecedented in the last 10,000 years.
*This warming could lead to a sea level rise between 35 and 65 centimeters in the next century. Although the range is large, it is prudent to take precautions.
*It is now technically feasible and cost-effective to reduce carbon dioxide emissions in all countries. There are enough opportunities for many industrialized countries to cut carbon dioxide by at least 20 percent by the year 2005 if they use energy more efficiently, employ alternative fuels and plant more forests to absorb carbon.
Scientists also said to understand climate it was vital to expand global observation systems and above all establish a network to study the world's oceans. Scientists say the workings of the ocean, the main regulator of the world climate, are poorly understood.

HEADLINE: The 1990 CAMPAIGN;
Whoever Wins, Weicker Race Means Change in Connecticut

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s bid to become Connecticut's first independent governor since the Civil War has fused the anti-incumbent rage that appears in many states with the purely local appeal of a curmudgeon-like politician who seems to have been enraged for years.
Mr. Weicker's critics call it egoistic bluster. But few deny that his third-party candidacy, whether it succeeds or not on Tuesday, will almost certainly change politics in a state where a strong two-party system has been the rule for decades. 
 Even before this race, Mr. Weicker, a three-term Republican United States Senator who was defeated for re-election in 1988 by a Democrat, Joseph I. Lieberman, had forged a larger-than-life reputation as a Senate maverick who would battle any and all who opposed him, including his own party.
But in this year's contest, which has been set against a backdrop of badly decaying cities, a huge state budget deficit and an economy jolted by worse news almost every week about jobs and layoffs, Mr. Weicker has gone head to head for the first time against the party machines that ran Connecticut during his 18 years in the Senate.
The Democratic nominee, Representative Bruce A. Morrison, and the Republican, Representative John G. Rowland, have argued that Mr. Weicker could not rule effectively without a political party organization to help him build a coalition of support in Connecticut's General Assembly.
 
A Health-Care Plan
 Mr. Morrison, in trying to attract traditional working- and middle-class Democrats, has promised to begin a universal health-care system to cover every state resident, and to stimulate business lending by having the state act as a sort of banking partner.
Mr. Rowland has pledged to slash state spending and avoid tax increases next year at all costs. He has also threatened state employees with layoffs unless their unions agree to renegotiate contracts and to have workers pay for part of their health insurance.
Mr. Weicker, the only candidate with a theme song, has said he would infuse state government with nonpoliticians, including academics and business people, and has dismissed the attacks about his lack of a party. It is the two-party system, he argues, that has made the state's problems worse.
Voters are plainly confused.
"Morrison is much too liberal, Rowland is much too conservative and Weicker is basically a windbag," said John Gesmonde, a lawyer in North Branford. But Mr. Gesmonde, a registered Republican, said he believed that Mr. Weicker was also the closest thing to a moderate in the race. On that belief, he intends to vote for Mr. Weicker's independent Connecticut Party.
 
Undecided Voters
 Although Mr. Weicker has led in every independent opinion poll since he entered the race in March, as many as 30 percent or more of the residents questioned last week by various polling organizations are still undecided. In a three-way race in which the winner is not expected to get more than 40 percent of the vote, analysts in all three campaigns said that huge block of undecided voters would probably determine the election.
Poll takers say -- and most Democratic and Republican party officials concede the point -- that even if Mr. Weicker loses, he will probably not finish with any less than 20 percent of the vote. Under state law, that would give Connecticut a third "major party" with all attendant rights and privileges, including a guaranteed ballot position for Connecticut Party candidates in every local and state election until at least the next gubernatorial race in 1994.
The next question is who could lose badly as a result of the rise of what is known as A Connecticut Party. Many Democrats are expressing fears that their party, which has dominated state government for most of the last half century but has trailed badly in almost every poll in this campaign, could be crushed.
In a poll released today by The Hartford Courant, Mr. Morrison was favored by only 10 percent of the 729 respondents who said they were registered and certain to vote, compared with 34 percent for Mr. Weicker, 23 percent for Mr. Rowland, and 34 percent undecided. The poll, made from Oct. 31 through Nov. 2, had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
Under the state's party regulation laws, a finish of under 20 percent for Mr. Morrison would make Connecticut's largest political party a "minor party." Such a loss would humble the powerful machine built by Gov. William A. O'Neill and his predecessors to the point where new Democratic candidates would have to submit petitions to get their names on the ballot until at least 1994.
"From an image standpoint, it would be catastrophic," said Jonathan Pelto, the political director for the state's Democratic Party. "It would mean that Connecticut is still a two-party state, but that Democrats just aren't one of them."
 
Compounding the Threat
 What has compounded the threat to the Democrats is what Mr. Morrison calls "strategic voting" driven by poll results and the oddities of the three-way contest. The idea behind strategic voting is that unlike an ordinary two-way race, a vote for Candidate A could inadvertently elect Candidate C by taking votes away from Candidate B, who might win.
Mr. Weicker's campaign has that logic. His supporters began calling registered Democrats last week, for instance, telling them that since Mr. Morrison cannot win, voting for him anyway increases the odds of electing Mr. Rowland, a conservative two-term Congressman from Waterbury.
Mr. Weicker, a liberal Republican who depended on Democratic votes in his Senate races, has also gone head to head against Mr. Rowland in a series of recent television commercials that ignore Mr. Morrison, thus furthering the public perception that it is a two-man race.
A spokeswoman for Mr. Weicker, Avice A. Meehan, said today that the telephone calls to Democrats urging them to abandon Mr. Morrison were not being made at the direction of the campaign, although she said she agreed with the message.
In an appeal on Friday for the undecided vote, Mr. Morrison said he believed the "cynical appeal that is involved in telling people not to vote for the person they believe would be the best governor" would offend voters, who would return to the Democratic fold on Election Day and fuel a "come from behind" victory.
Both Mr. Rowland and Mr. Morrison are counting on voters like John and Joan Dobbins of Southington. "He's too much of a maverick; he can't be trusted," Mr. Dobbins said of Mr. Weicker.
"He was never true to the Republican Party," Mrs. Dobbins said. "Now he's calling himself an independent, and I can't believe anything he says."

HEADLINE: Town Hall To Survey A Century In a Decade

BYLINE: By C. GERALD FRASER

 BODY:
Town Hall, a venerable institution devoted to music and the spoken word, is about to begin a 10-year, decade-by-decade look at the arts and social history of 20th-century New York.
The survey, a series titled Century of Change, is to consist of five programs each year, from now through 1999, devoted to the music, art, literature, politics and technology of each decade. If Town Hall has come to be thought of as a place for musical and literary performances, the series' strong component of social issues harks back to the hall's founding. 
 The programs are scheduled for Monday and Tuesday nights, starting tonight with "The First Decade (1900-09): Immigration, Assimilation, Industrialization, Urbanization," a round-table discussion that is to run from 5 to 8 P.M. Tomorrow night at 8, a concert titled "From Ragtime to Broadway," a sampling of early musicals, is scheduled. "Projecting an Era," featuring screenings of rare early films, is to be presented next Monday at 8 P.M.; "Chamber Music at the Crossroads," a program of music by American composers, is scheduled for Nov. 13 at 8 P.M. The final event planned for this year's series is "Literary Images of an Age," an evening of dramatic readings, on Nov. 19 at 8 P.M.
 
Comparing Turning Points
 The series was conceived by Laura Kaminsky, Town Hall's artistic director. Ms. Kaminsky says she finds striking parallels between New York's past and present. "When you look at the turn-of-the-century New York life, one of the first images that comes to mind is the boats coming in at Ellis Island," she said the other day. "Clearly, that's a critical turning point in American history."
Now, she continued, "in the last decade of the 20th century we are again faced with this huge influx of immigration.
"Different populations from different parts of the world, but there are many comparable issues. A changing work force, issues of language and education -- issues that were so critical 90 years ago are critical again. At that point America was moving into the machine age; this time it's moving into the computer age. What impact does that have on the economy and the shape of life?"
These and other questions will be grist for members of tonight's panel: Ruth Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President; Jack Salzman, of the Center for American Studies at Columbia University; Kenneth Jackson and James Shenton, historians, and John Kuo Wei Tchen, an associate director of the Queens College Asian/ American Center and a co-founder of the Chinatown History Project.
 
Musings Before an Election
 Ms. Kaminsky, a native New Yorker and a composer who joined Town Hall in February 1989, said she viewed the opening program as "really relevant to today's life."
"It is the night before Election Day," she said, "so I think people are very much thinking about the quality of life, the diversity of New York's population and how to make this city work."
Tuesday night's ragtime program, she said, "looks back at history with a new perspective and with a much more open eye."
"I wouldn't say that we're rewriting history," she said, "but we're writing some chapters that are not as well known." Ms. Kaminsky said Richard M. Kassel of the Town Hall staff and Earl McIntyre, a composer and arranger, began work on the program at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture.
"They started researching the lost black theater at the turn of the century," she said. "Everybody always says Broadway owes a debt to ragtime and the black vernacular music. But in fact, that old music is not that well known except for Scott Joplin. So they spent a good deal of time trying to find lost or unknown works by Bob Cole, J. Rosamond Johnson and his brother James Weldon Johnson, and others."
The program also features compositions by George M. Cohan, Victor Herbert, Tom Turpin, Bert Williams, Jelly Roll Morton and Joplin. Performing will be Obba Babatunde, Renee Manning, Howard Pinshasik and Jane Seaman, vocalists; Bernie Leighton, piano; Vinnie Johnson, drums; Billy Butler, banjo and guitar, and Mr. McIntyre, tuba and musical direction.
 
The Film Panel
 The film program, next Monday, is to be moderated by Sybil Del Gaudio, a teacher of film studies and production. Panel members are William Everson, a professor of cinema and the author of "American Silent Film"; Charles Musser, a teacher of film studies and a film historian, and the director Joan Micklin Silver. The program includes excerpts from Ms. Silver's "Hester Street," and early films by D. W. Griffith and Edwin S. Porter.
The chamber music evening features D'Anna Fortunato, mezzo-soprano; Alan Feinberg, pianist, and the Orion String Quartet in works by Amy Beach, Edward MacDowell and Charles Ives, among others.
In her prospectus for Century of Change, Ms. Kaminsky recalls Town Hall's history "as the leading public platform for debate and discussion in the City of New York" and as a leading recital hall with superior acoustic qualities. Town Hall has a history that includes talks by Winston Churchill, William Butler Yeats, Eleanor Roosevelt, Richard Nixon and Margaret Sanger, who was arrested on stage for talking about birth control, and has been the scene of performances by Rachmaninoff, Andres Segovia, Pablo Casals, Jan Peerce, Marian Anderson, Richard Tucker, Duke Ellington and Miles Davis.
 
In the Beginning, Suffragists
 Although the doors opened for the first time in 1921, plans for the hall began taking shape in 1894, when the League for Political Education began raising money for a headquarters for lectures and meetings. The league itself was founded by suffragists working to overturn New York State laws barring women from voting.
The literary program that concludes the first series on Nov. 19 is, Ms. Kaminsky said, a fitting finale to the first chapter in Century of Change. The years 1900-09, she said, were the first decade in which "a very powerful American voice in literature" was heard.
"There was an urban population that was being described through novels and there was the expansion of the country out West," she said. "There were authors such as Willa Cather, who was writing about the immigrants, and Theodore Dreiser, who was writing about the vicissitudes of urban life."
This program, directed by Isaiah Sheffer, will include readings from work by L. Frank Baum, Dreiser, Paul Laurence Dunbar, Jack London, Edith Wharton and Owen Wister. The selections will be read by the actors Paul Hecht, Estelle Parsons, John Rubinstein and Hattie Winston.
Ms. Kaminsky said she is already looking ahead to next season and the next decade in Century of Change, the years 1910-19. "We're thinking for the next decade we might mount a production of Scott Joplin's 'Treemonisha,' " she said. "That is clearly much more costly than a solo singer on stage with a piano. The more money I have, the bigger the production I can give. The budget is a floating budget."
The city-owned radio station, WNYC-FM, will record the music and discussion programs for future broadcast.

HEADLINE: With Ebullience Gone, Auctioneers Are Sober About the Coming Sales

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
The ebullient mood that characterized art sales throughout the 1980's and as recently as last spring has vanished from the auction rooms at Sotheby's and Christie's in New York. Now auctioneers, art dealers and collectors are taking a sober view of the two-week round of sales of postwar, modern and Impressionist art that begins tomorrow night at Sotheby's. 
 The forecast of how well these sales will do is decidedly mixed, although the expectation is that major works by van Gogh, Renoir, Modigliani, Matisse, Willem de Kooning and Robert Rauschenberg will probably sell for the prices estimated by the auction houses, and the more moderately priced artworks may fare less well. Art specialists at Sotheby's and Christie's say that they have scaled back estimates to May 1989 levels, after which prices soared, particularly in the contemporary market. However, a number of art dealers are saying some of the estimates are still too high.
"There is a total lack of electricity in the air," said Allan Stone, a contemporary art dealer in Manhattan. "I haven't gotten a single phone call about the artworks in these postwar art sales. I think it may be tough sledding. The market was flat last spring and it's pretty flat now. The outstanding works in the auctions should do pretty well. But I don't know if the market will absorb all these paintings at $180,000, $200,000 and $250,000. The downturn may be the healthiest thing that could happen to the art market. It will let the air out of the bag and we'll come down to earth again."
David J. Nash, who heads fine art sales at Sotheby's, said the slowdown in the economy in the United States had affected sales of postwar art more than those of Impressionist and modern art. "Contemporary art, by and large, is predominantly an American market," he said. "The demand for Impressionist and modern paintings is more international."
Mr. Nash said he was urging sellers "to be as realistic as possible."
"There have been several warning signals that the market had become less euphoric than it was 12 months ago," he continued. "We have taken these signals into account in giving estimates and tried not to increase the price levels at which works are estimated to be sold. In some cases, these levels represent no increase from 1988."
In spite of the downturn seen in sales over the last six months, the chairman of Christie's International, Lord Carrington, found reason for some optimism about the coming auctions. In an interview last week in New York, he said Christie's sales in New York in September and October were well ahead of a year ago, up more than 35 percent, due in part to sales of items other than art. Quality artworks that are fresh on the market will probably do well, he said.
 
Not as Much Jam
 "The bread and butter are there," Lord Carrington said. "It's the jam we don't know about yet. The jam for Sotheby's and ourselves comes with the Impressionist and contemporary sales. We are not going to starve, but the jam may not be laid on so thick."
At Sotheby's, the larger of the two auction houses, the total for sales in September and October is "significantly down" compared with a year ago, said Diana Phillips, a spokeswoman. She said that "we have had no equivalent this season" of two sales in October 1989 that totaled $184 million.
 At both houses contemporary art sales have been sharply off, with the totals between half and two-thirds of the low estimate. At auctions of modern and Impressionist art, the totals have been close to or within the auction houses' estimates.
 
From Garbo and Ford
 The most important sales in the next two weeks are of Impressionist and modern art and include the collections of Greta Garbo and Henry Ford 2d, both of which are to be auctioned next week at Sotheby's. Miss Garbo's paintings, part of a collection valued at more than $20 million, include three Renoirs -- a portrait of the artist's nephew Edmund, "Gabrielle and Coco Reading" and an intimate study of a woman whispering to a man, "Secret." The Garbo art is to be auctioned on Nov. 13; her French antiques go under the hammer on Nov. 15.
The Henry Ford property -- 35 artworks from his estate and one painting from the Ford family collection -- is to be auctioned next Monday in a sale that is expected to bring $66 million to $85 million. The most important work is Renoir's "Cup of Chocolate" from 1878, a painting Renoir refused to sell for 20 years. Mr. Ford's father, Edsel, bought the work in 1937. Henry Ford's children -- Edsel, Charlotte Ford Downe and Anne Ford Scarborough -- are the sellers of the painting, which Sotheby's estimates will bring $15 million to $18 million.
Among the Ford paintings being sold by his estate is an 1880's Cezanne landscape, "Le Jas de Bouffan," showing property owned by the artist's father. Bought at auction in New York in 1966 for $350,000, it is now estimated to bring $7 million to $9 million. The Ford Modigliani, a 1918 portrait of the American artist Morgan Russell, was auctioned in 1965 in London for $88,000. Sotheby's presale estimate is $8 million to $10 million.
 
2 by van Gogh
 On Nov. 14, Christie's is selling two works by Vincent van Gogh: a drawing of a garden, valued at $5 million to $7 million, and a major still life, "Vase With Daisies and Poppies" from 1890, estimated to bring $12 million to $16 million. Since 1962, the painting has been exhibited at the Albright-Knox Museum in Buffalo, which will receive 65 percent of the proceeds.
Christie's will also auction three works from the collection of Leonard Yaseen, a New York real-estate executive who died a year ago. The Yaseen art, estimated to bring $9.8 million to $13 million, includes a 1949 "drip" painting by Jackson Pollock, which is to be auctioned on Wednesday night. The two other paintings -- Monet's "Waterlilies" from 1920 and Ernst Ludwig Kirchner's 1912 study of lovers -- are to be auctioned on Nov. 14.
None of the works in these sales are expected to bring prices equal to those realized in May when van Gogh's "Portrait of Dr. Gachet" was sold for $82.5 million at Christie's, and Renoir's "At the Moulin de la Galette" brought $78.1 million at Sotheby's. The total estimate for the art to be auctioned at the two houses in the next two weeks is $508 million to $665 million, with Sotheby's sales expected to bring $274 million to $365 million and Christie's $234 million to $300 million. The May series of sales realized $924.7 million.
 
Criticism of Estimates
 Some art dealers were critical of the auction house estimates in the coming sales, especially those for postwar art.
Leo Castelli, the SoHo art dealer, said: "My feeling is the good paintings will bring high prices. However, I was surprised to see that the estimates in the auctions on many other works are pretty high in view of the fact that everyone has been saying the market for reselling postwar art is rather soft."
Larry Gagosian, a Madison Avenue dealer in postwar art, said, "I think some of the auction estimates are still too high -- particularly in the middle range of the market. The problem may be in the artworks estimated to sell for $100,000 to $1 million. What I am afraid of is, if the sales are poor -- and they may be -- that the press will exaggerate the results."
 
A Last-Minute Review
 Auction house estimates, printed in the catalogues, are based on the reserves -- the minimum prices the auction houses and sellers have agreed they will accept. These are not disclosed. Both houses say most of the reserves are below the low estimate; by law in New York they must be below the high estimate. "On major artworks, the reserves are discussed when we write the contract, but they are never set until just before the sale," said Christopher Burge, president of Christie's in New York. "We always ask for a last-minute meeting to actually fine tune the reserve."
Both Sotheby's and Christie's continue to use guarantees to attract desirable property to their sales, guaranteeing the seller an agreed-upon price whether or not the work sells at the auction. The amount of the guarantee is not disclosed. Sotheby's has guaranteed 81 works, valued in all at $80.8 million to $108.3 million and including all the paintings from the Ford estate. Christie's has guaranteed the three paintings from the Yaseen collection.
Both houses report that requests for reserved seats at the sale are as strong as ever. "It's going to be absolutely packed if they all come," Mr. Burge said. "That could be people coming for the blood bath. Who knows?"

HEADLINE: Review/Dance;
On Rising Above Adversity And Then Tasting Its Fruits

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
The Salon Project got off to a rather dryly cerebral start on Thursday at the Dia Center for the Arts (155 Mercer Street), where the three-program series runs through Nov. 16. Devoted to providing rehearsal space and informal but professional performances to choreographers selected by Susan Osberg and Joan Duddy, curators for the event, the series also got off to a difficult start, though professionalism triumphed, when a dancer in one piece and the choreographer-performer of another were unable to appear at the last moment because of illness.
Neta Pulvermacher's "Cintura," a duet to be danced by Ani Udovicki and Keely Garfield, suddenly became a solo for Ms. Udovicki. Set to haunted music by George Crumb, the solo was a nicely meditative showcase for Ms. Udovicki's fluid, lyrical way of moving. Ms. Osberg's "Soliloquy," substituted for a dance by Sarah Skaggs, had an oddly distanced quality but eventually reached the level of intensity and commitment one might expect from the text, a poem by the choreographer that explored woman's nature. The mysterious score, a sort of cantata for small jungle animals, was composed by Joan La Barbara. 
 Gina Gibney's "Calibrations" was a spare and shadowed ritual for two men that made inventive use of vertical and horizontal stage patterns, clipped semaphoric arm gestures and brusque walks and slow half-falls. It was danced with just the right dry economy by J. Hammons and Doug Johnson.
Brenda Daniels has the longest, most stretched arms and legs in New York dance, as well as a memorably amusing punkish pout. But it would be nice to see her do something more with both features than she did in "Three Dumb Love Songs," a suite of brief solos set to the songs "Only You," "They Can't
Take That Away From Me" and "Our Love Is Here to Stay."
The series, presented on Thursdays and Fridays through Nov. 16, will also feature dance by Santa Aloi, Martha Bowers, Sarah Perron, Theresa Reeves, Pat Cremins, Ms. Garfield, Shelley Lee and Amos Pinhasi.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Object: Survival

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In August of 1989, a terrifying explosion ripped apart the Al Qaqaa munitions plant in Iraq. Sound waves carried the fact of the non-nuclear disaster for hundreds of miles, but news of what had happened remained Saddam Hussein's most closely guarded secret.
 Farzad Bazoft, a journalist for a British publication, disguised himself as a medical technician and went to take a look. He was caught, and despite pleas from civilized capitals (Mr. Bush's White House, in its appeasement mode, remained mute) the too-inquisitive reporter was hanged. 
 That sent a message to obsequious U.S. senators and diplomats that Saddam Hussein sure knew how to deal with the press, but his defiance of civilized norms sent a more significant message to the world's intelligence agencies: the Iraqi dictator would go to any length to protect the secret of Al Qaqaa.
There is reason to believe the secret is this: At Al Qaqaa (pronounced with two choking sounds), a material was being produced called HMX, which stands for "high melting point explosive." This was what was accidentally set off.
Dozens of Iraqi and foreign scientists and munitions technicians paid with their lives to determine this fact: Control of detonation required electronic switches and low-inductance, high-voltage capacitors that Iraq did not yet have.
 After frantic repairs to the damaged munitions plant, Iraq was able to recommence production of HMX, along with another exotic explosive called RDX, which stands for "rapid detonation explosive." But it still lacked the sophisticated triggers calibrated to millionths of a second.
In March of this year, American and British agents seized some of these triggers being smuggled to Iraq via London's Heathrow Airport. It is not known for certain if other shipments of capacitors evaded detection, but that possibility cannot be dismissed.
What the seizure at Customs did confirm was that the technology being sought at Al Qaqaa was closely related to the detonation of HMX and RDX. Why is that information so important? Because it tells the world the purpose of the explosive material and the state of the art in Iraq.
The purpose of high-melting-point and rapid-detonation explosives is to implode on uranium-235. If timed correctly, that then sets off a nuclear explosion.
It is safe to assume (more accurately, it is unsafe not to assume) that the Iraqis already have both the explosive and the triggers to set off U-235. Your next question: Do they have the "yellowcake" to make gaseous uranium hexafluoride that can be fed into centrifuges to separate out the U-235?
Beats me. But ever since writing in this space a couple of months ago that 26 centrifuges were to be the first targets of an air strike on Iraq, I have been asked by a variety of scientists, spooks and snoops how I knew that Iraqi nuclear scientists decided on the difficult implosion-device route to admission to the atomic club. Those queries led to the additional information above.
With a quarter-million U.S. and allied troops massed within striking distance of Saddam Hussein, it seems urgent to task our intelligence resources with this mission: How soon will Iraq be able to detonate a "dirty" nuclear device to decimate our forces?
With his Tammuz 1 missile coming along nicely, with its range of 1,200 miles, how soon will Mr. Hussein have unstoppable nuclear delivery potential throughout the Middle East and (through Mauritania, whose leaders he owns) to Paris and London?
That is the clear and present danger the world faces, and that is the information to determine the timing of the strike to prevent nuclear equalization. Our old-book generals who want to wait until next year until we outnumber Iraqis on the ground are allowing Mr. Hussein the time to develop weaponry to inflict horrendous casualties.
How comfortably our editorialists say "let the sanctions work" for a year or two, as if the scientists at Al Qaqaa were not feverishly racing to complete their work. How complacent some diplomats are that Mr. Hussein could be induced to give up the weapon that would give him effective control of the world.
We are not confronting this aggressor to save the oil flow, or to protect allies, or to reassert our leadership, or even primarily to establish the noble principle of collective security that would have averted World War II.
We are dealing here with our own survival. As soon as Iraq gets the bomb and the missile, millions of American lives are in peril. Those are the stakes. And for all we know, it may be two minutes to midnight.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: How to Make U.N. Ready for the 21st Century;
Add to Security Council

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 In "Bonn and Tokyo as Global Police" (editorial, Oct. 22), you say of Japan and Germany that "it's hard to imagine future collective security and peacekeeping operations without them," and "when will Bonn and Tokyo start carrying their fair share?"
For Germany and Japan to carry their fair share and be fairly and justly represented in security and peacekeeping matters, shouldn't the size of the Security Council of the United Nations be increased from five to seven permanent members so as to include Japan and Germany?
In this respect then, the economic and political power of Germany and Japan would be recognized as more akin to that of the United States, Britain, France, the Soviet Union and China.
 
JACK PERFECT
New York, Oct. 22, 1990

HEADLINE: Golf Ball Specialist

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Up to two years ago, while playing golf, I observed that brand-new golf balls could often be found in the rough just off the fairway" (Steven B. Siepser, letter, Oct. 19). "While playing last spring I noticed that no golf balls were to be found. Why would these same golfers, who once left quantities of balls in the rough, suddenly go into the rough and retrieve those balls? How does this relate to an early recession?" 
 Next to my school is a golf course where I spend as much time as I can during lunch and recess looking for lost golf balls. Usually I find two or three a day. I think Mr. Siepser should think about hiring a sharp-eyed kid like me to help him look for golf balls. Either that or come to Massachusetts, where there still seem to be plenty of lost golf balls around for those who know where to look for them.
 
DAVID HAENDLER
Quincy, Mass,, Oct. 22, 1990
 
The writer, 9 years old, is in the fourth grade at the Charles A. Bernazzani School.

HEADLINE: Kenan Erim, Leading Excavator Of Marble Roman City, Dies at 61

BYLINE: By PETER B. FLINT

 BODY:
Dr. Kenan T. Erim, a noted archeologist and professor of classics at New York University, who for 30 years led excavations of the ancient Roman city of Aphrodisias in southwestern Turkey, died on Friday while visiting the British Embassy in Ankara. He was 61 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.
He died of a heart attack, a family spokesman said. 
 Since 1961, Dr. Erim (pronounced eh-REEM), a native of Turkey, supervised the digging in the all-marble city, which contains a bounty of late Greco-Roman art 100 miles from the Aegean. Aphrodisia had a wealth of marble that was used to build even workers' huts and a two-mile-long city wall, which still stands.
Among the discoveries, Professor Erim wrote in 1972, have been "300 fragments of inscribed stone panels" in the marketplace. The panels list fixed prices, a devalued currency to deter "runaway inflation" and penalties that include death for speculators, who were denounced by Rome as "insatiably greedy men."
 
Hundred of Statues Found
 Highlights of the treasure-trove are a cultural complex with a virtually intact stadium for 40,000 people, a theater seating 10,000, a concert hall, luxurious baths, more than 200 exquisite statues and a great temple that lured pilgrims for the worship of Aphrodite.
Dr. Erim summarized the creative and versatile work by the city's sculptors and other artists, particularly in the first two centuries A.D., in "Aphrodisias: City of Venus Aphrodite," published with many color photographs in 1987 by Facts on File.
R. J. A. Wilson, a lecturer at the University of Dublin, wrote in The New York Times Book Review that Dr. Erim had written not only with passion and devotion, but also "with ease and polish, and with all the thrill of a detective story."
Kenan Tevfik Erim was born in Istanbul on Feb. 13, 1929, and received his early education in Geneva, where his father was a Turkish representative to agencies of the League of Nations.
 
Arrived in U.S. in 1947
 The son came to the United States in 1947, earned a Bachelor of Arts degree and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa at New York University. He earned Master of Arts and Ph.D. degrees at Princeton.
He had been a faculty member at N.Y.U. since 1958 and a professor of classics there since 1971. He was fluent in many languages besides Turkish and English, including French, Italian and German, as well as Latin and Greek, which were among the courses he taught.
His awards included honors from the National Geographic Society, New York City and several countries. In later years Dr. Erim concentrated increasingly on the digging at Aphrodisias and on raising funds for the project, which he termed his "love affair with Aphrodite."
He is survived by a sister, Canan Camogly of London.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Kenan T. Erim (National Geographic Society, 1973)

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
How Ronald Reagan Overcame Doubts and Became President

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

An American Life
The Autobiography
By Ronald Reagan
Illustrated. 748 pages. Simon & Schuster. $24.95.
In the touching early part of his autobiography, former President Ronald Reagan confesses to a lack of self-esteem when he was a boy. "I suppose it isn't unusual for schoolchildren to suffer feelings of inferiority and lack of self-confidence -- I'd be surprised if it wasn't one of the most common afflictions of childhood -- but when it's happening to you, it can seem the biggest thing in the world, and for a while it caused me a lot of heartache." 
 Part of his problem, he writes, was that his family moved so often that it was hard for him to make friends; ever since he has found it difficult "to get close to people." Part of it was that his father, whom from adolescence he called Jack, was an alcoholic, though the young Reagan never stopped loving and respecting him, if only because his mother always stressed that drinking was a disease. And part of it was that he wasn't any good at sports. He was smaller than other boys his age, and he simply couldn't keep his eye on the ball.
Some relief came when his mother urged him to memorize and recite a speech for a dramatic group she was active in. "For a kid suffering childhood pangs of insecurity, the applause was music," he recalls. "I didn't know it then, but, in a way, when I walked off the stage that night, my life had changed." And then one Sunday during a family drive, he idly tried on his mother's eyeglasses: "The next instant, I let out a yelp that almost caused Jack to run off the road. Nobody knew what I was yelling about, but I'd discovered a world I didn't know existed before."
To judge from "An American Life," that was the end of Mr. Reagan's doubt about himself. To hear him defend what many would call the vulnerable points of his Presidency, one might even go so far as to say the glasses (or contact lenses) he wore from that point on were rose-colored ones. He writes, for example, that for him not to have gone to the military cemetery at Bitburg, where 48 SS storm troopers are buried, during his state visit to West Germany in the spring of 1985, would have been the same as West German leaders refusing to go to Arlington National Cemetery while on a visit to the United States.
 He writes that he never traded arms for hostages during the imbroglio that developed into the Iran-contra affair: "None of the arms we'd shipped to Iran had gone to the terrorists who had kidnapped our citizens." As for the economic program contemptuously called Reaganomics (at least, as he writes, until it started working): everything about it was a success except that "the vested interests that hold sway over Congress prevented us from cutting spending nearly as much as I had hoped to, or as the country required."
Of course, this is what Presidential autobiographies are for: to explain away, to justify and to rationalize. Beyond the vulnerable portrait Mr. Reagan offers of his youth, there is nothing very surprising about "An American Life." What one gets is the commonsensical man from Middle America who started out as a Roosevelt Democrat and grew up to hate high taxes, big government and Communism, and whose greatest pride as President was to have started down the road toward nuclear disarmament.
What one also gets is the sort of public-private prose that can sometimes be stultifying. "As the pages of the calendar were turning in 1987, so were the pages of history," a typical passage reads. Even Mr. Reagan's greatest achievement -- his breakthrough to one-on-one diplomacy with the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev -- is ultimately tedious to read about at such length. It may simply be that nuclear-arms diplomacy is too momentous for the scale of a memoir.
 Still, as Presidential memoirs go, this one is not bad, especially when compared with those of other recent Presidents. Mr. Reagan has a distinct and personal voice (thanks in part to the writer Robert Lindsey, who, the author acknowledges, "was with me every step of the way"). His public voice is tempered by well-timed jokes and anecdotes.
He is movingly devoted when he writes about his wife and "best friend," Nancy. ("I just dropped my head and cried," he reports, when he learned that she had breast cancer.) He is touchingly tongue-tied when it comes to explaining his failed marriage to Jane Wyman and his alienation from his daughter Patti Davis. Despite the subtitle of his book, "The Autobiography," he comes across as an unpretentious and likable man.
What is most striking of all is the sense of authenticity that "An American Life" conveys. Somehow, the impression has grown up that the public Ronald Reagan was an amalgam of images, a manufactured presence, a product of the "fellows" who worked for him. But the portrait that emerges here is of a gifted youngster who taught himself to read at the age of 5 and showed an ability to lead people as early as high school.
He learned the art of negotiation when as president of the Screen Actors Guild he went head-to-head with Hollywood's studio heads, who were not exactly shrinking violets, and he learned to fight Communism when he challenged those he believed were trying to subvert well-meaning liberals in the film business (although he slips somewhat by never offering precise evidence of how he "knew from the experience of hand-to-hand combat that America faced no more insidious or evil threat than that of Communism.")
In the end, the reader is denied both the empty figurehead and the two-dimensional opponent of the "evil empire" that Mr. Reagan is sometimes too facilely portrayed as being. The bountiful evidence of the personal command he exerted in the negotiations with Mr. Gorbachev contradicts the former image. The results of those dealings belie the latter.
Like many other Americans, Mr. Reagan worried when he first heard the call of politics that he was "only an actor," as one of his early opponents called him. Later he came to wonder "how you could be President and not be an actor." Despite its longueurs and other deficiencies, what "An American Life" conveys is that Ronald Reagan was both a consummate actor and a man of considerable substance. It was not with mirrors that despite the the Iran-contra scandal, he recovered his prestige and left office the most popular President of modern times.
If this book is any evidence, the American people were not entirely mistaken in admiring him so avidly.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Big Costs Imposed On Drug Makers

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
CHANGES that Congress has voted in the Federal-state Medicaid programs for
 the indigent are expected to cost pharmaceutical manufacturers at least $3.4 billion over five years in rebates on prescription drug prices.
The 1991 budget calls for $1.9 billion in Federal savings on Medicaid drugs and would lead to reductions of $1.5 billion in spending by the states for drugs. 
 Until recently Medicaid programs had to reimburse pharmacies on full list price for most prescription drugs under patent protection -- an estimated $4.7 billion this year. Last spring, however, Merck & Company, the largest pharmaceutical company, began offering price-cutting deals, and some companies followed. The companies hoped to head off restrictions proposed by Senator David Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas, who heads the Committee on Aging, and which were later taken up by White House budget cutters.
But most drug companies did not accept the idea, and the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, a trade group, protested again last week that legislating rebates is "inconsistent with free market principles." Nevertheless, in all-night negotiations of the Senate Finance Committee, the Aging Committee, the House Energy and Commerce Committee and the Office of Management and Budget, the drug makers were hit even harder than the Bush Administration had intended. Congress stiffened the bill, partly to get money for new Medicaid programs for poor children and for elderly and disabled people.
The rebates would start slowly, costing only about $91 million in the first year, but surging to more than $1 billion a year in 1994 and 1995, theCongressional Budget Office estimates.
For makers of brand-name drugs who rebuffed all Medicaid demands for concessions, the law requires rebates of at least 12.5 percent of the average manufacturer's price in the first two years. Those companies that had granted deep discounts to veterans' hospitals and other high-volume customers would have to do the same for Medicaid, with a 25 percent limit at first. In October 1992, the minimum would become 15 percent, and the drug makers would have to give Medicaid the best price that they give to any customer, which in some cases would mean cuts of 40 percent or more.
Charles A. Sanders, chief executive of the American unit of Glaxo Holdings P.L.C., one of the largest drug makers, said some companies might be unfairly penalized. "Companies that have traditionally given discounts to charitable hospitals and the Veterans Administration will now have to pay greater discounts than companies that historically didn't give discounts," he said. He would not discuss Glaxo discounts.
The makers of lower-priced generic drugs, which do not have patent protection and have longmade discount deals with Medicaid, would have to give rebates of at least 10 percent for three years and 11 percent thereafter.
The drug makers would not be allowed to raise prices to Medicaid faster than the rise in the Consumer Price Index. "In the last 10 years, the price of prescription drugs has increased three times as fast as general inflation," Senator Pryor said. "I think this measure was long overdue."
The drug makers did get one concession: the restrictions that kept Medicaid patients in some states from getting the most expensive drugs were eased on the ground that the poor and the elderly should not be limited to "second-class medicine."
In the recent company deals, Medicaid programs had to make room for the excluded drugs. Merck, for example, offered 10 percent cuts if most Merck products were approved. John L. Zabriskie Jr., president of Merck Sharp & Dohme, a Merck unit, said that his company's program, which 38 states have accepted, was intended "to insure that Medicaid patients have the same access to important medicines as the general public."
The budget bill would prevent states from excluding a product outright. But states can still require advance approval for certain drugs.
Congressional aides said existing programs like Merck's would remain in effect until they are due for renewal. Then the companies would have to meet the minimum rebates in the bill, which securities analysts said could slow earnings growth.
Hemant K. Shah, an independent analyst in Warren, N.J., said companies like American Home Products, Eli Lilly, SmithKline Beecham and Upjohn have "above-average business with Medicaid and give above-average discounts to V.A. hospitals." He said that because the manufacturers' costs would not change, the rebates would come out of profits. "The most negative result is that the Federal Government is now directly involved in paying for pharmaceuticals," Mr. Shah said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Has Sharp Decline On Fears About Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply yesterday, reaching record lows against the German mark and the Swiss franc, as traders continued to take a pessimistic view of the United States economy.
Gold prices rose in response to the dollar's decline.
Analysts said no new developments affected the dollar yesterday, but it slid on continuing expectations that the Federal Reserve would be forced to lower interest rates to shore up the economy.
 
 Fall Likely to Continue
<
 Market participants said they expect the dollar's decline to continue. "There's no reason why the trend should not continue," said Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager with the Bank of New York. 
 As long as the economy weakens, traders are expected to shun the dollar. Like all currencies, it is supported by higher interest rates, and the prospect of lower rates weakens the dollar's ability to compete against currencies of nations with higher rates.
The dollar fell to its lowest close against the German mark since the mark was created in 1948, ending at 1.4850 German marks, down from 1.4945 on Friday, its previous low.
The dollar also reached a new closing low against the Swiss franc, ending at 1.2505 francs in New York, down from late Friday's 1.2605. The previous low was 1.2558 francs on Aug. 23.
Against the French currency, the dollar fell below 5 francs, closing in New York at 4.9810 francs, down from 5.0180 on Friday.
The dollar also fell against the Japanese currency and the British pound.
Against the yen, the dollar dropped in New York to 126.55 yen, from 127.78 on Friday. Earlier, in Tokyo trading, the dollar fell to a closing 127.35 Japanese yen, from 129.10 yen at Friday's close. In London, it was quoted at 127.05 yen.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9675, from $1.9515 late Friday. The pound also rose in New York, where it closed at $1.9740, up from Friday's $1.9590.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included 1,116.00 Italian lire, down from 1,123.75, and 1.15875 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16475.
Gold rose $3.10 on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $379.50 an ounce. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $378.65, up $2.40.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $377.25 an ounce, from $376.25 late Friday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $376.30, up from $375.50 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $3.13, closing at $376.93.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
At Coast Savings, Is the Worst Over?

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
COAST SAVINGS FINANCIAL INC., the parent of the nation's 10th-largest savings and loan association, is at a crossroads.
Coast, which has assets of $10.2 billion and 120 branches in California, has been running up big losses for two years. Its capital is badly depleted and barely meets the minimum Federal requirements. Last month it suspended its quarterly dividend of 10 cents a share on common stock. 
 Reflecting the company's troubles, Coast's stock has been in free fall -- from $20 last year to as low as $2 in recent weeks. It closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $2.75, down 25 cents.
Some analysts say Coast will do no better than limp along, suffering further losses, until Government regulators take it over or arrange a merger with a healthier financial institution. Coast's management argues -- and some analysts agree -- that the worst is behind, and that the institution can survive, if not prosper. In either case, the next few quarters will be crucial for Coast and its operating subsidiary, Coast Federal Bank.
"They're walking a tightrope," said Michael Abrahams, an analyst at Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards in Los Angeles.
If Coast is to make a comeback, the first step will be its planned sale of 27 branches in Southern and central California. The 27 have a total of $1.2 billion in deposits, and based on recent prices paid for other institutions' branches, Coast should realize a gain of some $60 million from the transaction, analysts said. Final bids are to be submitted this week. The $60 million would help buttress Coast's capital position just in time to help it meet stricter new Federal regulatory requirements for financial health that go into effect for the savings and loan industry at the beginning of next year.
As it sold branches and deposits, the company would also sell assets, like loans and mortgage-backed securities. The shrinking process would help the company's capital position because the Government's capital standards, in general terms, are calculated as a ratio of capital to size.
But the gain from the branch sale would mean little if the company had further substantial losses. In the third quarter, Coast lost $24.4 million after adding $61 million to its general loan loss reserves -- funds set aside to cover any unexpected losses. In the second quarter, Coast had added $31.5 million to its loss reserves for troubled loans and $16.5 million to its reserves for losses on foreclosed real estate. Through the first three quarters of the year, Coast lost $47.2 million.
The additional reserves were taken as a result of a joint examination by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Office of Thrift Supervision, the primary Federal regulators. It was one of the first major examinations of a savings institution undertaken by the F.D.I.C. since it assumed regulatory responsibility for the savings and loan industry, and it clearly showed that the agency is pushing savings institutions to bring loss reservesup to the higher levels maintained by commercial banks.
Many of Coast's troubled or potentially troubled loans were made in themid-1980's, when it moved aggressively to lend to commercial real estate developers outside California. Now Coast is also facing the incipient downturn in the California economy and troubles in the state's formerly robust real estate markets. During the third quarter, Coast foreclosed on its largest single loan, a $29 million credit on a Long Beach office building.
Some analysts think Coast faces a strong possibility of significant further losses inside and outside California, potentially wiping out its capital or leaving it below Government requirements. "They have no defenses against any further major hits, and they stand a good chance of taking some," said Peter Treadway, an analyst at Smith Barney.
Ray Martin, Coast's chairman and chief executive, said the company believed that its reserves were adequate to protect it from further deterioration of the economy and the real estate market. Coast does not expect to have to make further large additions to its loss reserves, he said, adding that the company expected to be profitable in the fourth quarter.
The company stopped making out-of-state commercial loans several years ago, Mr. Martin said, and now makes only residential loans within California. Like most California savings and loan executives, Mr. Martin said he thought the softening of the real estate market here would never reach the proportions of the downturns in Texas and Arizona.
"We don't think there's going to be any serious real estate problem in California as far as residential loans" are concerned, he said.
Coast will probably shrink to $9 billion to $9.5 billion in assets after the branch sale, Mr. Martin said, then will begin growing again. "We're feeling pretty good about the future," he added.
