HEADLINE: Families of American Troops in Gulf Find Solace in Talking to Each Other

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Nov. 4

 BODY:
As the Bush Administration talked tough about Saddam Hussein last week, families of American troops in the Persian Gulf region wondered if the renewed bellicosity signaled danger for their loved ones, who so far have battled only sand, scorpions and restlessness.
"This feels like 'It,' " said Gaye Jacobson of South San Francisco, whose son Derek is a medic with a Marine mortar unit in Saudi Arabia, near the Kuwaiti border. "Within a month, I think we'll be in a fighting war. The only question in my mind is whether it will it be long-term or short-term, 20,000 lives or 100,000 lives." 
 "I think the President is trying to prepare the American people for an offensive move," said Ms. Jacobson, the founder of a counseling group here for relatives of American troops and hostages in the Middle East. "It's a way for him to recover his popularity. And historically, when the economy suffers, one of the healers is war."
 
'Keep the Pressure On'
 Lee Mulligan of Danville heard something different in the renewed tough talk from Washington: an inducement to the Iraqi leader to negotiate a peaceful end to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and a sign that Mr. Mulligan's son Patrick, a Marine lieutenant, might be rotated home as new troops take his place.
"President Bush should keep the pressure on more strenuously," Mr. Mulligan said. "He let it lie too long because of the budget. But my wife and I have different opinions. Maybe it goes with the personality of the individual. I'm an optimist and I think they're going to talk their way out of this crisis."
Ms. Jacobson and Mr. Mulligan are among several dozen mothers, fathers, spouses and siblings in the San Francisco area who have gathered in this Silicon Valley suburb each Sunday since late summer to share their feelings, exchange letters from the front and offer each other the commiseration that they say does not come from neighbors, colleagues or friends.
Ernie Reyes of San Bruno, whose son Vincent is a Marine lieutenant aboard the Durham, an amphibious cargo ship, said the group is valuable because "we don't know anyone else with a son over there." Mr. Reyes added, "It's hard to have a heavy burden and no one to share it with."
 
A Heavy Agenda
 At meetings of the group, called Operation Yellow Ribbon, the family members digest the latest news, and this week they had a heavy agenda. Since they last met, 11 more Americans had accidentally died. The Pentagon had announced the deployment of up to 100,000 new troops, including reservists, and President Bush had said he would spend Thanksgiving in the Saudi desert. The President had also declared that he has "had it" with the cruel treatment of American hostages in Iraq and Kuwait.
But current events paled before more mundane concerns.
Carmen Reyes, Ernie's wife, was dismayed to realize that the 14 pounds of chocolate chip cookies she sent her son had probably melted in the Saudi heat. Windy Underwood of Fremont was near tears when she said she would reschedule her Dec. 8 wedding to Jesse Spencer, an Army paratrooper, because she doubted he would be back in time.
And Barbara Seith of San Jose asked lots of questions about the supplies carried by the medics in the desert. Would they have the right ointment or pill if her son James, a Marine lance corporal, was stung by the scorpions and spiders that all the boys were writing home about?
Much of the talk was of packages planned or sent.
Cynthia Lewis's son had just returned home because he needed ear surgery, but the Oakland woman was going to send a shipment of dehydrated Japanese noodle soup to the friends he had left behind. Ms. Jacobson's son included additional requests in each letter: Kool-Aid powder and beef jerky, a Walkman and a Frisbee, back issues of Surfer magazine and a six-pack of Coors light beer.
Molly Webb's son had been in the desert with the Army First Cavalry for "three weeks and one day" and had yet to receive the care packages she had sent him. "Wait a month before you get concerned," said Bo Oldham of South San Francisco, whose son Casey is a medic.
 
Complaints About the News
 Many family members complained about the dearth of news from the Middle East in their local newspapers in recent weeks as the Bush Administration and Congress wrestled with the Federal budget. "I was real angry when that Washington stuff was being figured out and there was nothing on the front pages about our boys," said Mary Economy of San Jose, whose son Brian is a Navy gunner's mate.
Ms. Jacobson said she almost fell apart the day she was spinning the television dial looking for news from the gulf and found instead a report that Clark Kent was about to marry Lois Lane. "I became volatile," she said.
The families are also angry by what they describe as indifference from neighbors, friends and co-workers, who remind them that their loved ones enlisted and thus have no ground for dismay that they may be casualties of war.
"People in society seem so callous," said Audrey Tyler, whose brother is an Air Force sergeant in Saudi Arabia. "Even my own boyfriend said, 'Well, he signed up for it.' "
"They don't know how to react to us and so they react coldly," said Teresa Murphy of Fremont, whose father, a teacher, is a hostage in the American Embassy in Kuwait City. "It's not so much that they're hard-hearted, but they don't know what to say."
Ms. Murphy is the only relative of a hostage who attends meetings of Operation Yellow Ribbon, but the military families have welcomed her despite their sometimes conflicting interests. Her presence here makes the group unusual since support groups elsewhere tend to be segregated, like the counselling centers on military bases, reserved for dependents, who are overwhelmingly wives.
Here the group members are mostly mothers and they tell similar stories of children who fared poorly in school and enlisted seeking direction, discipline and career opportunities. Ms. Jacobson's 23-year-old son Derek seems typical, a young man disabled by dyslexia, who struggled to finish the 12th grade and now, inspired by his training as a medic, talks of becoming a doctor.
 
'This Sandbox'
 Derek's letters, five in all, are riddled by misspellings but eloquent nevertheless. He writes of "this sandbox" that is now his home and the flies that are "eating us up like crazy." He hypothesizes that "we or President Bush is waiting for the embargo to work" and says he plans to use his accumulated military pay for a "new car or a computer downpayment."
Before dawn on Saturday, Derek called home for the first time, during a trip to base camp with an injured marine. In an earlier letter, Derek had said he expected to be reassigned to the camp for two months, a comforting prospect to his mother, who thought he would be safer there.
On the phone, Derek said he had turned down the reassignment. "There's heavy rumors we'll be in combat soon," he told his mother. "And mom, if that happens, I want to be with my unit."
Recounting the story at the meeting, Ms. Jacobson brushed back tears and smiled gamely.
"This son of mine went over there not understanding what responsibility was," she said. "All he cared about was surfing. Now I'm hearing a young man who has grown up. Even in view of today's circumstances, I'm glad Derek did what he did."

LENGTH: 904 words

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Up 8.6% in Late October

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks rose 8.6 percent in late October, compared with soft sales in the period last year. But weak consumer confidence and recent moves by the Big Three to cut production suggest problems ahead, analysts said.
Discounts of more than $1,000 on many models helped lift car sales to 229,616 for Oct. 21-31, up 12.1 percent from 204,793 in the period last year. Sales of light trucks remained slow, as manufacturers sold 123,191 pick-ups, mini-vans and four-wheel-drive vehicles, a gain of 2.6 percent from last year. Analysts speculate that the slowdown in light trucks may be related to concern over fuel economy. 
 On a seasonally adjusted basis, cars sold at an annual rate of 7 million in late October, in line with the rate for the year so far, and ahead of the 6.4 million rate set in late October 1989.
For the month, car sales increased 2.7 percent, while sales of light trucks were down 3.1 percent, compared with sluggish demand last year.
Analysts were divided in their interpretations.
 
 Sales 'Perhaps Too Good'
 Contrary to predictions, "sales have not headed south," said Ann Knight of Paine Webber. "That's good for the industry, perhaps too good for the economic climate we're facing."
Some analysts suggested that sales to rental car companies and other large fleets may have inflated the sales of the Big Three. Joel Pitcoff, a market analyst with the Ford Motor Company, said sales of Ford cars to fleets rose several percentage points in October, compared with a year earlier. Ms. Knight said she believed fleet sales at General Motors were unusually high.
"Retail business is softer than fleet business," said Mr. Pitcoff.
Ronald A. Glantz of Dean Witter Securities Inc. in San Francisco, suggested the sales figures looked better than they actually were because of statistical anomalies in the Commerce Department formula used to derive the seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales.
Deep production cuts announced last week by G.M., Ford and Chrysler provided ample evidence that the domestic auto makers are bracing for a drop in sales. In the past week, G.M. has cut 204,000 cars and light trucks from its fourth-quarter assembly schedule, while Ford has trimmed 44,000 and Chrysler 40,000, according to Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry newsletter. The cuts add up to 7.8 percent of the 3.3 million vehicles the Big Three had planned to build in the fourth quarter.
 
 Orders Slow Down
 Dealer orders for new cars and trucks have already slowed down, said James B. Fitzpatrick, a General Motors Corporation vice president. "Looking toward the final two months of 1990, we expect increased competitive pressure," he said.
Prospective car buyers in October reported the lowest level of confidence in the economy since 1981, according to the University of Michigan's long-running Survey of Consumer Sentiment.
"Conventional wisdom seems to be that sooner or later the barrage of bad news since early August is bound to take its toll on the automotive market," said Robert L. Rewey, vice president of sales for Ford's North American automotive operations.
But sales since the Persian Gulf crisis began have exceeded Ford's expectations, Mr. Rewey said.
For the month, the Big Three showed surprising strength in car sales, recording a collective gain of 6.1 percent. The share of the car market claimed by the Big Three rose in October to 63.8 percent, from 61.8 percent last year, with G.M. accounting for most of the increase.
 
 Imports From Japan Fall
 In contrast, imports of cars made in Japan fell 11 percent in October, translating into a decline in market share, to 17 percent of the United States car market, from 19.6 percent last year. But Japanese auto factories in the United States lifted their sales by 36.5 percent during the month, and increased their collective market share to 10.9 percent, from 8.2 percent last year, an even larger gain than that posted by the Big Three.
General Moors sold 96,453 cars in late October, up 5 percent from the period last year.
G.M.'s light truck sales were up 1 percent, to 47,226 units.
 
 Ford Sales Are Up
 Ford reported car sales of 61,799, a 13.4 percent gain. Ford's Escort and Tracer subcompacts continued to gain momentum while, at the luxury end, the Lincoln Town car also attracted buyers.
Ford sold 42,386 light trucks, up 6.5 percent, on strong sales of the four-wheel-drive Explorer.
Chrysler sold 31,435 cars, a gain of 10.1 percent. Chrysler's light trucks fell 8.2 percent, to 26,818.
Honda Motor Company sold 14,882 cars made at its plant in Marysville, Ohio, a decline of 4.6 percent.
Toyota Motor Corporation nearly doubled sales of cars made at its factory in Georgetown, Ky., to 14,970, reflecting added production capacity.
Nissan Motor Company sold 5,472 cars, up 45 percent, and 4,815 light trucks, a gain of 12.4 percent, assembled in Smyrna, Tenn.
 
 Chrysler Adds to Production
 DETROIT, Nov. 5 (Reuters) -- The Chrysler Corporation will introduce a new shift at its St. Louis II plant in Fenton, Mo., to increase production of its mini-vans, the United Auto Workers union said today.
According to a UAW document detailing the union's tentative contract agreement with Chrysler, reached Oct. 30, the additional shift is being added to meet strong demand for the Plymouth Voyager and Dodge Caravan mini-vans.

HEADLINE: Voters to Decide on Bond Act For Environmental Projects

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 5

 BODY:
With New York State virtually out of money to buy land, protect watersheds, promote recycling and initiate other environmental projects, voters must decide on Tuesday whether to authorize large-scale borrowing for such purposes.
Proposal One, the $1.975 billion Environmental Quality Bond Act, would allow the state to issue bonds over the next 10 years to pay for measures that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and top lawmakers say are needed to protect the environment. 
 Despite a flurry of campaigning by Mr. Cuomo and several leaders of environmental groups, proponents of the measure say they are concerned that many people do not understand the bond act and might vote against it. Opponents say the act should be defeated because the state cannot afford to add to its long-term debt; some say that even if money were available, the state should not be buying land with it.
The last environmental bond act, for $1.45 billion, in 1986, passed by a 2-to-1 ratio. Practically all of the $250 million in that measure for land acquisition has been spent, and much of the rest of it was set aside for cleanup of toxic-waste sites.
 
Bond Cost Minimized
 Bond-act votes are never easy to predict. A poll released last week by the nonpartisan Marist Institute of 1,032 registered voters found that 59.7 percent of respondents said they knew nothing about the bond act. Of those who said they were likely to vote on it, 40.2 percent said they would favor it, 14.4 percent said they would oppose it and the rest described themselves as undecided. The poll reported a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.
Perhaps not surprisingly, proponents of the bond act have minimized its cost, pointing out that it would be about $7 a year for each state resident, while opponents have sought to magnify it, saying that with inflation the true price could be close to $4 billion statewide over the 30 years it would take to pay off the bonds.
Many local government leaders have said they desperately need money to help close landfills or start recycling, and many have said they could be forced to raise local property taxes without money from the state. State officials say that because of the state's severe budget problems, if the bond act fails, they will be left with practically no way to finance state purchases of environmentally sensitive land in the Adirondacks, the Catskills and on the Long Island aquifer.
The $1.975 billion would be broken down in this manner:
*Land acquisition, $800 million.
*Water-quality improvements, $174 million..
*Projects like closing landfills and recycling, $525 million.
*Park renovations and historic preservation, $175 million.
*Other rehabilitation projects, $201 million.
*Continuing to develop an esplanade along the Hudson River on Manhattan's West Side, $100 million.
Rejection of the bond act would add from $60 million to $70 million to the state's current budget gap, Cuomo administration officials say, to finance park renovations and other state projects now under way that New York is hoping to pay for with bond act money.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN;
Voters Complain Negative Campaigns Are Driving Them Away

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WAUKEGAN, Ill., Nov. 2

 BODY:
At Aunt Millie's Restaurant, a diner in this industrial city 40 miles north of Chicago, Leonard Davis said political advertising had just about persuaded him to stay home on Election Day.
"There's a lot of mudslinging and they're pulling a lot of skeletons out of the closet to get elected, and it makes me think everybody in office is just out for their own gain," said Mr. Davis, a 42-year-old hospital orderly. 
 He said television commercials had reinforced his decision not to vote for the Republican candidate for the United States Senate, Representative Lynn Martin, because "she voted to give herself a $35,000 raise." But he said he probably would not vote for the incumbent, Senator Paul Simon, either, having learned from advertisements that "he's a crook, too."
 
 A National Pattern
 Mr. Davis's advertising-induced disaffection from politics appears to be part of a pattern that is being detected around the country. According to a new New York Times/CBS News Poll, voters are overwhelmingly aware of televised political advertising, and substantial numbers are saying that campaigns have become more negative than a decade ago.
The findings correspond with a growing distrust in the Federal Government's ability to act on behalf of the public; the trend coincides with the growth of negative campaigning in the 1980's.
The Times/CBS News telephone survey of 1,445 adults nationwide, conducted Oct. 28 to Oct. 31, included 1,137 registered voters and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Sixty-seven percent of the registered voters participating said they remembered political commercials they had seen on television this year; that figure was up from the 58 percent who said they could recall advertisements in a similar poll conducted four years ago. More than 4 registered voters in 10 said they perceived campaigns as more negative than a decade ago, and more than half said most of the advertisements they had seen attacked a candidate.
The negative commercials seem to be working, at least to some degree. Twenty-three percent of registered voters said their votes would be influenced by commercials they had seen -- an "astonishingly high number," said Daniel Yankelovich, a public opinion researcher, who has written widely on Americans' political and social attitudes.
 
 'Tip of the Iceberg'
 "People don't like to admit that commercials help them decide anything," explained Mr. Yankelovich. "They're not conscious of it, and it's not quite socially acceptable. You can be pretty sure that this is just the tip of the iceberg."
Asked in a survey after the 1984 election whether commercials had helped them choose a Presidential candidate, only 11 percent of registered voters said yes. A direct comparison cannot be drawn between a midterm election and a Presidential campaign, in which voters generally pay more attention and see the same commercials nationwide, but Mr. Yankelovich said the increase from 1984 to 1990 "could be a continuation of the trend."
When asked, "How much of the time do you think you can trust the Government in Washington to do what is right?" 73 percent of all respondents said some of the time or never, in the highest proportion indicating such distrust since March 1980, when the Carter Administration was drawing to a close amid economic sluggishness and the Iranian hostage crisis.
At Aunt Millie's, which calls itself "The Home of Real People," half a dozen real people were unanimous in their expressions of distaste for political advertising and candidates.
"Politics is supposed to be dirty, but not this much," said Jose Ospina, who emigrated from Colombia 23 years ago and worked on the assembly line at the Chrysler automobile plant in nearby Kenosha, Wis., before it closed two years ago.
 
 One Was Persuaded
 He said the advertisements by candidates for governor of Illinois -- State Attorney General Neil Hartigan, the Democrat, and Secretary of State Jim Edgar, the Republican -- had persuaded him that most politicians were part of the same corrupt fraternity.
"You have two candidates who worked together for many years, but they never attacked each other before," said Mr. Ospina, 53, of Waukegan. "If they knew three or five years ago about each other, why did they wait until now to say it?"
Most of the people surveyed for The New York Times/CBS News Poll and who were reached for interviews afterward said they trusted the information in such advertisements.
"I still believe in libel laws," said Allan Clarke, a 39-year-old postal clerk in Rochester. "How can they come out and say these things? There has to be some truth to it."
Other respondents who said their votes were influenced by political commercials said the advertisements had helped turn them against the system.
Debbie Meier, a veterinary nurse in Sacramento, Calif., said she had planned to vote for Pete Wilson, the Republican candidate for governor, but changed her mind after seeing advertisements against him by his opponent, Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat.
"I was in favor of Wilson, but her ads made me doubt him," said Ms. Meier, who is 29. "The ads have made me confused. Now, I don't want to vote for either of them."
Mr. Yankelovich, the public opinion researcher, speculated that public trust in the Government could grow once the campaign ends. "If your mood is fearful, and you can't get away from these attacks, then you'll be low and lacking in confidence," he said. "When the attacks stop, there will be certain relief, just through the absence of stimuli."

HEADLINE: Oil Drops More than $2, To $31.96

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Crude oil dropped more than $2 yesterday as traders' fear of normal supplies began to overpower their fear of war.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude for delivery next month closed at $31.96, off $2.04 a barrel, and down more than 9 percent since Thursday. Some traders said oil would fall back into the $20's later this week. Oil has not closed below $30 since mid-September, except for a one-day drop on Oct. 23. 
 Product prices also fell. Unleaded gasoline for December delivery closed at 87.54 cents a gallon, down 1.67 cents, or 70 cents a barrel. And heating oil closed at 84.46 cents a gallon, down 2.96 cents, or $1.24 a barrel.
"The fact that Mr. Baker is in Saudi Arabia and Mr. Bush is scheduled to go later on in the month implies that war is not imminent," said Shahrokh Nikkhah, of Prudential-Bache. This week's visit by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, and the scheduled visit by President Bush do not preclude military action, Mr. Nikkhah said, but the perception was that there would be no war before Thanksgiving.
 
 Attention to Fundamentals
 At Pegasus Econometric Group, Thomas P. Blakeslee, an oil market analyst, said, "The politicians aren't stirring the Middle East cauldron because they're campaigning."
With the threat of war receding from traders' minds, oil experts said the market was paying more attention to the fundamentals, the balance of supply and demand. The Saudi oil minister said over the weekend that his country was producing 8.2 million barrels a day and would reach 8.5 million barrels a day next year.
"People hadn't thought it had gotten that high yet," said Mr. Blakeslee. "The fundamentals are extremely strong, from the consumer's point of view."
World oil production, never something measured with precision, now seems roughly equal to what it was before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and the United Nations imposed a boycott on oil from those countries, which had previously produced more than 4.5 million barrels a day.
Equal production may not mean equal price, however, because of fear of war or other disruption. James A. Gibbs, the president of the American Association of Petroleum Geologists, said yesterday that production was within 2 percent of capacity: "If there is a major fire in the North Sea, a problem in shipping or a problem anywhere, 2 percent is not a very wide margin."
On the other side of the equation -- demand -- the International Energy Agency said yesterday that it expected demand in the fourth quarter to be 54.1 million barrels a day, down from 54.4 million barrels last year. The reason is a combination of resistance to higher prices and an economic slowdown.
 
 'Bunch of Scared Rabbits'
 The agency measures demand outside Communist and formerly Communist countries.
The degree to which oil demand responds in the short term to price changes is the subject of some debate. And Melvin A. Conant, a Washington-based oil consultant, said the demand figures should be regarded with some skepticism because they were based on just 30 days and because counting was still incomplete in some countries.
He added that while prices were up sharply, no third-world countries appeared unable to buy the oil they needed, at least thus far.
The market remains mercurial. Mr. Bentz said it was prone to sudden moves because everyone thinks the same way. Referring to market participants who had bought contracts that promise future delivery at a fixed price, he said, "You're long, you're happy, you're making money, and all of a sudden something comes out in the news or there's a turn in the marekt, and everybody jumps on the bandwagon to get out. Everybody wants to get through the door at the same time and there are these very very violent turns."
"A lot of traders seem like a bunch of scared rabbits," he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Dismisses Envoy Suspected as Spy

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today dismissed Felix S. Bloch, the American diplomat who has been under investigation for almost two years on suspicion of being a Soviet agent but has not been charged because of lack of evidence.
Mr. Bloch was dismissed because of "deliberate false statements or misrepresentations" to the Federal Bureau of Investigation during that inquiry, and because of "his behavior, activities and associations," the department said in a prepared statement. 
 The statement said Mr. Baker had found Mr. Bloch's removal "necessary and advisable in the interest of national security." Mr. Bloch was notified of his dismissal in writing today, the statement said.
Neither Mr. Bloch nor his lawyer, John M. Bray, returned telephone calls seeking their comment.
Mr. Bloch, 55 years old, was a top diplomat at the American Embassy in Vienna from 1981 to 1987, and then moved to the Bureau of European and Canadian Affairs. He worked there until 1989, when nvestigators said they had photographed him in Paris as he gave a briefcase to a man who was later identified as a K.G.B. agent.
 
First Such Case Since '61
 He is the first American diplomat to be disciplined on espionage-related charges since a low-level embassy officer was convicted of passing documents in Warsaw in 1961.
Mr. Bloch has declined to declare his innocence publicly, saying instead that the Government lacks the evidence to charge him with criminal wrongdoing. He has not contested any of the Government actions against him, but has never explained why he did not do so.
Mr. Baker's action has little immediate effect on Mr. Bloch, who had been suspended without pay from his $81,400-a-year job at State Department headquarters since February.
The dismissal does lay the groundwork for an effort to revoke Mr. Bloch's pension. That effort is being reviewed by the department's legal adviser, said a department official who spoke on condition of anonymity.
 
Record No Longer Spotless
 The dismissal also insures that Mr. Bloch will not leave the Government with an officially spotless record, an issue about which senior officials are said to feel strongly.
Mr. Bloch and the Government have been sparring at least since early 1989, shortly after he came under investigation. Then a senior economic official in the State Department's bureau of European and Canadian affairs, he was secretly photographed during a trip to Paris in the company of a K.G.B. agent.
In one such meeting, Mr. Bloch passed a valise to the man. He has since stated that he and the man are stamp collectors and that the valise contained several sheets of stamps.
The K.G.B. apparently learned of the inquiry and warned Mr. Bloch about it that spring, officials have said. But by that time, they said, investigators suspected that Mr. Bloch had been associated with the K.G.B. since the mid-1970's, when he was a commercial officer in what was then a new American Embassy in East Berlin.
Among the evidence is a surreptitious tape recording in which Mr. Bloch told his wife that he had been accepting money from Moscow for years, officials say. The inquiry also is said to have turned up evidence that Mr. Bloch spent large sums of money for the services of a prostitute during a tour of duty in Vienna in the 1980's.
He was assigned to the embassy in Vienna in 1981 as an economic officer and advanced to deputy chief of mission, in which he was second-in-command to the Ambassador and privy to virtually all the mission's secrets. He remained there until 1987.
He was suspended from his job with pay in June 1989. The disclosure of the espionage inquiry created a sensation, and for months he was trailed wherever he went by a throng of reporters, cameramen and F.B.I. agents.
The State Department revoked Mr. Bloch's pay in February and said it intended to dismiss him. After he protested, the department scheduled a private hearing in which he was to defend himself, but the hearing never took place.
The F.B.I. investigation into his activities remains open.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN;
CAMPAIGN ENDING WITH VOTERS SEEN IN A RESTIVE MOOD

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
An election year that began with the nation at peace and feeling prosperous wound up today with restless voters looking for ways to lash out at politicians and worried about war in the Persian Gulf and recession here at home.
Candidates around the country made their final appeals, and attacks, as their managers put the finishing touches on get-out-the-vote efforts. Everyone agreed it had been one of the wierdest midterm election seasons of modern times. 
 A restiveness was apparent on several fronts as election workers prepared to open the polls. More independent candidates were running well than at any time in recent memory. There were more ballot initiatives, the citizens' way of making an end run around politicians, than at any time since the Depression. And analysts said turnout could be as low as it was four years ago, or even lower; the rate in 1986 was the lowest in almost 50 years.
 
Possible Last-Minute Swings
 As campaigns shut down their polling operations, many reported that there were still unusually large numbers of voters who said they were undecided whom to vote for -- both a further index of dissatisfaction and a warning that last-minute swings could still produce upsets.
A lot depended on whether Americans expressed their frustration by going to the polls or by staying home. "If there is an intense angry last-minute minute vote, then a number of incumbents on both sides may get surprised," said Edward J. Rollins Jr., co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee.
President Bush began the year as a Republican Party asset and ended it perceived as a liability by many Republicans after embracing tax increases, something he long disavowed. He spent the day before the election campaigning with one of the few candidates still eager to appear with him, Clayton Williams, the Republican candidate for governor of Texas.
Officials in the campaign of Jim Edgar, the Republican candidate for governor of Illinois, declined Mr. Bush's offer of a late campaign stop because, the campaign spokesman, Mike Lawrence, said, "It might detract from the focus being on the two candidates."
The turn in Mr. Bush's fortunes reflected the roller coaster that all politicans have ridden this year. A few months ago Republicans thought that with the President receiving record approval ratings they might actually gain seats this year in Congress, even though the President's party historically loses seats in midterm elections. By about two weeks ago, they were fearing an electoral blowout, driven by anger over how Mr. Bush and the Republicans handled the deficit reduction deal. In the final days, these fears have calmed a bit, as the White House has tried to coax the nation's attention away from taxes and the economy and toward the Persian Gulf.
 
Senate Forecast: Little Change
 Both sides were predicting modest gains for the Democrats in the House of Representatives, perhaps 6 to 12 seats, and little if any change in the current balance in the Senate, where there are now 55 Democrats and 45 Republicans.
"After all the folderal it's going to be a regular midterm election," said Mary Matalin, chief of staff at the Republican National Committee.
Several crucial governor's races, including contests in Texas, Florida and Illinois, remained too close to call. But Republicans were bouyant about their chances to win this year's single biggest prize, the governorship of California. They were also optimistic about winning back the governorship in Ohio, a crucial swing state in Presidential races. Republicans even thought they had a shot at winning in Massachusetts, even though Democrats outnumber Republicans 4 to 1.
In New York, Governor Mario M. Cuomo was coasting toward a third term, one of the many incumbent governors, senators and House members whose opposition was underfinanced or nonexistent.
In Connecticut, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a former Republican Senator, was having success with his independent candidacy for governor with a campaign built around attacks on both political parties.
This illustrated the power of a national mood of disgust with politicians and political parties. Since the Depression only one independent candidate has been elected governor. James B. Longley was elected governor of Maine in 1974, an election year dominated by Watergate, on a promise to restore faith in government. But as this Election Day approached, two independent candidates for governor were front-runners, Mr. Weicker in Connecticut and Walter J. Hickel, the former Interior Secretary, in Alaska.
In Vermont, an independent who is a socialist, Bernard Sanders, was given a good chance of unseating Representative Peter Smith, a Republican. The Democratic candidate was not even a factor in that race.
 
Two National Tides
 While most midterm elections are fought out on local issues and local personalities, two national tides seemed to be running, and not always in the same direction.
"On the one hand people want to vote against politicians, not just incumbents," said Mark Mellman, a poll taker for Democratic candidates in Oregon, Minnesota and other states. "They're angry and they want to send a message. At the same time, they want to vote for a Democrat because they are concerned about the economy. In some places, these trends reinforce. In some places, they contradict."
Voters were also torn between their desire for change and their increasing edginess about a world that grew more risky, both domestically and internationally, as the year went on. This seemed to shift the advantage in the campaign from candidates who offered dramatic change, like Dianne Feinstein, the Democratic candidate for governor of California, to those who also said they wanted to move, but more slowly, like her opponent, Senator Pete Wilson.
Right to the end Ms. Feinstein continued presenting herself as an agent for change. "Their blue suits mean business as usual," she declared. "I say elect this dress."
White House spokesmen stressed that the results of Tuesday's voting should not be viewed as a referendum on the President, a position they presumably would not be taking if they expected major gains.
The White House was spurned in recent days when it tried to arrange campaign appearances for Mr. Bush with a number of major candidates, including Mr. Edgar in Illinois, where taxes have become a central election issue. Mr. Bush ended up spending more time in Texas than he had orignally planned.
"It's the only place people want him," said a Republican strategist.
 
The Budget Issue
 The Republicans stressed that their projected loses would probably still be smaller than the historic average of 28 House seats for the President's party. But Democrats countered that the Republicans, with their 176 House seats, were already close to their historic lows in the number of seats they hold, and thus had few left to lose.
It was the President's mishandling of budget talks, Democrats said, that handed Democrats their closing advantage on domestic issues. The confrontation in the gulf and the weakness of the economy had the effect of pushing to the back issues that had been viewed as crucial earlier in the year, particularly abortion and the environment.
They remain relevant in a number of races. But six months ago it was universally thought that an environmental referendum known as Big Green was headed for passage in California. Today its chances appear to be bleak.
Of the 34 Senate seats to be filled on Tuesday, the closest races appeared to be in Hawaii, Minnesota and North Carolina. In North Carolina, Harvey Gantt, the Democrat, was seeking to unseat the three-term Senator, Jesse Helms. In Hawaii, the Democratic establishment was trying to protect Senator Daniel K. Akaka, appointed to the seat a few months ago, from a powerful challenge from the Republican Representative, Patricia Saiki. And in Minnesota, Senator Rudy Boschwitz, a Republican, was trying to turn back the challenge of Paul Wellstone, a college professor, by painting Mr. Wellstone as someone who would socialize health care and "double taxes of everyone making over $20,000."
Also on the ballot were 6,247 state legislative seats, and more than usual interest was focused on some of them because of the role legislators will have in drawing new political maps next year.
Among the 67 proposals on statewide ballots on Tuesday, the most since the Depression, were measures in Colorado and California to limit the terms of elected officials. Those measures have tapped a vein of voter frustration.
An estimated 186 million Americans are old enough to vote, but Curtis Gans, director of the Study of the American Electorate, said he expected that turnout would be close to, or even below, the 36 percent rate in 1986. That rate was the lowest for a midterm election since 1942, when the country was disrupted by the mobilization for World War II.
One reason for the expected low turnout, he suggested, was the unrelenting negative tone of many campaigns this year.

HEADLINE: Stocks Advance Broadly; Dow Gains 11.39

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday for the third straight session but trading activity lagged as many investors marked time until after today's elections.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which climbed 12.62 points on Thursday and 35.89 on Friday, tacked on 11.39 yesterday, to 2,502.23. 
 Volume slumped to 147.5 million shares, from 168.7 million on Friday. But 1,029 stocks advanced yesterday, more than half the total traded, while only 547 fell, showing that gains extended well beyond the blue-chip stocks.
The Standard & Poor's average of 500 stocks rose twice as much as the 30-stock Dow average in percentage terms, while the Nasdaq composite index of smaller stocks was up three times as much.
 
 Gains at the Amex
 Even the American Stock Exchange's market-value index gained a little more than the Dow in percentage terms, showing that the smaller Amex stocks were picking up a bit.
Moreover, while new lows continued to pepper the Big Board list, the list of new highs rose to 14, while new lows were at 70.
Birinyi Associates said that despite some program buying, three selling waves clipped 6.43 points off the Dow by the end of the day.
Oil prices fell $2.04 a barrel, to $31.96, with $1 of the decline coming in the final hour and 45 minutes. In the same time span, the Dow made all of its gains of the day.
Still, analysts hardly mentioned oil, attributing yesterday's rise in stocks to expectations that the Federal Reserve might lower interest rates soon. They said that before moving into the market, other investors were watching the elections and the results of the Treasury's big auctions today, tomorrow and Thursday.
 
 Economic 'Free Fall'
 In support of lower rates, H. Erich Heinemann, chief economist for Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, said: "The economy is on the edge or actually in a free fall. Employment is down 700,000 since June, unemployment claims are skyrocketing, real income is down and personal savings are sharply lower."
He forecast that the Federal funds rate, which banks charge one another for overnight loans, would drop from 7 3/4 now to 5 to 6 percent by the first half of next year.
Michael Metz, chief market analyst for Oppenheimer & Company, called the market "very resilient."
"There's been no change in the fundamental background," he said. "It's dominated by fears of recession/depression and the possibility of a financial catastrophe, but it looks like the market has largely discounted it. So many investors have so much cash that it's making both the stock and bond market go up. The trillion-dollar question is whether it's a short-term rally or a sustained rebound."
 
 Weak Credit Demand
 Discussing interest rates, Mr. Heinemann of Ladenburg, Thalmann, argued that "credit demand is so weak now that the Fed has to drain money out of the banks to keep rates from going down even more than has been the case."
"This 'tightening' is inadvertent," he said, "but is setting the stage for a much stronger drop in Fed funds later on."
In what appeared to be strong investor recognition that interest rates were on the way down, six of the Big Board's 10 most-active stocks were financially oriented: C&S/Sovran, which yields 9.83 percent, rose 1/8, to 16, on 7.3 million shares; Fannie Mae rose 7/8, to 30 1/8; BankAmerica 1 1/2, to 21 7/8; Kemper, the insurer, 5/8, to 19 1/2, and General Electric, with huge real estate loans, 7/8, to 53 7/8. Citicorp fell 1/4, to 12 3/8.
Among other financial stocks, A.I.G., the insurer, rose 2 1/2, to 69 3/8; Loews, which owns most of CNA, another big insurer, rose 2 1/2, to 81 3/4; Geico, another big insurer, rose 2 1/4, to 131 1/4, and Wells Fargo, the West Coast banking company, rose 2 1/8, to 47 1/2.
 
 Active Takeover Issue
 Takeover stocks were also active yesterday. Neiman Marcus, the store chain, fell 1 7/8, to 12 3/4, after General Cinema withdrew a bid for the company. Neiman Marcus had been recommending the offer but then rejected it. Wall Street traders guessed that the company now believed the business was worth more than originally believed. Mario Gabelli, head of an investor group, said it had raised its stake to 13.04 percent, from 12 percent.
Square D, the electrical equipment producer that rose 7 3/8 last week on vague rumors that foreign buyers might be interested, rose 2 7/8, to 47 7/8, although traders discounted the rumors.
News Corporation, headed by Rupert Murdoch, the publisher, rose 2 1/8, to 9 1/4. Mr. Murdoch agreed on Friday to merge his Sky Television satellite service with that of the rival British Satellite Broadcasting.
 
 Tokyo Rally Fades
 TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 6 (Reuters) -- Stocks closed lower in Tokyo today on thin volume as traders expressed caution over the outcome of elections in the United States. The 225-share Nikkei index lost 419.58 points, or 1.72 percent, to end the day at 2,3965.75.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Saudis to Give Free Hand to U.S. If Attack on the Iraqis Is Approved

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 5

 BODY:
The United States and Saudi Arabia tightened their pressure on Iraq today by agreeing on new command arrangements they would follow if they mounted an offensive strike, senior American and Saudi officials said.
In a step clearly intended to demonstrate the credibility of American military options, the two sides agreed that any offensive against Iraqi troops in Kuwait, or against Iraq, begun from Saudi territory would be undertaken only after President Bush and King Fahd both gave their approval. 
 But it was agreed that once an attack was authorized by the two political leaders, American forces would be free to plan and execute the attack entirely under their own commanders, without interference from the Saudi military leadership, officials said.
 
Joint Defensive Command
 If Iraq should attack Saudi Arabia and a defensive military operation is required, the two sides agreed that the joint command structure set up since American troops began arriving on Saudi soil in the week after the Iraqi invasion on Aug. 2 would remain in force.
The Saudi-American understanding on command and control was reached in talks tonight between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Saudi Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, and King Fahd. The accord is significant for several reasons.
First, it clears away an important obstacle to any military operation against Iraq by reassuring the Saudi leadership that American troops on their soil will not undertake any unilateral offensive, while assuring the American military commander in Saudi Arabia, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, that if his forces have to take the field against Iraq he will be free to carry out the operation as he deems fit.
Second, the fact that the Saudis would agree to such an arrangement marks a clear development in their internal deliberations. Two months ago, the Saudi Defense Minister, Prince Sultan, declared flatly that Saudi territory could not be used for "offensive" operations against Iraqi forces. And for the first three months of the crisis, the two countries had no firm understanding on how to coordinate any offensive strike.
Third, the decision should enhance the credibility of the mounting threats of force that President Bush has been making to persuade President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait unconditionally. The understanding is intended to make clear to Iraq that Washington now has a degree of flexibility in using Saudi territory for such an operation.
 
Baker Sees 'a New Phase'
 "This crisis is entering a new phase," Mr. Baker told reporters before today's talks, "and while we are still seeking a peaceful, political and diplomatic solution, we have to, I think, put ourselves in a position where we would be able to exercise any options that might be available. I don't think that we can, nor should we, rule out resort to force, if that should be necessary."
Nevertheless, senior American and Saudi officials insisted that the command-and-control understanding did not foreshadow any imminent offensive military operation.
Both nations said they still wanted to try to work through the United Nations. They apparently agreed in principle to work together in the near future to try to persuade the Security Council to adopt a resolution authorizing the use of force if it is deemed to be the only way to evict Iraq from Kuwait.
Saudi officials said the fact that American troops based in Saudi Arabia would be allowed to operate independently in an offensive should not be read as a signal that no Saudi forces would take part in such an operation.
"We are trying to enhance the United Nations measures that will give us a peaceful solution," a senior Saudi official said. "If that doesn't happen, we will cross that bridge when we come to it. You would be very wrong to leave this place thinking that we have closed the door on diplomacy."
 
Coordination With Americans
 If Saudi Arabia or other nations decide that they want their forces to take part in an offensive against Iraqi troops, they will have to coordinate the operation with the American military.
Officials said Mr. Baker, who goes on Tuesday to Egypt and Turkey, and then on to Moscow, London and Paris, would confer with other key members of the international force confronting Iraq about how they would like to coordinate any offensive. At the moment, each military contingent in Saudi Arabia has its own arrangement with the Saudi Army command.
Explaining today's understanding, a senior American official said of the procedures: "They are different when talking about matters of the defense of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia as opposed to elsewhere. If it goes beyond Saudi borders, American commanders will command American troops."
If the operation is offensive, and aimed outside Saudi Arabia, the senior official added, "the authority for planning and approving those types of operations with respect to United States forces will rest with The United States command. There will be an agreement at the highest political level between the two Governments if those kinds of activities are undertaken."
 
Meeting With Kuwaiti Emir
 Before his meeting this evening with Saudi officials, Mr. Baker flew to the Saudi mountain resort of Taif, where he met with the exiled Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah. Speaking to reporters before his talks with Mr. Baker, the Emir said his Government would like to see the Iraqis evicted in any way necessary and as soon as possible.
"As far as I am concerned," Sheik Jaber said, "I would like my country to be liberated today and before tomorrow. I would like to see the liberation of Kuwait as soon as possible, whether through the Security Council or not."
Mr. Baker spent Sunday visiting with American troops of the First Cavalry Division, which is stationed in eastern Saudi Arabia near the border with Iraq.
On the financial front, Mr. Baker told the Emir that the funds that the Kuwaiti leader had committed two months ago to support the military operation in the gulf would be used up by the end of the year. Sheik Jaber promised Mr. Baker that he would make an unspecified commitment of fresh funds for 1991, a senior Administration official said.
The Secretary also asked Sheik Jaber if he would consider providing financial assistance to the fledgling new democracies of Eastern Europe, where fragile economies have been badly hurt by the steep rise in oil prices. Sheik Jaber said he had dispatched a mission to Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary to assess their needs.
Yahya al-Sumait, Kuwait's exiled Minister of Housing, told reporters in Taif that the Kuwaitis were eager to bring the Iraqi invasion to a close before the Iraqis managed to forcibly expel all of Kuwait's citizens.
"We believe that with every day that passes in Kuwait, our people are being humiliated, tortured and killed by the hour," Mr. Sumait said. "This kind of atrocity cannot be tolerated anymore. To us, to our people, inside and outside Kuwait, we need a resolution, a solution, an immediate one."
Already, the Kuwaiti Minister said, 60 to 70 percent of the one million Kuwaitis are outside the country. Most are in Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain or Western Europe.

HEADLINE: Equitable Real Estate Unit Is Vulnerable but Confident

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Cracks are starting to appear in the portfolio of the nation's largest investor of real estate assets for pension funds. Equitable Real Estate Investment Management Inc., a unit of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, is grappling with rising withdrawals of pension money from its managed funds and, like others in the industry, faces growing delinquency rates in its mortgage portfolio.
At a time when mortgage delinquencies are expected to begin rising sharply, Equitable Life has about $12.1 billion invested in commercial real estate mortgages for its own account, a major portion of its $44.9 billion in assets. 
 On top of that, Equitable Life is already struggling with the debacle of the high-interest investment securities it sold throughout the 1980's. The fall in interest rates has hurt the insurance giant's ability to make enough money to cover those commitments and it will probably lose more than $1 billion as it continues to make those payments. In addition, potential losses on the company's $3.9 billion portfolio of "junk bonds" could add to its troubles.
Even so, none of Equitable Life's problems are likely to affect its ability to meet insurance policy claims. Equitable Life is one of the nation's remaining mutual insurance companies. It is owned by its policyholders rather than public shareholders.
Two weeks ago, Equitable Real Estate raised eyebrows when it put a partnership in which it was the general partner into bankruptcy. That prompted speculation in the industry that the move signified the beginning of an aggressive housecleaning.
According to the real estate unit's top management, the bankruptcy of this partnership was an isolated incident. "That is the only tax-oriented, high-leverage partnership transaction of its kind in our portfolio," said George R. Puskar, chairman of Equitable Real Estate, referring to changes in the tax law in 1986 that made real estate partnerships less attractive. "After that investment was made, many of the senior people made a conscious decision that we would not pursue that kind of business and so it was a stand-alone situation."
The company says neither the recent sales or planned sales of some of its properties nor the bankruptcy filing should be construed as a sign that it is tightening oversight, but that its portfolio review process is functioning as usual.
"The current market conditions are no surprise to us," Mr. Puskar said. "We started sending the caution signals in 1986, and we have been culling out problems in our equity portfolio for some time now."
Many industry experts say that in all likelihood Equitable Real Estate will weather the industry turbulence.
With more than $35 billion in assets under management, Equitable Real Estate, which is based in Atlanta, is the leading manager of pension fund money invested in real estate and is one of the biggest sources of financing for the nation's developers.
 
 $24 Billion in Investments
 The company's nearly 550 professionals manage a portfolio of $24 billion in equity real estate investments and more than $11 billion in mortgages. It has equity interests in about 800 properties, including about 51 million square feet of industrial space, 76 million square feet of office space, 63 million square feet of retail space and nearly 20,000 hotel rooms.
Although its insurance parent has been struggling to cut costs and improve its profit, the real estate unit, which generated a modest 8 percent increase in pretax profits in 1989, has been spared along with the other investment subsidiaries.
"Our business is growing," Mr. Puskar said. "We have not had to cut on the people side of the equation, but we have made cuts on the overhead and expense side."
Still, like every other major investor in the country's faltering real estate market, the Equitable unit is vulnerable. Only weeks ago, John Portman, a large developer, was forced to give up control of Peachtree Center, a huge office and retail complex in Atlanta, after he failed to make payments on a $333 million Equitable mortgage.
The company's main investment fund, the $3.8 billion Prime Property Fund, has already refunded $140 million to investors this year and 33 investors recently asked to redeem an additional $330 million.
Prime, which invests in regional shopping malls, industrial projects and office space, does not have enough cash on hand to meet those requests, and company executives estimate that it will take about 12 months before it can meet them.
Equitable Real Estate executives say the company's delinquency rate on commercial mortgages has remained stable at about 1 percent for the last few years and they do not expect it to rise sharply.
 
 A Growing Problem
 But delinquencies among commercial mortgages, the underwriting standards on many of which deteriorated during the building boom of the mid-1980's, are expected to pose a growing problem for insurance companies over the next three or four years. Falling real estate values and rental incomes can make it impossible for developers to make their debt payments. And if the market value of these properties falls below the value of the underlying mortgage, developers may be tempted to simply hand over the deeds to the mortgage holders instead of making payments, as is allowed under their contracts.
The problem could be exacerbated if interest rates rise. Billions of dollars of such mortgages will mature over the next several years, and if they are rolled over at a higher rate buildings will face an even tougher time meeting mortgage payments.
Equitable Real Estate says it is cutting its ties with troublesome projects. "We are actively going over these loans and asking ourselves whether we want to roll them over," Mr. Puskar said.

HEADLINE: Ventures Test Rival Ways to Recreate the World in a Spacecraft

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
AS space enthusiasts in Arizona prepare to seal themselves inside an eight-story, $100 million greenhouse for two years, an event tourists can commemorate with T-shirts and other memorabilia purchased at the nearby gift shop, the scientific field that parallels ther endeavor has been making quiet progress beyond the limelight.
Both ventures are bids at futuristic recycling, studying how green plants can take human wastes (urine, feces and carbon dioxide) and turn them into oxygen, water and food for humans living in closed spaces. The result would be a closed, independent, self-contained system in which plants would provide all material sustenance for the humans, including food. 
 The ultimate aim of both groups is to help astronauts cut supply lines to Earth and roam the universe at will. That is no mere fantasy: the White House's bold plans to return to the Moon and venture onward to Mars may require just such recycling.
But while ends of the two groups are similar, the means to achieve them are very different, illustrating the divergent paths science can take. The contrasting methods are partly a result of different types of financing, one private, the other public. But while the Government has traditionally pursued far out ideas, with industry lagging behind, space-age entrepreneurs in this case are boldly going where no one has gone before.
In Oracle, Ariz., the four men and four women of Biosphere 2 (they refer to the Earth as Biosphere 1) are entering a realm more akin to Noah's ark than a laboratory. Their exotic, 3.15-acre, glass-enclosed habitat, containing some 3,800 species of plants (as well as fish, chickens, goats and pigs), is to produce all their physical needs for two years, starting early next year. It is to be a little Eden or Shangri-La. All are single and free to form whatever relationships they wish. Their dream is to erect such a structure on Mars.
Biosphere 2 is a privately financed, all-or-nothing experiment. The glass habitat, which is to last a century, is so expensive and bold that no government or scientific center would be likely to pioneer one.
In contrast, scientists at universities and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration are taking a more traditional, step-by-step approach that centers on first mastering the basics of plant-human relationships, usually by focusing on a single plant, and then applying those insights to the design of small systems that could enter space far sooner than the mammoth structures of the Arizona group. Their life-support systems could be used in space stations, ships or planetary outposts. The NASA scientists have been at it for more than a decade, and their work has been picking up speed of late.
Genetic engineers at Purdue University are now working to improve the productivity of candidate plant species. Researchers at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida are growing wheat under artificial light in a closed chamber, achieving up to 80 percent of the growth in sunlight. And soil scientists at the Johnson Space Center in Houston are raising lettuce in mock lunar soil, seeing what might prosper at a Moon outpost.
The two groups keep close tabs on one another, partly out of friendly rivalry. "It comes down to what is science, and what are the right questions to ask," said Dr. Robert D. MacElroy, chief scientist of the advanced life support division at the space agency's Ames Research Center in California.
The Biosphere 2 project, run by Space Biosphere Ventures, a private ecological research firm, says its vision to create a complex ecosystem from scratch is just as scientific but more holistic. Its aim, according to a company brochure, is to "greatly enhance our understanding of our present biosphere" and pioneer the "means of establishing permanent stations in space or on other planets as research bases and eventually settlements."
Kathleen A. Dyhr, a Space Biosphere spokeswoman, said the distinction between the two groups was "systematists versus reductionists," or experts who look at whole systems versus ones who break them into component parts, adding that "war between these schools of thought has been going on for a long time." The Biosphere approach, she said, mimicked the complexity of the planet and sought to better understand that intricacy.
"With the Earth, we have a lot of detailed information on the parts but don't know how it all fits together," Ms. Dyhr said. The group says even a life-support failure (they joke about everything turning into green slime) would be a qualified success, since much would be learned in the process.
Dr. Arthur W. Galston, a Yale University botanist who advises the NASA program, said the Arizona group was "flaky" but provocative. "They're looking at areas that haven't been looked at before," he said.
Both efforts were ultimately important, Dr. Galston said, "because they're a paradigm of what man here on Earth has to face" in years ahead. "We have a burgeoning population," he said, "a decline of arable land, and waste heaps that are growing continuously. We have to find ways of producing more food in less space to feed more mouths, with less nonrecyclable refuse. This work is going to have a lot of civilian spinoffs."
 
Keeping Astronauts Alive
 Today, the usual way of keeping astronauts alive in space is with a continuous supply of food, water and air. On the space shuttle, oxygen and nitrogen are mixed into artificial air. After breathing, this mixture is passed through canisters that remove exhaled carbon dioxide.
Also aboard the shuttle are fuel cells that mix oxygen and hydrogen to produce electrical power and drinking water. Excess water vapor in cabin air is condensed and placed in waste tanks. Liquid wastes like urine, perspiration and lung vapor are periodically shot into space. Solid wastes, including feces and vomit, are exposed to the vacuum of space for drying and stored aboard the spacecraft.
The economic penalties for what NASA calls its "physico-chemical" life support system add up fairly quickly. The average astronaut needs about 10 pounds of consumables every day, including 1.3 pounds of food, 6.27 pounds of water and 1.76 pounds of oxygen. Because of these and other demands that tax storage space, shuttle missions are usually limited to about 10 days. Moreover, the cost of shipping these supplies into space is high, running about $5,000 a pound.
NASA's planned space station, which would be manned year round, will need huge amounts of fresh supplies on a continuous basis. Studies show that if life-support equipment weighs 5 tons at first deployment, the total weight will reach nearly 10 tons after the first year, nearly 15 tons after the second, nearly 20 tons after the third, and so on.
In theory, "bioregenerative" life support could cut that climb. The initial investment would be greater, owing to the greater bulk of plants and a larger array of equipment. For instance, bioregenerative life-support equipment might weigh 12 tons at deployment rather than 5 tons, according to contractor studies. But, in theory, hardly anything else would be needed -- certainly no food, water or oxygen -- once the apparatus was installed and running.
Many billions of dollars would be saved for long missions like that of the space station, which is to operate for more than three decades. Indeed, bioregenerative life support, with technology now on the horizon, is seen as being cheaper than the physico-chemical alternative for any space mission whose duration is slightly longer than a year.
Such considerations prompted NASA to start an effort to master bioregenerative life support in the late 1970's. But there was little enthusiasm within the agency's upper ranks. The program went against the can-do, hard-edged, mechanistic philosophy of many NASA officials, who quietly dismissed it as mushy and ecological.
"Fundamentally," recalled Dr. MacElroy of NASA's Ames center, "there was a philosophical resistance, a feeling that hard machines had done it in the past" and would do it in the future.
 
Aims of Program
 But the bioregenerative program, which received some $30 million in the last decade, nonetheless made headway. The goals have mainly been to develop plant-growth equipment and to evaluate different species and improve their productivity by such means as raising carbon dioxide levels and growing temperatures. This work, done mainly at NASA-financed universities, has found wheat to be an especially good candidate.
At the space center in Florida, work got under way in 1985 to apply these lessons to a closed test. Completed in 1987, the growth chamber, 24 feet high and 11 feet wide, has now grown five crops of wheat, two of soybeans, and is scheduled to try lettuce, rice, peanuts as well as sweet potatoes. Researchers are also working to make meals out of candidate plants and to find efficient ways to process wastes back into fertilizer and other usable products.
At Kennedy, a feeding method known as thin-film hydroponics uses water about an eighth of an inch deep rather than soil to carry nutrients. So far, scientists have used regular plant food rather than human wastes.
Starting this year, they plan to slowly introduce human liquid wastes for nutrients, and later human-type waste gases to the air. By 1993, their chamber should be able to chemically mimic the consumption and excretion of one person. If financing materializes, the scientists hope to build a new experimental apparatus in 1995 that would house three to four human volunteers for full-fledged tests.
Dr. William M. Knott 3d, who directs the work at Kennedy, said aspects of it might be tested in space as soon as 1991 on flights of the space shuttle, with attention focusing on a zero-gravity nutrient membrane that is seen as solving the vexing problems of weightlessness by feeding plant roots directly. But perfecting the whole recycling idea might take decades, he cautioned.
"Bioregenerative life support is in such a stage of infancy right now that we don't have the technology base or science base to predict how or when it's going to be done," Dr. Knott said. "You can make guesses. But you're almost trying to predict when you're going to cure cancer."
At the Johnson center in Houston, researchers are gambling that the work will eventually be needed on the Moon. Dr. Donald L. Henninger, a soil scientist there, has grown several crops of wheat and lettuce on mock lunar soil. Getting nutrients to plants would be easier on the Moon than in free space, he said, because its mild gravity would help localize liquid nutrients and the lunar soil would make for good, low-cost root support.
 
Much to Learn
 But he too warned that the effort was tentative. "We know very little," Dr. Henninger said. "We've got lots of work ahead of us."
NASA recently expanded its effort, awarding a five-year, $5 million grant to a nine-member scientific team from Purdue University. Dr. Cary A. Mitchell, its leader, said that one aim was for genetic engineers to alter the balance of amino acids, or protein building blocks, in candidate plants to increase their food value.
In contrast to the plodding NASA effort, the Biospherians in Arizona want recycling achieved in one fell swoop. They are being bankrolled by Edward Bass, a wealthy Texan.
Their hope is that the sheer diversity of their project will protect them from ecological disaster on Earth, from chemical distortions in the air, water or soil that could destroy their Eden. Beneath the glass domes are five climatic zones -- rain forest, desert, savanna, ocean and intensive agriculture -- meant to mimic the Earth's diversity and be a protective buffer for the eight Biospherians., as they call themselves.
Uncertainties are legion, its architects agree. No one, for instance, knows exactly how many of the 3,800 species of plants, selected to provide a rich, miniature version of the climatic zones, will survive for the two years. Many plants are likely to die off as the domes are closed off from the Earth's atmosphere and the internal environment strikes its own unique balance.
To curb some uncertainties, the recycling effort is to receive a huge massive influx of technological aid. Beneath tropical plants and flowers lie mechanical parts that look like a battleship's engine room, the masses of pipes and pumps and fans meant to cool and filter the air, store water, recycle human and animal waste and move the structure's air as it expands and contracts with changing temperatures during the day and night.
The Arizona site has a 3.7-megawatt power plant to provide the recycling effort with much-needed electricity.
 
Questions Are Raised
 Some scientists question the method's rigor, saying too many variables have been left untested and too much confidence has been placed in its ability to regulate its own processes.
Dr. Charles F. Hutchinson, associate director of the Office of Arid Lands Studies at the University of Arizona, described the project as "a scientific crapshoot." The main criticism, he said, is "their top-down approach to the science, in which you take a bunch of components, throw them all together, shake them up and hope everything will work in the end."
"It's more fun than science," he said. "It's virtually impossible to do that kind of research with government funding."
The Biospherians say their effort is just as legitimate and perhaps more important than the NASA work, since it promises to unlock some of the Earth's ecological secrets.
